, inf. n. TabanN [accord. to the CK TabonN, which is wrong]; and Tabana lh, aor.
Tabina
, inf. n. TabaAnapN and TabaAniyapN and TubuwnapN; He understood it; or knew it; or had knowledge, or was cognizant, of it: (S, K:) some say that TabanN relates to good, and tabanN to evil; but AO says that TabaAnapN and tabaAnapN are one, meaning the being very intelligent or knowing; and Lh says that TabaAnapN and TabaAniyapN, and tabaAnapN and tabaAniyapN, and laqaAnapN and laqaAniyapN, and lahaAnapN and lahaAniyapN [app. mistranscriptions for kahaAnapN and kahaAniyapN], are one [in meaning]. (TA. [See more in the first paragraph of art. tbn.])

Tabina lahaA, in which the pronoun refers to a woman, a phrase occurring in a trad., is expl. as meaning He apprehended what was the state, or disposition, of her mind, and that she was one who would comply with the endeavour to seduce her: or, accord. to Sh, it is Tabana lahaA, like Daraba, and means he deceived her, or corrupted her, and beguiled her: accord. to Az, Tabinotu bihi, aor.
Tabana
, inf. n. TabinN; and Tabanotu, aor.
Tabina
, inf. n. TabaAnapN; signify I deceived him, or deluded him. (TA.)
And TabaAniyapN, accord. to IB, signifies also A man's looking at his wife, and either debarring her from appearing or being angry and jealous. (TA.)

Tabana AlnRaAra, (S, K,) aor.
Tabina
, (K, TA, [in the CK
Tabana
,]) inf. n. TabonN, (K,) He covered the fire [in a hollow] in the earth, in order that it might not become extinguished. (S, K.)

3. TaAbino hecihi AlHuforapa (S) or AlHafiyrapa (K) means Lower thou [or deepen thou] this hollow in the ground [app. for fire to be covered over therein; see 1, last sentence]; syn. TaOominohaA and TaOoTiYohaA. (The former syn. in some copies of the S and K; the latter in other copies of the S; and both in
some copies of the K.)
And TaAbana Zahorahu He lowered, or bent down, his back; syn. TaAmanahu. (TA.)
And TaAbanahu, (K,) inf. n. muTaAbanapN and TibaAnN, (TA,) He, or it, agreed, or accorded, with him, or it. (K.)

Q. Q. 4. AiTobaOanRa i. q. AiTomaOanRa; (S, K;) formed from the latter by substitution [of b for m]. (S in art. Tmn.) So in the phrase AiTobaOanRa qalobuhu, meaning His heart became quiet, at rest, at ease, or tranquil. (TA.)

TabonN A numerous collection or body (K, TA) of men; (TA;) as also TabanN↓. (K, TA. [Freytag adds TibonN and TubonN in this sense; but they are mentioned in the K as syns. of TabonN meaning a certain game: and Golius adds, instead of these two, TibinN and TubunN, which are altogether wrong.])
And one says, maA OadoriI OaIRu AlTRaboni huwa, (S, K, *) meaning OaIRu AlnRaAsi huwa [i. e. I know not what one of mankind he is]: (S, K:) and so OaIRu AlTRaboli huwa. (S and O in art. Tbl.)

Also, [and it is implied in the K that the following explanation applies likewise to TubonN↓ and TibonN↓ and TubanN↓, but the TA restricts it to TabonN,] A carcass which is placed for the purpose of capturing upon it the vultures and beasts of prey. (K, TA. [Freytag assigns this meaning to TubanN only.])
See also TubonapN.
TubonN The [kind of mandoline called] Tunobuwr: (IAar, K:) or the Euwd [i. e. lute]. (K.)
See also TubonapN.
And see TabonN.
TibonN: see TubonapN:
and see also TabonN.

AlTRibonu also signifies What the wind brings, [or bears along,] of firewood [app. meaning of fragments thereof], and AlnRamaX: [but this seems to be a mistranscription; for it is immediately added,] and sometimes the house (Albyt) that is built, or constructed, therewith is thus called. (TA.)
TabanN: see TabonN:
and see also TubonapN.

TabanN and TaAbinN↓ Intelligent, understanding, skilled, or knowing, (S, K, * TA,) in everything: (TA:) the former is syn. with tabinN [q. v.]: (M in art. tbn:) and TubunRapN↓ signifies [very intelligent &c., being of a measure proper to intensive epithets; or simply] skilled, or skilful. (TA.)
And for the first of these words (TabinN), see also TubonapN.
TubanN: see TubonapN:
and see also TabonN.

TubonapN, (S,) or TabonN↓ and TubonN↓ and TibonN↓ (K) and TabanN↓ and TabinN↓ (TA) and TubanN↓, (K,) or this last is pl. of TubonapN, (S, TA,) A certain game, (S, K, TA,) [said to be] played by children, by means of a circular line, [drawn on the ground, (but see what follows,)] and [also] called by them AlrRaHaI; (TA;) called in Pers. siho barahN, or siydarahi, (accord. to different copies of the S,) or sidorah, (accord. to some copies of the K, and the TA, [this and siydarah being app. for sihN darahN, which is syn. with siho baraho,] in a MS. copy of the K saco maraho, and in the CK sido mazoh, [both app. mistranscriptions for siho baraho,]) i. e. “ having three doors; ” (TA;) [app. the same that is sometimes called in Pers. siho darako;] the game that is called in Turkish Twqwrjwn [and Tuwqurojino], and in Arabic called also qrq; (TK;) [i. e. qiroqN, which is said in the K and TA in art. qrq to be the game called sudRar; accord. to an explanation and diagram there given, played by means of twenty-four lines, composed of four squares, or parallelograms, one of these having within it another, the latter having within it another, and this last having within it another; to which are added a line drawn from each angle of the outermost of these to the corresponding angle of the innermost and another line drawn from the middle of each side of the outermost to the middle of the corresponding side of the innermost; within which combination of twenty-four lines they place (yaDaEuwna, in the CK yaSufRuwna,) pebbles. sudRar is evidently from the Pers. siho daraho: it is said in the TA in art. sdr to be also pronounced sidRar and sadRar, and to be a Pers. term arabicized. Golius, without mentioning any other authority than that of the K, explains TubanN as follows: “ Pers. sadaraho, Turc. duqurojuno AuwyuniI, Græc. τριώδιον, Trium, vel novem, scruporum ludus. ” Freytag explains the same word as meaning “ Triodii seu trivalli ludus; ” adding a loose rendering of the explanation of qiroq in the K.]
TubonapN signifies also The sound of the [musical instrument called] Tubon. (IAar, K.)
TibonapN Intelligence, understanding, skill, or knowledge: (S, K:) pl. TibanN. (K.)
TubunRapN: see TabinN.
TubaOoniynapN i. q. TumaOoniynapN [q. v.]. (TA.)
TaAbinN: see TabinN.
TaAbuwnN A place in which fire is covered [in a hollow] in the earth, in order that it may not become extinguished: (S, K:) pl. TawaAbiynu. (TA.)
muTobaYinRN i. q. muTomaYinRN [q. v.]. (S.)

1. TabaAhu, (S, K,) aor. yaTobuwhu, (S,) inf. n. TabowN; (K;) and TabaAhu, aor. yaTobiyhi, (S, TA,) inf. n. TaboIN; (TA in art. TbI;) He called him: (S, K:) or, accord. to Sh, he called him with a gentle calling: (TA:) an ex. of the latter verb occurs in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh cited voce DaAribN, (S,) or, as Lh cited that verse, an ex. of the former verb: (TA:) and AiTRabaAhu↓, (Sh, S, K, [in the CK erroneously written AaTobaAhu,]) of the measure AifotaEalahu, (S,) signifies the same. (Sh, S, K.) And [hence] one says, lAa OadoriI mino Oayona ATbyt, [a mistranscription for Tubiyta,] with damm, and ATRbyt, [i. e. QTRubiyta↓,] meaning [I know not whence thou hast been called; or] whence thou hast come. (TA in art. TbI.)
8: see 1, in two places.

One says also AiTRabaI banuw fulaAnK fulaAnFA, (S, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AaTobaI,]) The sons of such a one associated as friends with such a one and slew him: (S, K, TA:) and AiTRabayotuhu I acted with him as a friend, then I slew him. (IKtt, TA.)

AiTRabaI Alquluwba, in a trad. of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, means He showed love, or affection, to the hearts [of others], and drew them near to him. (TA.) And AiTRabaAhu signifies also He attracted him to himself; or sought to make him incline. (TA.)

[TbAp (thus written without any vowel-sign) is said in the TA, in art. TbI, to signify OaHomaqu (i. e. Stupid, &c.): but I think it probable that this is from a mistranscription for ZaboOapN, properly meaning “ a hyena; ” a beast proverbial for stupidity: see DabuEN.]
TabowaMCu: see TabiyapN, in the next art.
1. Tabayotuhu Eanohu, (S, K,) aor. OaTobiyhi, inf. n. TaboIN, (TA,) I turned him away, or back, from it, (Lth, S, K, TA,) namely, his opinion, and his affair, &c. (Lth, TA.)
And Tabayotuhu Uilayohi I called him to it; as also AiTRabayotuhu↓ [in the CK erroneously written AaTobayotuhu]. (K, TA. See also art. Tbw.)
And Tabayotuhu I led him. (K, TA.) And thus Lh explains the ex. of this verb in the verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh cited voce DaAribN. (TA.)

Tabiyato, aor.
TabaIa
, inf. n. TabFI; (TA;) or Tabiyato TabFI XadiydFA; (K; [in the CK, erroneously, TaboyFA;]) said of a she-camel, Her TuboI [q. v.] was, or became, flaccid, flabby, or pendulous; (TA;) or very flaccid &c.; (K;) on the authority of Fr. (TA.)
8: see the preceding paragraph: and see also the same verb in art. Tbw.

TuboIN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and TiboIN↓ (S, K) [A teat, or dug, of any of certain animals mentioned in what follows; agreeably with an explanation of its pl. in the O, voce DaroEN, on the authority of AZ; and agreeably with a usage of its pl. in the TA, voce xilofN, on the authority of Lth: this is the most usual, if not the only proper, signification:] the DaroE [which sometimes means the teat, or dug, and is app. here used in this sense]; mostly, of a beast of prey: (Mgh:) or it is to the beast of prey, and to the solid-hoofed animal, (As, T, S,) like the DaroE to others; and sometimes to the camel; (S;) or that of the camel and of the cloven-hoofed animal is termed xilofN: (As, T:) or, to the camel, and to the cloven-hoofed animal, like the vadoI [which some-
times means the teat] to the woman; and in rare instances, to the solid-hoofed animal, and to the beast of prey: (Msb:) or the HalamaAt [meaning teats], (K, TA,) or, accord. to the M, the HalamataAni [meaning pair of teats], (TA,) of the DaroE [or udder], of the camel, and of a cloven-hoofed animal, and of a solid-hoofed animal, and of a beast of prey: (K:) [and TuboyapN↓ is perhaps a dial. var.: (see xaAtamN, last sentence but two:)] pl. OaTobaMCN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) It is said in a prov., (S,) [and] in a letter of 'Othmán to 'Alee, (TA,) jaAwaza AlHizaAmu AlTRuboyayoni (S, K) The girth passed beyond the TuboyaAn [or two teats, or two pairs of teats]; (TA;) meaning (assumed tropical:) the affair, or case, became distressing, and formidable. (K, TA.)
El-Hoseyn Ibn-Muteyr uses the pl. metaphorically in relation to rain, by way of comparison, saying,

[in which, for tajalRato, I read taHalRaba; for the verse, literally rendered, seems to mean, (tropical:) Its teats were abundant as the abundance of its heavy rain, (or rather I would read likavorapi wblh by reason of the abundance &c.,) so that when it flowed with rain, as though it were milked, the teats poured forth exuberantly]. (TA.)
OaTobaMCu Alkalobapi (assumed tropical:) [Bitch's dugs] is an appellation of the tree called muxaATap [i. e. the sebesten]. (TA in art. mxT, q. v.)
TiboIN: see the next preceding paragraph.
TuboyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

TabiyapN, like fariHapN, on the authority of Fr, in the K erroneously written TabiyRapN, (TA,) [and also there misplaced, for, with fahiIa (in the CK fahuwa) preceding it, it should follow immediately after the explanation of the phrase Tabiyati AlnRaAqapu, being the part. n., and thus signifying Whose TuboI is flaccid, flabby, or pendulous,] applied to a she-camel; (Fr, TA;) and TabowaMCu signifies the same; (Fr, K, TA;) or this is applied to a she-goat, meaning whose dugs (xilofaAhaA) descend towards the ground. (So in one of my copies of the S: in the other copy omitted.)

xilofN TabiIRN i. q. mujiybN [meaning Yielding milk]; (S, K; [thus in my copies of the S, and in copies of the K; but said in the TA to be written in the K and in the copies of the S, mujayRabN, which is evidently wrong;]) as though called, and answering the call. (JM.)

1. TajonN The act of frying: (K:) an adventitious word in the Arabic language. (TA.) You say, Tajana AlXRaIoCa, aor.
Tajuna
, inf. n. TajonN, He fried the thing. (TK.)

TaAjanN, (S,) or TaAjinN, (T,) or both, (Msb, TA, and in a copy of the S written TaAjanN,) and TayojanN↓, (S, Msb, K,) A frying-pan; syn. miqolFI; (Msb;) a TaAbaq upon which one fries: (S, K:) arabicized words, (S, Msb, K,) because T and j do not occur in the original language of the Arabs: (S, TA:) [app. from the Greek τήγανον:] the pl. of TAjn is TawaAjinu; (Msb, TA;) and that of Tyjn↓ is TayaAjinu, (Msb,) or TayaAjiynu. (MA, TA.)
TayojanN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
muTajRanN Fried in a TaAjin. (K.)

1. TaHRahu, aor.
TaHuHa
, (S, O,) inf. n. TaHRN, (S, O, K,) He scraped it with his heel so as to remove its superficial part; grazed it with his heel: (S, O, K: *) or he put his heel upon it and then so scraped it. (TA.)
And He spread it, or expanded it. (IDrd, O, K.)
4. ATHRhu He made it to fall, threw it down, or let it fall: and he threw it. (Fr, O, K.)
7. AnTHR It (a thing, O) became spread or expanded; or it spread, or expanded, itself. (O, K.)

R. Q. 1. TaHoTaHa bihimo, (S, O,) inf. n. TaHoTaHapN and TiHoTaAHN, (S,) He dispersed, or scattered, them, (S, O, TA,) destroying them: (TA:) or he dispersed, or scattered, them, and overcame them. (IF, O.) And TaHoTaHahu He dispersed, or scattered, it, destroying it: (Lth, TA:) or he destroyed it: (IDrd, O:) and he broke it: (S, O:) or he broke it, destroying it: (TA:) and he dispersed, or scattered, it. (S, O.) And TaHoTaHahumo, said of time, or fortune, It destroyed them; and dispersed, or scattered, them. (A.) And TaHoTaHa maAlahu He dispersed, or scattered, his property. (A.)
And TaHoTaHa He laughed slightly: (K:) or so TaHoTaHa fiI DaHikihi; (TA;) which means the same as TahoTaha and katokata (O, TA) and TaxoTaxa and kadokada and karokara. (TA.)
TuHuHN i. q. masaAHiju [pl. of masoHajN and of masoHajN: see these two words]. (IAar, O, K.)
TaHRaAnu [A grinder of corn &c. with a mill] is said by Ks to be of the measure faEolaAnu from [the inf. n.] AlTRaHRu. (O, TA.) [But see art. THn.]

maA EalaI raOosihi TiHoTiHapN means There is not upon his head a single hair: so says AZ: Lh says, OataAnaA wamaA Ealayohi TiHoTiHapN He came to us not having upon him anything: (O:) or the last word in mA Elyh THTHp signifies anything: or any hair. (K.) [See also TiHolibapN.]
AlTRaHoTaAHu The lion. (IDrd, O, K.)

miTaHRapN The hinder part of the hoof of a sheep or goat: (Lth, IAar, O, K:) or a thing resembling a falokap [generally meaning the whirl of a spindle], in its foot, with which it scrapes the ground: (Th, O, K:) Lth says that, beneath its hoof, in the place of the miTaHRap, is a little bone like the falokap. (O.)

1. TaHalahu, (S, O, K,) aor.
TaHala
, inf. n. TaHolN and TaHalN, (K,) He hit, or hurt, his TiHaAl [or spleen]. (S, O, K.)

And TaHalahu, (O, K,) aor.
TaHala
, (K,) inf. n. TaHolN, (O,) He filled it; (O, K;) namely, a vessel. (O.)

TaHila, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
TaHala
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. TaHalN, (S, O, Msb,) He had a complaint of his TiHaAl [or spleen]: (S:) or he became large in his TiHaAl: (O, Msb, K:) and TuHila, like EuniIa, inf. n. TaHolN, [accord. to the CK TaHalN,] has the former of these two meanings. (K, TA.)
And TaHila, (K, TA,) inf. n. TaHalN, (TA,) He was, or became, of the colour termed TuHolap; said of a wolf; and in like manner one says of a sheep or goat. (K, TA.)
And TaHila said of water, (S, O, K,) as also Tahila, (S, O,) It was, or became, corrupt, (S, O, K,) and altered in odour, (S, O,) or stinking, by reason of black mud. (K.)

TaHilN Having his TiHaAl [or spleen] large, or enlarged: (Msb, K:) or having pain therein; as also maToHuwlN↓; (O;) or this latter signifies having a complaint of the TiHaAl; (TA;) or it signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (TA,) hit, or hurt, therein. (S, TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) [Spleenful, as meaning] angry. (IAar, O, K.)

And Black: (O, K:) or of a dusky, or dingy, black colour; (IAar, TA;) which, Z says, may be from [the colour of] the TiHaAl, or from the meaning of AlTRuHolubu: (TA: [see also OaToHalu:]) [for it signifies also]

Overspread with [the green substance termed TuHolub; (IAar, O, K;) or having much THlb; applied to water: (AZ, IAar, * O, * Msb, K:) and in like manner one says EayonN TaHilapN a source having much THlb. (Msb.)
Also Full; (IAar, O, K;) and so maToHuwlN↓; applied to a vessel. (K.)

TuHolapN A colour between that of dust and whiteness, (S, M, O, TA,) with a little blackness, like the colour of ashes: (M, TA:) or a colour between that of dust and blackness, with a little whiteness. (K.)

TiHaAlN [The spleen;] one of the intestines, (Msb,) or a piece of flesh, (K, TA,) well known, (S, O, Msb, K,) black, (or rather blackish,] and broad, in the belly of man and of others, on the left, cleaving to the side, (TA,) or cleaving to the ribs on the left side, (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán, ”) and said to pertain to every ruminant except the horse, which has none: (Msb: [a strange assertion, involving a double mistake; partly originating from a saying which will be mentioned in what follows:]) it is of the masc. gender: (Lh,
TA:) the pl. is TuHulN (Msb, K, TA) and OaToHilapN and TiHaAlaAtN. (Msb. [The second and third of these pls. appear to be rare; for it is said in the TA that the first is the only pl. form: and the last is anomalous.]) One says of the horse, laA TiHaAla lahu [lit. He has no spleen]; which is a metaphor, meaning (tropical:) he is quick, or swift, in his running; like as one says of the camel, laA maraArapa lahu [lit. “ he has no gall-bladder ”]; meaning “ he has no daring. ” (S, O.)
TaAHilN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

OaToHalu Of a colour like that of the TaHaAl [or spleen], (Ham p. 96, and TA,) thus applied to a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, (TA,) and this is said to be the primary signification: or of the colour of ashes: (Ham ubi suprà:) or of the colour termed TuHolap expl. above, (S, O, K,) thus applied to a wolf, (O, K,) and thus the fem. TaHolaMCu applied to a sheep or goat (XaApN), (K,) and the masc. applied to ashes (ramaAdN): (S, O:) also, (S, O,) and (O) TaAHilN↓, (O, K, [in the CK TaHilN, q. v.,]) applied to beverage or wine (XaraAbN), (S, O, K,) meaning not clear, (S, O,) or turbid; and so TaAHilN↓ applied to dust (gubaArN, K, TA, [in the CK guraAbN,] and qataAmN, O and TA). And one says farasN OaxoDaru OaToHalu meaning A horse whose xuDorap [i. e. dingy ash-colour, or dark dust-colour,] is overspread by a little yellowness. (S, O.)
maToHuwlN: see TaHilo, first sentence:
and the same, also, last sentence.
Q. 1. TaHolaba AlmaMCu, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. TaHolabapN, (KL,) The water became overspread with the green substance called TuHolub: (S, * TA:) or had much thereof. (K, TA.)
And TaHolabati AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) The land became green with herbage: (K, TA:) or began to become so: (TA.)
TaHolaba AlUibila He sheared the camels. (K.)
And TaHolaba fulaAnFA He slew such a one. (K.)

TuHolubN and TuHolabN (S, Msb, K) and TiHolibN (Lh, M, K) The green substance, (S, K,) or green slimy substance, (Msb,) that overspreads water (S, Msb, K) which has become stale: (K:) or what is upon water, resembling the web of the spider: n. un. with p. (TA.) [See also EaromaDN.]
maA Ealayohi TiHolibapN There is not upon him a hair. (K.) [See also TiHoTiHapN.]

EayonN muTaHolibapN, (S,) and maMCN muTaHolibN (IAar, K) and muTaHolabN, (K,) this last anomalous, like musohibN, or originating from the supposition of the verb's being trans., (MF,) A source, (S,) and water, (K,) overspread with TuHolub, (S,) or having much thereof. (K.)

1. TaHamahu, [aor.
TaHama
,] inf. n. TaHomN, He filled it. (TA.)

TaHomapN (S, K) and TuHomapN↓ (K, and thus also in some copies of the S) and TiHomapN↓ (K) The dufoEap [as meaning tide, or rush,] of a torrent, (S, K,) and so [as meaning tide] of a valley, (K,) and so [as meaning irruption, or invasion,] of night; (S, K;) and the greater, or main, part of a torrent, and of night: (S:) or the first dufoEap, and the greater, or main, part: or the impulse, or driving, of the greater, or main, part [of a torrent]: and accord. to Z, THmpu AllRayoli is tropical, and means (tropical:) the greater, or main, part of the blackness of night. (TA.)

And (tropical:) A company, or congregated body, of men: (S, A, K, TA:) or, as in the M, a rush, or rushing body, of men, more in number than such as are termed qaAdiyap, which means the first that come to one, or come upon one. (TA.)
And TaHomapu Alfitonapi means (tropical:) The jawolap [or wheeling about, or the defeat, and return to fight,] of men on the occasion of ftnp [i. e. conflict and faction, or the like]. (TA.)
See also TaHomaMCu.
TuHomapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
TiHomapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
TuHamapN A man vehement in conflict. (S, K.)
And Numerous camels. (K.)

TaHomaMCu A species of plant, (S, K,) growing in plain, or soft, land, of the kind called HamoD: (TA:) or i. q. najiylN, (AHn, K, TA,) which is the best of all the HamoD, [herbaceous, i. e.] not having wood fit for fuel nor such as is fit for carpentry, and eaten by the camels; (AHn, TA;) as also TaHomapN↓, (K, TA,) which is said by AHn to be of the kind called HamoD, broad in the leaves, and having much juice. (TA.)
TaHowmN That impels, or propels, much, or vehemently: (K:) applied to a bow; as also TaHuwrN: or a bow of which the arrow is swift. (TA.)
suyuwlN TawaAHimu i. q. dawaAfiEu [i. e. Torrents pouring as though impelling, or propelling, themselves]. (TA.)
maToHuwmN Filled. (K.)

1. TaHana AlburRa, aor.
TaHana
, inf. n. TaHonN, (S, Msb, K,) said of a man, (S,) He ground the wheat; i. e. he made the wheat into daqiyq [i. e. flour]; and so [but app. in an intensive sense] THRnhu↓. (K.)

[Hence] one says, TaHanahumo faOaholakahumo (assumed tropical:) [He crushed them and destroyed them]. (T and M and K in art. dm.) And HarobN taToHanu kulRa XaIoCK (assumed tropical:) [A war that crushes every thing]. (TA. [See also TaHuwnN.]) And TaHanatohumu Almanuwnu (assumed tropical:) [Time, or death, reduced them to dust]. (TA.)
And one says also, TaHanati AlrRaHaI [The mill-stone ground; or revolved]. (S.)
And [hence,] TaHanati AlOafoEaI The viper turned round about; or coiled itself. (S, K. *)
2: see the preceding paragraph, first sentence.
TaHonN: see what next follows.

TiHonN Flour; (S, MA, K;) as also TaHiynN↓: (MA:) or ground wheat and the like; [or meal;] and sometimes the inf. n., TaHonN↓, is used in this sense. (Msb.) Hence the prov., OasomaEu jaEojaEapF walaA OaraI TiHonFA [I hear a sound of the mill, or mill-stone, but I see not flour]. (K.)

TuHanN A certain small creeping thing, (duwayobRapN, S, K, TA,) in form like [the species of lizard, or reptile, called] OumR Hubayon, [see art. Hbn,] but more slender (OaloTafu) than this latter, that raises its tail like as does the pregnant camel, and, when bidden to grind, by the children of the Arabs of the desert, grinds with itself the ground until it becomes concealed in the soft soil; and one never sees it but in a tract of ground such as is termed balRuwqap: Az says that TuHanapN↓ signifies a certain small creeping thing (dwybRp) like the [beetle called] juEal; and that TuHanN is the pl.: [but, properly speaking, the latter is a coll. gen. n., and the former is the n. un.:] As says that it is [a creature] smaller than the hedge-hog, that comes into existence in the sands, appearing sometimes, and turning round as though grinding, and then diving [into the sand]: (TA: [see also EawaAnapN:]) and, (K,) accord. to Aboo-Kheyreh, (TA,) the TuHan is what is called layovu EifirRiyna [q. v. in art. Efr], (K, TA, in the CK layovu Eiforiyna,) resembling the pistachio-nut, in colour like the dust, that buries itself in the earth. (TA.)

[Hence, app.,] Short: (K:) [or] accord. to Zj, TuHanapN↓ signifies short, having in him luwvap [app. meaning stupidity, or the like]; and IB says that he who is tall, having in him lwvp, is termed EusoqudN: (TA:) accord. to IAar, short in the utmost degree: (Az, TA:) accord. to IKh, the shortest of the short; and the tallest of the tall is termed samaro TuwlN. (TA.)
TuHanapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
TaHuwnN (assumed tropical:) A war (HarobN) that crushes (taToHanu) everything. (TA.) And [hence] AlTRaHuwnu is a name for (assumed tropical:) War. (Az, K, * TA.)
And [hence also] (tropical:) A katiybap [or troop] that crushes (taToHanu) what it meets: (S, TA:) or a great katiybap: (K:) or a ktybp of horsemen, mighty, or valorous, and numerous. (TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) Numerous camels; as also TaHRaAnapN↓: (S, K:) or both signify camels when they are [many, and are] such as are termed rifaAq, and have their owners with them; (TA;) as also raTuwnN and raTRaAnapN: (As, TA in art. rTn, q. v.:) and the former, about three hundred sheep or goats; (K;) accord. to Lh; but ISd
says, I know not any other who has mentioned the THwn of sheep or goats. (TA.)
TaHiynN and maToHuwnN↓ (Msb, TA) and muTaHRanN↓ (TA) Ground wheat (Msb, TA) and the like thereof. (Msb.)
For the first, see also TiHonN.
TiHaAnapN The craft, or occupation, of the TaHRaAn [or miller]. (K.)
TaHiynapN The dregs of the oil of sesame. (TA.)

TaHRaAnN [meaning A miller, or grinder of wheat and the like,] is thus, perfectly decl., if you do not derive it from AlTRaHRu: (K, TA:) i. e. TaHRaAn, if you derive it from AlTRaHonu, is perfectly decl.; but if you derive it from AlTRaHRu, or from AlTRaHaA which signifies “ the expanded tract of land, ” it is imperfectly decl.: (S, TA:) if from AlTRaHRu, it is of the measure faEolaAnu, not faERaAlN; and if from AlTRaHaA, it would be by rule TaHowaAnu. (IB, TA.)
TaHRaAnapN: see TaAHuwnapN:
and see also TaHuwnN.

TaAHinN The bull, of those that tread the wheat, that stands [AlRaciI yaquwmu, for which AlRRatiI taquwmu is erroneously put in the K and TA,] in the middle of the heap thereof and around which the other bulls turn: (K, TA:) mentioned by En-Nadr, on the authority of El-Jaadee. (TA.)
[TayoHanN, mentioned by Freytag as meaning A frying-pan (“ sartago ”), is evidently a mistranscription, for TayojanN.]

TaAHinapN, (Msb, TA,) in which the p is added to give intensiveness to the signification, (Msb,) [or to convert the epithet TaAHinN into a subst.,] sing. of TawaAHinu, (Msb, TA,) which signifies (assumed tropical:) The OaDoraAs [as meaning the molar teeth, or grinders,] (S, Msb, K, TA) of a man and of others; as being likened to a mill. (TA.)
TaAHuwnN: see what next follows.

TaAHuwnapN A mill: (S, Msb, K:) [also called in the present day TaAHuwnN↓: and the same meaning is assigned by Golius and Freytag, by the latter as on the authority of the K, (in which I do not find it,) to miToHanapN↓, pl. maTaAHinu; and by Golius to miToHaAnN↓ likewise:] or a mill that is turned by water; (Lth, MA, Mgh;) as also TaHRaAnapN↓: (Lth, Mgh, TA:) or this signifies a mill that is turned by a beast [as TAHwnp and TAHwn do in the present day]: (MA, Mgh:) pl. of the first TawaAHiynu. (Msb, TA.)
[maToHanapN is said by Golius, as on the authority of the KL, (in which however I do not find it,) to signify A place where grinding is performed.]
miToHanapN: see TaAHuwnapN.
muTaHRanN: see TaHiynN.
miToHaAnN A viper turning round about; or coiling itself. (S, K.) A poet says,

L.foreign: UicaA faziEato maMCN huriyqa EalaI jamori

sense.s: [With a coiling viper, as though its hissing, when it is frightened, were the sound of water poured upon live coals]. (S, TA.)
See also TaAHuwnapN.
maToHuwnN: see TaHiynN.
Also (tropical:) Milk: so called as being likened to corn ready-ground, and fit for food. (L in art. msd.)

1. TaHaA, aor. yaToHuw, inf. n. TaHowN; and TaHaI, aor. yaToHaI, inf. n. TaHoIN; two dial. vars., though only TaHaI, like saEaI, is mentioned in the K; (TA;) He spread [a thing]; spread [it] out, or forth; expanded [it]; or extended [it]. (K, TA.) You say, TaHawotuhu, like daHawotuhu, i. e. I spread it; &c. (S.)
And you say, Alqawomu yaToHaI baEoDuhumo baEoDFA The people, or party, repel one another. (TA.)

TaHaI, (K,) or TaHaA, (TA,) also signifies It, or he, became spread, spread out or forth, expanded, or extended; (K, TA;) being intrans. as well as trans. (TA.) Accord. to As, (TA,) TaHaA mina AlDRarobapi means He became extended (S, TA) upon the ground (TA) in consequence of the blow: (S, TA:) [and this is probably meant by what here follows:] TaHaA is said when one throws down a man upon his face; (K, TA;) or when he spreads, or extends, him; or when he prostrates him on the ground: (TA:) but accord. to Fr, one says, Xariba HatRaI TaHRaI↓ i. e. [He drank until] he stretched out his legs: and AlbaEiyru THRI↓ UilaI AlOaroDi i. e. The camel stuck to the ground, either from emptiness or from emaciation: and in like manner one says of a man when people call him to aid or to do an act of kindness: the verb being in all these instances with teshdeed: as though, by saying this, he contradicted As as to its being without teshdeed. (TA.) Accord. to AA, (S,) TaHayotu means I lay, or lay upon my side, or laid my side upon the ground. (S, K. *) And you say, naAma fulaAnN fataTaHRaI↓ i. e. [Such a one slept, and] lay, or lay upon his side, in a wide space of ground. (TA.)

Also, i. e. TaHaA, (AA, S,) or TaHaI, (K,) He (a man, AA, S) went away into the country, or in the land: (AA, S, K:) like TahaA. (S in art. Thw.) One says, maA OadoriI Oayona TaHaA [I know not whither he has gone away &c.]. (S.) And TaHaA bihi qalobuhu His heart carried him away (cahaba bihi) in [the pursuit of] anything: (S, K:) whence the saying of Alkameh Ibn-'Abadeh,

L.foreign: TaHaA bika qalobN fiI AlHisaAni Taruwbu

sense.s: [A heart much affected with emotion has carried thee away in the pursuit of the beauties long after youthfulness, in the time when entering upon hoariness has arrived: buEayoda being here a dim. used for the purpose of enhancement]. (S, TA.) And TaHaI bika hamRaka Thy anxiety has carried thee away in a far-extending course. (TA.) And TaHaI biAlkurapi He threw the ball. (TA.) And TaHaI bifulaAnK XaHomuhu Such a one became fat. (TA.)
TaHaA, aor. yaToHuw, signifies also He, or it, was or became, distant, or remote. (K.)
2: see 1, former half, in two places.
5: see 1, latter half.
TaHFA An expanded tract of land. (S, K.)
[And the same word, app., written in the TA THI, is there expl. as meaning The lower, or baser, or the lowest, or basest, of mankind, or of the people.]
TaHoyapN A portion of clouds; as also TaxoyapN. (K.)

Oaqobala AltRayosu fiI TaHoyaAYihi is expl. by AZ as meaning [The he-goat came] in his state of rattling at rutting-time (fiI habiybihi). (TA. [But probably the right expression is fI TaxoyaAYihi: see TaxoyaMCu.])
TaHRaAnu as derived from AlTRaHaA: see TaHRaAnN, in art. THn.

TaAHK Spread; spread out, or forth; expanded; or extended. (S, * K. [See also muTaHRK.]) And That has filled everything by its multitude: (K, TA:) in this sense [or in the former sense as is implied in the S] applied to an army. (TA.) And one says miZalRapN TaAHiyapN and maToHuwRapN↓ and maToHiyRapN↓, meaning A great (T, K, TA) spreading (TA) tent. (T, K, * TA.) And AlmudawRimapu AlTRawaAHiI The vultures that circle [in the sky] around the bodies of the slain. (S, TA.)

Also High, elevated, or lofty: so in the phrase laA waAlqamari AlTRaAHiI [No, by the high moon]; an oath of some of the Arabs. (TA.) [And Tall as applied to a horse: so TAHI is expl. in the TA; but this, being without the article Al, is a mistake for TaAHK.]
And A great congregated body of men. (IAar, K.)
maToHuwRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
maToHiyRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muTaHRK Spread, expanded, or extended; [like TaAHK;] or thrown down upon his face; or lying, and stretching himself, upon his face, on the ground. (TA.) And Cleaving, or sticking, to the ground. (TA.) And baqolapN muTaHRiyapN A herb, or leguminous plant, growing upon the surface of the earth, (K, TA,) having spread itself upon it. (TA.)

1. TaxaA AllRayolu, [aor.
1a2u2a
,] inf. n. TaxowN and TuxuwRN; and TaxaI [of which the aor. is app.
1a2i2a
, and the inf. n. TaxoIN]; The night was, or became, dark. (TA. [The former of these verbs, with the latter of its inf. ns., is mentioned by Golius as on the
authority of J; but I do not find it in either of my copies of the S.])
And TaxaI, inf. n. TaxoIN, He was, or became, foolish, stupid, or unsound [as though obscured] in intellect or understanding. (TA.)
4. OaToxati AlsRamaMCu The sky became overspread with TaxaMC, meaning clouds, and darkness. (TA.)
TaxoIN: see TaxoyaMCu.
TaxowapN: see the next paragraph.
TaxoyapN Darkness; as also TuxoyapN↓ and TixoyapN↓: (ISd, K:) and so TaxaMCN↓. (TA.)

And A portion of clouds; like TaHoyapN: (K:) or a thin cloud; (M, TA;) and so TaxowapN↓: (M, K, TA: [see also TaxaMCN:]) but, (TA,) accord. to Lh, one says, maA fiI AlsRamaMCi TuxoyapN↓, with damm, meaning There is not in the sky aught of clouds. (S, TA.)
Also Foolish; stupid, or unsound [as though obscured] in intellect or understanding: pl. Taxoyuwna. (Az, ISd, K.)
TuxoyapN: see the next paragraph above, in two places.
TixoyapN: see TaxoyapN.
TaxowaMCu: see the next following paragraph.
TaxoyaMCu The darkness of clouds. (Lth, Mgh, TA.)

And layolapN TaxoyaMCu (S, * ISd, Mgh, K *) A dark night; (S, K;) as also layolapN TaxowaMCu↓: (TA:) or a night intensely dark, (ISd, Mgh, TA,) in which the clouds have concealed the moon: (ISd, TA:) and layolN TaAxK↓ and TxI [app. TaxoIN↓, as inf. n. used as an epithet,] dark night: and layaAlK TaAxiyaAtN↓ dark nights. (TA.)
And kalimapN TaxoyaMCu [A sentence, or an expression,] not understood. (S, K. *)

And [hence, perhaps,] one says [of a he-goat], kaAna celika fiI TaxoyaAYihi, meaning fI hibaAbihi [i. e. That was in his state of rattling at rutting-time]. (JK. [See a similar phrase in art. THw and THI; in which TaHoyaAYihi is probably a mistranscription for TaxoyaAYihi.])
TaxaMCN: see TaxoyapN.

Also Clouds: (TA:) or high, or elevated, clouds; (A'Obeyd, Az, S, K;) as also TahaMCN: (TA:) or, accord. to the M, thin clouds: [see also TaxoyapN:] and Lth says that minN gayomK TaxaMCapN↓ signifies any round portion of cloud that excludes the light of the moon. (TA.)

And Any covering, or envelope, of a thing: one says, EalaI qalobihi TaxaMCN, and TaxaMCapN↓, Upon his heart is a covering: (M, TA:) the TaxaMC of the heart is said to be a covering thereof like that of the moon: (TA:) or TaxaMCN signifies karobN, (K,) or the like thereof, (S,) [i. e. grief, or anxiety, that presses heavily,] upon the heart; (S, K;) as in the saying, wajadotu EalaI qalobiI TaxaMCF [I experienced, upon my heart, grief, or anxiety, that pressed heavily]: (S:) or it signifies heaviness: or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (T, TA.)
TaxaMCapN: see the next paragraph above, in two places.
TaAxK, and the fem. pl.: see TaxoyaMCu. You say also ZalaAmN TaAxK (S, K) Intense darkness; (K, TA;) [in like manner] expl. in some of the copies of the S as meaning HinodisN. (TA.)

diynN, (S, TA,) the latter word formed by transposition from waATidN; (M, TA;) and EaAdapN TaAdiyapN, (S, K,) the latter word said to be formed by transposition from waATidapN, (S,) A custom, or habit, that is constant, settled, or established; old, or inveterate. (S, K.) TaAdK and waATidN are also expl. as meaning Continuous; or constant and uninterrupted. (TA in art. wTd.)

1. TarRa, aor.
Tarura
, (A, Msb, TA,) inf. n. TarRN, (S, A, Msb, K,) He cut, or divided, lengthwise; slit; or rent; (S, A, Msb, K;) a garment or piece of cloth: (TA:) and he cut [in any manner] (S, A, K) the same, (A, TA,) or some other thing. (A.)

He cut off a man's arm or hand, by a blow, or stroke; (A;) as also ATrR↓; (S, A, K; *) and so AtrR. (TA.) He cut, or clipped, his mustache. (TA.) And one says of a woman, taTurRu XaEarahaA She cuts her hair short. (A.) [And app. She cuts her hair over the forehead so as to form what is termed a TurRap: see also 2.]
And TarRati AlUibilu AljibaAla wAlMkaAma (tropical:) The camels traversed the mountains and the hills. (A.) And Tararotu Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) I passed by the people, all of them. (Yoo, TA.)
Also, TarRa, (S, A,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. TarRN (A, K) and TuruwrN, (K,) He sharpened (S, A, K, TA) a spear-head, (S,) or a knife (A, K) &c., (K,) or an iron implement. (TA.)
And TarRa He polished a sword. (O.)
And, (TA,) inf. n. TarRN, (K,) He renovated a building. (K, TA. [In the CK, taHodiyd is put for tajodiyd as the explanation of the inf. n.])
And He plastered with clay his wateringtrough, or tank: (S, TA:) and likewise his mosque, or oratory, and decorated it. (TA.)

And TarRahu bivanaMCK HasanK, aor.
Tarura
, inf. n. TarRN, He eulogized him. (TA voce xamRa.)

And, aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. TarRN, (S, A, K,) He drove away; syn. XalRa; (S, A, K, TA;) and ATrR↓, inf. n. UiToraArN, signifies [the same, i. e.] Tarada. (As, TA.) In some copies of the K, [and in a copy of the A,] AlXRadRu is erroneously put for AlXRalRu as an explanation of AlTRarRu. (TA.)

And you say Tararotu AlUibila, (S,) inf. n. TarRN, (K,) I drove, or brought, or gathered, the camels together, from their several quarters; (S, K; *) like TaradotuhaA: (S:) or, accord. to Yaakoob, I walked on one side of the camels, and then on the other side, to put them in right order. (S.)
And TarRN signifies also The act of seizing, or carrying-off, by force; or snatching at unawares. (Kr, K.)
And The act of slapping with the palm of the hand. (Kr, K.)

As an intrans. v., TarRa, aor.
Tarura
(S, A, Msb, K) and
Tarira
, (Msb, K,) the latter agreeable with analogy, (TA,) [but the former the more common,] inf. n. TuruwrN, (S, Msb,) or TarRN, (K,) or both, (TA,) (tropical:) It (a plant) clave the earth: (A:) or grew forth, or sprouted: (S, Msb:) or came up, or forth. (K.) And it is likewise said of the mustache (S, A, Msb, K) of a boy, (S, A, Msb,) and of hair in general; meaning (tropical:) It burst through the skin: (A:) some say, TurRa XaAribuhu [meaning his mustache grew forth]; (O, TA;) but TarRa is more chaste. (Az, TA.)

TarRati AlnRujuwmu, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) The stars rose; (O, TA;) from TarRa said of a plant: (TA:) or the phrase, as some relate it, is TurRati Alnjwm, which means (assumed tropical:) the stars shone; (O, TA;) from TarRa meaning “ he polished ” a sword. (O.)

And TarRato yaduhu, (S, K, * TA,) aor.
Tarira
and
Tarura
(K, TA) by common consent of the authorities on inflection, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) His arm, or hand, fell off; (S, K, * TA;) [being severed by a blow, or stroke;] like tarRato. (S, TA.)
See also 4.
TarRa said of a man, [app. of the measure faEula, originally Tarura,] inf. n. TaraArapN, He was, or became, beautiful, goodly, or comely. (ISh, TA.)
And TarRato naAqatiI, [app. of the measure faEilato, originally Tarirato, aor. taTarRu,] inf. n. TararN, My she-camel was, or became, clear in colour. (O, TA.)
2. TarRarato, [and TrRrt XaEarahaA,] inf. n. taToriyrN, She (a girl) made to herself a TurRap [q. v.]. (TA.) [See also 1.]
4: see 1, second sentence.
ATrRhu signifies also He made it to fall off. (K, TA.) One says, ATrR QllRehu yada fulaAnK God made, or may God make, the arm, or hand, of such one to fall off; as also AtrRhu. (TA.)
And ATrR, (K,) inf. n. UiToraArN, (AZ, S,) He excited, or incited; syn. OagoraI. (AZ, S. K.)
See, again, 1.

ATrR is also syn. with OadalRa [as meaning He acted with boldness, or he emboldened himself: in the CK, erroneously, AacalRa]. (S, K.) Hence, [accord. to ISk,] OaTirRiI faUinRaki naAEilapN, (ISk, S, K,) or TirRiI↓, (K,) both mentioned by Aboo-Sa'eed, (TA,) a prov., (S, TA,) meaning Act thou with boldness, or embolden thyself, (OadilRiI,) for thou art wearing sandals: (ISk, S, K:) applied alike to a male and to a female and to two and to a pl. number, for it was originally said to a woman, and is therefore used as thus said: (S:) or, (S, K,) accord. to AO, (S,) it means (assumed tropical:) venture thou upon the affair that is difficult, for thou hast strength for it; and was originally said by a man to a woman who was pasturing his cattle in the soft, or plain, land, and leaving the rugged; [lit.] meaning take thou to the Turar, i. e. sides, of the valley; and he says, I think that by the sandals he meant the roughness of the skin of her feet: (S, K: *) or it means
collect thou together the camels: (K:) or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, take thou to the OaToraAr, i. e. sides, of the camels; i. e. take care of them, from the most remote of them [inclusively], and keep them in safety. (TA.) Some say OaZirRiI. (M and K in art. Zr.)
And one says, of a man, maAOaTarRahu, meaning How beautiful, or goodly, or comely, is he! (ISh, TA.)
10. AstTrR UitomaAma AlXRakiyri It caused the [downy, or fine,] hair to grow to its full, or complete, state: occurring in some verses of El-Ajjáj. (O, TA.)

R. Q. 1. TaroTara, [inf. n. TaroTarapN,] (K,) said of a man, (TA,) He gloried, or boasted, vainly, and praised himself for that which was not in him; syn. Taromaca. (K.) IDrd says, TaroTarapN is an Arabic word, [i. e. it is genuine Arabic,] though in common use with the post-classical writers: one says, rajulN fiyhi TaroTarapN, meaning A man in whom is vainglorying &c. (TaromacapN) and loquacity. (O, TA.)
And TaroTara biDaOonihi He called his ewes to be milked, (O, K, TA,) saying to them Taro Taro. (TA.)

Q. Q. 3. AiToraworaI He (a man, TA) became filled by repletion of the stomach, or by anger; (O, K, TA;) as also AiZoraworaI. (O.) [But the former verb is also mentioned in the K, in art. Trw, as of the measure AifoEawoEala; and the latter, in art. ZrI.]
TaroTaro a cry by which ewes are called to be milked. (TA.) [See R. Q. 1, last sentence.]

Turo Turo is said in enjoining one to abide in the neighbourhood of the House of God [at Mekkeh], (O, K,) and to do so constantly: (K:) so says IAar: (TA:) Az has mentioned it in this art.; but if it be a word repeated, from TaAra, aor. yaTuwru, its proper place is art. Twr: the present art. would be its proper place only if it were TaroTiro [imperative of TaroTara]: (O:) [F says,] in my opinion it should rightly be mentioned in art. Twr; but Az and others have mentioned it among reduplicate words; therefore I have followed them, and notified [the case]. (K.)
TarRN [The fur, or soft hair, called] wabar, and hair of the ass, that comes forth after the falling off of former hair. (K.)

TurRN A collective body [of men]. (Yoo, TA.) One says, jaAWuwA TurRFA They came all; (S, TA;) and it is said that TurRFA is here in the accus. case as a denotative of state, or as an inf. n.: Sb mentions the phrase mararotu bihimo TurRFA I passed by them all; and he says that the last word is used only as a denotative of state: but Khaseeb En-Nasránee used it otherwise; replying to one who said to him, How art thou? OaHomadu QllReha UilaI TurRi xaloqihi [I praise God to all his creatures]; and the phrase raOayotu baniI fulaAnK biTurRK I saw the sons of such a one, all of them, has also been transmitted: some say that TurRFA in the first of the phrases above is put in the place of an act. part. n., and is [originally] an inf. n. (TA.)
TirRN: see TurRapN, latter half.
TarRapN A single act of cutting [&c.: an inf. n. of 1, q. v.]. (TA.)

And Impregnation by a single act of initus: (O, L, K:) [used in relation to camels:] or it signifies [simply] a single act of initus: thus in the phrase OaloqaHahaA biTarRapK [He (the stallion) impregnated her by a single act of initus]. (TK.)
AlTRarRapu, (AHeyth, O, K,) thus with fet-h, (O,) and thus written by AHeyth, (TA,) signifies also The flank. (AHeyth, O, K.)
TurRapN A thing that is cut. (TA.)

The hair that is cut over (lit. over against, HicaMCa,) the forehead: (Mgh, Msb, voce quSRap:) what a girl cuts short, of the full hair upon her forehead, and forms into a row or rows: (A:) [so accord. to present usage; the hair over the forehead of a girl or woman, cut with a straight or even edge, or with two such edges one above the other, so as to form a kind of border; as also quSRapN:] what is cut, in the fore part of the naASiyap [or hair over the forehead] of a girl, like the Ealam [or ornamental border], (K, TA,) or like the TurRap [which seems here to signify the same as Ealam, or nearly so], (TA,) which is beneath a crown: and sometimes it is [an imitation of a band, across the forehead,] made of [the black substance called] raAmak: as also TuruwrN↓; (K, TA;) or TaruwrN↓: (so in the O:) or the latter signifies a TurRap made of raAmak: (O, TS:) pl. (of TurRapN, TA) TurarN, and (of TuruwrN [or TaruwrN], TA [and accord. to analogy of TurRapN also]) TiraArN. (K.)
Also (K) [absolutely] The hair over the forehead; syn. naASiyapN. (S, O, K.)
[Hence, app., The TurRap of a building; also called its SufRap: see this latter word.]

And (tropical:) The kufRap of a garment or piece of cloth; (S, A, O, Msb;) i. e., (S,) the border, or side, thereof, that has no hudob [or end of unwoven threads]: (S, O, K:) [and the fringed end thereof: (see SanifapN and hudobN:)] or the ornamental, or figured, or variegated, border (Ealam) thereof: and, in like manner, of a [water-bag of the kind called] mazaAdap: (K, TA: [wAlmazAdpu in the CK is a mistake for wAlmzAdpi:]) or the TurRap of a garment or piece of cloth is a thing resembling two ornamental, or figured, or variegated, borders (EalamaAni) sewed upon the two sides of a burod, upon its border: (Lth, TA:) pl. TurarN (Msb, K) and TiraArN. (K.) And TurRaAtN [is likewise a pl. of TurRapN, and] occurs in a trad. as meaning Veils (sutuwr), or head-veils, (O, TA,) or pieces [or strips], (Z, TA,) cut by women from a garment of the kind called siyaraMC. (Z, O, TA.)

And (tropical:) The side, or edge, of a river, and of a valley: (S, A, O, K:) the border of a land or country: (TA:) and the edge of anything; (S, O, K;) its extremity: (K:) pl. TurarN (S, O, K) and TiraArN: (K:) and OaToraArN also signifies the sides of a valley; and in like manner, of a country, and of a road; (TA;) and the extremities of a country; (S, O, TA;) and its sing. is TirRN↓; or, accord. to the T, TurRapN: (TA:) and TurarN signifies also (tropical:) the margins of a book or writing; (A, TA;) and the sing. is TurRapN. (TA in arts. HXI and hmX.)

And (tropical:) The two lines, or streaks, (xuTRataAni,) upon the two shoulders (katifaAni) of the ass: (K:) or AlTurRataAni signifies the streaked place upon each side of that animal: (TA:) or two black streaks (xTRtAn, as above,) upon the two shoulders (ktfAn) of the ass: and applied by Aboo-Dhu-eyb to those of the wild bull: (S, O:) or two stripes, or streaks, on the back of the ass: (A:) and TurRapu matonihi the streak of his back. (S.)
(tropical:) A streak of cloud: (S, A, * O, K:) an oblong portion of cloud, commencing from the horizon: (TA:) its dim., TurayorapN, occurs in a trad. (O, TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) A goodly aspect of a man. (TA.)
And one says, raOayotu TurRapa baniI fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) I saw the mode, or manner, of alighting and abiding of the sons of such a one, from afar. (TA.)
And badato Turaru AlOamori (tropical:) The indications, or signs, or tokens, of the affair, or event, appeared. (A, TA.)
And takalRama biAlXRaIpCi mino TiraArihi (assumed tropical:) He spoke the thing eliciting it from his mind. (TA.)
TuruwrN, or TaruwrN: see TurRapN.
TariyrN Sharpened; applied to a spear-head; (A, K, TA;) as also maToruwrN↓: (A, TA:) or, so applied, polished; (O;) or thus also, applied to an arrow; and so maToruwrN↓ applied to a sword. (TA.)

And (tropical:) Goodly, or pleasing, in aspect; (S, A, O, K;) applied to a man: (A:) a beautiful, goodly, or comely, man: (ISh, TA:) a man beautiful, goodly, or comely, in face: and some say, whose prime of manhood is future: (TA:) or a youth, or young man, soft, or tender, fleshy, and fat: (Ham p. 513:) pl. TiraArN. (ISh, TA.) See also TaArRN.
TurRaI A she-ass driven away: (O, K, TA:) or a brisk, lively, or sprightly, ass. (TA.)

TarRaArN A cutpurse; one who cuts, or slits, purses, (A, Mgh, Msb, * TA,) and takes people's money at unawares: (Msb:) or who slits a man's sleeve, [in which he carries his money and the like,] and gently extracts what is in it: (TA:) from AlTRarRu “ the act of slitting ” (S, Msb) and “ cutting. ” (S.)
TirRiyaAnN A table upon which one eats; syn. xiwaAnN: (K:) or a dish, or plate, (TabaqN,) upon which food is eaten. (O.) [But see TiriyRaAnN, in art. Trw.]
TaArRN (tropical:) A boy whose mustache is growing forth: (S, A, Msb:) or whose mustache has grown forth; (Lth, L, K;) as also TariyrN↓. (K.)
And xazRN TaArRN (tropical:) A sort of [cloth of the kind called] xazR [app. having a nap]. (A, TA.)

TuroTuwrN A sort of qalanosuwap [q. v.], (S, K,) worn
by Arabs of the desert, (S,) tall, or long, and narrow (S, K) in the head, or top: (S:) [in the present day applied to a sort of high, conical, cap: and a cowl.]
And (assumed tropical:) A slender and tall man. (S, K.)
And, (K,) accord. to IAar, (O,) Low, ignoble, mean, or sordid, (wagodN,) and weak: (O, K:) pl. TaraATiyru. (O.)
muTirRN A boy having a TurRap; as also muTarRarN↓: and the latter with p is applied to a girl. (So in a copy of the A.)
jalabN muTirRN (assumed tropical:) [A thing, or things, brought for the purpose of traffic,] come from the extremities (OaToraAr) of the country. (TA.)
gaDabN muTirRN Anger that is misplaced, and for a thing that does not require it: (S, K:) or in which is somewhat of boldness, or presumptuousness: or such as is vehement, or violent. (TA.)
jaMCa fulaAnN muTirRFA Such a one came domineering, or exalting himself; behaving boldly, or presumptuously. (As, S.)

miTarRapN, (O,) or muTirRapN, or muTarRapN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) with damm, (K,) [and accord. to the TK with fet-h to the T,] Custom, habit, or wont: (O, K:) so says AZ: (O:) [the form given in the O seems to be preferable: but] F has also mentioned it as without teshdeed, [i. e. maToirapN,] and thus it is mentioned [in the K] in art. mTr. (TA.)
muTarRarN: see muTirRN.
maToruwrN: see TariyrN, in two places.

1. TaraOa Ealayohimo, aor.
TaraAa
, inf. n. TuruwoCN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and TaroCN, (S, K,) He came to them from a place; (K;) or from a distant place, unexpectedly: (Mgh:) or he came forth upon them (S, Msb, K) from a place, (K,) or from a distant place, (TA,) unexpectedly, (K, TA,) or from another country, or territory, or town, or the like: (S:) or he came to them without their knowledge: or he came forth upon them from an opening, or a wide, open tract: the original word is [said to be] daraOa [q. v.: see also TaraA, in art. Trw]. (TA.) And TaraOa, (Msb, TA,) said of a thing, (Msb,) aor. as above, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. TrAn [app. TaraMnN], (Msb,) It came, (Msb, TA,) came to pass, happened, or occurred, (Msb,) unexpectedly. (Msb, TA.) It is said in a trad., TaraOa EalaIRa mina AlquroMni, as though meaning A portion of the recitation of the Kur-án came to my turn at an unexpected time. (TA.)

TaruWa, [aor.
TaruAa
,] (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. TaraMCapN (Mgh, K) and TaraMCN, (K,) in some of the copies of the K TaroOapN and TaraMCapN, (TA,) It (a thing, Msb) was, or became, fresh, juicy, or moist; (Msb;) contr. of cawaI; (K;) i. q. Taruwa, inf. n. TaraAwapN, (Mgh, Msb,) of which it is a dial. var., (Msb,) and which is the more common. (TA.)
2. TrROhu, inf. n. taToriYapN, He rendered it fresh, juicy, or moist. (TA.)

4. ATrOhu He praised him: (TA:) or he praised him greatly, or extravagantly; or exceeded the just, or usual, bounds, in praising him: (K, TA:) accord. to Es-Sarakustee, OaToraOotuhu signifies I praised him: and OaTorayotuhu, [in like manner,] I eulogized, or commended, him. (Msb.) [See also the latter verb in art. Trw.]
TuroOapu AlsRayoli i. q. dufoEatuhu [i. e. The tide, or what pours forth at once, of the torrent]: (K:) from TaraOa “ he came forth ” from a land. (TA.)

TuroMnN, (O, K,) or TuroMniIRN↓, occurring in the poetry of El-'Ajjáj, (TA,) A road, or way, and an affair, or event, unknown, or disapproved, or deemed strange or extraordinary: (O, K:) [or an affair, or event,] unknown, &c., and wonderful. (TA.)

TuroMniIRN, an epithet applied to a pigeon, (O, K,) and to an event, (K,) Of which one knows not whence it has come: (K:) an irregular rel. n. from TaraOa EaloyanaA fulaAnN “ Such a one came forth upon us without our knowing him: ” (TA:) [or] TuroMn is the name of a certain mountain in which are many pigeons; (O, K;) and hence the epithet above mentioned as applied to a pigeon: (O, TA:) Aboo-'Obeyd El-Bekree writes this name, in the Moajam, with damm to the first letter and teshdeed to the second: the vulgar say HamaAm TuwraAniIR, which is a mistake. (TA.)
See also TuroMnN.
TariIoCN Fresh, juicy, or moist; (A, * Mgh, * Msb, TA;) a dial. var. of TariIRN. (Msb.)

TaAriYN part. n. of TaraOa, applied to a man, and to a thing: (Msb:) the pl. is TurRaMCN, (K, TA,) like zuhRaAdN, (TA,) and TuraOLCu, (K, TA,) like EulamaMCu, and MF mentions, as from the M, TaraON, like xadamN, [but this is properly termed a quasi-pl. n.,] and TaraOapN, like katabapN, and in some copies TuraApN, like quDaApN: (TA:) and TurRaA is applied to strangers, for TurRaMCN, meaning Persons coming from a distant place. (L, TA.) One says, huwa mana AlTRurRaMCi laA mina AltRunRaMCi [He is of those who come from another place, or country; not of the settled residents]. (A, TA.)
[It is also applied to a signification, as meaning (assumed tropical:) Adventitious.]
TaAriYapN (assumed tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune, (O, K, TA,) of which one knows not whence it has come. (TA.)

mTrY [thus written, without any syll. signs, in the TA, and there said to be the subst. (Aisom) from OaToraOahu: but I think that it is evidently muToriYN; and not the subst., but the act. part. n. (Aisomu AlfaAEili), of OaToraOahu].

1. Tariba, (S, Msb, TA,) aor.
Taraba
, (Msb,) inf. n. TarabN, (S, * Msb, K, * TA,) He was, or became, affected with emotion, or a lively emotion, or excitement, agitation, or unsteadiness, (xifRap, S, Msb, K, TA,) [of the heart or mind,] by reason of joy or of grief, (K, TA,) or of intense grief or joy, (S,) or of intense fear or joy: (Msb:) or [he was moved with joy, or delight;] he was joyful, mirthful, or glad: and the contr., i. e. he was affected with grief, sadness, or sorrow. (K, * TA.) [See TarabN, below.]
And Taribati AlUibilu liloHudaMCi [The camels became excited by reason of the driver's urging them with singing]. (A, TA.)
And Trbt Eani AlTRariyqi [written in the TA without any syll. signs, app. Taribotu,] i. q. Edlt Enh [i. e. I deviated (Eadalotu) from the road, or way]. (TA.)

2. TrRb, (TA,) inf. n. taToriybN, (K,) He sang. (K, TA.) And TrRb fiI Sawotihi He trilled, or quavered, and prolonged, his voice: (Msb:) or AltRaToriybu fiI AlSRawoti is the prolonging of the voice, and modulating it sweetly. (S, TA.) And, said of a bird, or, accord. to some, peculiarly of the mukRaMC, It prolonged its voice, and trilled, or quavered, it, or warbled. (TA.) And in like manner, TrRb fiI qiraMCatihi (A, TA) He prolonged, and trilled, or quavered, his voice in his reciting, or reading; (TA;) and fiI ginaAYihi [in his singing]. (A.) And qaraOa biAltRaToriybi [He recited, or read, with a prolonging, and trilling, or quavering, of the voice]. (A, TA.)
And TarRabuwA They raised their voices, cried out, or cried aloud, time after time. (Skr, TA.)
TRrbhu: see 4.
[Freytag adds that, in the “ Fákihet el-Khulafà, ” p. 42, l. 5 infr., it means He asserted him to have sung excellently.]

4. ATrRbhu He, (S,) or it, (one's voice, A,) caused him to be affected with Tarab [i. e. emotion, or a lively emotion, &c.]; as also tTrRbhu↓; (S, A;) [and TrRbhu↓; for] taToriybN signifies the same as UiToraAbN, like taTarRubN↓; (K:) [generally, he, or it, rendered him lively, brisk, or sprightly: and] ATrbhu is said of joy, and of grief, meaning [it affected him with Tarab; or] it rendered him restless, or unsteady. (MA.)
5: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
10. AstTrb He, or it, sought, or demanded, Tarab [i. e. emotion, or a lively emotion, &c.], (K, TA,) and diversion, sport, or play. (TA.)
And They (a party, or company of men,) became affected with intense Tarab. (A, TA.)

AstTrb AlUibila He put in motion the camels by urging them with singing. (K.) You say AstTrb AlHudaApu AlUibila [The drivers, singing to them, excited, moved, or stirred, the camels,] when the camels have become lively, brisk, sprightly, or agile, because of their urging them with singing. (O, TA.) Az cites the saying of Et-Tirimmáh,

L.foreign: Mlu AlDRuHaI naAXiTFA mino daAEibaAti dadi

sense.s: but in his poem it is waQsotaTorafato, with faAC [i. e. with the letter f]: (O:) [this latter reading is, I doubt not, the right; and the meaning seems to be, And their women borne in the camel-vehicles, when the mirage of the early part of the forenoon elevated them to the eye, elicited anew longing desire for their homes, or accustomed places, from jocose, sportful females, lit., from jesting females of sport or diversion: the verse as cited by Az may admit of a similar rendering if we suppose AstTrbt to be there used tropically: the writer of my copy of the TA has endeavoured, in marginal notes in the present art. and in art. dd, but in my opinion unsatisfactorily, to explain it; and has supposed AstTrbt to mean Taribat: his two notes, moreover, are inconsistent:] naAXiTFA in this verse means XawoqFA naAziEFA. (K in art. dd. [The verse is there cited with two readings differing from the words given by Az; waQsotaToraqat, thus written with q instead of f, a manifest mistake, and mino daAEibK dadidi.])
AstTrbhu signifies also He asked him to sing. (A, TA.)

TarabN Emotion, or a lively emotion, or excitement, agitation, or unsteadiness, (xifRapN, S, A, Msb, K,) [of the heart or mind,] by reason of joy or grief, (A, K,) or of intense grief or joy, (S,) or of intense fear or joy: (Msb:) or joy, mirth, or gladness: and the contr., i. e. grief, sadness, or sorrow: (Th, K:) or, as some say, the lodgement of joy, mirth, or gladness, and departure of grief, sadness, or sorrow: so in the M: (TA:) the vulgar apply it peculiarly to joy; (Msb;) [but] the application of it peculiarly to joy is a mistake: (K:) it signifies also motion; syn. HarakapN: (K:) it is said in the M, Th says that AlTRarabu is derived from AlHarakapu; whence it seems that AlTRarabu is, in his opinion, syn. with AlHarakapu; but [ISd adds] I know not this: (TA:) [it does, however, obviously imply the signification of motion, either ideal or actual:] also desire, or yearning or longing of the soul: (K:) the pl. is OaToraAbN. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, En-Nábighah El-Jaadee, using it in relation to anxiety, (TA,)

[And I perceive myself to be affected with emotion, or a lively emotion, after them, (i. e. after the loss of them,) with the emotion of him who is bereft of offspring or friends, or like him who is insane in mind]: (S, TA:) AlwaAlih here signifies AlvRaAkil; and Almuxotabal means mano junRa fiI Eaqolihi. (TA.)
And [the pl.] OaToraAbN signifies Choice sweet-smelling plants: (K:) or [simply] sweet-smelling plants: (TA:) and the more fragrant of such plants. (O, TA.)
TaribN Affected with Tarab [i. e. emotion, or a lively emotion, &c.]: (S, A, O, Msb, TA:) pl. TiraAbN. (A, TA,) A Hudhalee says,

L.foreign: baAtato TiraAbFA wabaAta AllRayola lamo yanami

sense.s: [They passed the night joyful, or glad, and he passed the night without sleeping]: (O, TA:) meaning that the [wild] bulls or cows, thirsting, passed the night joyful on account of the lightning that they saw, and the water for which they hoped in consequence thereof. (TA.) See also another ex. in the verse cited voce TarabN.

UibilN TiraAbN means Camels yearning for their accustomed places of abode: (S, O, TA:) or they are so termed when they are excited (UicaA Taribato) by reason of their drivers' urging them with singing. (A, TA.)

Also The head [meaning the hair of the head]: so called because of the sound that it makes when it is twisted with fingers: occurring in the phrase HatRaI yaronaOa AlTRariba [That he may dye the hair of the head with yuranRaO, i. e. HinRaMC]. (L, TA.)

TaruwbN (A, O, Msb, K, TA) and miToraAbN↓ (A, O, K, TA) and miToraAbapN↓ [which is of a very unusual form (see miEozaAbapN)], (Lh, K, TA,) applied to a man, (O, K, TA,) Much, or often, affected with Tarab [i. e. emotion, or lively emotion, &c.]: (O, Msb, TA:) [but the last is doubly intensive, signifying very much, or very often, so affected:] pl. [of the second and third] maTaAriybu. (A.) One says, UicaA xafaqati AlmaDaAriybu xafRati AlmaTaAriybu↓ [When the plectra of the lutes quiver, the persons who are wont to be affected with emotion become lively, or light-hearted]. (A, TA.) And HamaAmapN miToraAbN↓ [A pigeon that cooes much or often]. (A, TA.) And UibilN maTaAriybu↓ [Camels that yearn much, or often, for their accustomed places of abode: or that are much, or often, excited by reason of their drivers' urging them with singing: see TaribN]. (A, TA.)

maTorabN and maTorabapN↓ A separate, or straggling, road, or way: (S, O:) or a narrow road, or way: (K:) or the former, a conspicuous road or way: (IAar, TA:) and the latter, a small road, or way, leading into a great one: or a narrow road, or way, apart from others: (TA:) or a small road, or way, branching off from a main road: (O:) pl. maTaAribu: (S, O:) [it is said (but see 1, last sentence,) that] there is no verb corresponding thereto. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Aboo-Dhu-eyb, (O, TA,)

(S, O, TA) i. e. Many a desert tract, like the division of the hair of the head in narrowness, narrow conspicuous [or straggling] roads, or ways, [whereof the portions over which the eye can reach are far-extending,] protract; some of these roads, or ways, tending this way and some that way. (TA. [mTArb is here with tenween for the sake of the measure. See also zaqabN. Perhaps the poet means to liken the said roads to the ropes of a tent.]) It is said in a trad., laEana QllRehu mano gayRara AlmaTorabapa↓ [May God curse him who alters the mTrbp]; i. e., the road thus called. (TA.)
maTorabapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
miToraAbN, and its pl.: see TaruwbN, in four places.
miToraAbapN: see TaruwbN.
Q. 1. Tarobala bawolahu He extended [or emitted] his urine upwards. (S, O, K.)
And Tarobala He dragged his skirt, and walked with a proud and self-conceited gait, stretching out his arms. (O.)

TirobaAlN A high portion of a wall; (S, O;) whence the saying, in a trad., that when any one passes by a leaning TrbAl, he should quicken his pace: (O:) it resembles a manoZarap of the manaAZir of the 'Ajam, being in form like a SawomaEap [q. v.]: (AO, O, TA:) or a sign of the way, constructed (O, K) upon a mountain: (O:) and (O, K) accord. to IDrd, (O,) a portion of a mountain, and of a wall, elongated in form towards the sky, (O, K,) and inclining: (O:) and any high building: (K:) [and this seems to be meant by what here next follows:] accord. to IAar, a high, or an overtopping, or overlooking, hadaf: (TA:) and, (S, O, K,) as some say, (O,) a great, high, or overtopping, rock (S, O, K) of a mountain: (S, K:) ISh says that it is a structure erected as a sign for horses to run thereto in a race, and one kind thereof is like the manaArap [q. v.]: Fr, that it signifies a SawomaEap [q. v.]: (TA:) and [it is said that] the TaraAbyl of Syria are its SawaAmiE. (S, O, K.) Az mentions his having heard [the pl.] TaraAbiylu, and EaraAziylu likewise, applied to Booths constructed of palm-branches, in which the watchers of the palm-trees shelter themlseves from the sun. (TA.)
TirobiylN [perhaps from the Latin “ tribula ” or “ tribulum ”] The [machine, or drag, called] naworaj [q. v.] with which the heap of corn is thrashed. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
jarRapN muTarobalapu AljawaAnibi A jar long in the sides. (Sh, TA.)
R. Q. 2. taTarovava He gathered, or collected, the species of plants called Turovuwv. (S, Msb, K.)
TarovN Any plant (nabaAt, K [so in the TA and in my MS. copy of the K, in the CK binAC, which is an evident mistranscription,]) that is fresh and juicy. (K.)
TirovN The extremity of the baZor [q. v.]. (K.)
And Flaccidity, or flabbiness. (L.)

TurovuwvN A species of plant, which is eaten; (S, K;) [app. a kind, or species, of fungus; perhaps a species of phallus;] a plant of the same kind as
the cuWonuwn and the Eurojuwn; (IAar, T in art. cOn;) accord. to Lth, a slender, oblong plant, inclining to redness, and serving as a dibaAg to the stomach [app. meaning a stomachic], included among medicines, of which there is a bitter sort and a sweet sort; (Msb;) in the M said to be a plant of the sands, long and slender, similar to the fuTor [q. v.], inclining to redness, which dries, and serves as a dibaAg to the stomach; n. un. with p; on the authority of AHn: it is of two sorts; one sweet, which is the red; and one bitter, which is the white; IAar says that it is a plant of the length of a cubit, having no leaves, as though it were of the same kind as the truffle; (TA;) Az says that the Trvwv of the desert has no leaves (Msb, TA) nor any fruit, (TA,) grows in the sands (Msb, TA) and in the level grounds, (TA,) has in it no acidity, (Msb,) but a sweetness inclining to astringency and bitterness, and is red, with a round head, (Msb, TA,) like the glans of a man's penis: (TA:) [Ibn-Seenà (whom we call Avicenna), in his list of medicinal simples, (book ii., p. 183 of the printed ed.,) describes TaraAviyv as pieces of wood in a rotting state, of the thickness of a finger, and in length less and more, having an astringent taste, and dust-coloured; said to be brought from the desert. See also suwqapN.] The Arabs say, TaraAviyvu laA OaroTaI lahaA [Turthoothehs without artáhs]: because the former grow not save with the latter: a prov., like caMniynu laA rimova lahaA: applied to him who is ruined, and has nothing remaining, after having had ancestry and rank and wealth. (TA. [See also art. cOn, last sentence.])
Also (tropical:) The glans of a man's penis: (K, TA:) so called as being likened to [the head of] the plant above described. (TA.)

1. TaraHahu, and TaraHa bihi, (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the latter allowable because a verb that is syn. with another verb may have the same government as the latter, and TaraHa is syn. with a verb that is trans. by means of b, as will be shown in what follows, (Msb,) aor.
TaraHa
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. TaroHN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) He cast it, threw it, or flung it; or cast, threw, or flung, it away; [and particularly as a thing of no account; (see TiroHN;)] syn. ramaAhu, (S, A, O, K,) or ramaI bihi, (Mgh, Msb,) and OaloqaAhu; (A, Mgh;) mino yadihi [from his hand]. (Mgh.) You say, TaraHa lahu AlwisaAdapa (A, TA) He threw to him the pillow, or cushion; syn. OaloqaAhu. (TA.) And TaraHotu AlrRidaMCa EalaI EaAtiqiI I threw the [garment called] rdMC upon my shoulder; syn. Oaloqayotuhu. (Msb.) And [hence] TaraHa Ealayohi AlmasoOalapa (tropical:) He put, or proposed, (lit. threw,) to him the question: (A, * TA:) thought by ISd to be post-classical. (TA.) [And in post-classical language, TarHN signifies also The making a throw in the game of backgammon and the like; and the making a move in the game of chess &c.]

Also, i. e. TaraHahu and TaraHa bihi, He removed it; placed it, or put it, at a distance; put it away, or far away; [cast it off, rejected it, or discarded it;] (ISd, K, TA;) as also AiTRaraHahu↓; (S, A, O, K;) [respecting which see 8 in art. DrH;] and TrRHhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taToriyHN; (TA;) or this last signifies he cast it, threw it, or flung it, or he cast, threw, or flung, it away, much, or frequently. (S, A, O.) One says, TaraHati AlnRawaI bifulaAnK kulRa maToraHK i. e. (tropical:) [Removal, or distance, or the place to which he journeyed,] rendered such a one [utterly] remote [or cast away]. (S, O, TA. [Here maToraH is an inf. n.]) And [in like manner] TaraHa bihi AldRahoru kulRa maToraHK i. e. (tropical:) [Time, or fortune,] removed him, or separated him, [utterly,] from his family and kindred. (TA.) And maA TaraHaka UilaI hecihi AlbilaAdi (tropical:) [What has driven thee to these regions?]. (A.) And AiToraHo Uilayohimo Eahodahumo (assumed tropical:) [Cast thou from thee, to them, their covenant; i. e. reject it, or renounce it, to them]. (Bd in viii. 60.) And hecaA AiTRariHo↓ AlHadiyva (tropical:) [Dismiss thou this discourse]. (A, TA. [See the pass. part. n., below.]) And AiTRariHo↓ XukoriI walawomiI (assumed tropical:) Let thou alone, or abstain thou from, thanking me and blaming me. (Har p. 332.)

TariHa, (IAar, O, K,) aor.
TaraHa
, (K,) inf. n. TaraHN, (TK,) He (a man, IAar, O) was, or became, evil in disposition. (IAar, O, K.)
And He enjoyed, or led, a life of ample ease and comfort. (IAar, O, K.)
2: see 1.

TrRH, (S, A, O, K,) inf. n. taToriyHN, (S, K,) signifies also (tropical:) He made a thing long, or he made it high: (TA:) or he made his building long; (S, K;) as also TaromaHa↓, (S, and K in art. TrmH,) in which the m is [said to be] augmentative: (S:) or both signify he made his building long and high: (A:) or the former signifies he made his building very long. (O.)
And He (a horse) took long, or wide, steps in running. (O, TA.)

3. muTaAraHapu AlkalaAmi is a phrase well known: (S, K:) AlmuTaAraHapu signifies (assumed tropical:) The bandying of words, one with another; (KL, and Har p. 190;) the holding a colloquy, or a discussion, with another: and it is [said to be] primarily used in relation to singing. (Har ibid.) You say; TArHhu AlkalaAma (assumed tropical:) He held a colloquy, or a discussion, with him. (MA.) And TaAraHotuhu AlEiloma and AlginaMCa (tropical:) [I bandied with him scientific discourse and songs]. (A.) [See also 6.]
4. OaToriH (tropical:) Look thou: (A, TA:) from TarofN miToraHN and TariyHN. (TA.)
5. tTrRH He attired himself with a TaroHap: a post-classical word.]
6. tTArHwA (tropical:) They bandied questions, one with another; put, or proposed, (lit. threw,) questions, one to another. (A.)
8. AiTRaraHa: see 1, in three places.
Q. Q. 1. TaromaHa: see 2; and see also art. TrmH.

TiroHN (S, A, K) and TurRaHN↓ and TariyHN↓ (K) A thing (S, A) cast, thrown, or flung, away, syn. maToruwHN, (S, A, K,) and not wanted by any one. (S.) One says, lawo baAta mataAEuka TiroHFA maA Ouxica [If thy household goods passed the night, or remained during the night, cast away and neglected, they would not be taken]. (A, TA.)
And TiroHN signifies also The leopard: so says Aboo-Kheyreh: pl. TuruwHN. (O.)
TaraHN (assumed tropical:) Distance, or remoteness. (TA.)
See also TaruwHN, in two places.

TaroHapN The [article of apparel called] TayolasaAn [q. v.]: (O, K:) it was not known to the Arabs. (O.) [See De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., ii. 267-269: and Dozy's Dict. des Noms des Vêtements chez les Arabes, pp. 254-262. It is now applied in Egypt to a kind of head-veil worn by women, the two ends of which generally hang down behind, nearly reaching to the ground: but it is often worn in another manner; about a quarter of it hanging down behind, and the remainder being turned over the head, and under the chin, and over the head again, so that the middle part covers the bosom, and both ends hang down behind: it is a piece of muslin, or the like, often embroidered at each end; about three quarters of a yard in width, and in length nearly equal to twice the height of the wearer.]
TurRaHN: see TiroHN.
TaraAHN: see the next paragraph.

TaruwHN (assumed tropical:) A distant place; as also TaraHN↓, (S, K,) and TaraAHN↓, (K,) and [app. TaAriHN↓, for] one says diyaArN TawaAriHu (tropical:) Distant dwellings or abodes [as though the latter word were pl. of TaAriHapN]. (A, TA.) [Hence,] EuqobapN TaruwHN (tropical:) [A stage of a journey] far-extending. (A, * O: in a copy of the former EaqabapN.) And sayorN TuraAHiIRN↓ (assumed tropical:) A far, or distant, journey: (As, S, O, K:) or a hard journey. (TA.) And niyRapN TaruwHN, (TA,) or TaraHN↓, (T, K, TA, and O in art. DrH,) like DaraHN, (O in that art.,) i. q. baEiydapN [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A distant, or remote, thing, or place, that is the object of an action or a journey]. (T, O, K.) And naxolapN TaruwHN (assumed tropical:) A palm-tree having long racemes: (S, O, K:) or of which the upper part is far from the lower: pl. TuruHN, with two dammehs. (TA.)

qawosN TaruwHN (tropical:) A bow that propels the arrow with vehemence; (S, A, O;)
i. q. DaruwHN: (S, O, K:) or that sends the arrow far: (TA:) or that sends it to the furthest limit. (AHn, TA.) And rajulN TaruwHN (tropical:) A man who, when he compresses, impregnates. (Lh, O, K.) And faHolN TaruwHN (assumed tropical:) i. q. miToraHN, q. v. (O.) And zamanN TaruwHN (tropical:) A time that casts the people thereof into places, or positions, of peril: and nawaAYibu TuroHN [or TuruHN, as above, (tropical:) Accidents that cast people into such places or positions]. (A.)
TariyHN: see TiroHN:
and see also miToraHN.
sayorN TuraAHiIRN: see TaruwHN.
TarRaAHapN: see miToraHN.
TaAriHN: [fem. with p; and pl. of the latter TawaAriHu:] see TaruwHN.
sanaAmN UiToriyHN A long, (S, O, L, K,) or tall, (S, * O, * L, K, *) camel's hump, (S, O, L, K,) leaning on one side. (L.) [See an ex. voce UisoliyHN.]
OuToruwHapN (assumed tropical:) A question that one puts, or proposes, lit. throws. (TA.)
fulaAnN yuloqiI AlOaTaAriyHa is expl. by AO as meaning Such a ones moves both his arms up and down [in walking]: denoting a proud and self-conceited manner of walking. (O.)
maToraHN A place where, or into which, a thing [or person is cast or thrown or] is made to be: pl. maTaAriHu. (Har p. 188.)
[And hence,] (tropical:) A state in which a person is [put, or placed]: so in the saying, maATaraHaka hecaA AlmaToraHa (tropical:) What hath put, or placed, thee in this state in which thou art? (A.)
miToraHN I. q. miforaXN [q. v.: and TarRaAHapN↓ has the same, or a similar, meaning; applied in the present day to a horse-cloth, and the like; and to a mattress]: pl. maTaAriHu. (A, TA.)

faHolN miToraHN (tropical:) A stallion that sends his semen far into the womb; (A, * O, K;) like TaruwHN↓. (O.) And TarofN miToraHN (tropical:) An eye that sees far; (A, O, K;) as also TariyHN↓. (A, TA.) And rumoHN miToraHN (tropical:) A long spear. (A, K.) And UibilN maTaAriHu (tropical:) Quick, or swift, camels. (A, TA.)

[miToraHN, as stated by Freytag, is also expl. by Reiske as meaning Camela in cujus ventrem aqua profunda cadit: but this explanation may have originated from a doubtful instance of the same epithet applied to a stallion camel: see above.]
qawolN muTRaraHN (tropical:) A [rejected] saying, to which no regard is paid. (A, TA.)

maXaI mutaTarRiHFA (assumed tropical:) He walked, or went, in a slack, or languid, manner; as though repeatedly stumbling, or throwing himself down; syn. mutasaAqiTFA; (IDrd, A, O;) like one fatigued, or weary, (IDrd, O, K,) and weak. (TA.)

1. Taradahu, aor.
Taruda
, (S, A, Mgh, &c.,) inf. n. TarodN (S, A, L, Mgh, Msb, K) and TaradN, (S, A, L, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) He drove away him, or it; as also TrRdhu↓ and AiTRaradahu↓: (L:) he drove him away, expelled him, or banished him, (ISk, S, L, K,) and said to him, Depart thou, or go thou away, from us: (ISk, S, L:) he removed him, or it; put, or placed, him, or it, at a distance, away, or far away; (S, A, Mgh, L, K; *) with his hand, or arm, or with an instrument in his hand; as when one says Taradotu AlcRubaAba Eani AlXRaraAbi [I drove away the flies from the wine, or beverage]. (Durrat el-Ghowwás, in De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Ar., p. 60 of the Ar. text.) You say, Taradotuhu facahaba [I drove him away, &c., and he went away], (Sb, S, Msb,) using chb in the place of the quasi-pass., (Msb,) not using [in this case] the measure AinofaEala (S, A) nor AifotaEala, (S,) [i. e.] you do not say AnTrd↓ nor ATRrd↓, (Sb, Msb,) except in a bad dialect. (S, A, Msb.) And you say, marRa fulaAnN yaToruduhumo Such a one went along driving them away and pursuing them. (S, L.)

And Tarada AlUibila, [aor.
Taruda
,] (S, L,) inf. n. TarodN and TaradN, He drove, or brought, or gathered, the camels together, from their several quarters. (S, L, K. *)

[And Tarada, aor. and inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He coursed, pursued, hunted, or strove to gain possession of or to catch, wild animals or the like]: the inf. n. TaradN is expl. as signifying muzaAwalapu AlSRayodi [and TarodN is very frequently used in this sense]. (S, K.) You say, xaraja yaTorudu Humura AlwaHoXi (tropical:) He went forth to course, pursue, hunt, snare, entrap, or catch, the wild asses. (A.) And Taradati AlkilaAbu AlSRayoda (assumed tropical:) The dogs drove away, and pursued closely, the wild animals, or the like. (L.) And AlSRayoda TArd↓, inf. n. TiraAdN, (assumed tropical:) He circumvented, in order to snare, entrap, or catch, the wild animal, or wild animals, or the like; and in like manner, a serpent. (L.)
And Taradotu Alqawoma I came to the people, or party, or came upon them, or destroyed them, (Oatayotuhumo, K, or OatayEtu Ealayohimo, T, S, L,) and passed through them. (T, S, L, K.)
And AlrRiyHu taTorudu AlHaSaI waAlSRafaI (tropical:) The wind blows away with violence the pebbles and the dust. (A.)
And AlqiyEaAnu taTorudu AlsRaraAba (tropical:) The plains have the mirage running along them like water. (A.)
And Taradotu baSariI fiI Oamori Alqawomi (tropical:) [I directed my observation to the affair, or case, of the people, or party]. (A.)
And Taradotu AlxilaAfa fiI AlmasoOalapi (assumed tropical:) I put forward an opposition, or a contradiction, in the question: app. from AlmuTaAradapu meaning “ the making to run in a race. ” (Msb.)
2: see 1, first sentence: and see also 4; the latter, in two places.

One says also, TrRd Sawotahu (tropical:) He prolonged his voice; syn. madRahu: (A, TA: *) or taToriydu AlsRawoTi signifies madRuhu [i. e. the extending, or stretching forth, the whip]. (K, TA.) [The latter I think a mistranscription.]
TrRdhu jaroHahumo, said of a judge, means (tropical:) He bade him, (i. e. a litigant) to invalidate their testimony, or evidence, if able to do so. (TA, from a saying of EshSháfi'ee.)

3. TArd qironahu, (A,) inf. n. muTaAradapN and TiraAdN, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) He charged upon, or assaulted, or attacked, his adversary, (S, A, K,) in war (S) &c., (TA,) the latter doing the same, (S, K,) and fought him, whether he drove him away or not. (A.) One says, humo furosaAnu AlTRiraAdi (tropical:) They are the horsemen who charge upon, assault, or attack, one another. (S, K, TA.)
TArd, inf. n. muTaAradapN, signifies [also] (assumed tropical:) He made [a horse] to run in a race. (Msb.)
TArd AlSRayoda: see 1, latter half.

4. ATrdhu He made him, or caused him, (ISh, ISk, S, Mgh,) or he ordered him, (L, K,) to be driven away, expelled, banished, removed, or put or placed at a distance or away or far away, (ISh, ISk, S, Mgh, L, K,) so as not to be in a state of security; (ISh, Mgh, TA;) said of the Sultán: (Mgh:) or he (the Sultán, S, L) ordered that he should be expelled, or banished, (S, L, K,) from his, (S, L,) or from the, (K,) town, or country: (S, L, K:) or ATrdhu Eani Albaladi, and TrRdhu↓ with teshdeed, he (the Sultán) expelled him, or banished him, from the town, or country. (Msb.)
And ATrd AlUibila He ordered that the camels should be driven, or brought, or gathered, together, from their several quarters. (S, L.)
And OaToradonaA Alganama We sent the he-goats among the herd. (IAar, TA.)

And ATrdhu, (L, K,) inf. n. UiToradN, (A 'Obeyd, Mgh,) He (i. e. a person about to race with another, L) said to him, If thou outstrip me I will give thee such a thing, and if I outstrip thee thou shalt give me such a thing; (A 'Obeyd, Mgh, L, K;) as also TrRdhu↓. (L.)
