6. tTArdA (tropical:) They two charged upon, assaulted, or attacked, and fought, each other, whether they drove each other away or not. (A.)
7. AnTrd a word of a bad dialect. (S, A, Msb.) See 1.
8. AiTRarada, as trans.: see 1, first sentence.
As quasi-pass.: see 1, second sentence.

AiTRarada AlmaMCu (tropical:) The water flowed in a regular, or a continuous, or an uninterrupted, course, one portion following another: (A, * L, Msb:) and ATRrdt AlOanohaAru (assumed tropical:) The rivers so flowed: (Msb:) or [simply] the rivers ran, or flowed. (S.) And AiDoTarada Alxayolu (tropical:) The horses ran, following one another: occurring in a trad.: the verb is originally AiTotarada; the augmentative t being changed into T, and then the radical T is changed into D: (L:) and for AiDoTiraAdN, some say AiloTiraAdN, changing the D into l [as in AiloTajaEa for AiDoTajaEa]. (Az, TA in art. DjE.) And ATRrdwA UilaI Almasiyri (tropical:) They followed one another to go on a journey. (A.) And ATRrd AlXRaIoCu, (S, A, L,) or AlOamoru, (Msb, K,) (tropical:) The thing, or the affair, followed a regular and con. tinuous course, one part, or stage, following another
uninterruptedly: (S, A, L, Msb, K:) and ATRrd AlOamoru signifies also the affair followed a right, a direct, or an even, course. (S, L, K.) And ATRrd AlkalaAmu (assumed tropical:) The language, or speech, was consecutive, or uninterrupted, in its parts. (L.) And ATRrdt qiraMCatuhu (assumed tropical:) His recitation, or reading, continued uninterruptedly: from yawomN TarRaAdN meaning “ a long day. ” (Mgh.) And ATRrd AlHadRu (assumed tropical:) The definition was of uniform, undeviating, or general, application; it uniformly, or commonly, or constantly, applied, or obtained; i. e. all the things to which it related followed one uniform, or undeviating, way, like the course of rivers. (Msb. [And in like manner one says of a rule.]) ATRrd said of a word, form or measure, construction, or government, means (tropical:) It was agreeable with the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of analogy, or rule; it was agreeable with common, or constant, analogy, or rule: and, said of the same, or of a rule, it was agreeable with the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of usage; it was agreeable with common, or constant, usage; it commonly, or constantly, obtained: [the verb is used absolutely to express each of these two meanings; the context in general showing clearly which meaning is intended:] the former meaning is also expressed by the phrase ATRrd fiI AlqiyaAsi; and the latter, by the phrase ATRrd fiI AlAisotiEomaAli. (Mz, 12th nwE. [See also the contr. XacRa: and see muTRaridN, below.])
10. AstTrd He desired, or sought, to drive away, expel, banish, remove, or put or place at a distance or away or far away. (KL.)

AstTrd lahu (S, L, Msb, in the K AstTrdhu lahu,) denotes a kind of stratagem, (S, L,) or what is as though it were a kind of stratagem, (K,) meaning (assumed tropical:) He fled, or wheeled about widely, from him, i. e. from his adversary in fight, to turn again, by way of stratagem, and then returned upon him; as though he drew him from a position which he could not maintain to one which he could maintain. (Msb.)
And hence, app., the phrase, waqaEa celika EalaI wajohi AlAisotiToraAdi (assumed tropical:) That occurred in the way of a digression, not being mentioned in its proper place. (Msb.)

TaradN i. q. firaAxu AlnRaHoli [as though meaning The young ones of bees: but app. a mistranscription for frAx AlnRaxoli (assumed tropical:) the suckers, or offsets, of palmtrees; as though pushed forth; of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like nafaDN &c.]. (TA, from AHn.)
maMCN TaridN Water in which beasts have waded, and in which they have voided their urine and dung. (K.)
TirodapN (assumed tropical:) A charge, or an assault, of two horsemen, each upon the other, at one time. (K.)
TurodiynN A certain food of the [people called] OakoraAd [pl. of kurodN]. (K.)
TiraAdN: see miToradN.
fulaAnN yamoXiI maXoyFA TrAdFA [app. TiraAdFA, from TiraAdN meaning “ a spear; ” or perhaps TarRaAdFA↓;] (assumed tropical:) Such a one walks in a straight, a direct, or an even, course. (L, TA.)

TariydN and maToruwdN↓ (S, L, Msb) and muTarRadN↓ (A) [and muTRaradN↓ A man driven away, expelled, banished, or outcast; (L;) a man removed; put, or placed, at a distance, away, or far away: (S, L:) TariydN is likewise applied to a female, as also TariydapN; and the pl. of both in this case is TaraAYidu. (M, L.) naAqapN TariydN, without p, means A she-camel driven away, and taken away: pl. TaraAYidu. (L.)

And (tropical:) One who is born after another: (S, L, K:) the second is termed the Tariyd of the first. (S, L.) Also (assumed tropical:) One who is born before another. (K.) And hence, AlTRariydaAni (tropical:) The night and the day: (A, L, K:) each being the Tariyd of the other. (A, L.)
See also TarRaAdN.

Also (tropical:) Old; applied to a garment, or piece of cloth; syn. XaArifN. (A, TA.) And vawobN TaraAYidu is mentioned by Lh as meaning (assumed tropical:) An old, worn-out, garment, or piece of cloth. (TA.)
And The base, or lower part, of the raceme of a palm-tree; (S, L, K;) as also TariydapN↓. (L.)

TariydapN [a subst. from TariydN, rendered so by the the affix p,] A wild animal, or the like, that is coursed, hunted, snared, entrapped, or caught: (S, L, K, TA:) pl. TaraAYidu. (TA.) The female that is the object of the chase of a male [wild] ass. (M * and K * and MF, all in art. Alb.)
And A number of camels driven away together, i. e., (S,) camels that are stolen: (S, K:) a number of camels attacked by a troop of horsemen and driven away. (A, L.)

(assumed tropical:) A cane wherein is a notch (HuzRap), which is put upon spindles and arrows, (S, L, K,) and upon a stick, (L,) and thus used for planing them: (S, L, K:) (tropical:) i. q. safanN, (AHeyth, A, L,) i. e. a cane which is hollowed, and has some notches cut in it, (AHeyth, L,) through which an arrow is put (AHeyth, A, L) and repeatedly drawn [to smooth it]: (AHeyth, A:) or a small piece of wood, in the form of a water-spout, as though it were the half of a cane, of the size required by the bow or arrow [which are to be smoothed therewith]. (AHn, L.)

(tropical:) An oblong piece (A, K) of a garment (A) or of silk: (K:) or a long strip (AA, IAar, TA) of rag (AA, TA) or of silk. (IAar, TA.) (assumed tropical:) A piece of rag, which is moistened, or wetted, and with which the [kind of oven called] tanRuwr is wiped; as also miToradapN↓. (K.)
And (tropical:) A narrow strip of herbage (A, * K, TA) and of land. (K, TA.)
And (tropical:) The line, or streak, (xuTRap,) between the rump-bone and withers. (L.)
See also TariydN, last sentence.

AlTRariydapu is also the name of A certain game (K, TA) of the boys of the Arabs of the desert, (TA,) called by the vulgar AlmasRapu, (K, TA,) and some say AlmaAsRapu, (TA,) and AlDRaboTapu: when the hand of the player falls upon the body or head or shoulder of another, it is [said to be] AlmasRapu; and when it falls upon the leg, or foot, it is AlOasonu: (K, TA:) but this [app. meaning AlOasonu] is not of established authority: it was also played by girls. (TA.)
See also what here follows.

TarRaAdN A small and swift kind of ship or boat: (K, TA:) called by the vulgar taToriydapN↓ [perhaps a mistranscription for TariydapN↓, which is a postclassical term for a vessel used for the transport of horses; and of which TaraAYidu is the pl.: see Quatremère's Hist. des Sultans Mamlouks, i. 144]. (TA.)

Also (assumed tropical:) One who prolongs a recitation, or reading, [of the Kur-án] to people so that he drives them away: (K:) or one who drives away people by the length of his standing and the muchness of his recitation, or reading. (Mgh.)

And (tropical:) Wide, spacious, or ample; (A, K;) applied to a plain, (A,) or place. (K.) And (tropical:) An even, wide, roof. (K, TA.) And bilaAdN TarRaAdapN (tropical:) Wide, or spacious, regions or lands, (A, L,) in which the mirage [in appearance] flows. (L.)

Also, (A, Mgh, L, K,) and TariydN↓, and muTarRadN↓, (L, K,) (tropical:) A long day: (L, Mgh, K, TA:) (tropical:) a whole, or complete, day, (A, L,) or month. (A.) And sinuwna TarRaAdapN (tropical:) Whole, or complete, years. (A.)
See also TiraAdN.
TaAridN [act. part. n. of 1: fem. with p, and pl. of the latter TawaAridu].
[Hence] TawaAridu AlUibili (tropical:) Those that remain behind, [as though driving away the others,] of the camels. (A.)
taToriydapN: see TarRaAdN.

miToradN A spear; so called because one hunts (yTrd) with it: (Msb:) or, (S, M, A, Mgh, L, K,) as also TiraAdN↓, (L, K, [in my copy of the Mgh, app., TarRaAd, its pl. being there plainly written TarRAdAt, though the sing. is doubtfully written, and it may be that Freytag, who mentions TarRaAdp as signifying a spear, was led to do so from his finding TiraAdaAt, which I believe to be pl. of TiraAdN, written TrRAdAt,]) a short spear, (M, A, Mgh, L, K,) so called for the reason above mentioned, (Mgh,) [i. e.] with which one hunts (yTrd), or with which one hunts wild animals; (M, L;) [a short hunting-spear;] or a short spear with which one thrusts, or pierces, (S, L,) wild animals, (S,) or wild asses: (L:) pl. maTaAridu. (A.) [And Freytag mentions maTaAridu as a pl. without sing., occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, meaning Long arrows.]

maToradapN A means of driving away, removing, &c.: so in the phrase maToradapu AldRaMCi Eani Aljasadi (assumed tropical:) A means of driving away, or removing, disease from the body. (L, from a trad.)
And (assumed tropical:) The beaten track; or main part, and middle; of a road; as also miToradapN↓. (K.)
miToradapN: see TariydapN, latter half:
and maToradapN.
muTarRadN: see TariydN:
and TarRaAdN.

[muTarRidN, accord. to Freytag, occurs in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, applied to a spear, as meaning Altogether straight, so that the whole trembles:
for that which is crooked does not. But this, if not a mistranscription, is app. used by poetic license, for muTRaridN↓.]
maToruwdN: see TariydN.
muTRaradN: see TariydN.
jadowalN muTRaridN (assumed tropical:) A rivulet, or streamlet, [regular, or uninterrupted, and] swift in course. (L.)

[In a copy of the A, among tropical phrases, I find jadowalN muTRaridu AlOanaAbiybi waAlkuEuwbi; but it seems that there is an omission here, and that after jadowalN we should read muTRaridN; and then, warumoHN Alx, i. e. (tropical:) A spear even and regular in the internodal portions and the knots.] See muTarRidN.
[Hoseyn Ibn-Homám El-Murree applies muTRarid, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, to A coat of mail, app. meaning even and regular in texture: see Ham p. 189.]
baEiyrN muTRaridN (assumed tropical:) A camel that continues his pace, or course, uninterruptedly, and does not become out of breath from running. (L.)
muTRaridu AlnRasiymi is used by a poet as a name for (assumed tropical:) The nose of a running horse [app. meaning uninterrupted in breathing]. (S, L.)

muTRaridN applied to a word, form or measure, construction, or government, means (tropical:) Agreeable with the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of analogy, or rule; agreeable with common, or constant, analogy, or rule: and, applied to the same, or to a rule, agreeable with the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of usage; agreeable with common, or constant, usage; commonly, or constantly, obtaining: (Mz, 12th nwE:) [but what is thus termed is not strictly speaking and in every case without exception; for, taking 24 to represent universality, 23 in comparison therewith is muTRarid;] 20 in comparison with 23 is gaAlib; 15 is kaviyr; 3 is qaliyl; and I is naAdir. (Mz, 13th nwE. [See also the contr. XaAcRN: and see 8 in this art.])
ramolN mutaTaAridN (assumed tropical:) Sand of which one part drives away and follows another. (L.)

1. Tariza, aor.
Taraza
, (K,) inf. n. TarazN, (TK,) He became goodly in shape, form, or aspect, after having been thick. (Sgh, * K, * TK.)
(tropical:) He became good in disposition, after having been evil. (K.)

Tariza fiI Qlomalobasi, (K,) and fiI QlomaToEami, (TA,) (tropical:) He was nice, or dainty (taOanRaqa, K, or tanawRaqa, A) in apparel, (K, * TA,) and in diet; (TA;) not wearing, (K, TA,) and not eating, (TA,) aught but what was good: (K, TA:) as also fiyhimaA tTrRz↓. (TA.)

Accord. to IAar, AlTRRarozu signifies AlrfE bAllkz; [thus in the L and TA; but, I think, incorrectly, for AldRafoEu biAllRakozi;] and one says, Tarazahu, inf. n. TarozN [app. meaning He repelled him by striking with his fist]. (L, TA.)
2. TrRz AlvRawoba, (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. taToriyzN, (Msb, K,) He embroidered, or variegated, A or figured, the garment, or piece of cloth. (S, A, Msb, K.) [See TiraAzN.]
5. tTrRz It (a garment, or a piece of cloth,) was embroidered, or variegated, or figured. (K.)
See also 1.

TurozN, (Msb, and so in two copies of the K, and in the TK,) like falosN [in measure], (Msb,) or TirozN↓, (so in the K accord. to the TA, and so in a copy of the A,) Form; shape; outward appearance; or garb; syn. XakolN; (IAar, Msb, TA;) and hayoYapN; (K;) and bizRapN: (TA:) as also TiraAzN↓; syn. hayoYapN. (S.) You say, hecaA Tarozu hecaA This is of the form, or shape, of this. (Msb.)

(tropical:) A way, or manner, of acting; (A, TA;) as also TiraAzN↓; syn. of the latter namaTN, (S, Msb, K,) and OusoluwbN. (TK.) You say, maA OaHosana fulaAnK Tiroza↓ (tropical:) How good is the way of acting of such a one! and TirozN HasanN Tirozuhu↓ (tropical:) His way of acting is a good way of acting. (A, TA.) And AlOawRali mina AlTRiraAzi↓, (S, Msb,) occurring in a verse of Hassán Ibn-Thábit, (S,) signifies Of [the people of] the first [and best] way of acting; i. e., mina AlnRamaTi AlOawRali. (S, Msb.) [But see a different explanation of this phrase below, voce TiraAzN.]
Anything good, goodly, or excellent; as also TiraAzN↓. (TA.)
TirozN: see TarozN, in three places.
Also A house, or chamber, (bayot,) somewhat long; [said to be] a Pers. word arabicized: or a summerhouse, or summer-chamber. (TA.)

TiraAzN The embroidery, or variegated or figured work, (Ealam,) of a garment, or piece of cloth: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) a Pers. word, (S, A, TA,) arabicized: (S, A, Msb, K:) said to be originally tirozo, meaning, in Pers., “ even measurement: ” (TA:) [or originally TiraAzo, which has the same meaning in Pers. as the arabicized form has in Arabic:] pl. TuruzN. (Msb.)

And A garment, or piece of cloth, woven for the Sultán: (K:) also arabicized [from the Pers. TiraAzo, meaning, a royal robe, or rich embroidered garment]: and one also says, vawobN TiraAziIRN↓: (TA:) or this last is so called from a place named TiraAz. (Mgh.)

And A place in which goodly garments or cloths are woven: (Lth, Az, A, K:) and this also is arabicized [from the Pers. TiraAzo, which has the same meaning]. (TA.) You say, Eumila hecaA AlvRawobu fiI TiraAzi fulaAnK This garment, or piece of cloth, was made in such a one's place for weaving goodly garments or cloths. (A.) And huwa maA Eumila fiI TiraAzi QllRehi (tropical:) [It is what has been made in God's place of creation of goodly things]: said of a beautiful face. (A, TA.) And hecaA AlkalaAmu AlHasanu mino TiraAzi fulaAnK (tropical:) [This beautiful language is of the elegant composition of such a one]. (A, TA.) And huwa mina AlTRiraAzi AlOawRali (tropical:) [app. He is of the first noble extraction]. (A, TA. [See also TarozN.]) And one says of a man, when he utters a good thing of his own excogitation, hecaA mino TiraAzihi (assumed tropical:) [This is of his clever excogitation]. (Sgh, TA.) And in like manner is expl. the phrase, in a trad., layosa hecaA mino TiraAziki (assumed tropical:) This is not of thine own authorship and excogitation. (TA.)
See also TarozN, in four places.
TiraAziIRN An embroiderer; one who does figured work upon garments or cloths; as also muTarRizN↓ (TA) [and TarRaAzN↓].
vawobN TiraAziIRN: see TiraAzN.

TiraAzadaAnN, or TiraAzodaAn, or TirozadaAn, (accord. to different copies of the Mgh and K,) The case (gilaAf) of the balance (AlmiyzaAn); an arabicized word; (Mgh, K;) mentioned by Sgh; in Pers. taraAzuwdaAno [but this is expl. in Pers. dictionaries as meaning the scale of a balance]. (TA.)
TarRaAzN: see the paragraph next but one above.
muTarRizN A garment, or piece of cloth, embroidered, or variegated, or figured. (S, Msb.)
muTarRizN: see TiraAziIRN.
1. Tarasahu, inf. n. TarosN, He wrote it; namely, a writing or book; as also saTarahu. (TA.)
See also 2.
Tarisa, a verb like fariHa, He (a man) became worn out in body, and aged. (Sgh, TA.)

2. TrRshu, (M, A,) so written by El-Urmawee, (TA,) inf. n. taToriysN; (A;) or Tarasahu↓, aor.
Tarisa
; (K;) He obliterated it, or effaced it; (K, TA; [compare darasahu;]) and (TA) he marred, or spoiled, it: (M, TA:) or he obliterated it, or effaced it, well. (A.)
Also, the former, (M,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He blackened it; namely, a door. (M, K.)
And TrRs, (TK,) inf. n. as above, (Lth, K,) He restored the writing upon a thing whereon the writing had been obliterated, or effaced. (Lth, K. *)
5. tTRrs He ate not, nor drank, aught save what was good; (K, TA;) like tnTRs: so says IF. (TA.)
tTrRs Eanohu He shunned it; kept aloof, or preserved himself, from it; (Sgh, K, TA;) and held himself above the commission of it. (Sgh, TA.)

TirosN A written paper or the like; syn. SaHiyfapN, (S, A, Msb, K;) or SaHiyfapN UicaA kutibato; as also TilosN: (Sh, TA:) or one of which the writing has been obliterated, or effaced, and which has then been written upon [again]; (S, A, Msb, K;) [a palimpsest;] as also TilosN: (S:) or one of which the writing has been obliterated, or effaced, well: (Az, in TA, art. Tls:) or a writing that has been obliterated, or effaced, and then written [again]; as also TiroSN: (M:) or an obliterated, or effaced, writing upon which one is able to renew the writing: (Lth, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaToraAsN (S, M, Msb, K) and [of mult.] TuruwsN. (M, A, Msb, K.)

mutaTarRisN One who seeks, pursues, or desires, the
most pleasing of things; who picks, or chooses. (T, K, TA.)

1. TariXa, aor.
TaraXa
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. TaraXN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) He was, or became, deaf: or affected with something less than SamamN [or deafness]: (Msb:) or like deafness: (Mgh:) [meaning, heaviness, or dulness, of hearing: (see OaToraXu:)] or TaraXN is the slightest deafness: (S, A, K: [in the CK it is erroneously written TaroX:]) but some say that it is not pure Arabic: (Msb:) and some say that it is post-classical: (S, Msb, K:) so says IDrd: (O:) AHát disallows the root and its derivatives, and says that they have not been content with the barbarousness of saying TaraXN, but have formed from it a verb, namely, TariXa: (O, TA:) ElMa'arree says that the verb has been formed by the vulgar from OuToruwXN, which is an Arabic word. (TA.)
5. tTrRX He stood and sat; said of one who is convalescent: (O:) or he became convalescent, and nearly recovered, and arose and walked; syn. AiboragaXRa. (K.)

tTrRX biAlbahomi i. q. Aixotalafa bihaA [i. e. He went to and fro, repeatedly, with the young lambs or kids: strangely expl. in the TK as said of a camel, and as meaning he became mixed, or confounded, among the beasts]. (O, K.)
6. tTArX He feigned himself deaf: (O, K:) or heavy, or dull, of hearing. (Mgh.)
bihi TuroXapN In him is the slightest deafness. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.)

OaToraXu, (Msb,) or OuToruwXN↓, (Az, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) of which Az says, I know not whether it be Arabic or adventitious, (Msb,) and IDrd says that it is not genuine Arabic, (Mgh,) and AHát disallows it, but El-Ma'arree says that it is Arabic, though the verb is a barbarism, (TA,) Deaf; (Msb, K;) and in some of the copies of [the work of] Yaakoob, OuToruXN↓ is found, thus expl.: (TA:) or heavy, or dull, of hearing: (Mgh:) or affected with something less than deafness: (Msb:) or with the slightest deafness: (A:) the fem. of OaToraXu is TaroXaMCu: (Msb:) and the pl. is TuroXN. (Mgh, O, Msb, K. *)
Accord. to Z, [in the A,] OaToraXu, applied to a man, signifies Having thin eyebrows. (TA. [But I think that this is a mistranscription for OaToraTu.])
OuToruXN: see the next preceding paragraph.
OuToruwXN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. TariTa, [aor.
TaraTa
,] inf. n. TaraTN, He had thin eyebrows: (Ibn-'Abbád, O:) or he had light, thin, or scanty, hair of the eyes, of the eyebrows, and of the eyelashes. (K.)
And He was, or became, foolish, stupid, unsound in intellect or understanding, or deficient therein. (K.)
TaraTN Thinness of the hair in the eyebrow. (IAar, TA.)
TariTN: see OaToraTu.
Also Foolish, stupid, unsound in intellect or understanding, or deficient therein. (K)
TaAriTN Light, thin, or scanty, in the hair; (IAar, O, L, K) applied to an eyebrow. (L.)

OaToraTu AlHaAjibayoni A man destitute of eyebrows; (AZ, S, O;) as also OamoraTu AlHljbyn; (O;) and some say OaDoraTu, but Abu-l-Ghowth knew it not: (S, O:) or having light, thin, or scanty, hair of the eyebrows; and so AlHaAjibiyoni TariTu↓: (K:) the mention of the HaAjibaAni is indispensable; (AZ, S, O, K;) but sometimes omitted, on the ground of a weak authority: (K, TA:) and accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, OaToraTu signifies having thin eyebrows. (O.) And TaroTaMCu AlEayoni A woman having scanty eyelashes. (O, K.)

Q. 1. TaroTaba biAlmiEozaI, inf. n. TaroTabapN, He (the milker) called the goats, [app. by making a sound with the lips; for,] accord. to AZ, TaroTabapN is with the lips: (S:) he called the goats: (IKtt, TA:) and TaroTaba biAlnRaEojapi he called the ewe: (AZ, TA:) [and Freytag says, on the authority of the “ Kitáb el-Addád, ” that TaroTaba signifies also he drove away sheep from himself:] the inf. n. signifies the milker's making a sound to the goats with his lips, (ISd, K, TA,) to quiet them, or appease them: (ISd, TA:) and the calling sheep or goats to be milked, (K, TA,) as some say, with the lips: (TA:) also the calling of asses: (Az, TA:) and, accord. to some, the whistling with the lips to sheep. (TA.)

yuTaroTibu XuEayoraAtK lahu, occurring in a trad., means Putting in motion his mustache [lit. some small hairs that he had] in his speech: or, as some say, blowing with his lips into his mustache by reason of rage and pride. (O.)
And TaroTabapN signifies also The agitation, or commotion, of water in the belly (IKtt, K, TA) and in a skin. (IKtt, TA.)
And The act of fleeing. (IKtt, TA.)
TuroTubN: see TuroTubRN, in two places.
TuroTubapN: see TuroTubRN:
and TuroTubRapN.

TuroTubRN A long breast: (S:) or, as also TuroTubN↓, and, accord. to him who makes vadoIN [the “ breast ”] fem., TuroTubRaI↓, a large, flabby breast: (K:) or a large, flabby, long breast: (TA:) and the first word, a long udder; (Ham p. 809;) [and] so TuroTubapN↓, written without tenween, in the dial. of El-Yemen; on the authority of Kr. (TA.) One says, OaxozaI QllRehu TuroTubRayohaA May God expose to shame her long breasts. (A, TA.)

Also, and TuroTubN↓, (assumed tropical:) The penis: (K:) [not found by SM in any work except the K; but the former word is mentioned in this sense in the O:] app. so called as being likened to a long and flabby breast. (TA.)
duhodurRayoni waTuroTubRayoni [or each of these two words by itself] is said to, or in reference to, a man whom one derides. (AZ, S, O, K. [See art, dhdr.])

TuroTubRapN A woman having long breasts: (S, TA:) or having large breasts: or having flabby breasts. (TA.) And, or accord. to the TA and some copies of the K TuroTubapN↓, (said in the TA to be without teshdeed,) as also TuroTubaAniyRapN↓, Having a long udder: (K:) or a she-goat having long teats. (TA.)
TuroTubRaI: see TuroTubRN.
TuroTubaAniyRapN: see TuroTubRapN. This art. is included in some of the lexicons in art. Trb.

1. Tarafa, aor.
Tarifa
, inf. n. TarofN, He looked from the outer angle of the eye: or [he twinkled with his eye, i. e.] he put the edge of his eyelid in motion, or in a state of commotion, and looked: (M, TA:) or AlTRarofu signifies the putting the eyelids in motion, or in a state of commotion, in looking: (Mgh, * TA:) one says, XaxaSa baSaruhu famaA yaTorifu [His eye, or eyes, has, or have, become fixedly open, or raised, and he does not put his eyelids in motion, or does not twinkle with his eye, or eyes, in looking]: (TA:) [or] one says, Tarafa AlbaSaru, aor. and inf. n. as above, meaning the eye, or eyes, [twinkled, or] became in a state of commotion: (Msb:) [or] Tarafa baSarahu, (O, K, TA, and so in a copy of the S,) or baSaruhu, (so in one of my copies of the S,) aor. and inf. n. as above, [he winked, i. e.] he closed one of his eyelids upon the other: (S, O, K: [see also 4:]) or Tarafa biEayonihi [in the CK bEayonayohi] he put his eyelids in motion, or in a state of commotion: (K, TA:) and Turifato Eayonuhu, aor. tuTorafu, inf. n. as above, his eyelids were put in motion or in a state of commotion, by looking. (As, TA.) [Another meaning of Tarafa baSarahu, and another of Turifato said of the eye, will be found below.] EayonN taTorifu, signifying An eye that [twinkles, or] puts the eyelid in motion, or in a state of commotion, with looking, is used for cuw EayonK taTorifu, meaning (assumed tropical:) a living being. (Mgh.) maA baqiyato minohumo EayonN taTorifu [There remained not of them one having an eye twinkling] means (tropical:) they died, (O, K, TA,) or (O, in the K erroneously “ and, ” TA) they were slain. (O, K, TA.)

[Also He looked: for] AlTRarofu is used as meaning the act of looking (Er-Rághib, Msb, TA) because the putting in motion of the eyelid constantly attends that act: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and Tarafotuhu, inf. n. as above, signifies I saw, or I looked at or towards, him, or it; syn. OaboSarotuhu. (Ham p. 111.) It is said in the Kur [xiv. 44] laA yarotadRu Uilayohimo Tarofuhumo [Their look shall not revert to them; i. e., shall not be withdrawn by them from that upon which they shall look]. (S, O.) And in the same [xxvii. 40], OanaA Mtiyka bihi qabola Oano yarotadN Uilayoka Tarofuka, [meaning, in like manner, I will bring it to thee before thy look at a thing shall revert to thee, or be withdrawn by thee therefrom: or,] accord. to Fr, meaning before a thing shall be brought to thee
from the extent of thy vision: or, as some say, in the space in which thou shalt open thine eye and then close it: or in the space in which one shall reach the extent of thy vision. (O.) And one says, naZara fulaAnN biTarofK xafiIRK [Such a one looked with a furtive glance], meaning, contracted his eyelids over the main portion of his eye and looked with the rest of it, by reason of shyness or fear. (Har p. 565.) And taTorifu AlrRijaAla [app. meaning She looks at the men] is said of a woman who does not keep constantly to one. (TA. [See maToruwfapN.]) And taTorifu AlrRiyaADa rawoDapF baEoda rawoDapK [app. meaning She looks at the meadows, meadow after meadow, to pasture upon them in succession,] is said of a she-camel such as is termed TarifapN [q. v.]. (As, TA.)

Tarafotu Eayonahu, (S, O, Msb, in the K Tarafa Eayonahu,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) I (S, O, Msb) hit, struck, smote, or hurt, his eye with a thing, (S, O, Msb, K, [in the CK XaIoCN is put for biXaIoCK,]) such as a garment or some other thing, (TA,) so that it shed tears: and one says of the eye, Turifato. (S, O, K. [See another explanation of the latter in the first sentence.]) Ziyád, in reciting a xuTobap, said, qado Tarafato OaEoyunakumu AldRunoyaA wasadRato masaAmiEakumu AlXRahawaAtu [The good of the present world hath smitten your eyes, and appetences have stopped your ears]. (O.) And one says Tarafahu and TrRfhu↓ meaning He, or it, struck, smote, or hurt, his eye. (TA.) And TarafahaA AlHuzonu waAlbukaMCu Grief and weeping hurt it (the eye), so that it shed tears. (TA.) And TarafahaA HubRu AlrRijaAli The love of the men smote her eye, so that she raised her eyes and looked at every one that looked at her; as though a Tarofap [or red spot of blood], or a stick or the like, hurt her eye. (Az, TA.)
AlTRarofu signifies also The slapping with the hand (K, TA) upon the extremity of the eye. (TA.)
Then it became applied to signify The striking upon the head. (TA.)
Tarafahu Eanohu signifies He turned him, or it, away, or back, from him, or it. (S, O, K.) Hence the saying of a poet, (S, O, TA,) 'Amr Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah, (TA,) or a young woman of the Ansár, (O,)

so in the S; but the right reading is Eani AlOaqodami, for the next verse ends with taSorimiI: (IB, TA:) [i. e. Verily thou, by Alláh, art one having a weariness: the nearer turns thee away, or back, from the older:] meaning, he turns away, or back, thy sight from the latter: i. e. thou takest the new (Aljadiyda tasotaTorifu↓), and forgettest the old. (S, TA.) You say, Tarafotu AlbaSara Eanohu (S * Msb) I turned away, or back, the sight from him, or it. (Msb.) And AiTorifN baSaraka Turn away, or back, thy sight from that upon which it has fallen and to which it has been extended. (TA.)
And Tarafahu EanRaA XugolN Business, or occupation, withheld him from us. (TA.)
And Tarafahu He drove him away. (Sh, TA.)

Tarifato, (S, O, K,) [aor.
Tarafa
,] inf. n. TarafN; (TA;) and tTrRft↓; She (a camel) depastured the sides, or lateral parts, (OaToraAf,) of the pasturage, not mixing with the other she-camels, (S, O, K,) tasting, and not keeping constantly to one pasturage. (Har p. 569.)
Tarufa, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. TaraAfapN, (O, TA,) It (property) was recently, or newly, acquired: (S, O, K: *) or it (a thing) was good [and recent or new or fresh]. (Msb.)
And the same verb, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, TA,) He was such as is termed TariyfN [and TarifN q. v.] as meaning the contr. of quEodud. (S, K.)
2. TrRfhu [from the subst. AlTRarofu meaning “ the eye ”]: see 1, latter half.

TrRf [from AlTRarafu], (S, O, K,) inf. n. taToriyfN, (K,) He (a man, S, O) fought around the army; because he charges upon, or assaults, those who form the side, or flank, or extreme portion, of it, (S, O, K,) and drives them back upon the main body: (S, O:) or, as in the M, he fought the most remote thereof, and those that formed the side, or flank, thereof. (TA.)

And TrRf EalaIRa AlUibila He drove, or sent, back to me those that formed the sides, or extreme portions, of the camels. (O, K.) And TrRf Alxayola He drove back the foremost of the horsemen (O, K, TA) to, or upon, the hindmost of them. (TA.) Accord. to El-Mufaddal, taToriyfN, signifies a man's repelling another man from the hindmost of his companions: (O, TA: *) one says, TarRifo EanRaA hecaA AlfaArisa [Repel thou from our rear this horseman]. (O, TA.)
For another signification [from AlTRarafu] see 4.
[Hence also,] TrRft banaAnahaA She (a woman) tinged, or dyed, the ends (OaToraAf, O, Msb, TA) of her fingers with HinRaMC. (O, Msb, K, * TA.)

And taToriyfo AlOucuni The making the ear of a horse to be pointed, tapering, or slender at the extremity. (TA.) [Hence,] Khálid Ibn-Safwán said, xayoru AlkalaAmi maA TurRifato maEaAniyhi waXurRifato mabaAniyhi (assumed tropical:) [The best of language is that of which the meanings are pointed, and of which the constructions are crowned with embellishments as though they were adorned with Xuraf, pl. of XurofapN, q. v.]. (TA: there mentioned immediately after what here next precedes it.)
And TrRf AlXRaIoCa [from TarafN signifying “ anything chosen or choice ”] means He chose, or made choice of, the thing; as also tTrRfhu↓. (TA. [See also 10.])
TrRf said of a camel means He lost his tooth [or teeth] (O, K, TA) by reason of extreme age. (TA.)
4. ATrf He (a man, K) closed his eyelids. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K. [See also 1, first sentence.])

ATrf AlvRawoba, inf. n. UiToraAfN, He made two ornamental or coloured or figured borders (Ealamayoni) in the ends, or sides, of the garment (fiI Tarafayohi); as also TrRfhu↓, inf. n. taToriyfN. (Msb: and in like manner the pass. of the former verb is expl. in the S and O, as said of a ridaMC of xazR.)

ATrf fulaAnFA He gave to such a one what he had not given to any one before him: (L, K, * TA:) or he gave him a thing of which he did not possess the like, and which pleased him: (TA:) [and he gave him property newly, or recently, acquired.] You say, OaTorafahu kacaA and bikacaA, meaning OatoHafahu [He gave him such a thing as a tuHofap, i. e. Turofap, q. v.]. (Har p. 54.)

[Hence,] ATrf fulaAnN signifies jaMCa biTurofapK, (S, and Har p. 54,) as meaning Such a one brought something newly found, or gained, or acquired: (Har p. 54:) and as meaning he brought a thing that was strange, or extraordinary, and approved, or deemed good: (Id. p. 615:) and as meaning he brought new information or tidings. (Id. p. 32.) And one says, ATrfhu xabarFA [and bixabarK (see Har p. 529)] meaning He told him new information or tidings. (Az, TA.)

OaTorafa bihi mano HawaAlayohi [a phrase used by El-Hareeree] means They who were around him became possessors, thereby, of a new and strange piece of information, (SaAruwA bisababihi cawiI TurofapK,) and said, maA OaTorafahu [How novel and strange is it!], by reason of their wonder at it; so that the verb is intrans., and mn is its agent: or it may mean he made to wonder by reason of it those who were around him. (Har p. 474.)
AlUiToraAfu signifies also kavorapu AlMbaMCi [i. e., app., The being numerous, as said of ancestors, meaning ancestors of note]. (TA.)
ATrf Albaladu, (S, O, K, TA,) and ATrft AlOaroDu, (TA,) The country, and the land, abounded with [the kinds of pasture called] Tariyfap [q. v.]. (S, O, K, TA.)
5. tTrRf [as quasi-pass. of 2 signifies It became pointed, tapering, or slender at the extremity: see cubaAbu AlsRayofi in art. cb].
[And] i. q. SaAra TarafFA [It became an extremity, or a side; or at, or in, an extremity or a side]. (TA.)
kaAna laA yataTarRafu mina Albawoli, in a trad. respecting the punishment of the grave, means He used. not to go far aside from urine. (L, TA. *)
tTrRft said of a she-camel: see 1, near the end.
Said of the sun, It became near to setting. (TA.)
tTrRf EalaI Alqawomi He made a sudden, or an unexpected, attack upon the territory, or dwellings, of the people. (TA.)
tTrRf AlXRaIoCa He took from the side of the thing: [and] he took the side of it. (MA.)
See also 2, last signification but one.
8. AiTRarafotu AlXRaIoCa, of the measure AifotaEalotu, I purchased the thing new. (S, O, K. [See also 10.]

10. AstTrfhu He counted, accounted, reckoned, or esteemed, it new; (PS;) or Tariyf [as meaning newly, or recently, acquired]. (S, O, K.) One says of good discourse, yasotaTorifuhu mano samiEahu [He who has heard it esteems it new]. (K.)
And AstTrf AlXRaIoCa He found, gained, or acquired, the thing newly. (S, O, K. [See also 8.])

You say of a woman who does not keep constantly to a husband, tasotaTorifu AlrRijaAla (assumed tropical:) [She takes, or chooses, new ones of the men]: she who does thus being likened to the she-camel termed TarifapN, that depastures the extremities, or sides, of the pasturage, and tastes, and does not keep constantly
to one pasturage. (Har p. 569.) See also 1, last quarter.
And one says of camels, AstTrnt AlmarotaEa They chose, or selected, the pasturage: or they took the first thereof. (TA. [See also 2, last signification but one.])

TarofN The eye; a word having no pl. in this sense because it is originally an inf. n., (S, O, K,) therefore it may denote a sing. and may also denote a pl. number [i. e. may signify also eyes]: (S, O, Msb:) or, (K,) as Ibn-'Abbád says, (O,) it is a coll. n. signifying the baSar [which has the sing. and the pl. meanings mentioned above, as well as the meaning of the sense of sight], and is not dualized nor pluralized: or, as some say, it has for pl. OaToraAfN: (O, K:) but this is refuted by the occurrence of Tarof in a pl. sense in the Kur xxxvii. 47 and xxxviii. 52 and lv. 56: (O:) and though AlOaToraAf is said to occur as its pl. in a trad. of Umm-Selemeh, this is a mistake for AlUiToraAq: (Z, O:) it is said, however, that its being originally an inf. n. is not a reason for its not being allowable to pluralize it when it has become a subst., and especially when it is not meant to convey the signification of an epithet: (MF:) [but it may be regarded as an epithet; meaning seer, and, being originally an inf. n., seers also; and this is the more probable because] AlTRawaArifu↓ [is an epithet used as a subst., and thus] signifies the eyes, (S, O, K,) as in the saying huwa bimakaAnK laA taraAhu AlTRawaArifu [He is in a place in which the eyes will not see him]; (S, * O, * TA;) pl. of TaArifapN↓. (TA.)

[Hence,] AlTRarofu is the name of (assumed tropical:) Two stars, which precede Aljabohapu, (S, O, K,) so called because (K) they are [regarded as] the two eyes of Leo; one of the Mansions of the Moon: (S, O, K:) [often called AlTRarofapu, q. v.:] the Tarof of Leo, consisting of two small stars in front of Aljabohap, like the faroqadaAni, but inferior to them in light, and having somewhat of obliquity; the Ninth Mansion of the Moon: (Kzw in his descr. of that Mansion:) or the star [app. lambda] in the face of Leo, together with that which is outside [app. alpha] on the figure of Cancer: (Kzw in his descr. of Leo:) or the bright star [alpha] on the hinder, southern, leg, or foot, [i. e. claw,] of Cancer. (Kzw in his descr. of Cancer.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.]
And Tarofu AlEayoni signifies The eyelid. (TA.)
Also TarofN, A man generous, or noble, (K, TA, [see also TirofN,]) in respect of ancestry, up to the greatest [i. e. most remote] forefather. (TA.)
See also TarafN, first sentence.
TurofN: see TariyfN, with which it is syn., and of which it is also a pl.

TirofN A generous horse: (As, S, O, K:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, one that is looked at (yuTorafu) because of his beauty; so that it is originally maToruwfN, i. e. manoZuwrN; like niqoDN in the sense of manoquwDN: (TA:) pl. TuruwfN (As, S, O, K) and OaToraAfN: (O, K:) accord. to AZ, an epithet applied peculiarly to the males: (S, O, K: *) or generous in respect of the sires and the dams: (Lth, O, K:) or recently acquired; not of his owner's breeding; fem. with p, (O, K,) occurring in a verse of El-'Ajjáj: Lth says that they sometimes apply the epithets TirofN and TirofapN as syn. with najiybN and najiybapN, in a manner unusual in the language: (O:) accord. to Ks, TirofapN is applied as an epithet to a mare: (TA:) and TirofN signifies also a horse long in the legs or the neck, having the ears pointed, tapering, or slender at the extremities. (TA in the supplement to this art.)

And (tropical:) Generous (S, O, TA) as an epithet applied to a young man (S, TA) or to a man; (O, TA;) as also TarafN↓: (O, K:) or a man generous in respect of his male and his female ancestors: (K, * TA:) pl. OaToraAfN: (O, K:) when applied to other than man, its pl. [or rather one of its pls.] is TuruwfN. (K.)
See also TarafN, latter half.
And rajulN TirofN fiI nasabihi, (K, TA,) with kesr, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, TarofN,] (assumed tropical:) A man whose nobility is recent: as though a contraction of TarifN↓. (K, TA.)
And AimoraOapN Tirofu AlHadiyvi, (K, TA,) with kesr, (TA,) [in the CK Tarof,] A woman whose discourse is good; every one who has heard it esteeming it new (yasotaTorifuhu). (K, * TA.)
And One desirous of possessing everything that he sees. (K.)
See also TarifN, in two places.
And see TariyfN.
Also Anything of the produce of the earth still in the calyxes thereof. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, *)

TarafN The extremity, or end, of anything; [as of a sword, and of a spear, and of a rope, and of the tongue, &c.;] thus accord. to ISd; but in the K this meaning is assigned to TarofN↓: (TA: [several evidences of the correctness of the former word in this sense will be found in the present art.; and countless instances of it occur in other arts. &c.: it seems to have been generally regarded by the lexicographers as too notorious to need its being mentioned:]) and a side; a lateral, or an outward, or adjacent, part or portion; a region, district, quarter, or tract; syn. naAHiyapN: (S, O, Msb, K:) and a part, portion, piece, or bit, (syn. TaAYifapN,) of a thing: (S, O, K:) it is used in relation to bodies, or material things, and to times &c.; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and is thus used in the sense of TaAYifap of a people, in the Kur iii. 122; (Ksh;) [and may often be rendered somewhat of a thing, whether material (as land &c.) or not material (as in the T and S voce carowN, where it is used of a saying, and as in the S and A and K in art. hws &c., where it is used of madness, or insanity, or diabolical possession):] the pl. is OaToraAfN. (O, Msb, K.)

[Hence,] AlOaToraAfu signifies The fingers: and [when relating to the fingers] has no sing. unless this is used as a prefixed noun, as in the saying OaXaArato biTarafi UiSobaEihaA [She made a sign with the end of her finger]: but the pl. is said by Az to be used in the sense of the sing. in the following ex. cited by Fr,

[so that the meaning is, They show an elegant finger like a fruit of the species of tree called Eanam]; therefore the poet says Eamanah [which is a n. un.: but I think that it is much more reasonable, and especially as the verb is pl., to regard the h in this case as the h of pausation, of which see an ex. voce HiynN; and accordingly to render the saying, they show elegant fingers like fruits of the Eanam]. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Abraham, when he was a little child, juEila rizoquhu fiI OaToraAfihi [His sustenance was made to be in his fingers]; meaning that he used to suck his fingers and find in them that which nourished him. (TA.)

And [hence] OaToraAfu AlEacaAraI (tropical:) A species of grapes, (A, K, TA,) white and slender, found at Et-Táïf: (A, TA:) or, as in the L, black and long, resembling acorns, likened to the fingers of virgins, that are dyed [with HinRaMC], because of their length; and the bunch of which is about a cubit long. (TA.)

cuw AlTRarafayoni is an appellation of A sort of serpent, (K,) a sort of black serpent, (TA,) or the [serpent called] Oasowad, (O,) having two stings, one in its nose and the other in its tail, with both of which, (O, K, TA,) so it is said, (O, TA,) it smites, and it suffers not him whom it smites to linger, killing at once. (O, K, TA.)
TarafaA AldRaAbRapi sometimes means The fore part and the hinder part of the beast. (TA.)

And OaToraAfu Aljasadi (O) or Albadani (K) means [The extremities of the body; i. e.] the arms or hands, and the legs or feet, and the head: (O, K:) or, as in the L, OaToraAfN is pl. of TarafN as syn. with XawaApN [n. un. of XawFI, q. v.]. (TA.)

[And the dual has various other meanings assigned to it, derived from the first of the significations mentioned in this paragraph.] It is said in a trad. (O, K) of the Prophet, (O,) kaAna UicaA QXotakaI OaHadN mino Oaholihi lamo tazali Alburomapu EalaI AlnRaAri HatRaI yaOotiIa EalaI OaHadi Tarafayohi [It was the case that when any one of his family had a complaint, the cooking-pot did not cease to be on the fire but he arrived at one of his two limits]; meaning (assumed tropical:) convalescence or death; because these are the two terminations of the case of the diseased. (O, K.)
And one says, laA yamoliku Tarafayohi (assumed tropical:) He will not have control over his mouth and his anus: referring to him who has drunk medicine or become intoxicated. (AO, ISk, S, O, K.)
And fulaAnN faAsidu AlTRarafiyoni (assumed tropical:) Such a one is corrupt in respect of the tongue and the faroj. (TA.)

And laA yadoriI OaIRu Tarafayohi OaTowalu, (in the CK yudoraI,) [He will not, or does not, know which of his two extremities is the longer,] meaning (tropical:) his cakar and his tongue; (S, O, K, TA;) whence TarafN is used as signifying (assumed tropical:) the tongue: (TA:) or the meaning is, as some say, (assumed tropical:) which of his two halves is the longer; the lower or the upper: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the lineage of his father or that of his mother (O, K, TA) in respect of generosity, or nobility: (O, TA:) i. e., which of his two parents is the more generous, or noble: so says Fr. (TA.)

kariymu AlTRarafayoni means
(tropical:) Generous, or noble, [on both sides, i. e.] in respect of male and female ancestors. (S, O, TA.)
And OaToraAfN means also (assumed tropical:) A man's father and mother and brothers and paternal uncles and any relations whom it is unlawful for him to marry. (AZ, S, O, K.)

And (assumed tropical:) Noble, or exalted, men: (Th, S:) or OaToraAfu AlOaroDi means (tropical:) the noble, or exalted, men, and the learned men, of the earth, or land: (O, K, TA:) one of whom is termed TarafN, or TirofN↓. (O, See the latter of these words.) And hence, as some explain it, the saying in the Kur [xiii. 41, like one in xxi. 45], Oawalamo yarawoA OanRaA naOotiI QloOaroDa nanoquSuhaA mino OaToraAfihaA (assumed tropical:) [Have they not seen that we visit, or bring destruction upon, the land, curtailing it of its learned men?]; the meaning being, the death of its learned men: (O, TA:) or, as some say, [curtailing it of its inhabitants and its fruits; for they say that] the meaning is, the death of its inhabitants and the diminution of its fruits: (TA:) or it means, curtailing it of its sides, or districts, one by one: (Az, O, L:) Ibn-'Arafeh says that the meaning is, we lay open by conquest, to the Prophet, (nafotaHu EalaI AlnRabiIRi,) the country around Mekkeh. (O, TA.) [
OaToraAfu AlnRaAsi also means (assumed tropical:) The lower orders of the people: but this I believe to be post-classical.]

TarafaIi AlnRahaAri, in the Kur xi. 116, means gudowapF waEaXiyRapF [i. e. Morning and afternoon]; by the former being meant daybreak; and by the latter, noon and the EaSor [q. v.], (Ksh, Bd,) or the EaSor [only]. (Bd.) And OaToraAfa AlnRahaAri, in the Kur xx. 130, means At daybreak and at sunset: (Ksh, Bd:) or at noon and at the EaSor; so says Zj: or, accord. to IAar, in the hours (saAEaAt) of the day: Abu-l-'Abbás says that it means TarafaIi AlnRahaAri. (TA.)
[EalaI TarafK often occurs as meaning Beside, aside, or apart; like ElI jaAnibK, and ElI naAHiyapK: and in like manner the Persians say baro Tarafo.
And mino Tarafi fulaAnK is often used as meaning On the part of such a one; but is perhaps post-classical.]

And you say, liloOamori TarafaAni [meaning (assumed tropical:) There are two ways of performing the affair, either of which may be chosen; as though it had two ends, or two sides]. (TA voce SaroEN.) And jaEalahu muTolaqa AlTRarafayoni (assumed tropical:) [He made it allowable, or free, in respect of both the alternatives, either way one might choose to take]. (Msb in art. bwH.)

[And hence, perhaps,] TarafN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Anything chosen or choice: pl. OaToraAfN: [whence] OaToraAfu AlHadiyvi means (assumed tropical:) Chosen, or choice, subjects of discourse; as also AlHadiyvi TaraAYifu↓: and OaToraAfu AlOaHaAdiyvi means [the same, or] colloquies of friends, consisting of mutual communications, and oblique expressions, and allusions: so says ISd: and this is likewise a meaning of AlTRiraAfu↓ and AlsRibaAbu, which latter [properly signifying “ mutual reviling ”] is given in the K as an explanation of the former. (TA.)
Also Flesh, or flesh-meat; syn. laHomN. (TA.)

TarifN, in the K Tirof↓, but the former is the right, (TA,) A male camel that removes from one pasturage to another; (K, TA;) not keeping constantly to one pasturage. (TA.) And TarifapN A she-camel that does not keep constantly to one pasturage; (S, O, K;) that depastures the extremities, or sides, of the pasturage, and tastes, and does not keep constantly to one pasturage: (Har p. 569:) or, accord. to As, that looks at the meadows (taTorifu AlrRiyaADa), meadow after meadow [app. to pasture upon them in succession]: (TA:) and musotaTorifapN↓, so applied, signifies the same as TarifapN: (TA, but not as on the authority of As:) and miToraAfN↓, so applied, that will not feed upon a pasturage unless she choose anew, or take the first of, (HatRaI tasotaTorifa,) another. (As, S, O, K.)

And [hence (see 10)] TarifN applied to a man signifies (assumed tropical:) That does not keep constantly to a wife, or woman, nor to a companion: (S, O, K:) and Tirof↓, thus accord. to the K, (TA, [in which it is said that by rule it should be TarifN, as above,]) a man who does not keep constantly to the companionship of one person, by reason of his weariness. (K.) And mutaTarRifapN↓ applied to a woman (assumed tropical:) That chooses new ones of the men (tasotaTorifu AlrRijaAla), not keeping constantly to a husband; as being likened to the she-camel termed TarifapN. (Har p. 569.)

And TarifN, applied to a she-camel, (O, K, [but in some of the copies of the latter, where it follows next after another explanation of the epithet thus applied, mentioned above, “ or, ”]) accord. to IAar, Whose fore part of the head has gradually shed its hair (AlRatiI taHaAtRa muqadRamu AlrRaOosi fiyhaA, O) or whose fore part of her mouth has shed its teeth one after another (AltI taHaAtRa muqadRamu fiyhaA, K) by reason of extreme age. (O, K. [See 2, last sentence.])

Also, and TaryfN↓ (assumed tropical:) Contr. of quEodudN; (S, M, K, TA;) i. e., as the latter is further expl. in the S, and each in the M, having many ancestors, up to the greatest [i. e. most remote] forefather; and J adds that sometimes it is used in praise: thus also As explains AlnRasabi Tariyfu↓: accord. to IAar, TariyfN signifies mnHdr fI AlnRasabi [app. munoHadirN, as though meaning of long descent]; and he says that it is with the Arabs more noble than quEodudN: the pl. of TarifN as meaning the contr. of quEodudN is Tarifuwna; and the pl. of TariyfN↓ in the same sense is TurufN and TurafN and TurRaAfN, the second and third of which pls. are anomalous. (TA.)
[TarifN seems also to have the contr. meaning; or (assumed tropical:) One whose nobility is recent: and the like is said of quEodudN; that it has two contr. meanings:] see TirofN.

TarofapN [A wink, i. e.] a closing of one of the eyelids upon the other: (S, O, K:) or [a twinkling of the eye, i. e.] a putting the eyelids in motion or in a state of commotion. (K.) One says OasoraEu mino Tarofapi EayonK [Quicker than a wink, or a twinkling of an eye]. (S, O.) And maA yufaAriquniI Tarofapa EayonK [He does not separate himself from me during a wink, or a twinkling of an eye]. (TA.)
Also A red spot of blood, in the eye, occasioned by a blow or some other cause. (S, O, K.)
And A brand, or mark made with a hot iron, having to it no OaToraAf [or sides, or lateral portions], being only a line. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

And AlTRarofapu A certain star or asterism (najomN). (K. [There thus mentioned as though different from the asterism commonly called AlTRarofu, which I do not believe to be the case: see the latter appellation.])
TurofapN A hurt of the eye, occasioning its shedding tears. (K.)

And Newly-acquired property; (S, O, K;) anything that one has newly acquired, and that pleases him; as also OuToruwfapN↓; (TA;) a thing newly acquired; (Har p. 54;) and a thing that is strange and deemed good; (Id. p. 615;) [a pleasing rarity;] a welcome, or pleasing, thing; (KL;) and a gift not given to any one before; (K, * TA;) and a gift of which the recipient did not possess the like, and which pleases him; (TA;) [generally, a novel, or rare, and pleasing, present; like turofapN and tuHofapN:] pl. TurafN. (Har p. 32.) [See also TariyfN and TariyfapN.]
TarafapN A single tree of the species called TarofaMC, q. v. (AHn, S, O, K.)
TurofaI Remoteness in lineage from the [chief, or oldest,] ancestor: quEodaI is nearer therein. (IB, TA.) [See TarifN.]

TarofaMC [accord. to some TarofaMCN and accord. to others TarofaMCu, as will be seen from what follows,] A kind of trees, (S, O, K,) of which there are four species, one of these being the Oavol [q. v.]: (K:) [or it is different from the Oavol: the name is now generally applied to the common, or French, tamarisk; tamarix gallica of Linn.: (Forskål's Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. lxiv. no. 181; and Delile's Floræ Aegypt. Illustr. no. 349:)] AHn says, it is of the kind called EiDaAh; its hadab [q. v.] are like those of the Oavol; it has no wood fit for carpentry, coming forth only as even and smooth rods towards the sky; and sometimes the camels eat it as HamoD [q. v.] when they find no other HamoD: AA, he adds, says that it is a sort of HamoD: (TA:) the n. un. is TarafapN↓, (AHn, S, O, K,) [which is irreg.,] and TarofaMCapN, (AHn, O, K, [in the CK, erroneously, TarofaApN,]) [and this requires TarofaMC to be with tenween, as a coll. gen. n.,] or, accord. to Sb, TarofaMC is sing. and pl.: (S, O:) or it is a pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] of TarafapN, like as XajoraMCu is of XajarapN: (S in art. Xjr: [see XajarN:]) or it is coll. gen. n.: accord. to IJ, the C in TarofaMC is a denotative of the fem. gender; but in TarofaMCapN, the p is a denotative of the fem. gender, and the C is augmentative. (M, TA.)
Also A place of growth of the Tarafap. (TA.)
TiraAfN The portion that is taken [app. meaning cut] from the extremities (OaToraAf) of corn, or seed-produce. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

tawaAravuwA
Almajoda TirafFA means Eano XarafK [i. e. They inherited, one after another, glory from nobility of ancestry]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
See also TariyfN.
And see TarafN, last sentence but one.
Also A tent of skin, or leather, (S, K, TA,) without a kifaMC [q. v., for it is variously explained]; of the tents of the Arabs of the desert. (TA.)
TariyfN: see maToruwfN.

Also, (S, O, Msb, K,) and TaArifN↓, (S, O, K,) and TiraAfN↓, (K,) [of which last it seems to be said in the supplement to this art. in the TA, that it may be either a pl. or a syn. of TariyfN,] Property newly acquired; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also TirofN↓ and TurofN↓ and muTorifN↓ (K) and musotaTorafN↓; (TA;) [and it is said in one place in the TA that miTorafN↓ and maTorafN↓ are dial. vars. of muTorifN; but I think that this last word is probably a mistake for muTorafN↓;] contr. of taliydN (S, O, Msb) and taAlidN (S, O) [and tilaAdN]: pl. of the first and third TurofN. (K.)

Also, the first, A thing that is good [and recent or new or fresh]: (Msb:) what is strange, (IAar, K, TA,) [or rare,] and coloured, or of various colours, (IAar, TA,) [or pleasing to the eye,] of fruits and other things, (IAar, K, TA,) mimRaA ystTrf bihi [in which ystTrf is evidently a mistranscription for yuTorafu, i. e., of such things as are given as Turaf (pl. of Turofap) meaning rare and pleasing gifts]. (TA, from IAar.)
See also TarifN, latter part, in three places.

TariyfapN The plant called naSiIR when it has become white (S, O, K, TA) and dry: (TA:) or when it has attained its full perfection; (ISk, S, O, K, TA;) and the plant called SilRiyaAn in this same state: (ISk, S, O, TA:) or the first of any herbage that the cattle choose and depasture: (TA:) or the best of pasturage, except such as is termed EuXob; including the sorts termed naSiIR and SilRiyaAn and Eanokav and halotaI and saHam and vagaAm. (O, TA.)

[As a subst. from TariyfN, rendered such by the affix p, it signifies Anything new, recent, or fresh: and anything choice: pl. TaraAYifu. (See also TurofapN.) Hence, TaraAYifu Albayoti The choice articles, such as vessels &c., of the house: see rafRN. And hence also,] TaraAYifu AlHadiyvi: see TarafN, last sentence but one.
TaArifN: see TariyfN.
TaArifapN [a subst. from TaArifN, rendered such by the affix p]: pl. TawaArifN: see TarofN, in two places.

[Also, app., A thing that causes a twinkling, or winking, of the eye. Whence, app.,] one says, jaMCa biTaArifapi EayonK, meaning (tropical:) He (a man, S, O) brought much property, or many cattle. (S, O, K, TA.)

The phrase maA Oaborazatohu TawaArifu AlqaraAYiHi, in which TawaArifu is pl. of TaArifapN, from TaArifN signifying property “ newly acquired, ” means maA OaHodavatohu AlqaraAYiHu AlmutaOaxRirapu [i. e. What the modern excogitative faculties have originated]. (Har p. 63.)

TawaArifu AlxibaMCi means The portions of the sides of the tent that are raised for the purpose of one's looking out: (S, O, K:) or, as some say, rings attached to the skirts (rufuwf) of the tent, having ropes by which they are tied to the tentpegs. (TA.)
And sibaAEN TawaArifu means Beasts of prey that seize, or carry off by force, the animals that are the objects of the chase. (O, K.)
huwa OaTorafuhumo He is the most remote of them from the greatest [or earliest] ancestor. (Lh, TA.)
OuToruwfapN: see TurofapN.
AixotaDabato taTaAriyfa She (a woman) dyed [with HnRaMC] the ends of her fingers. (O, K.)
maTorafN: see miTorafN:
and see also TariyfN.
muTorafN: see miTorafN: and muTorifN: and see also TariyfN.
muTorifN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.].

OanoXidi Albayotayoni AlmuTorifayoni, a phrase used by El-Hareeree, means Recite thou the two verses that adduce what is strange, or extraordinary, and approved, or deemed good: or, as some relate it, AlmuTorafayoni↓, expl. by Mtr as meaning that are ornamented at their two extremities; like the ridaMC called muToraf: or AlmuTarRafayoni↓, meaning, if correctly related, that are beautified, and excite admiration, in the first and last foot; as being likened to the horse termed muTarRafN, that is white in the head and the tail: and AlmTrRfyn [i. e. AlmuTarRafayoni] may mean AlmstTrfyn [i. e. AlmusotaTorafayoni]. (Har p. 615: in the next p. of which, an ex. is given.)
See also TariyfN.

miTorafN (S, O, L, Msb, TA) and muTorafN↓, (S, O, L, Msb, K, TA,) the latter, only, mentioned in the K, (TA,) and this is the original form, because it is from OaTorifa, but the dammeh was deemed difficult of pronunciation, and therefore kesreh was substituted for it, (Fr, S, O, TA,) like as is the case in miSoHafN [q. v.], (Fr, TA,) and IAth mentions also maTorafN↓, (TA,) A garment, (Msb,) or [such as is termed] ridaMC, (S, O, K,) of [the kind of cloth called] xazR, (S, O, Msb, K,) square, or four-sided, (S, O, K,) having ornamental or coloured or figured, borders (OaEolaAm): (S, O, Msb, K:) or a garment having, in its two ends, or sides, (fiI Tarafayohi,) two such borders (EalamaAni): (Fr, TA:) or a square, or four-sided, garment of xazR: (Msb:) pl. maTaArifu. (S, O, Msb, K.)
maTaArifu is also applied to (assumed tropical:) Clouds [as being likened to the garments thus called]. (TA in art. dkn.)
See also TariyfN.

muTarRafN A horse white in the head and the tail, the rest of him being of a different colour: and in like manner black in the head and the tail. (S, O, K.) And, accord. to AO, Oabolaqu muTarRafN A horse white in the head: and likewise white in the tail and the head. (TA.) And XaApN muTarRafapN A sheep or goat black in the end of the tail, in other parts white: (S, O, K:) or white in the ends of the ears, and for the rest part black: or black in the ends of the ears, and for the rest part white. (TA.)
See also muTorifN. And see sajoEN.

In a verse of Sá'ideh the Hudhalee, as some relate it, but accord. to others it is muTarRif [q. v.], (O, TA,) describing a horse, (O,) it signifies muradRadN fiI Alkarami [app. meaning Repeatedly improved in generosity by descent from a number of generous sires and dams]. (O, TA.)
See also musotaTurafN.

muTarRifN A man who fights around the army: (O, K, TA: [see 2, second sentence:]) or, as some say, who fights the OaToraAf [app. meaning noble, or exalted, pl. of TarafN q. v., or of TirofN,] of men. (TA.)

In a verse of Sá'ideh the Hudhalee, (O, TA,) describing a horse, (O,) that repels those that form the side, or flank, of the horses and of the [hostile] company of men: but as some relate it, the word is muTarRaf [q. v.]. (O, TA.)
miToraAfN: see TarifN, former half.
maToruwfN [pass. part. n. of Tarafa, q. v.]. You say, fulaAnN maToruwfu AlEayoni bifulaAnK, meaning Such a one is, exclusively of others, looked at by such a one. (S, O.)

And EayonN maToruwfapN An eye of which the lids are put in motion or in a state of commotion, by looking. (As, TA.) [And] An eye, hit, struck, smitten, or hurt, with a thing, so that it sheds tears. (S, O, K.) And TariyfN↓ applied to an eye signifies the same as maToruwfapN [in one of these senses, but in which of them is not said]. (TA.)

maToruwfapN applied to a woman means As though her eye were hit, struck, smitten, or hurt, with something, (O, and EM p. 83,) so that it shed tears, (O,) by reason of the languish of her look; (EM ibid;) and this is said to be its meaning in the saying of Tarafeh,

L.foreign: UicaA naHonu qulonaA OasomiEiynaA Qnobarato lanaA

sense.s:
(O, EM,) i. e. When we say, “ Sing thou to us, ” she betakes herself to us in her gentle way, as though her eye were hurt by something, by reason of the languish of her look, not straining herself in her singing; but as some relate the verse, the word is maToruwqapF, meaning “ weakly: ” (EM:) or it means whose eye the love of men has smitten, so that she raises her eyes and looks at every one that looks at her; as though a Tarofap [or red spot of blood], or a stick or the like, hurt her eye: (Az, TA:) or having a languishing eye; as though it were turned away, or back, (TurifatN,) from everything at which it looked: (IAar, TA:) or as though her eye were turned away, or back so that it, or she, is still: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) who looks at the men (taTorifu AlrRijaAla); i. e. (assumed tropical:) who does not keep constantly to one; the pass. part. n. being put in the place of the act.; but Az says that this explanation is at variance with the original purport of the word: (TA:) or maToruwfapN biAlrRijaAl means (tropical:) a woman who raises, or stretches and raises, her
eye at men, (S, O, K, TA,) and turns away her look from her husband, to others, (S, TA, *) and in whom is no good: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) who looks not at any but the men; (K;) or maToruwfapu AlEayoni biAlrRijaAli has this meaning. (AA, TA.)
OaroDN maToruwfapN Land abounding with the herbage called Tariyfap. (S, O, K.)
muTRarafN A camel newly purchased: (S:) or purchased from another part of the country, and therefore yearning for his accustomed place. (IB, TA.)

mutaTarRifN A man who does not, or will not, keep constantly to an affair; [but I think that Amr (which I have rendered “ an affair ”) in my original is evidently a mistranscription for QmoraOap, i. e. a woman, or wife;] as also musotaTorifN↓. (TA.) See also TarifN.
musotaTorafN: see TariyfN.
faEalotuhu fiI musotaTorafi AlOayRaAmi I did it in the first, or first part, of the days; (fI musotaOonafihaA;) as also AlAyRAm fI muTarRafi↓. (S, O, K.)
musotaTorifN: see mutaTarRifN. See also TarifN.

1. TaroqN signifies The beating [a thing], or striking [it, in any manner, and with anything]; (K, TA;) this being the primary meaning: (TA:) or with the miToraqap, (K, TA,) which is the implement of the blacksmith and of the artificer [with which he beats the iron], and the rod, or stick, with which one beats wool [or hair] to loosen or separate it: (TA:) and the slapping (K, TA) with the hand. (TA.) You say, Taraqa AlbaAba, aor.
Taruqa
, inf. n. TaroqN, He knocked [or (as we say) knocked at] the door. (Msb.) Taraqa AlSRuwfa, (S, O, TA, *) or AlXRaEara, (TA,) aor. as above, (S, O,) and so the inf. n., (S, O, K,) He beat the wool, (S, O, K, TA,) or the hair, (TA,) with the rod, or stick, called miToraqap, (S, O,) to loosen it, or separate it: (S, * O, * TA:) or he plucked it [so as to loosen it, or separate it]. (K, TA.) AuToruqiI wamiyXiI, a prov., and occurring in a verse of Ru-beh, [originally addressed to a woman,] and [lit.] meaning Beat thou the wool with the stick, and mix the hair with the wool, is said to him who confuses or confounds, in his speech, and practises various modes, or manners, therein. (Az, TA. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 28.]) And you say also, Taraqa AlHadiydapa He beat the piece of iron [with the miToraqap]: (Mgh, * Msb:) and TrRqhA↓ he beat it much, or vehemently. (Msb.) And Taraqahu bikafRihi, inf. n. as above, He slapped him with his hand. (TA.) And Taraqotu AlTRariyqa I travelled [or beat] the road. (Msb.) [And hence, app.,] TaroqN signifies also The being quick of pace; [probably as an inf. n.;] or quickness of going along. (Sh, TA.) And Turiqati AlOaroDu The ground was beaten so as to be rendered even, or easy to be travelled; and trodden with the feet. (TA.) And Taraqa AldRawaAbRu AlmaMCa biAlrRijoli HatRaI tukadRirahu [The beasts beat the water with the foot so as to render it turbid, or muddy]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or Taraqati AlUibilu AlmaMCa, (S, O, TA,) aor. as above, (O,) (tropical:) the camels staled and dunged in the water. (S, O, TA.)

Also (assumed tropical:) The coming by night; (K, TA;) because he who comes by night [generally] needs to knock at the door; as some say; (TA;) and so TuruwqN [which is the more common in this sense]. (K, TA.) You say, Taraqa, aor.
Taruqa
, inf. n. TuruwqN, He came by night. (S.) OataAnaA fulaAnN TuruwqFA (assumed tropical:) Such a one came to us by night. (S.) And Taraqa Alqawoma, aor.
Taruqa
, inf. n. TaroqN and TuruwqN, (assumed tropical:) He came to the people, or party, by night. (TA.) And Taraqa Oaholahu, (TA,) or Taraqa Oaholahu layolFA, (S, O,) inf. n. TuruwqN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He came to his Ahl [meaning wife] by night: (S, * O, TA:) the doing of which by him who has been long absent is forbidden by the Prophet. (O, TA. *) And Taraqa AlnRajomu, aor.
Taruqa
, inf. n. TuruwqN, (assumed tropical:) The star, or asterism, rose: and of anything that has come by night, one says Taraqa. (Msb.) One says also, Turiqa fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) Such a one was made an object of [or was visited by or was smitten by] nocturnal accidents or calamities. (TA.) And Taraqahu AlzRamaAnu binawaAYibihi (assumed tropical:) [Time, or fortune, visited him, or smote him, with its accidents, or calamities; or did so suddenly, like one knocking at the door in the night]. (TA.) And TaraqaniI xayaAlN (assumed tropical:) [An apparition, or a phantom, visited me in the night]. (TA.) And TaraqaniI hamRN (assumed tropical:) [Anxiety came upon me; or did so suddenly, like one coming in the night]. (TA.) And [hence, app.,] Taraqa samoEiI kacaA (assumed tropical:) [Such a thing struck my ear]: and Turiqato masaAmiEiI bixayorK (assumed tropical:) [My ears were struck by good tidings]. (TA.)

Also The stallion's covering the she-camel; (Msb, K; *) and so TuruwqN; (K, TA;) and TiraAqN likewise [app. another inf. n. of Taraqa, as its syn. DiraAbN is of Daraba]: (TA:) or his leaping her, (S, O, TA,) and covering her. (TA.) You say, Taraqa AlqaHolu AlnRaAqapa, (S, O, Msb, TA,) aor.
Taruqa
, (S, O, TA,) inf. n. TaroqN, (Msb,) or TuruwqN, (S) or both, (O, TA,) The stallion covered the she-camel: (Msb:) or leaped the she-camel, (S, O, TA,) and covered her. (TA.)

And [The practising of pessomancy;] i. q. DarobN biAlHaSaI, (S, IAth, O, K,) which is performed by women, (IAth, TA,) or by a diviner; (K;) a certain mode of divination: (S:) or [the practising of geomancy; i. e.] a man's making lines, or marks, upon the ground, with two fingers, and then with one finger, and saying, AibonaIo EiyaAno OasoriEaA AlbayaAno: (AZ, O, TA: [see this saying explained, with another description of the process, in the first paragraph of art. xT:]) or it is the making lines, or marks, upon the sand: (TA:) you say, Taraqa, aor.
Taruqa
, inf. n. TaroqN, He made lines, or marks, with a finger, (&c.,) in divining. (JK.) [See the last sentence in art. jbt.] Also The diviner's mixing cotton with wool when divining. (Lth, K.)

And TaraqonaA AlnRaEojapa, aor.
Taruqa
, inf. n. TaroqN, We branded the ewe with the mark called TiraAq. (ISh, O.)
Turiqa, (K, TA,) like EuniIa, (TA,) [inf. n., app., TaroqN, q. v.,] (tropical:) He was, or became, weak in intellect, (K, TA,) and soft. (TA.)

Tariqa, aor.
Taraqa
, (K,) inf. n. TaraqN, (Fr, S, O, K,) He (a camel) had a weakness in his knees: (Fr, S, O, K: [see HalalN:]) or, said of a human being and of a camel, he had a weakness in the knee and in the arm or the fore leg: (TA:) or, said of a camel, he had a crookedness in the saAq (Lth, * O, * K) of the kind leg, [app. meaning in the thigh,] without the [kind of straddling termed] faHaj, and with an inclining in the heel. (Lth, O.)
[See also TaraqN below.]

Tariqa signifies also He drank turbid, or muddy, water, (O, K, TA,) such as is termed [TaroqN and] maToruwqN. (TA. [In the K it is said to be, in this sense, like samiEa; which seems to indicate that the inf. n. is TaroqN, not TaraqN.])
2. TrRq AlHadiydapa: see 1, former half.

TrRq TariyqFA He made a road plane, or even, so that people travelled it [or beat it with their feet] in their passing along. (TA.) The saying laA tuTarRiquwA AlmasaAjida means Make not ye the mosques to be roads [or places of passage]. (TA.) TarRaqotu lahu is from AlTRariyqu: (S, O:) you say, TrRq lahaA [app. referring to camels] He made for them a road, or way: (K:) or TrRq lahu he gave a way to, or admitted, him, or it. (MA.)

TarRaqato said of the [bird called] qaTaAp, peculiarly, (inf. n. taToriyqN, O, K,) She arrived at the time of her egg's coming forth: (As, A'Obeyd, S, O, K:) or she (a qTAp) hollowed out in the ground a place wherein to lay her eggs: as though she made a way for them: so says A Heyth: but the verb may be similarly used of other than the qTAp, metaphorically; whence the saying,

i. e. (tropical:) Calamity [has prepared to bring forth her first-born]. (Az, TA.) [Hence, app.,] one says also, Darabahu HatRaI TarRaqa bijaEorihi [He beat him until he gave passage, or was about to give passage, to his ordure]. (As, S, O.) And TrRq liI, inf. n. taToriyqN, signifies Oaxoraja [app. meaning He gave forth, or produced, to me something]. (TA.)

TarRaqato biwaladihaA, said of a camel, means She brought forth with difficulty, her young one sticking fast, and not coming forth easily; and in like manner it is said of a woman: (As, S, O, K:) so in a verse of Ows Ibn-Hajar, cited voce nifaAsN: (O:) or TrRqt said of a woman and of any pregnant female, means the half of her young one came forth, and then it stuck fast. (Lth, TA.) [Hence,] TrRq fulaAnN biHaqRiI (tropical:) Such a one acknowledged my right, or due, after disacknowledging it. (As, S, O, K, TA.)

Accord. to AZ, (TA,) TrRq AlUibila means He withheld the camels from pasture, (S, O, K, TA,) or from some other thing: (S, O, TA:) Sh, however, says that he knew not this; but that IAar explained TarRafotu, with f, as meaning “ I repelled. ” (TA.)
Oaxaca fulaAnN fiI AltRaToriyqi means (assumed tropical:) Such a one practised artifice and divination. (TA.)

TarRaqotu AltRurosa I sewed the shield upon another skin: and TarRaqotu AlnRaEola, inf. n. taToriyqN, I made the sole of two pieces of skin, sewing one of them upon the other. (Msb. [See also the next paragraph.])

3. TaAraqotu AlnRaEola [meaning I sewed another sole upon the sole] is an instance of a verb of the measure faAEala relating to the act of a single agent. (AAF, TA in art. xdE.) [See also 2, last sentence.] You say also, TArq AlrRajulu naEolayohi, [inf. n. muTaAraqapN,] The man put one of his two soles upon the other and sewed them together. (As, TA.) And TArq bayona naEolayoni He sewed one sole upon another. (S, O, K.) And TArq byn AlvRawobayoni, (S,) or bayona vawobayoni, (O, K,) and byn AldRiroEayoni, (TA,) i. q. TaAbaqa, (K,) or ZaAhara, i. e. He put on himself one of the two garments, or one of two garments, [and one of the two coats of mail,] over the other. (S, O.) Tuwriqa is said of anything as meaning It was put one part thereof upon, or above, another; and so AiTRaraqa↓; (TA;) [and in like manner OuToriqa↓; for] one says of shields, yuToraqu baEoDuhaA EalaI baEoDK One of them is sewed upon another: (S, O, K:) and OuToriqato biAljilodi waAlEaSabi They were clad [or covered] with skin and sinews. (S, O.)
TArq AlgamaAmu AlZRalaAma The clouds followed upon the darkness. (TA.)
And TArq AlkalaAma (tropical:) He practised, or took to, various modes, or manners, in speech; syn. tafanRana fiyhi. (TA.)
4. ATrqhu faHolahu He lent him his stallion [camel] to cover his she-camels. (S, O, K.)
laA OaToraqa QllRehu Ealayoka, (O,) or Ealayohi, (K, TA,) means (tropical:) May God not cause thee, or him, to have one whom thou mayest, or whom he may, take to wife, or compress. (O, K, TA.)
See also 3, latter part.

ATrq raOosahu He inclined his head [downwards]. (TA.) And OaToriqo baSaraka Lower thine eyes towards thy breast, and be silent: occurring in a trad. respecting the looking unexpectedly [at one at whom one should not look]. (TA.) And OaToraqa, alone, He bent down his head: (MA:) or he lowered his eyes, looking towards the ground; (S, O, K;) and sometimes the doing so is natural: (TA: [and the same is indicated in the S:]) and it may mean he had a laxness in the eyelids: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or he contracted his eyelids, as though his eye struck the ground: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and he was, or became, silent, (ISk, S, O, K,) accord. to some, by reason of fright, (TA,) not speaking. (ISk, S, O, K.) It is said in a prov.,

[Lower thine eyes karà: lower thine eyes karà: (krA meaning the male of the karawaAn, a name now given to the stone-curlew, or charadrius ædicnemus:) verily the ostriches are in the towns, or villages]: applied to the self-conceited; (S, O;) and to him who is insufficient, or unprofitable; who speaks and it is said to him, “ Be silent, and beware of the spreading abroad of that which thou utterest, for dislike of what may be its result: ” and by the saying AnR AlnEAm fI AlqrI is meant, they will come to thee and trample thee with their feet: (O:) it is like the saying faguDRi AlTRarofa. (S. [See also karawaAnN: and see also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 30-31.]) It is asserted that when they desire to capture the krA, and see it from afar, they encompass it, and one of them says, OaToriqo karaA UinRaka laA turaI [or lano turaI (Meyd in explanation of the preceding prov.) i. e. Lower thine eyes, or be silent, karà: thou wilt not be seen:] until he becomes within reach of it; when he throws a garment over it, and takes it. ('Eyn, TA.) And OaToriqo karaA yuHolabo laka [Lower thine eyes, or be silent, karà: milk shall be drawn for thee:] is [a prov., mentioned by Meyd,] said to a stupid person whom one incites to hope for that which is vain, or false, and who believes [what is said to him]. (O.)
One says also, ATrq UilaI AllRahowi (tropical:) He inclined to diversion, sport, or play. (IAar, K, TA.)
ATrq AllRayolu Ealayohi: see 8:
and ATrqt AlUibilu: see 6.
ATrq AlSRayoda He set a snare for the beasts, or birds, of the chase. (TA.)

And hence, ATrq fulaAnN lifulaAnK (assumed tropical:) Such a one plotted against such a one by calumny, or slander, in order to throw him into destruction, or into that from which escape would be difficult. (TA.)
5. tTrRq UilaI kacaA He found a way to such a thing: (MA:) or he sought to gain access to such a thing. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

6. taTaAruqN signifies The coming consecutively, or being consecutive. (TA.) You say, tTArqt AlUibilu The camels came following one another, the head of each. [except the first] being at the tail of the next [before it], whether tied together in a file or not: (TA:) or went away, one after another; (S, O, K;) as also AiTRaraqat↓; (O, K, TA;) in the S, incorrectly, OaToraqat↓; (O, K, TA;) in mentioned in the K, in another part of the art., and there expl. as meaning the followed one another; but the verb in this sense is AiTRaraqat↓: (TA:) and, (O, K, TA,) as some say, (O, TA,) this last signifies they scattered, or dispersed, themselves upon the roads, and quitted the main beaten tracks: (O, K, TA:) As cited as an ex., (from Ru-beh, TA,) describing camels, (O,)

meaning They came together, and went away in a state of dispersion. (S, O, TA.) And you say, tTArq AlZRalaAmu waAlgamaAmu The darkness and the clouds were, or became, consecutive. (TA.) And tTArqt EalayonaA AlOaxobaAru [The tidings came to us consecutively]. (TA.)

8. AiTRaraqa: see 3. Said of the wing of a bird, (S, TA,) Its feathers overlay one another: (TA:) or it was, or became, abundant and dense [in its feathers]. (S, TA.) And ATRrqt AlOaroDu The earth became disposed in layers, one above another, being compacted by the rain. (TA.) And ATRrq AlHawoDu The watering-trough, or tank, had in it [a deposit of] compacted dung, or dung and mud or clay, that had fallen into it. (TA.) And ATRrq Ealayohi AllRayolu, as in the O and L; in the K, erroneously, OaToraqa↓; The night came upon him portion upon portion. (TA.) See also 6, in three places.
10. AstTrqhu faHolFA He desired, or demanded, of him a stallion to cover his she-camels; (S, O, K;) like AstDrbhu. (TA.)
And AstTrqhu He desired, or demanded, of him the practising of pessomancy (AlDRaroba biAlHaSaI), and the looking [or divining] for him therein. (K, * TA.)
And He desired, or demanded, of him the [having, or taking, a] road, or way, within some one of his boundaries. (TA.)

mino gayori Oano yasotaToriqa naSiyba AlMxari, a phrase used by El-Kudooree, means Without his taking for himself the portion of the other as a road or way [or place of passage]. (Mgh.) And AlAisotiToraAqu bayona AlSRufuwfi, a phrase used by Khwáhar-Zádeh [commonly pronounced KháharZádeh], means The going [or the taking for oneself a way] between the ranks [of the people engaged in prayer]: from AlTRariyqu. (Mgh.) And AisotaToraqotu UilaI AlbaAbi I went along a road, or way, to the door. (Msb.) [Hence a phrase in the Fákihet el-Khulafà, p. 105, line 15.]
[QsotaToraqato in a verse cited in the K in art. dd is a mistake for AstTrft, with fA: see 10 in art. Trb.]

TaroqN [originally an inf. n., and as such app. signifying An act of striking the lute &c.: and hence,] a species (DarobN) of the OaSowaAt [meaning sounds, or airs, or tunes,] of the lute: (TA:) or any Sawot [i. e. air, or tune], (Lth, O, K, TA,) or any nagomap [i. e. melody], (K, TA,) of the lute and the like, by itself: (Lth, O, K, TA:) you say, taDoribu hecihi AljaAriyapu kacaA wakacaA TaroqFA [This girl, or young woman, or female slave, plays such and such airs or tunes, or such and such melodies, of the lute or the like]. (Lth, O, K. *)
[Hence, probably,] Einodahu TuruwqN mina AlkalaAmi, sing. TaroqN, a phrase mentioned by Kr; thought by ISd to mean He has [various] sorts, or species, of speech. (TA.)
See also TaroqapN, in four places.
Also (tropical:) A stallion [camel] covering: (O, K, TA:) pl. TuruwqN and TurRaAqN: (TA:) an inf. n. used as a subst. [or an epithet]: (O, K, TA:) for cuw TaroqK. (TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) The sperma of the stallion [camel]: (S, K:) a man says to another, OaEironiI Taroqa faHolika AlEaAma i. e. [Lend thou to me] the sperma, and the covering, (As, TA.) which latter is said to be the original meaning, (TA,) of thy stallion [camel this year]. (As, TA.) And it is said to be sometimes applied metaphorically to (assumed tropical:) The sperma of man: or in relation to man, it may be an epithet, [like as it is sometimes in relation to a stallion-camel, as mentioned above,] and not
metaphorical. (TA.) And Taroqu Aljamali means also The hire that is given for the camel's covering of the female. (TA in art. Xbr.)

Also, and maToruwqN↓, (tropical:) Water (S, O, K, TA) of the rain (S, O, TA) in which camels (S, O, K) and others [i. e. other beasts] have staled, (S,) or waded and staled, (S, * O, K, TA,) and dunged: (S, O, TA:) or stagnant water in which beasts have waded and staled: (Mgh:) and TaraqN↓ [expressly stated to be muHarRakap] signifies [the same, or] water that has collected, in which there has been a wading and staling, so that it has become turbid; (TA;) or places where water collects and stagnates (S, O, K, TA) in stony tracts of land; (TA;) and the pl. of this is OaToraAqN. (TA.)
