And TfRf EalaI AlrRajuli (assumed tropical:) He gave to the man less than he had taken from him. (TA.) And TfRf AlUinaMCa He took what was upon [or above] the vessel [i. e. its TufaAf, or TufaAfap]. (TA. [See also 4, last sentence.])
Also He made full, or complete. (TA.) [Thus it has two contr. significations.]

TfRft AlXRamosu (tropical:) The sun drew near to setting: (TA:) [but this may be a mistranscription for TafRat↓, mentioned by Golius in this sense on the authority of Z: or each may be correct: that the latter is correct, and that TafaAfN↓ or TifaAfN↓ is its inf. n., seems to be indicated by the fact that SM adds immediately after the explanation of the former phrase,] OataAnaA Einoda TfAfi AlXRamosi means (tropical:) [He came to us] at the sun's drawing near to setting. (TA.)

TfRf, said of a bird, [or TafRa↓, mentioned by Freytag from Hamaker's Specim. catal. p. 49, 1. 4, of the Arabic text, or both may be correct,] The bird expanded his wings: (O, K:) so says Ibn-'Abbád. (O.)

And TfRf bihi Alfarasu (tropical:) The horse leaped with him. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K. [Golius has omitted this; and has assigned to TfRf, followed by b with the person who is the object, as on the authority of the S and K, the signification of AdnA (properly OadonaI), meaning “ prope admovit, ” a signification belonging to OaTafRa, but not assigned to either of these verbs in the S nor in the K.]) TafRafa biIa Alfarasu masojida baniI zurayoqK, in a saying of Ibn-'Omar respecting a horse-race, means (tropical:) The horse leaped with me (S, O, TA) so that he passed beyond the mosque of the Sons of Zureyk. (O, TA.)
4. xuco maAOaTafRa laka: see 1.
And ATfR lahu He had knowledge of it, i. e. an affair; (Lth, O, K;) and of him, i. e. a person. (O.)
And He desired to deceive him: (O, K:) or he had knowledge of him, and desired to deceive him. (O.)

And ATfR Ealayohi i. q. OaXorafa (O, K) i. e. OaXorafa Ealayohi [meaning He looked upon it, looked upon it from above, looked down upon it, got a view of it, saw it, or got knowledge of it]; namely, a thing; as also OaTalRa Ealayohi. (O.)

And, (AZ, O, K, TA,) as also OaTalRa Ealayohi, (AZ, TA,) He got possession of it, (AZ, O, K, TA,) and took it away, or went away with it; (AZ, O, TA;) namely, the property of another person. (AZ, TA.)
ATfR Ealayohi biHajarK He reached, or hit, him, or it, (tanaAwalahu,) with a stone. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

ATfRt AlnRaAqapu The she-camel cast, (Ibn-
'Abbád, O,) or brought forth, (K,) her young one in an imperfect state. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
ATfRh He put it, or brought it, near: 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd says, [using the verb in this sense,]
[Kaseer put the razor near to his nose]: (Ham p. 436:) or this means Kaseer put the razor near to his nose and cut it off. (TA.)

And i. q. makRanahu. (TA.) [You say, makRanahu mina AlXRaIoCi, and app., in like manner, ATfRhu mina AlXRaIoCi, i. e. He made him to have power over the thing; or to have the thing within his power or reach; and so, perhaps, ATfRhu lilXRaIoCa.]
And ATfR lahu AlsRayofa He held forth the sword towards him, and struck him with it. (TA.)
And ATfR Alkayola He made the contents of the measure to reach to its uppermost parts: (S, K:) or, as some say, he took what was upon [or above] the measure. (TA. [See also TafRafa AlUinaMCa.])
10. AstTfR, said of a camel's hump, It rose, or became high. (TA.)
And AstTfRt HaAjatuhu The thing that he wanted became prepared, and easy of attainment. (TA.) See also 1, in two places.
R. Q. 1. TafoTafa He (a man, TA) became lax [or weak] (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) in the hands of his adversary (Ibn-'Abbád, O) or in the hand of his adversary. (K.)

TafRN The side (O, K) of a thing: (O:) [like dafRN:] and the bank, or shore, (O, K,) of a great river or a sea; (O;) as also TafoTaAfN↓: (O, K:) accord. to Lth, of the Euphrates: (O:) or, as some say, the elevated part of the side of the Euphrates. (TA.) And AlTRafRu is applied to The part of the land of the Arabs that overlooks the cultivated region of El-'Irák: (IDrd, O, K:) said by As to be so called because it is near to the cultivated region: (O:) or it is a place in the district of El-Koofeh. (S, O, K. *)
And The exterior court or yard of a house. (TA.)
See also TafaAf, in two places.
And see TafRaAfN.
TafafN: see TafaAf.
TafafapN: see TufaAfapN.

TafaAfu AlmakRuwki (S, O, Msb, * K) and AlUinaMCi, (K,) and TifaAfuhu↓, (S, Mgh, * O, Msb, K,) and TafRuhu↓, and Tafafahu↓, (S, Mgh, * O, K,) The quantity sufficing for the filling (S, O, Msb, K) of the [measure called] mkRwk (S, O, K) and of the vessel (K) to its uppermost parts: (S, O, Msb, K:) or what remains in it after the wiping off of the head thereof: (M, K: [the measure being generally in the form of a truncated cone, much smaller at the top than at the base, the quantity rising above the top is not much:]) or the jimaAm or jamaAm or jumaAm (accord. to different copies of the K [generally meaning the quantity that rises above the top after the filling]) thereof: or the quantity sufficing for the filling thereof: (K:) or the quantity nearly sufficing for the filling thereof: (TA: [and the like explanation is given of the third word in the S &c., as will be shown by what follows:]) or the quantity that falls short of the filling thereof. (Mgh. [See also TufaAfapN.]) It is said in a trad. (S, Mgh, O) of the Prophet, (Mgh, O,) kulRukumo banuw Mdama AlSRaAEi TafRa↓, (S, O,) or TafRu AlSRaAEi, (so in my copy of the Mgh,) All of you, sons of Adam, are like the quantity nearly sufficing for the filling of the SAE; (S, * Mgh, O;) i. e. ye are all nearly alike; so says Az: (Mgh:) meaning, all of you, in being related to one father, are in one predicament in respect of defectiveness, like the thing measured that falls short of filling the measure: (IAth, Mgh, O:) the Prophet then proceeded to inform them that there is no excellence of one above another except by piety. (O.)
TafaAfN signifies also The blackness of night; (O, K;) and so TifaAfN↓. (K.)
See also 2.
TufaAfN: see TufaAfapN, in two places.
TifaAfN: see TafaAf, in two places:
and see 2.
TafiyfN Little in quantity: (S, O, Msb, K:) and incomplete: (IDrd, O, K:) applied to a thing in this sense, (IDrd, O,) and in the former sense. (TA.) [See tifolN.]
Also Low, base, vile, mean, paltry, or contemptible. (TA.)

TufaAfapN The quantity that is above the measure; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also TufaAfN↓ (S) or TafafapN↓: (O, K:) or the quantity that falls short of filling the vessel, (IDrd, O, K,) of beverage or wine, &c. (IDrd, O. [See also TafaAf.]) And Somewhat, little in quantity, remaining in a vessel. (TA.)
And TufaAfapu AlUinaMCi and TufaAfuhu↓ The uppermost part of the vessel. (K.)

TafRaAfN (O, K) and TafRN↓ (K) and xafRN and dafRN, as epithets applied to a horse, are alike (O, K) in meaning (K) [app. signifying Light, brisk, or quick: (see TafRafa bihi Alfarasu:) in the TK, and hence by Freytag, expl. as meaning thus, but as an epithet applied to a man].
UinaMCN TafRaAnu [in the CK TafRAnN] A vessel in which the measuring [or thing measured] has reached its uppermost parts: (S, O, K:) [or] a full vessel. (IAar, TA.)
AlTRaAfRapu What is between mountains and plains. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
And TaAfRapu AlbusotaAni What surrounds the garden: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) pl. TawaAfRu. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

TafoTafapN (S, O, K) and TifoTifapN, (O, K,) the latter mentioned on the authority of AZ, (O,) The xaASirap [or flank]: (S, O, K:) or any quivering flesh: (Az, O, K: [see XidoqN:]) or the flaccid flesh of the soft parts of the belly; (O, K;) thus the former word is expl. by IDrd: (O:) or the extremities of the side, adjoining the ribs: (K:) and said to mean the soft part of the liver; the pl. being used by Dhu-r-Rummeh in relation to the liver: (L, TA:) the pl. is TafaATifu. (O, K.)
TafoTaAfN The extremities of trees: (S, O, K:) or the soft, or tender, and succulent, of plants, or herbage: or, accord. to El-Mufaddal, the leaves of the branches. (TA.)
See also TafRN.

muTafRifN One who gives short measure, and short weight, (Zj, Msb, TA,) thus cheating his companion; but this epithet is not applied unrestrictedly except in the case of exorbitant deficiency: [or] accord. to Aboo-Is-hák [i. e. Zj], the mTfRf is thus called because he seldom or never steals from the measure or balance save what is paltry, i. e. Tafiyf; for it is from TafRu AlXRaIoCi, meaning “ the side of the thing: ” the pl. occurs in the Kur lxxxiii. 1. (TA.)

1. TafiYati AlnRaAru, aor.
TafaAa
, inf. n. TufuwoCN (S, Msb, K) and TafaON; (TA;) and AnTfOt↓; (S, K;) The fire became extinguished, or quenched: (Msb:) or ceased to flame: (K, TA:) [or rather, ceased to flame and its live coals became cool; for] when the flame of the fire has become allayed but its coals still burn, it is said to be xaAmidap; and when its flame is extinct and its coals have become cool, it is said to be haAmidap and TaAfiYap↓. (TA.)

4. ATfO AlnRaAra He extinguished, or quenched, the fire. (S, * Msb, K, * TA.) Hence, ATfO AlHaroba (tropical:) He extinguished the fire of the war. (TA.) And OaTofaOotu Alfitonapa (tropical:) I allayed the sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like. (Msb.)
7: see the first paragraph.
naArN TaAfiYapN [Fire becoming, or become, extinguished]: see 1.

muTofiYu Aljamori [The extinguisher of the live coals;] one of the [seven] days called OayRaAmu AlEajuwzi; (S, O;) the fifth of those days; (K;) so in the M &c.: (TA:) or the fourth thereof: (O, K:) or the last thereof. (Har p. 295.) [Accord. to modern Egyptian almanacs, it is the fourth of those days on which the last of the three jamaraAt becomes extinct: see jamorapN: and see also EajuwzN]

muTofiYapu AlrRaDofi (so in the M and O and L and in some copies of the K, in other copies of the K muTofiYu, TA) A piece of fat which, when it falls upon the raDof [or heated stones], melts, and quenches them. (Lth, O, K.) And in the M and L, it is said to signify A lean sheep or goat: the Arabs, as is related by Lh, used to say, Hadasa lahumo bimuTofiYapi AlrRaDofi (TA) i. e. He slaughtered for them a lean sheep or goat, which extinguished the fire and did not become thoroughly cooked: (M and L and K in art. Hds:) or a fat sheep or goat, (AO
and T, TA in that art.,) which quenched the raDof by its fat. (T, TA ibid. [See also damaga.])

Also A serpent, the poison of which, as it passes by the raDof, extinguishes their fire: (O, K:) in a verse of El-Kumeyt, [for the sake of the metre,] the former word is [altered to] muTafRiYap↓. (O.)
And (tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune: (O, K, TA:) said by AO to mean originally such as has made one to forget that which was before it, and extinguished its heat. (O, TA.)
muTafRiYapu AlrRaDofi: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. TafaHa, (S, A, K,) aor.
TafaHa
, (TA,) inf. n. TufuwHN (S, A, K) and TafoHN, (K,) It (a vessel, S, A, K, and a river, A, TA, and a wateringtrough, or tank, A) was, or became, full, so as to overflow: (S, A:) was, or became, full, and high [in its contents], (K, TA,) so as to overflow. (TA.) [See also miroqamN.]
TafaHa said of one intoxicated, (tropical:) He was full of wine. (T, S, TA.)

TafaHato biAlOawolaAdi (tropical:) She (a woman) brought forth children abundantly; brought forth many children: (A:) [or] TafaHato biAlwaladi she brought forth the child at the full period of gestation, or fully formed. (K.)
TafaHa Eaqoluhu (assumed tropical:) His understanding, or intellect, became eminent [or, app., exuberant]. (TA.)
TafaHa, aor. as above, also signifies (assumed tropical:) He ran. (As, TA.)
And one says, AiTofaHo EanRiI, meaning (assumed tropical:) Go thou away, or depart, from me. (S, K.)
TafaHa as trans.: see 4.
TafaHati AlrRiyHu AlquTonapa The wind raised, or carried up, the portion of cotton: (S, K:) and in like manner, a similar thing. (S.)
2: see the next paragraph.

4. ATfHhu; (S, A, K;) and TfRHhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. taTofiyHN; (S;) and TafaHahu↓, (K,) inf. n. TafoHN; (TA;) He filled it so that it overflowed: (S, A:) or he filled it so that it became high [in its contents]: (K:) namely, a vessel, (S, A, K,) and a river, or rivulet, and a watering-trough, or tank. (A.)
8. AiTRafaHa Alqidora (S, K, in the CK [erroneously] Alqidoru) He took off the TufaAHap (i. e. scum) of the cooking-pot. (S.)
TafoHaAnu; fem. TafoHay: see TaAfiHN.

TifaAHu AlOaroDi What would fill the earth (T in art. THf, and K,) so that it would overflow: (T:) so in the saying, in a trad., waUno kaAna Ealayohi TifaAHu AlOroDi cunuwbAF [Though there be upon him, or imputable to him, what would fill the earth so that it would overflow, of sins, or crimes]. (T.)
TufaAHapF What has come forth upon the surface of a thing, such as the scum of the cooking-pot, (S,) which is termed TufaAHapu Alqidori. (A, K.)
TafRaAHu AlqawaAYimi (tropical:) A horse that runs much. (A.) And TafRaAHapu AlqawaAYimi (tropical:) A she-camel having swift legs. (K, TA.)

TaAfiHN Full, so as to overflow; applied to [a vessel, and] a river, and a watering-trough, or tank: (A, TA:) or full: and full and high. (A'Obeyd, T, TA.) And UinaMCN TafoHaAnu↓, and qaSoEapN TafoHaI A vessel, and a bowl, of which the contents flow over the sides. (K.)
Applied to one intoxicated, (tropical:) Full of wine. (T, S, A, K.)
And (assumed tropical:) Running, or one that runs. (As, TA.)
And [the fem.] TaAfiHapN signifies Dry, or tough, or rigid: whence the phrase rukobapN TaAfiHapN meaning A knee which he to whom it belongs cannot grasp with his hand. (K.)
miTofaHapN A skimmer, or ladle with which the scum of the cooking-pot is taken off; (K;) called in Pers. kafoGiyr. (TA.)

1. Tafara, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
Tafira
, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. TufuwrN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and TaforN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) or TaforapN, (K,) [but] this has a more particular signification than TaforN, (Msb,) [being an inf. n. un.,] He leaped: (S:) or he leaped upwards, (Lth, T, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) as when one leaps over a wall to what is behind it. (Lth, T, Mgh, Msb.) One says, Tafara AlHaAYiTa, (TA,) or Tafara AlHaAYiTa UilaI maA waraMCahu, (A,) He leaped over the wall to what was behind it. (TA.) And Tafara Alfarasu AlnRahora [The horse leaped over the river, or rivulet]. (A, TA.)
2. TfRr Alfarasa AlnRahora He made the horse to leap over the river, or rivulet. (A, TA.)

8. AiTRafara farasahu, inf. n. AiTRifaArN; (O, TA;) accord. to the K, OaTofara, inf. n. UiTofaArN, but the former is the right; (TA;) He thrust his feet into the groins of his horse: the doing of which is a fault in the rider. (O, K, TA.) And in like manner one says of a man when he makes his camel to run: (O, TA:) i. e. AiTRafara baEiyrahu, inf. n. AiTRifaArN, He thrust his feet into the groins of his camel. (L.) [It seems to be tropical, from what here follows.]

AiTRafara AlrRajulu, meaning He stuck his nails [into a thing] is originally AiZRafara; (TA; [in which it is said to be tropical; but for this I see no reason;]) as also AiTRafarahu he stuck his nail into it. (TA in art. Zfr.)

TaforapN A leap: (S:) or a leap upwards, (T, A, * Mgh, Msb, K, *) as when one leaps over a wall; (T, Mgh, Msb;) said to be thus distinguished from wavobapN, which is downwards. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence Taforapu AlnRiZaAmi [app. meaning An overleaping the right order, or method: I have not found any explanation of it]. (A.)
huwa TafRaAru AlOanohaAri [He is the leaper over rivers, or rivulets]. (A.)
TinofisapN and its variations: see art Tnfs.

1. Tafiqa yafoEalu kacaA, (S, Mgh, O, K,) aor.
Tafaqa
; (S, K;) and Tafaqa, aor.
Tafiqa
, (S, O, K,) mentioned by Akh, (S, ISd, O,) and by Zj, (ISd, TA,) as said by some, (S, O,) but pronounced by Lth to be bad; (TA;) inf. n. TaqaqN, (S, K, TA, [in some copies of the K, erroneously, TafoqN,]) of the former verb; (S, TA;) and TufuwqN, (S, O, K,) of the latter verb; (S, O;) He set about, began, commenced, took to, or betook himself to, doing such a thing: (S, Mgh, O, TA:) expl. in the K as meaning he continued uninterruptedly the doing of such a thing (waASala AlfiEola [or in some copies waSala AlfiEola]), and by El-Háfidh Ibn-Hajar, in the “ Fet-h el-Bári, ” as meaning he entered upon, began, or commenced, and went on continually, doing such a thing; but it denotes the entering upon the doing of a thing irrespectively of the going on continually or not, and therefore it is not allowable to prefix Oano to its predicate: (MF, TA:) it is followed by a future [or an aor., as in the ex. above]: the saying faTafiqa masoHFA biQlsRuwqi waQloOaEonaAqi, in the Kur [xxxviii. 32], (TA,) i. e. He took to severing with the sword [the thighs and the necks], or, as some say, to wiping [or stroking] with his hand [the thighs and the necks], (Bd,) is for Tafiqa yamosaHu masoHFA: (Bd, * TA:) the verb is used only in an affirmative phrase: they do not say maA Tafiqa. (IDrd, O, K.)
Tafiqa fulaAnN bimaA OaraAda, (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, K, *) a phrase of the Arabs of the desert, (Aboo-Sa'eed, O,) means Such a one attained that which he desired. (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, K. *)

And one says Tafiqa AlmawoDiEa, aor.
Tafaqa
, He kept, or clave, to the place. (ISd, K.)

4. ATfqhu QllRehu bihi God caused him to attain him, or it. (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, K.) One says, laYino OaTofaqaniI QllRehu bihi laOafoEalanRa bihi [Verily if God cause me to attain him, or it, I will assuredly do something with him, or it]. (TA.)

1. Tafula, aor.
Tafula
, inf. n. TafaAlapN and TufuwlapN, It (anything) was, or became, soft, or tender; [as though resembling a Tifol;] (K, TA;) syn. raxuSa. (TA.)
Tafalat said of a she-camel: see 2.
Tafala, (K, TA,) inf. n. TufuwlN, said of a man, (TA,) He entered upon the [time called] Tafal, (K, TA,) which has two contr. meanings; (TA;) as also ATfl↓. (K.)
And Tafalati AlXRamosu The sun rose: (O, K:) so says Fr in his “ Nawádir. ” (O.)

And, (O, K,) accord. to Zj, (O,) The sun became red on the occasion of setting; and so OaTofalat↓: (O, K:) thus the former has two contr. meanings: (K:) and
AlXRamos TfRlt↓, (S, K,) or TfRlt liloguruwbi, (S,) inf. n. taTofiylN, (S, O,) The sun inclined to setting: (S, O:) or approached the setting; as also Tafalat, (K, TA,) aor.
Tafula
, inf. n. TufuwlN. (TA.)
Tafalati AlHumuru AlEuXoba The asses depastured the herbs so as to raise the dust upon them. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)

And Tafila AlnRabotu; (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K;) and Tufila; (Ibn-' Abbád, O, TA;) or, accord. to the K, TufRila↓, inf. n. taTofiylN; (TA;) The herbage became soiled by dust, (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K, TA,) and thereby marred, or injured. (Ibn- ' Abbád, O, TA.)

2. TfRlt AlnRaAqapu i. q. raXaHato TifolahaA or raXRaHatohu [i. e. The she-camel rubbed the root of her young one's tail, and pushed him on with her head; and went before him, and waited for him until he overtook her; and sometimes gently urged him on, and followed him]; (K accord. to different copies; [but both of these verbs signify the same, as expl. in the L;]) and so Tafalat↓, (K, TA,) aor.
Tafula
, inf. n. TufuwlN. (TA.)
TfRlt AlXRamosu: see 1.
TfRl AllRayolu The night began to be dark: (S, O:) or drew near. (K.)
TfRl AlUibila, (S, O, K,) inf. n. taTofiylN, (S, O,) He treated the camels gently, in journeying, in order that their young ones (OaTofaAluhaA) might come up to them. (S, O, K.)

And TfRl AlkalaAma, (tropical:) He considered, or forecast, the results of the speech, or saying; he looked to what would, or might, be its result; or he thought, or meditated, upon it, and endeavoured to understand it; syn. tadabRarahu; (K, TA;) and (TA) so ATflhu↓. (O, TA.)
See also 1, last sentence.
And see 5, in two places.

4. ATflt, said of a woman, (S, O, TA,) and of a girl, or young woman, (Sbyp, [but this, I doubt not, is a mistranscription for Zaboyap, i. e. a doe-gazelle,]) and of a she-camel, (TA,) or of any female, (Msb,) She had a Tifol [or young one of tender age]: (S, O, TA:) or she brought forth. (Msb.)
See also 1, in two places.
And see 2.

5. tTfRl He was, or became, an intruder at feasts, uninvited; (S, Msb, K;) as also TfRl↓, (K,) inf. n. taTofiylN: (TA:) or he imitated Tufeyl: (Har p. 179: [see TufayoliIRN:]) and Ealayohi TfRl↓ and tTfRl Elyh he intruded upon him at a feast, uninvited. (TA.) It is of the speech of the people of El-' Irák. (Lth, Msb.)

TafolN Soft, or tender; (S, O, K;) applied to anything, (K:) fem, with p; (S, O, K;) applied to a girl, or young woman, (S,) or to a woman: (O:) and pl. TifaAlN and TufuwlN, (K.) One says banaAnN TafolN [Soft, or tender, fingers, or ends of fingers]; this being allowable, though bnAn is a [kind of] pl. and Tfl is a sing., because every pl. [of the kind] that differs not from its sing. save in the p [affixed to the latter] is made sing. and masc. [as well as fem.]: and therefore Homeyd says,

[And when they (referring to females) removed from over him the clothing, they wiped him with the extremities of soft, or tender, fingers, that adorned a plump fore arm, tattooed]; meaning, biOaToraAfi binaAnK TafolK. (S, O.)

Also [Fullers' earth, which is used for scouring cloths, and is sometimes used in the bath, instead of soap;] a certain yellow [or rather yellowish, and sometimes white, or whitish,] earth, well known in Egypt, with which cloths are dyed [or rather scoured]; (TA;) also called bayoluwnN. (Esh-Shiháb El- ' Ajamee, TA in art. bln.)

TifolN A young one, or youngling, or the young, (Msb, K, *) of anything, (K,) [or] of a human being and of a beast: (Msb:) or (K) a new-born child, or young infant: and also a young one, or the young, of any wild animal: (S, O, K:) or it is applied to a child until he discriminates; (Msb, TA;) after which he is called SabiIR; thus some say, (Msb,) [and] thus says El-Munáwee: (TA:) or, accord. to Az, (Msb, TA,) on the authority of AHeyth, (TA,) a child from the time of his birth (Mgh, TA) until he attains to puberty: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) fem. TifolapN: (Zj, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and pl. OaTofaAlN: (Zj, S, O, Msb, TA:) but TifolN is also used as fem., (Zj, Mgh, O, Msb, TA,) and dual, (Zj, TA,) and pl., (Zj, S, O, Msb, TA,) occurring as pl. in the Kur xxiv. 31, (S, O, Msb,) and [xxii. 5 and] xl. 69: (Zj, TA:) and TifoyalN↓ signifies the same as TifolN; (K, TA;) used in this sense by a rájiz; but accord. to some, by poetic license, for the dim. TufayolN↓. (TA.)

[Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Any part or portion of anything, whether a substance or an accident: (K, TA:) pl. OaTofaAlN: whence they say Tifolu AlhamRi and AlHubRi (assumed tropical:) [The portion of anxiety and of love]. (TA.)

(tropical:) A falling spark or portion (siqoT [in the CK saqaT]) of fire: (M, K, TA:) or a live coal: (A, TA:) or fire when just struck; as also TifolapN: (T, TA: [but this latter is the n. un.:]) and the pl. is OaTofaAlN: one says, taTaAyarato OaTofaAlu, AlnRaAri, meaning (tropical:) The sparks of the fire [became scattered]. (TA.)
(assumed tropical:) Small clouds: so in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb. (TA.)

(tropical:) An object of want: (K:) or a small object of want. (TA.) One says, huwa yasoEaI fiI OaTofaAli AlHawaAYiji i. e. [(tropical:) He labours in the accomplishment of] small objects of want. (A, TA.)
(tropical:) Night: (K, TA:) or the first part thereof. (A, TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) The sun when near to the setting. (ISd, K, TA.)
TafalN: see TufuwliyRapN.

Also The period [next] after sunrise: from TifolN signifying “ a young one ” or “ youngling: ” (O:) or Tafalu AlgadaApi signifies the period from that when the sun is about to rise, or appear, until its light has ascendancy over the earth: (T, TA:) or when the sun is about to rise, or appear, and has not yet ascendancy in, or upon, the earth: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the period from the rising, or appearing, of the sun, until its having ascendancy [for UilaI QsotikomaAlihaA in a copy of the M, and AstkmAnhA and AstknAnhA in different copies of the K, I read AlI QsotimokaAnihaA, agreeably with the explanation in the the T and with that of Er-Rághib, in both of which the verb used is yasotamokin,] in, or upon, the earth. (M, K.) And (O) The period after [that called] the EaSor [q. v.] when the sun inclines to the setting: (S, O:) or Tafalu AlEaXiIRi signifies the last part of the afternoon, at sunset, (K, TA,) and at the time of the sun's becoming yellow, when it is about to set. (TA.) One says, Oatayotuhu TafalFA [I came to him at one of the periods termed Tafal]. (S, O.)
Also The coming of the night with its darkness. (TA.)
And The darkness itself. (O, K.)

Also Rain: so in the phrase Tafalu AlvRurayRaA [The rain of the auroral setting of the Pleiades]. (S, O.) [Or A shower of rain: for] one says, waqaEato OaTofaAlu AlwasomiIRi The showers of the [rain called] wsmIR [q. v.] fell: and jaAdahu TafalN mino maTarK [A shower of rain descended copiously upon him, or it]. (A, TA.)
And riyHN TafalN A wind that blows gently, or softly. (TA.)
TafilN Herbage that does not become tall (TA.)
TufaAlN and TafaAlN Dry clay: (K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

TafiylN, like OamiyrN, (K,) or, accord. to the L, TifoYilN↓, mentioned in the L in art. TfOl, (TA,) Turbid water remaining in a watering-trough: (K, TA:) n. un. with p; (K;) accord. to the L, TifoYilapN; meaning a portion thereof. (TA.)
TufayolN dim. of TifolN, q. v.
TifoYilN: see TafiylN.
TifoyalN: see TifolN.
TafaAlapN: see what next follows.
TufuwlapN: see what next follows.

TufuwliyRapN, mentioned by ISd and the expositors of the Fs and others, as well as in the K, and also pronounced without teshdeed, [i. e. TufuwliyapN,] which shows, as do several other reasons, that the I therein is not that which is the characteristic of rel. ns., though it has been asserted to be so, (MF, TA,) The state, or condition, of the Tifol; [i. e. early infancy: or, in a larger sense, childhood;] as also TufuwlapN↓ and TafaAlapN↓ and TafalN↓; (K;) [inf. ns.] having no verb [corresponding to them]. (TA.)

TufayoliIRN One who intrudes at feasts, uninvited; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also TifoliylN↓: (K:) the former is a rel. n. from TufayolN, the name of a certain man of El-Koofeh, (ISk, S, O, Msb, K,) who used to intrude at feasts, uninvited, (ISk, S, O, Msb,) and who was called Tufayolu AlOaEoraAsi and Tufayolu AlEaraAYisi: (ISk, S, O: [two other deriva-
tions are mentioned in the TA; but they are too far-fetched to deserve notice:]) such the Arabs [in their proper language] called waAriXN. (ISk, S, O, Msb.)
TafRaAlN One who sells Tafol [or fullers' earth]. (TA.)
TifoliylN: see TufayoliIRN.

[TaAfilapN, which Golius explains as meaning “ i. q. faAyidapN et xayorN, utilitas, bonum, ” referring to the KL as his authority, is evidently a mistake for TaAYilN, expl. as meaning faAYidapN and xayorN in my copy of the KL, which does not mention TaAfilapN in any sense.]

OaTofalu [More, or most, like to the TufayoliIR: and hence, more, and most, intrusive, uninvited]. OaTofalu mino layolK EalaI nahaArK [More intrusive, uninvited, than night upon day], and mino XayobK EalaI XabaAbK [than hoariness upon youthfulness], and mino cubaAbK [than flies], are proverbs. (Meyd.)

muTofilN, (A 'Obeyd, S, O, Msb, K,) and muTofilapN also, (TA,) applied to a female, of human beings and of wild animals, (K, TA,) and of camels, (A 'Obeyd, TA,) i. q. caAtu TifolK [Having a young one, or youngling, &c.], (A 'Obeyd, K, TA,) with her: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or applied to a she-gazelle and camel, (S, O,) or to any female, (Msb,) that has recently brought forth: (S, O, Msb: *) pl. maTaAfilu and maTaAfiylu. (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K.) [See also EaAYicN, in art. Ewc.] saArato qurayoXN biAlEuwci AlmaTaAfiyli i. e. Kureysh journeyed with the camels that had recently brought forth having with them their young ones, occurring in a trad., means, (assumed tropical:) with their collective company, their old and their young. (TA.) [See, again, EaAYicN.]
[It is also said by Freytag to be applied in the Deewán of the Hudhalees to clouds followed by small ones.]
And layolapN muTofilN means A night that kills the young ones by its cold. (K, TA.)

1. TafaA fawoqa AlmaMCi, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaTofuw, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. TufuwRN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and TafowN, (S, Msb, K,) It (a thing, S, Mgh, Msb) floated upon the water, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and did not sink. (S, Msb.)
[Hence,] one says, AlZRuEunu taTofuw watarosubu fiI AlsRaraAbi (assumed tropical:) [The women's camel-vehicles appear, as though floating, and disappear, as though sinking, in the mirage]. (TA.)
And Tafati AlxuwSapu fawoqa AlXRajari (tropical:) [The leaf of the date-palm, or of the Theban palm, &c.,] appeared [above the trees]. (K, TA.)
And TafaA said of a bull, (K,) or of a wild bull, (TA,) (tropical:) He mounted upon the hills (K, TA) and upon the sands. (TA. [In the CK, ElI AlAakami is erroneously put for EalaA AlOakama.])
And Tafawotu fawoqahu (assumed tropical:) I leaped upon it. (TA.) The saying

L.foreign: EabodN UicaA maA rasaba Alqawomu TafaA

sense.s: is expl. by IAar as meaning [A slave] who, when the people are grave, leaps by reason of his ignorance. (TA.)
And TafaA AlmaMCu [not a mistranscription for TagaA] (assumed tropical:) The water rose, or became high. (TA voce TuwfaAnN, q. v.)

And TafaA said of a gazelle, (assumed tropical:) He ran vehemently. (K.) One says of a gazelle, marRa yaTofuw, meaning (tropical:) He passed by, or along, or away, going lightly, or briskly, upon the ground, and running vehemently. (S, TA.)
And, said of a man, (K, TA,) by way of comparison [to a floating fish], (TA,) (tropical:) He died. (K, TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) He (i. e. a man) entered into [or upon] an affair: (K, TA:) [or,] accord. to the “ Nawádir, ” one says, TafaA fiI AlOaroDi he entered into the earth, either waAgilFA [app. as meaning penetrating, and becoming concealed], or raAsixFA [app. as meaning becoming firmly fixed therein]. (TA.)
[TafaA is made trans. by means of bi: see an ex. voce Oarosaba.]
4. ATfI He kept continually, or constantly, to the eating of fish found floating upon the water. (TA.)
TufoIN: see TufoyapN.
TafowapN, (K,) thus it should app. be accord. to the K, but in copies of the M, TufowapN↓, with damm, (TA,) A thin, or slender, plant. (K.)
TufowapN: see what next precedes:
and see also the paragraph next following.

TufoyapN The leaf of the muqol [or Theban palm]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and so TufowapN↓: (As, TA:) pl. TufoIN↓ (S, * TA) or [rather this is a coll. gen. n., and the pl. properly so termed is] TufFI, (Msb,) which is [also] pl. of TufowapN. (As, TA.) [Accord. to Forskål (Flora Ægypt. Arab., p. cxxvi.), the Theban palm itself, which he terms “ borassus flabelliformis, ” is called TfI, as well as dwm.]

And [hence] AlTRufoyapu, (K,) or cuw AlTRufoyatayoni, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) is the name of (assumed tropical:) A serpent (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of a foul, or malignant, sort, (K,) having upon its back two lines, or stripes, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which are black, (S, Mgh, Msb,) resembling two leaves such as are termed TufoyataAni: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and sometimes it is termed TufoyapN, meaning caAtu TufoyapK: and AlTRufaI is used as the pl., meaning cawaAtu AlTRufaI. (S.)
TufaAwapN The floating froth or scum (K, TA) and grease (TA) of the cooking-pot. (K, TA.)
And A halo around the sun, (S, K,) and also around the moon [like haAlapN]: (K:) the former accord. to Fr, and the latter accord. to AHát. (TA.)
And one says, OaSabonaA TufaAwapF mina AlrRabiyEi meaning XayoYFA minohu [i. e. We obtained somewhat of the herbage, or perhaps of the rain, of the season called rabiyE]. (S, TA.)
samakN TaAfK Fish floating upon the surface of the water, having died therein. (Mgh, Msb, TA.)
[Hence,] farasN TaAfK (assumed tropical:) A horse elevating his head. (TA.)
kaOanRa Eayonahu EinabapN TaAfiyapN [As though his eye were a floating grape], in a trad. respecting Ed-Dejjál, is expl. by Th as meaning his eye's being prominent and conspicuous. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. TaqoTaqa [He caused a thing to make a sound such as is termed TaqoTaqapN]. (K voce karaba.)

Taqo a word imitative of a sound; and sometimes they said TaqoTaqapN↓: (IDrd, O, TA:) or the former is a word imitative of The sound of stones; and ↓the latter is its noun: (K:) one says, AlHijaArapi samiEotu TaqoTaqapa↓ I heard [the sound of] the falling of the stones, one upon another, when they rolled down from a mountain: (IDrd, O:) or Taqo is a word imitative of the sound of the stone and of the solid hoof; and TaqoTaqapN↓ signifies the action thereof: (M, TA:) or this latter is a word imitative of the sound of the successive falling of stones, one upon another: (IDrd, O:) or this word signifies the sound of the legs of horses upon the hard ground; (IAar, TA;) [or] sometimes it signifies also the sound of the solid hoofs upon the ground; (IDrd, O;) or the sounds of the hoofs of horses or similar beasts [with quick reiteration]; like daqodaqapN; and sometimes they said HabaTiqoTiqo↓, of which El-Mázinee cites an ex.; (S, O;) but [J says] I have not seen this except in his book: (S:) another ex. of it, however, is cited by Lth. (TA.)
Tiqo The sound of a frog leaping from the margin of a river or rivulet. (M, K.) One says, laA yusaAwiI Tiqo [It is not, or will not be, equal to the sound of a frog &c.]. (M.)
TaqoTaqapN: see Taqo, in four places.
In the language of the common people, it means Lightness, or promptness, in speech. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) The death that results from the jinn's piercing or thrusting [i. e. from the TaAEuwn]. (TA.)
TuqoTuwqN and muTaqoTiqN↓ in the language of the common people, Light in person; and light, or prompt, in speech. (TA.)
muTaqoTiqN: see what next precedes.
HabaTiqoTiqo: see Taqo.

1. TalRati AlsRamaMCu AlOaroDa, [aor.
Talula
,] inf. n. TalRN, The sky rained small rain upon the earth, or land. (MA.) And TulRati AlOaroDu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) [meaning, as is implied in the S and O, The earth, or land, was rained upon by the weakest of rain; or was rained upon, or bedewed, by the TalR, q. v.; or] the TalR descended upon the earth, or land: (K:) and TalRahaA AlnRadaI [The rain, or dew, moistened it]: (S, O, TA:) and TalRat, with fet-h, signifies [accord. to some] It became
moist, or moistened: one says, TulRato bilaAduka, and TalRato; the former meaning May thy countries, or tracts of country, be rained upon; and the latter, become moist, or moistened: or, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, [i. e. Zj,] TulRato only, with damm; [and he adds,] one says, raHubato bilaAduka waTulRato, with damm, [i. e. May thy tracts of country be spacious to thee, and be moistened by the TalR, (or, as in art. rHb in the TA, OaroHabato Ealayoka waTulRato)], not TalRato; because the TalR is not from them, [i. e. it is not from the tracts of country,] but they are the objects thereof. (TA.) [Golius mentions, among the significations of TalRa, as on the authority of Z, i. q. rHb, said of land, or the earth, and followed by ElI relating to a person: but I think it most probable that he inferred this signification from his finding, in a copy of the A, the phrase raHubato Ealayoka AlOaroSu waTalRato (for waTulRato), without any explanation. And Freytag mentions OuTilRa↓ as meaning It was watered by fine rain; from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.] And [it is said that] TalRati AlsRamaMCu signifies AiXotadRa waqoEuhaA [i. e. The rain fell vehemently]. (TA.)

TalRa damahu, (AZ, S, O, Msb,) said of God, (S,) or of the ruling power, (Msb,) first pers. Talalotuhu, (K,) aor.
Talula
, (Msb,) inf. n. TalRN (Msb, K) and TuluwlN, (K,) He made his blood to go for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; made it to be of no account: (AZ, S, O, Msb, K, TA:) or held it to be of little account, as though it were but [the rain, or dew, termed] TalR, in its result; this, accord. to Er-Rághib, being the proper meaning: (TA:) and ATlRhu↓ signifies the same. (AZ, S, O, Msb, K.) And TulRa damuhu His blood was made to go for nought, &c.; (AZ, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also damuhu OuTilRa↓: (AZ, S, O, Msb, K:) and TalRa damuhu, (S, O, Msb, K,) with fet-h, accord. to Ks and AO, (S, O, Msb,) aor.
Talula
[contr. to analogy], (Msb,) or
Talila
[agreeably with analogy]; (K;) and TalRa, originally Talila, (Msb, K, *) aor.
Talala
; (Msb, K;) [his blood went for nought, &c.;] but this is disallowed by AZ; (S, O, Msb;) and it is more commonly with damm. (K.)

And TalRahu HaqRahu, aor.
Talula
, He diminished, or impaired, to him his right, or due; or deprived, or defrauded him of it, partly, or wholly: (K, TA:) or, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, (TA,) he denied him, or refused him, his right, or due; (K, TA;) and withheld it [from him]: (TA:) and he annulled it; or made it to go for nought, as a thing of no account, or as a thing that had perished or become lost. (K, TA.) You say, TalRuwA fulaAnFA HaqRahu, aor.
Talula
, inf. n. TalRN, They denied, or refused, such a one his right, or due: so says Khálid Ibn-Jembeh. (O.)

And TalRa gariymahu, (K,) aor.
Talula
, (TA,) inf. n. TalRN, (O, K,) He delayed, or deferred, with his creditor, or put him off, by promising time after time to pay him. (O, * K.)
And TalRN signifies also The driving of camels roughly, or rigorously. (K.) You say, TalRa AlUibila, inf. n. TalRN, He drove the camels roughly, or rigorously! (TK.)

TalRa, [sec. pers. Talilota, aor.
Talala
,] inf. n. TalaAlapN; like malRa, [sec. pers. malilota, aor.
Talala
,] (K, TA,) inf. n. malaAlapN; (TA;) [accord. to Freytag, followed by lahu, and in the Deewán of the Hudhalees by Uilayohi; and so, accord. to him, AstTlR↓, followed by lahu;] He, or it, was, or became, pleasing, (K, TA,) and goodly. (TA.)
And TalRahu, (K,) inf. n. TalRN, (TA,) is also syn. with TalaAhu: (K:) so in the phrase TalRahu biAlwarosi [He smeared it, or rubbed it over, with wrs, q. v.]; namely, a thing. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)
4: see 1, former half:
and the same, latter half, in two places.

ATlR Ealayohi He (a man, Msb) looked upon it, looked upon it from above, looked down upon it, got a view of it, or saw it; syn. OaXorafa, (S, O, K,) [i. e.] OaXorafa Ealayohi, (Msb,) or OawofaI Elyh; (Ham p. 208;) properly OawofaI Ealayohi biTalalihi, i. e. biXaxoSihi [meaning he looked upon it, &c., with his body; not in imagination]; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and AstTlR↓ signifies the same: (K:) and so OaTafRa Elyh. (O in art. Tf.) [See also 6.] Hence, in a trad., the saying of Safeeyeh the daughter of 'Abd-El-Muttalib, faOaTalRa EalayonaA yahuwdiIRN faqumotu faDarabotu raOosahu biAlsRayofi vumRa ramayotu bihi Ealayohimo [And a Jew looked upon us, and I arose, and smote off his head with the sword, then cast it upon them]. (O.)
[Hence, perhaps,] ATlR AlzRamaAnu (assumed tropical:) The time drew near. (Msb.)
And ATlR EalaI HaqRiI facahaba bihi (assumed tropical:) He got possession of my right, or due, and took it away, or went away with it. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) [See also OaTafRa.]

And ATlR Ealayohi (tropical:) He importuned him, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, TA,) HatRaI galabahu [so that, or until, he overcame him]. (TA.) And ATlR fulaAnN EalaI fulaAnK biAlOacaI (assumed tropical:) Such a one kept continually, or constantly, to the annoying, or molesting, or hurting, of such a one. (TA.)
An Arab woman of the desert is related to have said, maA OaTalRa XiEora jamiylK waOaHolaAhu [How pleasing is the poetry of Jemeel, and how sweet is it!]. (TA.)

5. hecihi AlOaroDu qado taTalRalato This land has produced herbage, and become replete, [for taxayRarato (to which I cannot assign any apposite meaning), in my original, I read taHayRarato,] and has not been trodden by any one: so says AA. (O.)

6. taTaAlRa (S, O, in the K in art. Twl written taTaAlala,) UilaI AlXRaIoCi (O) He stretched out his neck, looking at the thing, it being far from him: (S, O:) or he stretched out his neck to look: (TA in art. dmx:) or taTaAlalotu signifies I stood upon my toes, and stretched my stature, to look at a thing, (taTaAwalotu, K, TA, both of these verbs meaning thus, TA in art. Twl,) and looked: (K, TA:) or, accord. to AA, AltRaTaAlRu signifies the looking from above a place, or from a curtain or the like. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. Xrf, conj. 10: and see also 4 in the present art.]

AstTlR Alfarasu bicanabihi is expl. by Ibn-'Abbád as signifying marRamuTilRFA bihi UicaA naASabahu fiI AlsRamaMCi [app. meaning The horse went along raising his tail toward the sky: for I think that UicaA naASabahu should be UicaA kaAna naASibahu or OaIo naASibahu]. (O.)
See also 1, last sentence but one.

R. Q. 1. TaloTalahu He moved him, agitated him, shook him, or put him into a state of motion or commotion; (K, TA;) like talotalahu: (TA:) [or,] accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, AlTRaloTalapu signifies the moving about the arms in walking. (O.)

TalRN Light, (Msb,) or weak, (K,) [i. e. drizzling,] rain: (Msb, K:) or the lightest, (K,) or weakest, of rain: (S, O, Msb, K:) or dew (nadFI, K, TA) that descends from the sky in cloudless weather: (TA:) or above nadFI and less than maTarN: (K:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, rain that has little effect; and so in the Kur ii. 267: (TA:) pl. TilaAlN (S, O, K) and TilalN, (O, K,) the latter mentioned by Fr, and said by him to be the only instance of the kind that has been heard except HirafN pl. of HarofN as meaning the Harof of a mountain; (O;) [or] TalalN is a contraction of TilaAlN: in a saying of a poet, cited by IAar, (TA,) AlTRalal↓ occurs for AlTRalR [in the CK AlTRulR]: or in this instance, as some relate it, the word is AlTRilal. (K, TA.)

And Milk: (K:) or so TulRN↓, with damm, in the saying maA biAlnRaAqapi TulRN [There is not in the she-camel any milk], as Yaakoob says, and as is related on the authority of AA, (S,) and thus in the saying maA biAldRaAri TulRN [There is not in the house any milk]: (O:) or TulRN signifies thus: or blood. (K. [But see this word below.])
And Paucity of milk of a camel; as also TulRN↓. (K.)

And Fat, or fatness; syn. TiroqN [in the CK TaraqN, and in my MS. copy of the K TuroqN]: thus in the saying maA biAlnRaAqapi TalRN [There is not in the she-camel any fat, or fatness]. (M, K, TA: in the CK TulRN.)

[It is also used as an epithet.] You say yawomN TalRN, meaning cuw TalRK, i. e. [A day having drizzling rain, or dew; or] moist, or humid. (TA.) And OaroDN TalRapN Land moistened by dew [or by drizzling rain]; (TA;) as also maToluwlapN↓: (S, TA:) and [in like manner] TalRapN signifies a meadow (rawoDapN) moistened by TalR. (K.) And TalRN signifies Anything moist. (TA.)

[Hence, app.,] Goodly, or good, or beautiful, and pleasing: thus applied to a night, and to poetry (XiEor [in the CK XaEar]), and to water, &c.: (K, TA:) applied to these as meaning good, or beautiful; and so to discourse; (TA;) and thus TaliylapN↓ applied to a xuTobap. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.) And AimoraOapN TalRapN means A beautiful, elegant, or graceful, woman. (TA,) And xamorN TalRapN Pleasant, or delicious, wine: (S, O, K: *) or, as
some say, such as descends easily [or pleasantly down the throat]. (TA.) And TalRapN applied to an odour (raAYiHapN, K, TA, or rayRaA, TA) likewise signifies Pleasant, or delicious. (K, TA.)
Also An aged man: (Kr, K:) and TalRapN signifies an old woman: (K, TA:) and a woman foul, unseemly, or obscene, in tongue; (K, * TA;) annoying, or molesting. (TA.)
And A serpent; (K;) thus accord. to IAar: (O:) and so TilRN↓; (K;) thus accord. to AA; (O;) like TiloEN. (TA in art. TlE.)

TulRN: see TalRN, in two places. [But the signification of “ blood ” there mentioned requires consideration; for Sgh adds immediately after explaining the saying maA biAldRaAri TulRN what here follows.]

cahaba damuhu TulRFA and TilRFA↓ means hadarFA [i. e. His blood went for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O. [Then follows immediately in the O AlTRulRaMCu, expl. as below.])
TilRN: see TalRN, last sentence:
and see also TulRN.
TalRapN [fem. of TalRN, q. v.
And also used as a subst.: signifying] A wife. (S, O, K.)
And Daintiness, or delicacy, in food and clothing. (K, TA. [In the CK, AlnRiEomapu is erroneously put for AlnRaEomapu.])
TulRapN The neck. (K.)
And A draught of milk; (Az, K, TA;) as also TulRaI↓: (Az, TA:) pl. of the former TulalN. (K.)

TalalN A portion still standing of the remains of a dwelling or house; (S, O, Msb, * K;) as also TalaAlapN↓: (K:) pl. OaTolaAlN and TuluwlN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the latter pl. sometimes used: (Msb:) what cleaves to the ground is termed rasomN: (TA:) the people of the towns or villages apply the term OaTolaAlN to the remains of walls and of places of worship; and the people of the tents to [the remains of] places of eating and of drinking and of sleeping: (Ham p. 541:) [and] as pl. of TalalN it signifies elevated places: one says, raOayotu Talala Alqaroyapi, meaning I saw what was elevated of the land of the town, or village. (Har p. 139.)

And The XaxoS [or body, or bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance, such as one sees from a distance,] of a thing, (Msb, K,) whatever it be; as also TalaAlapN↓: pl. of the former as above: (K:) the XaxoS [as meaning body, or person,] of a man; as also TalaAlapN↓: (S, O:) or, of a man, the erect XaxoS. (Msb voce juvRapN.) And ZalaAlapN, with Z, signifies the same. (O and K in art. Zl.) One says, HayRaA QllRehu Talalaka and TalaAlataka↓, meaning [May God preserve, or save,] thy XaxoS [i. e. body, or person]. (S, O.) And HayRaA QllRehu Talalaka and OaTolaAlaka, meaning maA XaxaSa mino jasadika [i. e. May God preserve, or save, what has risen into view of thy body, or person]. (TA.)

Also A place in the SaHon [or court] of a house, prepared for the household to sit upon: ADk says that there was a place on which to eat and drink in the finaMC [or yard] of every house, called the Talal: (Az, TA:) accord. to ISd, (TA,) the Talal of a house is, or was, like the [kind of wide bench, of stone or brick &c., generally built against a wall, called] dukRaAnap [or dukRaAn], upon which to sit. (K, TA.)

And The jilaAl [or deck] of a ship or boat; (M, Mgh, O, K;) i. e. (Mgh) the covering thereof, which is like the roof (Mgh, Msb) of a house or chamber: (Mgh:) pl. OaTolaAlN. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) [In the TA it is said to mean the XiraAE of a ship or boat; which is a mistake, as is sufficiently shown by its being there immediately added, “ hence the trad. of Aboo-Bekr, that he used to pray upon the ATlAl of the ship or boat. ”]

[Hence, app.,] one says, (of a man, Ibn-'Abbád, O,) maXaI EalaI Talali AlmaMCi i. e. ElI Zahorihi, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) which, Z says, means ElI wajohihi [i. e. (tropical:) He walked, or went along, upon the surface of the water: but whether this relates to a pretended miracle or to sliding upon ice, I know not]: and he adds that it is a tropical phrase. (TA.)
Also Anything fresh, or juicy, or [like TalRN] moist; syn. TariIRN. (K.)
See also TalRN, first sentence.
TaliylN: see maToluwlN.

Also Sweet; syn. HulowN: (so accord. to the O and some copies of the K: accord. to other copies of the K, i. q. xilq; i. e., accord. to some of these copies, xaloqN; accord. to some, xalaqN; and accord. to some, xaliqN:) thus expl. by Ibn-'Abbád; and said by him to be of the dial. of Hudheyl. (O.) [The explanation in the O is, I doubt not, the right: and hence]
TaliylapN applied to a xuTobap: see TalRN, latter part.

Also A mat; syn. HaSiyrN: (IAar, O, K:) or such as is woven of [the leaves of the] dawom [or Theban palm-tree]; or of the leaves of the date-palm; or of the quXuwr [app. meaning the peels of the branches] thereof: (K, TA:) so in the M: in the T it is said that TaliylapN↓ means, accord. to AA, a [mat of the kind called] buwriyaMC; and accord. to As, a baAriIR [which signifies the same as bwryM]: (TA:) pl. OaTilRapN and TilRapN and TululN. (K.)

TalaAlapN [an inf. n.: see 1, last sentence but one. And, as a simple subst.,] A good, or goodly, state or condition; and a beautiful aspect, appearance, mien, or guise. (IAar, O, K.) And Beauty, or beauty of colour, or brightness: (O, K:) so in the saying, EalaI manoTiqihi TalaAlapu AlHusoni [Upon his diction is the glow of beauty]. (O.) Accord. to As, i. q. HusonN and maMCN [i. e. Goodliness, or beauty, and, app., lustre]. (TA.)
Also, (AA, O, K,) and some say TulaAlapN↓, (AA, O,) Joy, gladness, or happiness. (AA, O, K.)
See also TalalN, in four places.
[Hence,] one says farasN Hasanu AlTRalaAlapi, meaning [A horse goodly, or beautiful,] in what is high, or elevated, of his frame, or make. (TA.)
TulaAlapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
TaliylapN: see TaliylN.
TulRaI: see TulRapN.

TulRaMCN, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) like sulRaMCN, (K, TA,) [in the CK, TalRAC, like salRAC, and] in some copies of the K, erroneously, TilRaMC, (TA,) Blood, itself: and some say, a pellicle upon the surface thereof: (O:) [and in like manner TulRaMC is expl. in the K in art. TlO:] or blood that has been made to go for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct: (K: [and from the context in the O, it seems that this is probably meant by Ibn- 'Abbád: see TulRN:]) accord. to AAF, (TA,) the C in this word is originally l. (K, TA.)
TuloTulN A chronic, or permanent, disease. (IAar, Az, K.)
TulaTilN: see TulaATilapN.
TulaTilapN: see TulaATilapN: each in two places.
TalaATilu: see TulaATilapN: each in two places.
TulaATilN: see the next paragraph, in three places.
TulaATilapN A calamity, or misfortune; (S, O, K;) as also TulaTilapN↓ [in the CK TaloTalap] and TulaTilN↓ [in the CK TaloTal]. (K, TA.)

Also, (S, O,) or TulaATilN↓, (M, K,) A disease that wearies the physicians, (S, M, O, K,) for which there is no remedy: (S, O:) and said in the M to be a pain in the back. (TA.) And the former, A disease that attacks a man in his belly; as also TulaTilapN↓. (O.) And A disease in the backs of asses, that breaks their backs; (K, * TA;) so in the M; (TA;) as also TilATl with damm and fet-h [i. e. TulaATilN↓ and TalaATilu↓]. (K.)
And Death; as also TulaATilN↓; (K, TA;) so in the M, with damm; and with fet-h [i. e. TalaATilu↓]. (TA.)

And A certain piece of flesh in the fauces: (ISd, K, TA:) or the piece of flesh extending downwards upon [the upper extremity of] the musotaraT [or masoraT, i. e. the gullet]; (As, Az, O, K, * TA;) [meaning] the lahaAp [or uvula]: (TA:) or, (O, K,) accord. to AHeyth, (O,) the falling of the lahaAp [or uvula], so that neither food nor beverage passes the fauces easily by reason of it. (O, K.)

OaTolaAlu is the name of a certain mare, (O, K,) or of a she-camel, (K,) which, in reply to her rider's commanding her to leap a river, on the day of El-Kádiseeyeh, is asserted to have spoken, saying, wavobN wasuwrapi Albaqarapi [A leap, by the Chapter of the Cow!]. (O, K.) [Freytag has erroneously said, as on the authority of the K, that it is a name of the chapter of the Kur-án otherwise called bqrp.]
muTalRN: see maToluwlN.

OamorN muTilRN An affair not settled, or not established. (So accord. to some copies of the S and K, expl. by the words layosa bimusotaqirRK: in other copies of both,
and in the O, lys bimusofirK [to which I am unable to assign any probable meaning].)
muTalRilN i. q. DabaAbN [Mist; or moisture like clouds, or like dust, covering the earth in the early mornings; or thin clouds, like smoke; &c.: see art. Db]. (TA.)
maToluwlN: see its fem., with p, voce TalRN.
Also Blood made to go for nought, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; (S, O, K;) and so TaliylN↓ and muTalRN↓. (K.)

Also [or labanN maToluwlN] Pure milk with froth upon it, upon which water has been poured, and which one imagines to be good, or pleasant, whereas there is no goodness in it; and so maToluwlapN↓: or this latter, some say, signifies a piece of skin soaked and softened [for mawozuwnapN in my original, which I think a mistranscription, I read mawoduwnapN,] with pure milk, which they eat [app. in a time of scarcity].
maToluwlapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. Talabahu, (S, A, O, &c.,) aor.
Taluba
, (Msb,) inf. n. TalabN (S, A, MA, O, Msb, K &c.) and maTolabN (A, MA, Msb) and TilaAbN and TilaAbapN (A, MA) and TalibapN (MA) and taTolaAbN [which is of a measure denoting intensiveness]; (TA;) and AiTRalabahu↓; (S, A, O, Msb, K;) and tTlRbhu↓; (A, K;) [but see this last below;] He sought it, desired it, demanded it, or asked for it; (MA;) [he pursued it, pursued after it, or prosecuted it;] he sought, desired, or endeavoured, to find it and to get or take it: (A, K, TA:) and Talaba is also expl. as signifying AtbE [i. e. OatobaEa he followed in pursuit, &c.]. (TA.) One says, AuTolubo liI XayoYFA Seek thou, &c., for me, a thing. (Lh, TA.) And Talabahu minohu and Uilayohi, inf. n. as above, He sought it, desired it, demanded it, or asked for it, of him. (MA.) And Talaba UilaIRa means ragiba [i. e. He petitioned me, or made petition to me, &c.]: (K, TA:) or Talaba Uilayohi means saOalahu [he asked him]: or [it means] Talabahu raAgibFA Uilayohi [he sought him, petitioning him]; for it is generally held that Talaba is not trans. by means of a prep., therefore they explain the like of this phrase as implicative. (MF, TA.) See also 4, in two places: and see 5. You say also, Talabahu biHaqRK, meaning TaAlabahu, q. v. (K.) And Talaba bivaOorihi and bicaHolihi [He sought to obtain his blood-revenge, or retaliation; and in like manner, Talaba bidamihi]. (S and Msb in art. cHl.)
[Hence,] one says also, AlsRiraAju yaTolubu Oano yanoTafiYa (tropical:) [The lamp, or lighted wick, is near, or about, to become extinguished]; like as one says, jidaArN yuriydu Oano yanoqaDRa. (A.)

Taliba, aor.
Talaba
, (O, K,) inf. n. TalabN, (TK,) He, or it, [accord. to the TK said of a man,] was, or became, distant, or remote. (O, K. [See also 4.])
2: see 5.

3. TAlbhu, inf. n. muTaAlabapN and TilaAbN, (Msb, K,) He sought or demanded of him a thing [as being due to him; i. e. he sued or prosecuted him for it]; (Msb;) i. q. biHaqRK Talabahu↓ [he sought or demanded of him, &c., a right, or due]: (K:) and you say, TAlbhu biHaqRK lahu Ealayohi [he sought or demanded of him, &c., a thing due to him on his part]. (A.) muTaAlabapN is used in relation to a real thing: [but it does not necessarily imply the justice of the act:] one says, TAlb zayodN EamorFA biAldRaraAhimi [Zeyd sought or demanded of 'Amr, or sued or prosecuted him for, the money]. (Kull p. 349.) And TAlbhu biAldRayoni He sought or demanded of him [&c.] the debt. (MA.) And TAlbhu bikacaA, (S, O,) inf. n. muTaAlabapN, (S,) [He sought or demanded of him, &c., such a thing; or he prosecuted him for such a thing, as, for instance, blood, or mutilation, or a wound: see exs. voce xabolN.]

4. ATlbhu He performed, or accomplished, for him, (S, A, O, Msb, TA,) that which he sought, or demanded, (S, A, * O, Msb,) or the object of his want: (TA:) or he gave him that which he sought, or demanded. (K.) A man said to the Prophet, UilaIRa TalibapF faUinRiI OuHibRu Oano OuTolibakahaA AuTolubo↓ i. e. [Ask thou of me] an object of want, [for I love] to perform it, or accomplish it, for thee. (TA.) And one says, UilaIRa faOaTolabotuhu Talaba↓ i. e. [He asked of me a thing] and I performed, or accomplished, for him that which he sought, or demanded. (TA.) And ATlbhu AlXRaIoCa He aided him, or helped him, to seek the thing. (TA.) And OaToliboniI Aid thou me to seek. (Lh, TA.)
Also He, or it, (said of a man, Msb, and of poverty, A,) necessitated his seeking, or demanding. (S, A, O, Msb, K.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (S, O, K.)

And hence, (S, O,) OaTolaba said of water, and of pasture, or herbage, (S, A, O,) &c., (S, O,) It was distant, or remote, (S, A, O,) so as to be not attainable but by seeking, (S, O,) or so that it was sought. (A.)

5. tTlRbhu He sought it, or demanded it, repeatedly, or time after time: (S, O:) [he made repeated, or successive, endeavours to obtain it, or to attain it: he prosecuted a search after it:] or he sought it diligently, studiously, sedulously, or earnestly; syn. AibotagaAhu: (Msb:) or he sought, desired, or endeavoured, leisurely, to find it and to get or take it; (O, TA;) and (TA) so TlRbhu↓, inf. n. taToliybN; (K, TA;) and Talabahu↓; (TA;) from [various] places. (O, TA.)
See also 1, first sentence.

7. AnTlb lahu is quasi-pass. of Talabahu, and means It (an action [&c.]) was, or became, suitable to him; or fit, meet, or proper, for him: [as though it were sought, or desired, or desirable:] but they have been content to use AinobagaI in the place of this verb. (Zj, TA in art. bgI. [yanobagiI, in the Kur xix. 93, is expl. by yanoTalibu in the Ksh and in the Expos. of Bd.])
8: see 1, first sentence.
TilobN: see TalibapN, in two places:
and TaAlib.
TalabN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, A, &c.)
See also TaAlibN, in two places.
And see TalibapN.
TulobapN A far-extending journey: (O, K:) and so safarN TaluwbN↓. (A.)
TilobapN [A mode, or manner, of seeking &c.: an inf. n. of modality, like jilosapN &c.
And] a subst from TaAlabahu: (K:) see TalibapN, in three places.
OumRu Tilobapa The eagle. (O, K.)
TalibapN an inf. n. of Talabahu [q. v.]. (MA.)

[It generally signifies] A thing that one seeks, desires, demands, or asks for; a thing that one seeks, desires, or endeavours, to find and to get or take; an object of quest, or desire; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also TilaAbN↓, which is originally an inf. n. of TaAlabahu; (Msb;) and so TilobN↓; (Har p. 560;) and TilobapN↓ and TalabN↓ are substs. from TaAlabahu, (K,) signifying [the same, or] a right, or due, sought, or demanded: (TK:) and TalibapN signifies also an object of want, or need; a needful thing: (TA:) its pl. is TalibaAtN. (Msb.) One says, liI Einodahu TilobapN↓ [or TalibapN] I have an object of quest, or desire, or of want, or a right, or due, necessary to be sought, or demanded, of him. (A.) And fulaAnK hiIa Tilobu↓ She is the object of love of such a one; as also Tilobatuhu↓: (A, K:) or the former, (O,) or each, the latter mentioned by Lh, (TA,) means she is the object of quest, or desire, and the object of love, of such a one. (O, TA.)
And it is said on the authority of IAar that Tlbp [app., accord. to the context, TalibapN] signifies A company, or an assembly, of men. (TA.)
TilaAbN: see the next preceding paragraph.

TaluwbN, of which the pl. is TulubN, (K, TA,) and, as is said in the Msb, [but not in my copy of it,] TulobN; (TA;) and TalRaAbN↓, of which the pl. is TalRaAbuwna; and TaliybN↓, of which the pl. is TulabaMCu; Seeking, desiring, or demanding; or seeking, desiring, or endeavouring, to find and to get or take; (K, TA;) much, or often; all are intensive in signification. (TA.)
And biYorN TaluwbN (O, TA) [and] TaliybN↓ (thus in a copy of the A) A well of which the water is remote: (A, O, TA:) pl. of the former OaboMrN TulubN. (O, TA.) See also TulobapN.
TaliybN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
TalRaAbN: see TaluwbN.

TaAlibN Seeking, desiring, or demanding; or seeking, desiring, or endeavouring, to find and to get or take; or a seeker, &c.: (Msb, * K, TA:) [and used for TaAlibu EilomK a student of science or knowledge:] pl. TulRaAbN and TalabapN (Msb, K, TA) and TulRabN (K) and TaAlibuwna (Msb) and OaTolaAbN [a
pl. of pauc., like OaSoHaAbN,] (A) and TalabN↓, (S, A, O, K,) or this last, as is said in the M, is [properly speaking] a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) or, (Mgh, TA,) as IAth says, (TA,) it is either a pl. of TaAlibN or an inf. n. used as such, (Mgh, TA,) for Oaholu AlTRalabi: (TA:) fem., applied to a woman, TaAlibapN; of which the pl. is TaAlibaAtN and TawaAlibu. (Msb.) You say, huwa TaAlibN lilXRaIoCi He is a seeker, &c., of the thing. (TA.) And heWulaMCi OaEodaAYihimo Talabu↓ and OaTolaAbuhumo These are the troops that are the seekers [or pursuers] of their enemies. (A.) And nisaMCK huwa Tilobu↓, (A, K,) with kesr, (K,) He is a seeker, or desirer, of women: (A, K:) pl. OaTolaAbN and TilabapN. (K.)

maTolabN A place, (Msb, KL,) or time, (KL,) of seeking: (Msb, KL:) [and so muTRalabN↓:] pl. maTaAlibu. (KL.) [And particularly applied to A place in which treasure is buried and sought. And A place where anything remarkable is to be sought, or looked for, in a book.]

[And hence, (assumed tropical:) A person from whom one seeks a thing.] layosa liI maTolabN siwaAka (assumed tropical:) [I have none from whom to seek the accomplishment of my desires but Thee] occurs in a trad. respecting prayer. (TA.)
See also maToluwbN.
It is also an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (A, MA, Msb.)

muTolibN, applied to water, and to pasture, or herbage, Distant, or remote, (S, A, O,) so as not to be attainable but by seeking, (S, O,) or so that it is sought: (A:) or, applied to pasture, or herbage, distant, or remote: and, applied to water, distant, or remote, from the pasture or herbage: or between which and the pasture, or herbage, is twice the space termed a miyl, (K, TA,) or thrice that space, the myl being the space from one Ealam [or sign of the way] to another; (TA;) or a day, or two days, (K, TA,) i. e. a day's journey, or two days' journey; in the latter case being termed muTolibu UibilK [i. e. distant to be sought of camels]. (TA.) It is also applied to other things: a poet says,
[Has distant lightning, in the latter part of the night, excited thee?]. (S, O.)
maToluwbN Sought, desired, or demanded; and so maTolabN↓ [but app. as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, and used in the sense of TalibapN]. (KL.)
muTRalabN: see maTolabN.

1. TaliHati AlUibilu, (S, A,) [aor.
TalaHa
,] inf. n. TalaHN, (TA,) The camels had a complaint (S, A) of their bellies (S) from eating of the trees called TaloH. (S, A. [But see UibilN.])

And TaliHa, aor.
TalaHa
, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TK,) He (a man, TK,) was, or became, empty, or void of food, in his belly; as also TuliHa, like EuniIa. (K.)

TalaHa, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
TalaHa
, inf. n. TaloHN and TalaAHapN, (M, K,) said of a camel, (S, M, A, K,) He was, or became, lean, or emaciated, by reason of fatigue, or of disease: (A:) or fatigued, or wearied: (ISk, S, K:) or injured, or hurt, by fatigue: (AZ, T, TA:) or he was, or became, fatigued, and fell down by reason of travel: (M, TA:) or TaliHa, aor.
TalaHa
, inf. n. TalaHN; and TalaHa, aor.
TalaHa
, inf. n. TaloHN; he was, or became, fatigued: or lean, by reason of fatigue, or of disease. (MA.)
And TalaHa, inf. n. TalaAHN, (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, bad, corrupt, or vicious. (A, L. [See TalaAHN below.])

TalaHahu, aor.
TalaHa
, [inf. n. TaloHN,] He, or it, (a man, MA, Msb, or journeying, A,) rendered him lean, or emaciated him; (A, MA, Msb;) namely, a camel: (A, Msb:) [or] he fatigued him; (MA, K;) i. e., a camel; (S, K;) and (K) so ATlHhu↓; and TlRHhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. of the latter taToliyHN. (TA.)
2: see the last sentence above.
[Hence, app.,] TlRH Ealayohi, (A, K,) inf. n. taToliyHN, (K,) (tropical:) He importuned him, (A, K,) i. e., his debtor, so that he wearied him. (A.)
4: see 1, last sentence.

TaloHN, [a coll. gen. n.,] (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) and TilaAHN; (S, A, K;) the latter said to be pl. of TaloHapN, (TA,) which is the n. un. of TaloHN, (S,) or, accord. to Sb, the pl. of TaloHapN is TuluwHN, like as SuxuwrN is pl. of SaxorapN; and TilaAHN also; and the pl. of TaloHN is OaTolaAHN; (M;) [The acacia, or mimosa, gummifera; an appellation applicable also to the sanoT, which produces the gum-arabic: (see SamogN:) the former tree is termed by Forskål (Flora Ægypt. Arab. p. cxxiv.) “ mimosa gummifera; ” but it is more commonly termed an “ acacia: ” its pods are termed EulRafN, q. v.:] a species of large trees, (S, K,) of the kind called EiDaAhN; (S, Msb;) growing in El-Hijáz [and Egypt and Nubia and other countries]; the fruit of which is like that of the samurap; having curved thorns: the places in which it grows are the interiors of valleys; and it is that species of the EDAh which is the largest in its thorns, and the hardest in respect of its wood, and the best in respect of its gum: Lth describes it as above, and says that it is the same as the OumRu gayolaAna [and the like is said in the A]: ISh says that it is a tall tree, affording a shade in which men and camels repose, with few leaves, long and large branches, with many thorns, [more] than the prickles of the palm-tree, and a great trunk, which a man's arm cannot embrace; the same as the AmR gylAn; and grows in the mountains: AHn says that it is, of the trees called EDAh, the largest, and that which has most leaves, and the greenest, and has thick and long thorns, but these are of the least hurtful of thorns, producing no heat in the foot; it has a fruit (baramapN) of pleasant odour; and there is not among the trees called EDAh any that produces more gum than it, nor any more bulky; and it grows only in rugged, hard, fertile ground. (TA.) By TaloH in the Kur lvi. 28 may be meant the trees called AmR gylAn, because they have a blossom of a very pleasant odour. (Zj.) [But see below.]

TaloHN signifies also Banana-trees; syn. Xajaru Almawozi; and is said [by some] to have this meaning in the Kur lvi. 28: (Zj, T, TA:) or i. q. mawozN [which some expl. as meaning the trees above-mentioned; but others as meaning the fruit of those trees]: (Msb, K:) this, however, is said to be unknown in the [classical] language. (TA.)

And i. q. TaloEN [generally meaning The spadix of the palmtree; but sometimes the spathe thereof]: (K:) a dial. var. of the latter word: (S:) mentioned by ISk among words formed by the substitution of one letter for another: and this meaning, also, it is said [by some] to have in the Kur lvi. 28. (TA.)
And Remains of turbid water in a watering-trough or tank. (K.)
And Having the belly void of food. (K.)
See also TaliyHN.
TiloHN The tick; syn. quraAdN; (S, A, K;) sometimes applied thereto; (S;) as also TaliyHN↓: (S, K:) or a large tick. (TA. [See HamonaAnN.])

[Hence,] TiloHu maAlK (tropical:) One who keeps to camels, or cattle, and to the care of them, like as cleaves the TiloH, i. e. tick: (A:) a manager, tender, or superintendent, of camels, or cattle; or a good pastor thereof. (K.)
And TiloHu nisaMCi (tropical:) One who follows, or goes after, women (K, TA) much, or often. (TA.)

And TiloHN is also expl. as signifying A pastor fatigued, or wearied: (K, TA:) and [its pl.] TuluHN, as signifying [simply] pastors. (L.) El-Hotei-ah says, after mentioning certain camels and their pastors,

L.foreign: UicaA naAma TiloHN OaXoEavu AlrRaOosi xalofahaA

sense.s: When a pastor, dusty and shaggy or matted in the hair of the head, sleeps behind them, [and they become lost to him,] their breathing and their vehement respiration occasioned by the fulness of their bellies guides him to them, so that he finds them, even if they be distant. (S, * L.)
See also TaliyHN, in four places.
TalaHN (thus correctly written, not TaloHN as in [some of the copies of] the S, TA) Enjoyment of a life of ease and plenty. (S, K.)

TaliHN an epithet applied to a camel. (A.) You say UibilN TaliHapN and TalaAHaI [the latter being the pl.] Camels having a complaint (S, A, K) of
their bellies (S, K) from eating of the trees called TaloH: (S, A, K:) but [the meaning seems to be, from eating thereof immoderately, for] Aboo-Sa'eed disapproves of the phrase Abl TlAHI as meaning camels that have eaten of the TlH [and become disordered thereby, though it appears from what is said in art. EDh that camels are sometimes disordered by eating of any of the trees called EiDaAh], asserting it to signify camels that are fatigued, or wearied; for [he says that] the TlH do not disorder camels, but are wholesome food for them. (TA.) See also TaliyHN, in two places.
And OaroDN TaliHapN Land abounding with the trees called TaloH. (K.)
TaloHapN n. un. of TaloHN [q. v.]. (S.)
OumRu TaloHapu The louse. (TA.)
TaloHiyRapN meaning A piece of paper is a postclassical word. (K.)
TalaAHN, as an attribute of a man, (tropical:) Badness, corruptness, or viciousness: (A:) contr. of SalaAHN. (S, L, K.)

TaliyHN, (A, Mgh, Msb,) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Mgh, Msb,) Rendered lean, or emaciated, (A, Mgh, Msb,) applied to a camel; (A, Msb;) as also TaliHN↓, (A,) or TiloHN↓, (K,) and TaAliHN↓, so applied, by reason of fatigue, or of disease. (A.) Also, (S, Mgh, K,) applied to a camel, and TiloHN↓, (S, K,) the latter, (S, MF,) and the former likewise, (MF,) applied to the male and to the female of camels and of other animals, (S, MF,) and TaloHN↓, (K,) and TaliHN↓, (L, TA,) Fatigued: (S, Mgh, K, TA:) and in like manner, applied to a she-camel, TaliyHapN and TiloHapN↓, (K, in the CK TaloHpN,) but the forms commonly known of these two epithets thus applied are without p, because each has the signification of a pass. part. n., (MF,) and TaAliHN↓: (IAar, K:) the pls. are TulRaHN and TalaAYiHN, (S, K,) [both pls. of TaliyHN,] meaning fatigued, or jaded, and rendered lean, by travel, (S,) and TaloHaI, which last is [said by SM to be] anomalous, because [he holds that] it has the meaning of an act. part. n., [app. on the ground that some expl. TaliyHN as syn. with muEoIK and taEibN,] (TA,) and TuluHN is another pl., [app. of the second and third and fourth of the sings. mentioned above,] signifying fatigued: (L, TA;) and OaTolaAHN is pl. [of pauc.] of TiloHN. (S.) One says naAqapN TaliyHu OasofaArK meaning A she-camel jaded, and rendered lean, by journeys: (T, S:) and TaliyHu safarK, and safarK TaloHu↓. (IAar, TA.) raAkibu AlnRaAqapi TaliyHaAni means The rider of the she-camel and the she-camel are both fatigued, or jaded: (L, K:) for raAkibu AlnRaAqapi waAlnRaAqapu TaliyHaAni: or for raAkibu AlnaAqapi OaHadu AlTRalyHayoni. (L.)
See also TiloHN.

UibilN TilaAHiyRapN and TulaAHiyRapN, (S, K,) the latter anomalous, (S,) or the latter is a dial. var. of the former, which is not a rel. n. from the pl. TilaAHN, because, when a rel. n. is formed from a pl., the pl. is reduced to its sing. form, unless it is used as a name of a particular thing, (from a marginal note in copies of the S, [see also Ham pp. 791-2,]) Camels feeding upon the trees called TilaAH [or TaloH]. (S, K.)
TaAliHN: see TaliyHN, in two places.
Also, as an epithet applied to a man, (tropical:) Bad, corrupt, or vicious; (A, L;) in whom is no good: (L:) contr. of SaAliHN. (S, L.)
muTalRiHN (assumed tropical:) One who acts wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously, fiI AlmaAli [with respect to property, or camels, or cattle]. (Az, L.)

And, accord. to Az, One who breathes hard, or emits the voice with a moaning sound, fiI AlkalaAmi [in speaking]; syn. nahRaAtN [but the first letter in this word is written in the L without any diacritical point; so that the word may perhaps be bahRaAtN, meaning a great, or frequent, calumniator, slanderer, or false-accuser: see art. bht]. (L, TA.)

1. Talasahu, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
Talisa
, (K, MS, O, TA, but in a copy of the A,
Talusa
,) inf. n. TalosN; (S, M, A, K;) and TlRshu↓, (M, A, K,) inf. n. taToliysN; (A;) He obliterated it, or effaced it, namely, a writing; (S, O, K;) i. q. TarRasahu: (M:) or he obliterated it, or effaced it, namely a writing, [so far as] to mar, or spoil, its characters; thus differing from TrRshu, which signifies “ he obliterated it, or effaced it, well. ” (T, A.)
[Hence,] Talasa baSarahu (tropical:) He took away, or destroyed, his sight: (A, TA:) in the K [and O] Talasa baSaruhu his sight went away, or became destroyed; on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

Talisa, aor.
Talasa
, inf. n. TalasN, It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was, or became, old and worn-out. (IKtt.)

Talisa, aor.
Talasa
, inf. n. TalasN; and Talusa, aor.
Talusa
, inf. n. TulosapN; He, or it, was, or became, of a dusty colour, inclining to black. (IKtt: the inf. ns., only, are mentioned in the M.)
2: see above, first sentence.
5. tTlRs It (a writing) became obliterated, or effaced. (S.) [See also 7.]

tTlRs biTayolasaAnK, and taTayolasa↓, He clad, or attired, himself with a TayolasaAn. (M, TA.) [The former verb is used by El-Hemedhánee transitively, as meaning, He put on, or made use of, a napkin as a TylsAn: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., vol. iii., p. 90 of the Arabic text:) but perhaps this usage is only post-classical.]
7. AnTls Oavaruhu His trace, or track, or footsteps, became concealed, or unapparent: said of a beast: (Ibn-'Abbád, TS, O, TA:) Oamoruhu, in the copies of the K, is a mistake. (TA.) [See also 5.]
Q. Q. 2. taTayolasa: see 5.
TalosN Black; as also TayolasaAnN↓: (IAar, Az, TA:) accord. to the O and K, the former signifies a black TayolasaAn; but this is a mistake. (TA.)

TilosN i. q. TirosN: (S in art. Trs, M, Msb, TA:) i. e., (TA,) A written paper or the like; syn. SaHiyfapN: (K, TA:) or one of which the writing has been obliterated, or effaced, (A, K, TA,) but not well obliterated; thus differing from TirosN, accord. to the T: (TA:) pl. TuluwsN. (Msb, TA.) See TirosN.
Also The skin of the thigh of the camel (T, M, K) when the hair has fallen off. (T, K.)
See also OaTolasu, in three places.

TaliysN, of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (assumed tropical:) Having the eye blinded: in the O and K erroneously said to be TilRiys, like sikRiyt: but in the Tekmileh, correctly, Taliys, like Oamiyr. (TA.)
TalRaAsapN A piece of rag with which one wipes a tablet (A, K, TA) upon which is writing, and with which the writing is obliterated, or effaced. (A, TA.)
TayolasN: see TayolasaAnN.
TaAlasaAnN: see TayolasaAnN.

TayolasaAnN (El-Fárábee, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and TayolisaAnN, (M, O, K,) the latter form used by some, (El-Fárábee, Msb,) or by the vulgar, (S,) and disallowed by As, (M, Msb,) and TayolusaAnN, all these three forms being mentioned by 'Iyád and others, (K,) [accord. to the TA, following Lth; but the words of Lth, as cited in the TA, and in the O, rather signify that, if, instead of TayolisaAnN, with kesr to the l, one said TayolusaAnN, with damm to the l, like xayozuraAnN and HayosumaAnN, it would be more agreeable with analogy; and the like is said in the Msb, as on the authority of Az;] and TayolasN↓ (M, Mgh, O, K) and TaAlasaAnN↓; (M, TA;) arabicized words, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) from the Pers., (S, Msb,) originally taAlasaAno, (as in some copies of the K,) or taAlaXaAno; (as in other copies of the K, and in some copies of the T, and thus written by El-Urmawee, as is said in the TA, and thus written also in the Mgh;) differently expl. by different persons; (TA;) [app. accord. to the fashions of different times and countries;] accord. to some, (TA,) A certain kind of kisaMC: (M, TA:) or a certain article of apparel worn by the Eajam [Persians or other foreigners], (Mgh, Msb,) of a round form, and black; accord. to the “ Jema et-Tefáreek, ” having its woof and warp both of wool: (Mgh:) or a kisaMC, of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, (OaxoDar,) worn by persons of distinction: (EshShereeshee, in Har, p. 238:) [see also batRN, and saAjN: El-Makreezee mentions a kind of TylsAn
having a round piece cut out from the middle of it (muqawRarN) worn by the Egyptian Wezeer, and called, in his time, (the 14th and 15th centuries of our era,) TaroHapN: (see this word: and see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., ii. 267—269; and Dozy's Dict. des Noms des Vêtements chez les Arabes, 278—90:) it seems to have resembled our academic hood, of which it was perhaps the original: the term TylsAn is now commonly applied to an oblong piece of drapery, or a scarf, or an oblong shawl, worn in such a manner that one end hangs down upon the side of the bosom, the middle part being turned over the head and under the chin, and the other end being thrown over the shoulder, and hanging down upon the back: this is worn by many of the professional learned men in winter, in Arabian countries: it is also used in the sense of the word EacabapN, meaning an end of a turban, when made to hang down between the shoulders: see EacabN:] the pl. (of TayolasaAnN and TayolisaAnN and TayolasN, M) is TayaAlisapN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) in which the p is added because it is a foreign word, (S, M, K,) and TayaAlisu; (M, A;) or the latter is pl. of TayolasN: (TA:) I do not know (says ISd) any pl. of TaAlasaAnN: (M, TA:) it is not allowable to form an abbreviation of TayolisaAnN, with kesr to the l, as a compellation, because there is no instance of the measure fayoEilN, with kesr to the E, except in infirm words such as sayRidN and mayRitN. (S.) Hence the expression, (Mgh,) yaA Qbona AlTRayolasaAni, [lit., O son of the teylesán,] meaning, O 'Ajamee, (A, Mgh,) or Aajamee, (K,) [i. e., Persian, or foreigner,] used in reviling another; (Mgh, K;) for the Eajam are those who [most commonly] attire themselves with the TylsAn. (TA.)
See also TalosN.

OaTolasu Old and worn-out; (S, M, K;) applied to a garment, or piece of cloth: (M, K:) as also TilosN↓; pl. OaTolaAsN. (S.) You say, rajulN OaTolasu AlvRawobi A man whose garment is old and worn-out. (S.)
A dirhem [of which the impression is obliterated;] having no impression. (Msb, voce masiyHN.)

A wolf whose hair has fallen off by degrees; (Az, TA;) as also TilosN↓: (IAar, A, K:) or a wolf of a dusty colour inclining to blackness; (S, M, A, K;) and anything of that colour; (S, K;) whether a garment or any other thing: (TA:) fem. TalosaMCu: (M:) pl. TulosN. (A.)
A man having little hair upon the side of the cheek; pl. TulosN: or i. q. kawosajN [q. v.]: of the the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)
Dirty, or filthy; as also TilosN↓: (K:) the latter applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (K, TA,) in the colour of which is a dusty hue: (TA:) and TalosaMCu a dirty rag. (O.)
A man (tropical:) dirty, or filthy, in apparel: likened to a wolf in respect of the dusty hue of his clothes: (M:) or black and dirty. (O.)
[Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man who is accused of foul, or evil, conduct; (Sh, O, K;) and so OaTolasu AlvRawobayoni, an expression used by Ows Ibn- Hajar. (Sh, O.)
(tropical:) Black, as an Abyssinian and the like: (O, K:) as being likened in colour to a wolf. (TA.) [See also TalosN.]
(tropical:) A thief: (O, K:) because of his evil nature, (TA,) being likened to a wolf. (O, TA.)
[Satin; so called in the present day;] a garment, or piece of cloth, of woven silk: [app. because of its smoothness:] but this is not [of the classical] Arabic: pl. TulosN. (TA.)
falaku AlOaTolasi: see OaviyrN, last sentence.

Q. 1. Talosama He (a man) made his face to be displeasing, or odious; (M, L, TA;) he contracted it; or made it austere, or morose: and so Taromasa, and Talomasa, (L, TA,) and Tarosama. (TA in art. Tlms.)
And He (a man) bent down his head; or lowered his eyes, looking towards the ground; or was, or became, silent; syn. OaToraqa: and so Tarosama. (S in art. Trsm; and TA.)

[And, accord. to Golius, He receded, or drew back, from fight; followed by Eano: (one of the significations assigned in the K to Tarosama:) he mentions this as on the authority of J: perhaps he found it in a copy of the S in art. Trms (in which AlTRaromasapu is expl. as meaning AlAinoqibaADu and AlnRukuwSu), or in some other art. of that work in which I do not remember to have seen it.
Also He sculptured, engraved, or inscribed, a thing with talismanic devices or characters. And He charmed, or guarded, or preserved, by means of a talisman. See what follows.]

TilasomN, or, accord. to MF, TilRasomN, [also written TalisomN, and TilisomN, and TilRisomN, and TalosamN, and TalosimN, and TilosamN,] said by MF to be a Pers., or foreign, word; [perhaps from a late usage of the Greek τέλεσμα;] but [SM says] in my opinion it is Arabic; a name for A concealed secret; [i. e. a mystery: hence our word talisman: accord. to common modern usage, it signifies mystical devices or characters, astrological or of some other magical kind: and a seal, an image, or some other thing, upon which such devices, or characters, are engraved or inscribed; contrived for the purpose of preserving from enchantment or from a particular accident or from a variety of evils, or to protect a treasure with which it is deposited, or (generally by its being rubbed) to procure the presence and services of a Jinnee, &c.:] pl. TalaAsimu (TA) [and TilasomaAtN or TilRasomaAtN &c.].

1. TalaEati AlXRamosu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
TaluEa
[notwithstanding the faucial letter], (Msb, JM, TA,) inf. n.
