TuluwEN and maTolaEN and maToliEN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the second and third both used as inf. ns., and also as ns. of place [and of time], (S, O, K,) but the former of them is preferable on the ground of analogy as an inf. n., and the latter as a n. of place (Fr, O) or of time, (Zj, O,) The sun rose, (MA,) or appeared; (K;) and in like manner TalaEa is said of the moon, (TA,) and of a star, or an asterism; (S, O, K;) and so AiTRalaEa↓; (K;) [and OaTolaEa↓, for] OaTolaEati AlvRurayRaA means TalaEat [i. e. The Pleiades rose], as in a verse of El-Kumeyt [in which, however, the verb may, consistently with the metre, be a mistranscription for ATRalaEat]; (IB, TA); and OaTolaEa is syn. with TalaEa in the saying of Ru-beh,

[As though it, or he, were a star in the midst of clouds, that had risen]. (TA.) One says also, Mtiyka kulRa yawomK TalaEatohu AlXRamosu, meaning TalaEato fiyhi [i. e. I will come to thee every day in which the sun rises]: and it is said in a prayer, TalaEati AlXRamosu walaA taToluEu binafosi OaHadK minRaA [meaning The sun has risen, and may it not have risen with the soul of any one of us]; i. e., may not any one of us have died with its rising: the future being put in the place of the preterite. (TA.)

And TalaEa is said of anything that appears to one from the upper part [of a thing, or that comes up out of a thing and appears]. (Mgh, Msb.) It is said in the Ksh that AlTRuluwEu signifies The appearing by rising, or by becoming elevated. (TA.) One says, TalaEato sinRu AlSRabiIRi (tropical:) The tooth of the child showed its point. (K, TA.) And TalaEa AlzRaroEu, [aor.
TaluEa
,] inf. n. TuluwEN, (tropical:) The seed-produce began to come up, and showed its sprouting forth: (T, TA:) and AlzRaroEu OaTolaEa↓ (tropical:) The seed-produce appeared: (TA:) and nabotu AlOaroDi OaTolaEa↓ (assumed tropical:) The plants, or herbage, of the earth, or land, came forth: (Mgh:) and AlXRajaru OaTolaEa↓ (tropical:) The trees put forth their leaves. (TA.) And TalaEa AlnRaxolu, (O, K,) aor.
TaluEa
, inf. n. TuluwEN; (TA;) and (O, K) OaTolaEa↓; (Zj, S, Mgh, O, K;) or OaTolaEati AlnRaxolapu; (Msb;) (assumed tropical:) The palm-trees, or -tree, put forth the TaloE [q. v.]; (Zj, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also TlRE↓, (L, K, TA,) inf. n. taToliyEN. (L, TA. [These verbs, in this sense, are app. derived from the subst. TaloEN; but this is obviously from TalaEa.])

One says also, malaOotu lahu AlqadaHa HatRaI yakaAda yaToluEu mino nawaAHiyhi [I filled for him the drinking-vessel until it nearly overflowed from its sides]. (TA.) And AlmaMCu fiI AlUinaMCi taTalRaEa↓ (assumed tropical:) The water in the vessel poured forth [or overflowed] from its sides. (TA.)

And TalaEa Aljabala, (Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
TaluEa
, (TA,) inf. n. TuluwEN, (Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He ascended upon the mountain; (Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) the prep. [EalaI] being suppressed; (Mgh;) as also TaliEa, with kesr; (K;) and Aljabala AiTRalaEa↓ signifies the same as TalaEahu: (TA: [see also muDoTaliEN, in art. DlE:]) accord. to ISk, one says, TaliEotu Aljabala, with kesr, meaning (assumed tropical:) I ascended upon the mountain; (S, O;) but others
say, TalaEotu, with fet-h. (O.) And (tropical:) He ascended the mountain: (TA:) [or] TalaEotu fiI Aljabali means (assumed tropical:) I ascended the mountain. (Msb. [See also another explanation of this latter phrase in what follows.])

And TalaEa EalayonaA, aor.
TalaEa
and
TaluEa
; and AiTRalaEa↓; (assumed tropical:) He (a man) came to us; (K;) and came upon us suddenly, or at unawares: (TA:) and TalaEa Eanohumo he became absent, or absented himself, or departed, from them: (K:) or TalaEa EalaI Alqawomi he came forth upon the people, or party: and he looked upon them: (MA:) accord. to ISk, TalaEotu EalaI Alqawomi means I came to the people, or party: and TalaEotu Eanohumo I became absent, or absented myself, or departed, from them: (S, O:) and Ealayohimo OaTolaEotu↓ signifies the same as TalaEotu: (O:) and TalaEotu Eanohumo has the same meaning [also] as TalaEotu Eanohumo expl. above, accord. to ISk; EalaI being put in the place of En: accord. to AZ [likewise], TalaEotu EalaI Alqawomi, inf. n. TuluwEN, means I became absent from the people, or party, so that they did not see me: and also I advanced, or approached, towards them, so that they saw me: thus having two contr. meanings: and accord. to Az, the Arabs said, TalaEotu fiI Aljabali, inf. n. TuluwEN, as meaning I retired, or went back, into the mountain, so that my companion did not see me: [see another explanation of this phrase in what precedes:] and TalaEotu Eano SaAHibiI, inf. n. TuluwEN, I retired, or went back, from my companion: and TalaEotu Eano SaAHibiI [in which Eano seems to be evidently a mistranscription for EalaI] I advanced, or approached, towards my companion. (TA.) [In all of these phrases, TalaEa and TalaEotu may be correctly rendered He, and I, came forth, or went forth. And hence,] it is said in a prov., hecihi yamiynN qado TalaEato fiI AlmaxaArimi [expl. in art. xrm, voce maxorimN]. (AZ, TA.)
For another meaning of TalaEa followed by EalaI, see AiTRalaEa [which is more common as having that meaning].

TalaEa is also syn. with qaSada: so in the phrase TalaEa bilaAdahu (tropical:) [He tended, repaired, betook himself, or went, to, or towards, his country]: (K, TA:) and so in the saying, in a trad., hecaA busorN qado TalaEa Alyamana, (so in the O,) or hcA burRN, (so in the TA,) (tropical:) [These are ripening dates, or this is wheat, that have, or has, gone to, or towards, El-Yemen,] meaning from Nejd. (TA.)

And syn. with balaga; as also AiTRalaEa↓: (O, K:) so the former in the saying, TalaEa OaroDahumo (tropical:) [He reached, or arrived at, their land]; (K, TA;) and mataI TalaEota OaroDanaA (tropical:) [When didst thou reach, or arrive at, our land?]: (O, TA:) and so the latter verb in the saying, hecihi AlOaroDa ATRlE↓ [He reached, or arrived at, this land]: (O, K:) and hence, (TA,) EalaI AlOafoYidapi QlRatiI taTRaliEu↓, in the Kur [civ. 7], means (assumed tropical:) Whereof the pain shall reach the hearts: (Fr, O, TA:) or which shall rise above the hearts, (O, TA,) [or overwhelm them,] and burn them. (TA.)
2. TlRE said of the palm-tree: see 1, former half.
TlREhu, inf. n. taToliyEN, meaning He put it forth, or produced it, is a vulgar word. (TA.)
TlRE kayolahu, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He filled his measure. (O, K.)

3. TAlEhu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. muTaAlaEapN and TilaAEN, (K,) i. q. AiTRalaEa Ealayohi; (S, O, K;) i. e., a thing: (S, O:) Lth says that TilaAEN is syn. with AiTRilaAEN; but Az disapproves this: (O:) [the verb is correctly explained in what here follows:] one says, TaAlaEotu DayoEatiI, meaning naZarotuhaA waQTRalaEotu EalayohaA (tropical:) [I inspected, or considered with my eye, my estate, and obtained a knowledge of it, or acquainted myself with its condition]: (TA:) or muTaAlaEapN signifies the inspecting a thing well, in order to obtain a knowledge of it. (KL.) [Hence, muTaAlaEapu Alkutubi (assumed tropical:) The studying, and perusing, of books.]
See also the next paragraph, latter half, in three places.
4: see 1, former half, in five places.
ATlEt AlnRaxolapu signifies also (assumed tropical:) The palm-tree became tall. (Msb.)
And ATlE, also, (tropical:) He made his arrow to pass above the butt. (S, O, K, TA.)
And (tropical:) He vomited. (S, O, K, TA.)
And ATlEt AlsRamaMCu i. q. OaqolaEat [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The rain cleared away]. (TA.)
ATlE followed by EalaI: see 1, latter half:
and see also 8.
And ATlE as syn. with OaXorafa: see 8, in two places.
ATlE raOosahu (assumed tropical:) [He raised his head, looking at a thing; or] he looked at a thing from above; syn. OaXorafa EalaI XaIoCK. (TA.)

ATlEhu EalaI kacaA (assumed tropical:) He made him acquainted with such a thing; acquainted him with it, or made him to know it. (Msb.) UiTolaAEN signifies (assumed tropical:) The making to know, and to see. (KL.) For an ex. [of the latter meaning], in the pass. form of the verb, see 8. You say, ATlEhu EalaI sirRihi, (S, O, K, TA,) (tropical:) He made him to know, (TA,) or revealed, or showed, to him, (O, K, TA,) his secret. (O, K, TA.) [See also 8, last sentence.] And biHaqiyqapi AlOamori OanaA OuTaAliEuka↓ means OuToliEuka Ealayohi (tropical:) [I will acquaint thee with the truth of the case]. (TA.) And similar to this is the saying, bikutubika TaAliEoniI↓ (TA [and a similar phrase is mentioned without explanation in the S]) [meaning (assumed tropical:) Acquaint thou me with thy letters: and also, by means of thy letters; for] one of the meanings of muTaAlaEapN is The making one to know a thing by writing. (KL.) [And in like manner,] one says also, biAlHaAli TAlE↓, (O, K,) inf. n. muTaAlaEapN and TilaAEN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He showed, exhibited, or manifested, the case. (O, K.)
You say also, ATlE Uilayohi maEoruwfFA (assumed tropical:) He did to him, or conferred upon him, a benefit, benefaction, or favour. (O, K.)
And ATlE fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) He made such a one to hasten, or be quick. (O, K, TA.)
5. tTlRE (tropical:) It became full [to the top, or so as to overflow]; said of a measure for corn or the like. (O, K, TA.)
See also 1, former half.

And (assumed tropical:) He was proud, or self-conceited, [or lofty,] or was quick, with an affected inclining of his body from side to side, (zaAfa,) in his gait: (O:) or so tTlRE fiI miXoyatihi: (K:) app. syn. with tatalRaEa, meaning he advanced his neck, and raised his head. (TA.)

And (tropical:) He raised his eyes, looking [for a thing, or towards a thing]. (K, TA.) You say, tTlRE UilaI wuruwdihi (tropical:) He raised his eyes, looking for its, or his arrival. (K, TA.) And taTalRaEotu UilaI wuruwdi kitaAbika (S, O, TA) (tropical:) I raised my eyes, looking, (TA,) or I looked continually, (PS,) for the arrival of thy letter: (TA, PS:) or i. q. AinotaZarotu [agreeably with what here follows, and with an explanation of the inf. n. in the KL]. (PS.) And tTlRE UilaI liqaAYihi (assumed tropical:) He looked for the meeting him. (MA.) And [hence] one says, EaAfaI QllRehu rajulFA lamo yataTalRaEo fiI famika, meaning (tropical:) [May God preserve from disease, or harm, a man] who has not sought to find some slip, or fault, in thy speech: (O, K, TA:) mentioned by AZ, (O, TA,) and by Z. (TA.) [Hence likewise,] AltRaTalRuEu signifies also AlUiXoraAfu [as meaning (tropical:) The being eager, or vehemently eager, agreeably with what here follows]. (TA.) And AltRaTalRuEu UilaI AlXRaIoCi (tropical:) The inclining of the soul to the love of the thing, and the desiring it so that the man perishes. (TA.) And taTalRuEu AlnRafosi (assumed tropical:) The desiring, or yearning, or longing, of the soul. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. Sbr.]
tTlREhu (tropical:) He looked at him with a look of love or of hatred. (TA.)
And (tropical:) He overcame him, and overtook him; namely, a man. (TA.)
See also 6.
And see 8.
6. taTaAlaEatohu i. q. Taraqatohu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) She, or it, or they (referring to irrational things), came to him in the night]: Aboo-'Alee cites [as an ex.],

[Apparitions of Selmà come to me in the night, like as the creditor comes in the night to exact the debt]: but accord. to another, or others, it is only yataTalRaEu↓, because tafaAEala is generally intrans.: so that accord. to Aboo-'Alee, it is like tafaAwaDonaA AlHadiyva and taEaATayonaA AlkaOosa and tanaAXadonaA AlOaXoEaAra. (IB, TA.)
8. AiTRalaEa: see 1, first sentence:
and near the middle of the paragraph, in two places:
and last sentence, in three places.

Also (assumed tropical:) i. q. OaXorafa [meaning as expl. in the next sentence]; as also OaTalaEa↓, of the class of Oakorama. (Mgh.) One says, AiTRalaEotu mino fawoqi Aljabali and OaTolaEotu↓ (assumed tropical:) [I looked, or looked down, from above the mountain]. (TA.) And AiTRalaEotu Alfajora (tropical:) I looked at the dawn when it rose. (O, TA. *) And AiTRalaEotu Ealayohi (tropical:) I looked down, or from above, upon him, or it;
syn. OaXorafotu. (TA.) [Hence,] halo Oanotumo muTRaliEuwna faQTRalaEa, in the Kur [xxxvii. 52 and 53], means (assumed tropical:) Would ye [be of those who] look to see (tuHibRuwna Oano taTRaliEuwA) where is your place of abode among the people of Hell? and he (i. e. the Muslim) shall look (faQTRalaEa Almusolimu) and see his [former] associate in the midst of Hell-fire: but some read hl Antm muToliEuwna faOaToliEa↓ [in the CK fATRalaEa, but it is expressly said in the O that the hemzeh is with damm and the T quiescent and the l with kesr; the meaning being (assumed tropical:) Are ye of those who will make me to see? and he shall be made to see; as is indicated in the O and TA]. (K, O.)

And (assumed tropical:) He saw. (KL.) You say, ATRlE Ealayohi meaning (assumed tropical:) He saw it. (MA.) [Hence,] it is said in a prov., baEoda QTRilaAEK UiynaAsN (O, TA) i. e. (assumed tropical:) After appearance [or rather sight, is knowledge, or certain knowledge]. (Fr, TA in art. Ans. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 181.])

And ATRlE Ealayohi, (Msb, TA,) and ATRlEhu, and tTlREhu↓, and Elyh TalaEa↓, inf. n. TuluwEN, (K, TA,) and OaTolaEa↓ Elyh, (TA,) (tropical:) He got, or obtained, sight and knowledge of it: (Msb, TA: *) or [simply] he knew it; namely, an affair, or a case, or an event. (K, TA.) One says, ATRlE EalaI baATinihi, (K,) or ADRlE EalaI baATini Oamorihi, (S, O,) (tropical:) He became acquainted with, or obtained knowledge of, or knew, his inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances, or the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of his affair or case. (K, * TA.) And-accord. to some, AiTRilaAEu AlHijaAbi means (assumed tropical:) The stretching out the head [and looking over the veil of Paradise or of Hell]; for he who examines into a thing stretches out his head to see what is behind the veil, or covering. (TA voce HijaAbN, q. v.) [And one says also, ATRlE fiyhi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He looked into it: see an ex. voce hadara.]
AiTRalaEatohu EayoniI means (tropical:) My eye regarded him with contempt. (TA.)
[AiTRalaEa is used sometimes for AiDoTalaEa, as is shown in art. DlE: see muDoTaliEN: and see an instance in the first paragraph of art. Elw.]

And accord. to Kr, AiliA TRlaAEu signifies also AlnRajaApu. (TA. [But I think that both words are mistranscribed, and that Kr explained AlUiTolaAEu as meaning AlnRijaMCu, i. e. The acquainting with a secret.])

10. AstTlEhu signifies Talaba TuluwEahu (assumed tropical:) [He sought, or desired, its, or his, coming forth, or appearance]. (Har p. 47.) [And hence, (assumed tropical:) He sought, or desired, to elicit, or to discover, it: he sought, or desired, information respecting it, minohu of him: and he asked him to tell him a thing. (See Har pp. 134 and 82.)] You say, AstTlE raOoIa fulaAnK (S, O, K, TA) (tropical:) He looked to see what was the opinion, or advice, of such a one, (O, K, TA,) and what would be shown to him [thereof] respecting his affair, or case. (O, K.) It is doubly trans. [as shown above]: you say, AisotaTolaEotu zayodFA raOoyahu; as well as AstTlEt raOoIa zayodK. (Har p. 322.)
And (assumed tropical:) He took it away, or went away with it. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) You say, AstTlE maAlahu (assumed tropical:) He took away, or went away with, his property. (TA.)

TaloEN (assumed tropical:) The TaloE [i. e. spadix, or spadix in its spathe, and sometimes, the spathe alone,] of the palm-tree: (S, O:) the UigoriyD [or spadix] of the palm-tree, from over which the kaAfuwr [or spathe] bursts open longitudinally; or the flowers of the palm-tree, while in the kAfwr; (TA;) a thing that comes forth from the palm-tree, as though it were two soles, or sandals, closed together, with the Himol [meaning flowers] compactly disposed between them, and having the extremity pointed; or the vamarap [or produce] of the palm-tree, in the first stage of its appearance, the covering [or spathe] of which is called the kufurRaI (K, TA) and the kaAfuwr, (TA,) and what is within this the UigoriyD, because of its whiteness; (K, TA;) or the TaloE is what comes forth from the palm-tree and becomes dates if the tree is female; and if the tree is male it does not become dates, but is eaten in its fresh state, or is left upon the palm-tree a certain number of days until there becomes produced in it a white substance like flour, [i. e. the pollen,] having a strong odour, and with this the female is fecundated; (Msb;) or a certain white thing that appears from the kimR [or spathe] of the palm-tree, to the colour of which [that of] the teeth are likened, and to the odour thereof [that of] the sperma: and also, [sometimes,] the kimR [or spathe] that comes forth from the palm-tree, before it bursts open longitudinally: [and this is also called the kufurRaI, for] the phrase TaloEu AlkufuzRaI is an instance of the prefixing of a noun to an explicative thereof: (Mgh:) [or this phrase may mean the spadix of the spathe of a palm-tree: TaloEN, it should be added, is sometimes used as a coll. gen. n.: and its n. un. is with p: thus in explanations of UigoriyDN &c.] In the Kur xxxvii. 63, it is applied to (tropical:) The fruit, or produce, of the tree called AlzRaqRuwm, in the bottom of Hell, metaphorically, because partaking of the form of the TlE of dates, or because coming forth from the tree. (Bd.)
Also (assumed tropical:) i. q. miqodaArN [as meaning Number, or quantity]: (K, TA:) so in the phrase AljayoXu TaloEu OalofK [The army consists of the number of a thousand]. (K, * TA).
See also the next paragraph, in three places.

TiloEN (tropical:) a subst. from AlAiTRilaAEu: [meaning Knowledge:] whence the saying, AiTRalaEa TiloEa AlEaduwRi (tropical:) [He learned the knowledge of the enemy; meaning he obtained knowledge of the state, or case, or tidings, or of the secret, or of the inward, or intrinsic, or secret, state or circumstances, of the enemy]; (S, O, K, TA;) [for] TiloEa AlEaduwRi means xabarahu, (Msb,) or sirRahu, (PS,) or baATina Oamorihimo: (Har p. 82:) and [hence also] one says, OaTolaEotuhu TiloEa OamoriI, meaning (tropical:) I revealed, or showed, to him my secret. (O, K, TA.)

Also (assumed tropical:) An elevated place, above what is around it, from which one looks down (yuTRalaEu [in the CK erroneously yuTolaEu]); as also TaloEN↓. (K, TA.) You say, Ealawotu TiloEa AlOakamapi, meaning (assumed tropical:) I ascended upon a part of the hill from which I overlooked what was around it. (IDrd, O, TA.)

And (assumed tropical:) i. q. naAHiyapN [A side, or an adjacent tract, or a region, &c.]; as also TaloEN↓. (K.) One says, kuno biTiloEi AlwaAdiI and TaloEi↓ AlwAdI [i. e. biTaloEi AlwAdI also, meaning, as is indicated in the TA, (assumed tropical:) Be thou in the side, &c., of the valley]: (S, O:) and one says also, fulaAnN TiloE AlwaAdiI, without b [(assumed tropical:) Such a one is in the side, &c., of the valley]. (O.)

And (assumed tropical:) Any depressed piece of ground: or such as has in it a hill: (K:) [i. e.,] as expl. by As, any depressed piece of ground having in it a hill from which, when you ascend upon it, you see what is in it. (O.)
Also the serpent: (AA, O, K:) like TilRN. (TA.)

TaliEN (tropical:) [Desirous, eager, or vehemently eager]. nafosN TaliEapN and nufuwsN TaliEapN, like fariHapN [in form], mean (tropical:) A soul, and souls, desirous, eager, or vehemently eager. (TA.) [See also TulaEapN.]

TaloEapN (tropical:) The aspect; or countenance; syn. ruWoyapN: (S, O, K, TA:) or person and aspect: (L, TA:) or face: (K:) so in the saying, HayRaA QllRehu TaloEatahu (tropical:) [May God preserve his aspect, &c.]. (O, K.)

nafosN TulaEapN, means nafosN tukoviru AltRaTalRuEa lilXRaIoCi, (S, O,) or UilaI AlXRaIoCi, (K, TA,) i. e. (tropical:) A soul that inclines much to the love of the thing [that it would obtain], and desires it so that the man perishes: and TulaEapN is used also as applied to a pl., so that one says also nufuwsN TulaEapN, (TA,) or OanofusN TulaEapN, meaning souls eager, or vehemently eager, for the objects of their love and appetence. (O.) [See also TaliEN.] And in like manner one says AimoraOahN TulaEapN, (S,) or AimoraOapN TulaEapN xubaOapN: (TA:) or this latter means (tropical:) A woman that comes forth (taToluEu [in the CK erroneously taTRaliEu]) at one time (marRapF [omitted in the CK]) and conceals herself at another: (O, K, TA:) and in like manner one says AmrOp TulaEapN qubaEapN. (TA.)
TulaEaMCu, (S, O, K,) like gulawaMCu [in form], (S, O,) (tropical:) Vomit: (S, O, K, TA;) as also TawolaEN↓: (IAar, O, K:) or the former signifies a little vomit. (K voce qanasN.)
TalaAEN, like saHaAbN [in form], the subst. from AlATlAE [app. AlUiTolaAEu, i. e. a subst. syn. with UiTolaAEN; like as SalaAH is with UiSolaAHN, and fasaAdN with UifosaAdN]. (TA.)

TilaAEN (tropical:) A thing sufficient in quantity, or dimensions, for the filling of another thing, (S, O, K, TA,) accord. to A 'Obeyd, so as to overflow [an addition not always agreeable with usage]: (TA:) pl. TuloEN. (K.) TilaAEu AlOaroDi cahabFA means
(tropical:) What would suffice for the filling of the earth, of gold: (As, S, O, TA:) or, accord. to Lth, what the sun has risen, or appeared, upon, to which Er-Rághib adds and man. (TA.) And you say qawosN TilaAEu AlkafRi (tropical:) A bow of which the part that is grasped is sufficient in. size for the filling of the hand. (S, * O, * TA.) And hecaA TilaAEu hecaA (assumed tropical:) This is of the quantity, or measure, or size, of this. (TA.)
TaluwEN (assumed tropical:) Aspiring to, or seeking the means of attaining, lofty things, or eminence. (Ham p. 655.)

TaliyEapN, of an army, (assumed tropical:) [A scout; and a party of scouts;] a man, (S, O, K, TA,) and a party of men, (O, K, TA,) that is sent, (S, O, K, TA,) and goes forth, (TA,) to obtain knowledge of the state, or case, or tidings, or of the secret, or of the inward, or intrinsic, or secret, state or circumstances, of the enemy, (liyaTRaliEa TiloEa AlEaduwRi, S, O, K, TA,) like the jaAsuws; (TA;) a man, (Mgh,) or a party of men, (Mgh, Msb,) sent (Mgh, Msb) before another party (Msb) to acquaint himself, or themselves, with the tidings, or state, or case, of the enemy; (Mgh, Msb;) accord. to the 'Eyn, applied to a single man, and to a number of men when they are together; and as used by [the Hanafee Imám] Mohammad, three, and four; more than these being termed sariyRapN: (Mgh:) pl. TalaAYiEu. (Mgh, O, Msb, O, Msb, K.)

TalRaAEu AlvRanaAyaA and TalRaAEu AlOanojudi (tropical:) [lit. A man wont to ascend mountain-roads; meaning] a man experienced in affairs; wont to surmount them by his knowledge and his experience and his good judgment: or who aspires to lofty things, or the means of attaining eminence: (O, K, TA: [see also vaniyRapN:]) OanojudN being pl. of najodN; which means “ a road in a mountain, ” like vaniyRapN [of which vanaAyaA is the pl.]. (TA.) An ex. of the former phrase is presented by a verse of Soheym Ibn-Wetheel cited in art. jlw: and an ex. of the latter by the saying of Mohammad Ibn-AbeeShihádh Ed-Dabbee, said by ISk to be of Ráshid Ibn-Dirwás,

L.foreign: waqado yaqoSuru AlqulRu AlfataI duwna hamRihi
waqado kaAna lawolaA AlqulRu TalRaAEa Oanojudi

sense.s: [Certainly, or sometimes, or often, poverty withholds the young man from attaining his purpose; and certainly, or sometimes, or often, but for poverty, he would be a surmounter of affairs by his knowledge &c.]. (O, TA.)
qadaHN TalRaAEN (tropical:) A full drinking-vessel. (TA.) And EayonN TalRaAEN [or TalRaAEapN?] (tropical:) An eye filled with tears. (TA.)

TaAliEN [Rising, or appearing, as a star &c.:] anything appearing from the upper part [of a thing, or that comes up out of a thing and appears]: (TA:) [or appearing by rising, or by becoming elevated. (See 1.)]
[Hence,] one says, TaAliEuhu saEiydN, meaning His star [is fortunate]. (TA.)
[Hence also,] AlTRaAliEu means The false dawn: (S:) or so AlTRaAliEu AlmuSoEidu. (O.)

And The hilaAl [or moon when near the sun, showing a narrow rim of light; probably the new moon, from the sight of which the commencement of the month was reckoned; as appears from what follows]. (O, K.) maA raOayotuka munocu TaAliEayoni is mentioned as heard from some of the Arabs of the desert, meaning munocu Xahorayoni [i. e. I have not seen thee for two months, or during the period since two new moons]. (O.)

Also The arrow that falls behind the butt: (Az, O, K:) or that passes beyond the butt, going over it: (TA:) and Kt says that they used to reckon that falling above the mark as that which hit the butt: pl. TawaAliEu. (O, TA.) It is said of one of the kings, accord. to Sgh, [in the O,] kaAna yasojudu lilTRaAliEi, (TA,) meaning as expl. in art. sjd: (O, TA: *) or it may mean that he used to lower himself, or bend himself down, to the rising hilaAl, by way of magnifying God. (O, TA.)
TaAliEapu AlUibili means (assumed tropical:) The first, or foremost, of the camels. (TA.)
TawolaEN: see TulaEaMCu.

maTolaEN and maToliEN are inf. ns.: and signify also The place [and the time] of rising of the sun [&c.]: (S, O, K: [see 1, first sentence:]) but by Fr the former is explained as meaning the rising, and the latter as meaning the place of rising: and some of the Basrees say that when one reads HatRaI maToliEi Alfajori [in the last verse of ch. xcvii. of the Kur], with kesr to the l, the meaning is, [until] the time of rising [of the dawn]: (O, TA:) [the pl.] maTaAliEu signifies the places [and the times] of rising of the sun [&c.]. (TA.)

maTolaEu Aljabali means (assumed tropical:) The place of ascent of the mountain. (TA.) And you say, hecaA laka maTolaEa AlOakamapi, meaning (assumed tropical:) This is present before thee; i. e. as near to thee as if thou hadst to ascend for it the hill. (TA.)
maTolaEu AlqaSiydapi means (tropical:) The beginning of the qSydp [or ode]. (TA.)
See also muTRalaEN.
muToliEN (assumed tropical:) A palm-tree (naxolapN) putting forth its TaloE [q. v.]; and sometimes they said muToliEapN. (Msb.)
And the latter, (assumed tropical:) A palm-tree taller than the other palm-trees [around it or adjacent to it]. (S, O, K.)

muTRalaEN (assumed tropical:) [A place to which one ascends: or] a place of ascent from a low spot to a place that overlooks. (As, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad. (O, K) of the Prophet, (O,) maAnazala mina AlquroMni MyapN UilRaA lahaA ZahorN wabaTonN walikulRi HarofK HadRN walikulRi HadRK muTRalaEN i. e. (O, K) (assumed tropical:) Not a verse of the Kur-án has come down but it has an apparent and known [or exoteric] interpretation and an intrinsic [or esoteric] interpretation, (TA voce ZahorN, where see more,) [and every word has a scope, and every scope has] a place [meaning point] to which the knowledge thereof may ascend, (O, K, TA,) or, as some say, something that may be violated, God not having forbidden a thing that should be held sacred without his knowing that some one would seek to elicit it. (TA.)

And i. q. maOotFI; (S, O, K, TA;) muTRalaEu AlOamori meaning maOotaAhu; (S, O, TA;) as also AlOamori maTolaEu↓; (TA;) i. e. (assumed tropical:) The way, or manner, of attaining to the doing, or performing, of the affair. (TA.) One says, maAlihecaA AlOamori muTRalaEN (assumed tropical:) There is no way, or manner, of attaining to the doing, or performing, of this affair. (TA.) And Oayona muTRalaEu hecaA AlOamori i. e. maOotaAhu (assumed tropical:) [Where is the way of attaining to the doing, or performing, of this affair?]. (S, O, TA.)

And (tropical:) An elevated place from which one looks towards a low place. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) To this is likened the scene of the events of the world to come, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) after death, i. e. the station of the day of resurrection, (TA,) in the saying of 'Omar, lawo OanRa maA fiI AlOaroDi jamiyEFA laOafotadayotu bihi mino hawoli AlmuTRalaEi (tropical:) [If all that is in the world belonged to me, assuredly I would ransom myself therewith from the terror of the place whence one will look down on the day of resurrection]: (S, * O, Msb, * K, * TA:) or AlmuTRalaE means that which is looked upon of such hardships as the interrogation of [the angels] Munkar and Nekeer, and the pressure of the grave, and its solitude, and the like; and is [for AlmuTRalaEi Ealayohi, or] originally an inf. n. in the sense of AlAiTRilaAE: or it may be a noun of time, and thus applied to the day of resurrection. (Har p. 344-5.)

muTRaliEN Strong, or powerful; high, or eminent; one who subdues, or overcomes: (K:) or strong, or powerful; as also muDoTaliEN: or the latter has this meaning, from AlDRalaAEapu; and the former signifies high, or eminent; one who subdues, or overcomes: (O:) accord. to ISk, one says, huwa muDoTaliEN biHamolihi [“ he is one who has strength to bear it ”]; but not muTRaliEN bHmlh. (TA.) [See, however, muDoTaliEN, in art. DlE.]

muTaAlaEN [pass. part. n. of 3, q. v.]. One says, AlXr tlqI muTaAlaEa AlAisomi, [thus in my original, app. AlXRarRa taloqaI Alx,] meaning baArizFA makoXuwfFA [i. e., if I rightly read it, (assumed tropical:) Evil thou wilt find to be that whereof the name is manifest, or overt; so that, when it is mentioned, it is well known]. (TA.)

2. TlRf Ealayohi, inf. n. taToliyfN; (O, K;) and ZlRf is a dial. var. thereof; (TA;) He exceeded it; (O, K;) [meaning a certain number of years; for] it is like carRafa and ramRava and TalRava. (IAar, TA in art. Zlf.)
4. ATlf [He escaped being a victim of his adversary's blood-revenge; expl. as meaning] the blood-revenge of his adversary was ineffectual, or had not effect. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

ATlfhu He made it [i. e. a man's blood] to go for nothing
[i. e. unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct]; or to be of no account. (S, O, K.)
And He gave him (S, O, K) a thing (O) as a free gift. (S, O, K.)
TalofN: see the next paragraph in two places.

TalafN A thing that goes for nothing; [as blood that is unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct;] that is of no account, ineffectual, or null; syn. hadarN; (S, O, K;) [and so TalofN↓, as shown by what follows;] as also TaliyfN↓. (O, K.) You say, cahaba damuhu TalafFA, (AA, S, O, K,) and TalofFA↓, (AA, O, K,) and ZalafFA and ZalofFA, (AA, O,) His blood went for nothing; as a thing of no account; ineffectually; or in vain; unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; syn. hadarFA, (AA, S, O, K, TA,) and baATilFA: and in like manner, maAluhu [his property]. (TA. [See also talafN.]) And Ru-beh says,
[How many enemies are there whose possessions are things that have gone for nought!]. (O, as an ex. of the last word in the sense of hadar.)
And (S, O, K) hence (O) A gift; (S, O, K;) a gift freely bestowed, not for any compensation. (S, TA.)
And A thing that is easy; or of light estimation, paltry, or despicable; [as also ZalafN;] syn. hayRinN. (IF, O, K.)
And A redundant portion of a thing: (IF, O, K:) if this be not what is meant by the saying that TalafN is syn. with faDolN, this saying is of no account. (IF, O.)
TaliyfN: see TalafN, in two places.
Also A thing that is taken. (O, K. *) [And hence, perhaps, the saying of Ru-beh cited above.]
One says also, cahaba fulaAnN biAlmaAli TaliyfFA and ZaliyfFA i. e. Such a one went away with the property without compensation. (Yoo, O.)
And Oakala maAlahu fiI Taliyf He devoured his property in a vain, or an ineffectual, procedure. (O.)

1. Talaqati AlnRaAqapu, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
Taluqa
, inf. n. TuluwqN, (Msb,) The she-camel was, or became, loosed from her bond, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or cord, by which her fore shank and her arm had been bound together. (S, Mgh.) And Talaqati AlnRaAqapu UilaI AlmaMCi [The she-camel was, or became, loosed from her bond to repair to the water]: (Msb:) or Talaqati AlUibilu (AZ, As, S, TA) UilaI AlmaMCi, (AZ, TA,) aor. as above, (As, TA,) inf. n. TaloqN (AZ, As, S, TA) and TuluwqN, (AZ, S, TA,) the camels were, or became, loosed to repair to the water, it being distant two days' journeys, (AZ, As, S, TA,) and were left to pasture while going thither: and the subst. is TalaqN [q. v.]. (AZ, S, TA.)

[Hence,] Talaqato, (IAar, Th, S, Mgh, O, Msb,) or Talaqato mino zawojihaA, (K,) aor.
Taluqa
; (Th, S, O, Msb, K;) and Taluqato also; (IAar, Th, Mgh, Msb;) the latter of which is preferable, but the former is allowable; (IAar, TA;) or the latter is the more common; (Th, TA;) but accord. to to Akh, the latter is not allowable; (S, O, TA;) inf. n. TalaAqN, (Th, S, Mgh, O, K,) or [properly TaloqN, for it is said that] TalaAqN is the subst., (Msb,) [or] TalaAqN is also a subst. syn. with taToliyqN, [as will be expl. below,] as well as inf. n. of Taluqato and Talaqato;) (Mgh;) said of a woman; (IAar, Th, S, &c.;) (tropical:) She was, or became, [divorced, or] left to go her way, (O,) or separated from her husband [by a sentence of divorce]. (K, TA.)
And Taluqa lisaAnuhu, inf. n. TuluwqN and TuluwqapN, (assumed tropical:) His tongue was, or became, eloquent, or chaste in speech, and sweet therein. (Msb. [See also TaloqN: and see 7.])

And Taluqa, (S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. TalaAqapN, (S, O,) or TuluwqapN and TuluwqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He was, or became, laughing, or happy, or cheerful, and bright, (K, TA,) in face, or countenance: (S, O, K, TA:) or, inf. n. TalaAqapN, (assumed tropical:) it (the face, or countenance,) was, or became, cheerful, or happy, (MA, Msb,) the contr. of frowning or contracted, (Mgh,) displaying openness and pleasantness; (Msb;) and tTlRq↓ signifies the same; (MA, Mgh;) as also AnTlq↓; (Mgh;) syn. AnbsT; (K;) whence the saying, yanobagiI liloqaADiI Oano yunoSifa AlxaSomayoni walaA yanoTaliqu↓ bwajohihi UilaI OaHadihimaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) [It behooves the judge to treat with equity the two adversaries in litigation, and] he shall not speak to one of them with a cheerful countenance (biwajohK TaloqK) and with sweet speech, not doing this to the other: or it may be from AlAinoTilaAqu signifying “ the going away, ” and may hence mean, and he shall not turn his face, or pay regard, to one of them [in preference to the other]. (Mgh.)

And Taluqa, inf. n. TuluwqapN and TalaAqapN, said of a day, (tropical:) It was, or became, such as is termed TaloqN; i. e. [temperate,] neither hot nor cold; [&c.; see TaloqN;] and in like manner Taluqat is said of a night (layolap). (K, TA.)
Taliqa, (O, K,) with kesr, (O,) like samiEa, (K,) signifies tabaAEida [He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote; &c.]. (O, K.)
TaloqN is also trans., syn. with OaTolaqa: see the latter verb, former half, in two places.

[Hence,] Tuliqato, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. tuTolaqu, (S,) inf. n. TaloqN, (S, Mgh, * O, * Msb, K,) and inf. n. un. TaloqapN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) She (a woman, S, O, Msb) was taken with the pains of parturition: (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) a phrase implying a presage of good [i. e. of speedy and safe delivery]. (Mgh.) [And Tuliqato bihi (assumed tropical:) She was, or became, in labour with him.]
2. TlRq naAqatahu He left, left alone, or let go, his she-camel. (TA.) See also 4, second sentence.

[Hence,] TlRq QmoraOatahu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taToliyqN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) from TalaAqN [q. v.]; (O;) and ATlqhA↓, (K,) inf. n. UiTolaAqN; (TA;) (tropical:) [He divorced his wife;] he separated his wife from himself [by a sentence of divorce]. (K, TA.) [TlRq in this sense is opposed to raAjaEa: and hence the meanings of these two verbs in a verse of En-Nábighah which I have cited in art. ncr, (see conj. 6 in that art.,) and which is also cited in the S and O and TA in the present art.]

And TlRq AlbilaAda (tropical:) He left, or quitted, the country. (IAar, TA.) El-'Okeylee, being asked by Ks, OaTalRaqota QmoraOataka [Hast thou quitted thy wife?], answered, naEamo waAlOaroDa mino waraAYihaA (assumed tropical:) [Yes, and the land behind her]. (IAar, TA.) And one says, TalRaqotu Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) I left, or quitted, the people, or party: and TlRq AlEiyaAla (assumed tropical:) He left [or deserted] the household, like as the man leaves [or divorces] the woman, or wife. (TA.) And TlRq AlEayoru EaAnatahu (assumed tropical:) The he-ass passed by, or beyond, his she-ass, and then left her: and TalRaqatohu AlEaAnapu (assumed tropical:) The she-ass submitted herself [the verb which I thus render has been altered to Anqdt, for which I read QnoqaAdato,] to him, after having been incompliant. (TA.)

And TulRiqa AlsRaliymu (assumed tropical:) The person bitten by a serpent became rid of the pain: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or recovered himself, and his pain became allayed, (S, O, K,) after the paroxysm: (S, O:) inf. n. as above. (K.)
TalRaqa naxolahu: see 4, last sentence.

4. AlUiTolaAqu signifies The loosing, or setting loose or free, and letting go. (TA.) You say, ATlq AlnRaAqapa mino EiqaAlihaA, (S, O, Msb, TA,) or mina AlEiqaAli, i. e. He loosed the she-camel from the bond, or cord, by which her fore shank and arm were bound together; (Mgh;) as also TlRqhA↓. (TA.) And ATlq AlOasiyra, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA,) and ATlq Eanohu, (O, TA,) He let go the captive; (S, O, K, TA;) and set him free; (TA;) he loosed the bond of the captive, and let him go: (Mgh, Msb:) and OuToliqa Eanohu UisaAruhu [His bond was loosed from him], namely, the captive. (S.) And ATlq xayolahu fiI AlHalobapi He made his horses to run [in the race-ground]. (TA.) And ATlq AlnRaAqapa He drove the she-camel to the water: (TA:) or OaTolaqotu AlnRaAqapa UilaI AlmaMCi [I loosed the she-camel from her bond to repair to the water]: (Msb:) or OaTolaqotu AlUibila (AZ, S, O, TA) UilaI AlmaMCi (AZ, S, * TA) I loosed the camels to repair to the water, it being distant two days' journeys, and left them to pasture while going thither. (AZ, S, O, * TA.) And ATlq Alqawomu means The people, or party, had their camels loosed to repair to the water, it being distant two days' journeys, and the camels being left to pasture while going thither. (S, K, * TA.)
ATlq QmoraOatahu: see 2, third sentence.
ATlq AldRawaMCu baTonahu The medicine loosened, or relaxed, his belly [or bowels]; (Msb;) or moved his belly. (TA.)

[ATlq EinaAnahu He let loose, or slackened, his (a horse's) rein; and so (assumed tropical:) made him to quicken his pace. (See Har p. 356.)] And ATlq rijolahu (assumed tropical:) He hastened him; or desired, or required, him to hasten, or be quick; as also AstTlqhu↓. (TA. [Whether the pronoun relate to a beast or a man is not shown. By AstTlqh is not meant AstTlq rijolahu as rijol is fem.])

ATlq yadahu bixayori (S, O,
K, TA) and fiI xayorK, and bimaAlK and fiI maAlK; (TA;) and TalaqahaA↓, (S, O, K,) aor.
Taluqa
, (S,) or
Taliqa
, (K,) but expressly said in the S to be with damm, inf. n. TaloqN; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) He opened his hand [freely] with good, (K, TA,) and with property. (TA.) And ATlq lahu maAlFA (assumed tropical:) He gave him property: (MA:) and Talaqa↓ (assumed tropical:) he gave (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) a thing. (K.) And ATlq SaAHibu AldRayoni kacaM (assumed tropical:) [The creditor remitted so much of the debt; being asked, or desired, to do so: see 10]. (Msb.)

[ATlqh also signifies (assumed tropical:) He made it allowable, or free, to be done, or taken, &c.] You say, ATlq lahu fiEola kacaA (assumed tropical:) He permitted him, or gave him permission or leave, to do such a thing; i. q. Oacina lahu fiyhi. (Msb in art. Acn.)

[And (assumed tropical:) He made it to be unrestricted. Hence the saying, ATlq bihimu AlsRayofa (assumed tropical:) He made the sword to have unrestricted scope with them; i. e. he slew them without restriction.] And OaTolaqotu AlbayRinapa (assumed tropical:) I made the evidence, proof, or voucher, to be without any mention of the date; contr. of OarRaxotuhaA; (Msb in art. Arx;) or I gave the evidence without restricting it by a date: from OaTolaqotu AlOasiyra. (Msb in the present art.) And hence also OaTolaqotu Alqawola (assumed tropical:) I made the saying to be unrestricted, and unconditional. (Msb.) [And ATlq lafoZFA (assumed tropical:) He uttered, or mentioned, or used, a word, or an expression, without restriction: and in like manner, ATlq alone is often employed. And (assumed tropical:) He used, or applied, a word, or an expression, without restriction, EalaI maEonFI to signify a particular meaning: thus in the saying ATlq AlmaSodara EalaI AlfaAEili (assumed tropical:) He used, or applied, the infinitive noun without restricting it by the prefix cuw, or the like, to signify the active participial noun; as EadolFA to signify EaAdilFA: and thus in the saying ATlq Qsoma EalaI AljuzoCi (assumed tropical:) He used, or applied, the name of the whole without restricting it by a prefix to signify the part; as AlquroMn to signify AllMyap: and many similar exs. might be added: but this usage of the verb is conventional: see Kull p. 57. Hence also Oalifu AlUiTolaAqi: see art. A, p. 1, col. 3.]

AlUiTolaAqu fiI AlqaAYimapi [in which AlATlAq is inf. n. of the pass. v., OuToliqa,] is (assumed tropical:) The freedom from [the whiteness termed] waDaH [meaning taHojiyl, q. v.,] in the leg [of a horse]: and some make AlUiTolaAq to signify the having a fore leg and a hind leg in one side with tHjyl; and AlUimosaAku [as inf. n. of Oumosika], the having a fore leg and a hind leg without tHjyl. (TA.)
ATlq EaduwRahu (assumed tropical:) He dosed his enemy with poison. (IAar, O, K.)
And ATlq nxolahu (tropical:) He fecundated his palm-trees; (IAar, O, K, TA;) said when they are tall; (IAar, O, TA;) as also TlRqhu↓, (IAar, O, K,) inf. n. taToliyqN. (K.)

5. tTlRq, said of a gazelle, He went along, (S, O, Msb, K,) or bounded in his running, or ran briskly in one direction, (AisotanRa fiI Eadowihi,) and went along, (TA,) not pausing nor waiting for anything; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) as also AstTlq↓. (TA.) And tTlRqt Alxayolu The horses went [or ran] a heat without restraining themselves, to the goal. (TA.)
And, said of a horse, (tropical:) He staled after running. (AO, O, K.)
Said of the face: see 1, latter half.

7. AnTlq, inf. n. AinoTilaAqN, of which the dim. is nuTayoliyqN↓, the conjunctive A being rejected, so that it becomes niTolaAqN, (S, O,) [He was, or became, loosed from his bond: whence,] AinoTilaAqu AlEinaAni [The rein's being let loose, or slackened,] is a phrase metonymically used to denote quickness in going along. (Har pp. 355-6.)

[Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He (a captive loosed from his bond) went his way: (Msb:) or [simply] he went away, or departed: (S, Mgh, O, K:) or he went removing from his place. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Thus in the Kur [lxxvii. 29], AinoTaliquwA UilI maA kunotumo bihi tukacRibuwna (assumed tropical:) [Depart ye to that in which ye disbelieved]; (TA;) meaning to the punishment: (Bd, Jel:) or, accord. to IAth, [it seems to mean go ye away quickly into the lowest depth of misery or affliction; for he says, app. in explanation of this verse of the Kur, that] AlAinoTilaAqu means suroEapu AlcRahaAbi fiI OaSoli AlmiHonapi. (TA.) And one says also, AnTlq yafoEalu kacaA (tropical:) He went away doing, or to do, such a thing. (TA.) waQnoTalaqa QlomalaOu minohumo Oani QmoXuwA [in the Kur xxxviii. 5 may be expl. in a similar manner; Oan being here used in the place of yaquwluwna: or this] means [And the chief persons of them] broke forth, or launched forth, with their tongues, [saying,] Go ye on, or continue ye, in your course of action &c. (Mughnee, voce Oano.) And one says, AunoTuliqa bihi, (S, O, K,) meaning He, or it, was taken away; (K;) like as one says, AunoquTiEa bihi. (S, O.)
[AnTlq lisaAnuhu means (assumed tropical:) His tongue was, or became, free from impediment; and hence, eloquent, or chaste in speech. See an ex. in the Kur xxvi. 12: and see also Taluqa lisaAnuhu.]
AnTlq said of the face: see 1, latter half, in two places.

8. maA taTRaliqu nafosiI lihecaA AlOamori, (S, O, K, *) of the measure tafotaEilu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. AiTRilaAqN, of which the dim. is TutayoliyqN↓, the [latter] T being changed [back] into t because the former T becomes movent, (S, O,) (assumed tropical:) My mind does not become free from straitness [for, or with respect to, this thing, or affair]. (S, O, K. *)
10. AisotiTlaAqN [primarily signifies The desiring to be loosed, unbound, set loose or free, and let go]: its dim. is tuTayoliyqN↓. (S, O.)
[Hence,] AstTlq baTonuhu (assumed tropical:) His belly [or bowels] became [unbound,] loosened, or relaxed; (Msb, TA;) or became moved; (S, O, K, TA;) and the contents thereof came forth. (TA.)
Said of a gazelle, i. q. tTlRq, q. v. (TA.)
[It is also trans., as such primarily signifying The desiring a person or thing to be loosed, unbound, set loose or free, and let go.

Hence,] one says, AstTlq AlrRaAEiI naAqapF linafosihi (S, O) [meaning The pastor desired a she-camel to be left, or he left a she-camel, for himself, not milking her at the water; as is plainly indicated by what immediately precedes it in the S: or] the pastor took, (PS,) or retained, [which is virtually the same,] a she-camel for himself. (PS, TA.)
And AisotaTolaqotu mino SaAHibi AldRayoni kacaA (assumed tropical:) [I desired. or demanded, of the creditor, the remission of so much of the debt]. (Msb.)
See also 4, former half.

TaloqN [Loosed from his bond, set loose or free, or], as expl. by IAar, let go; as also TaliyqN↓ and muTolaqN↓: and a man not having anything upon him, as expl. by Ks: and Taloqu Alyadayoni a camel not having the fore legs bound. (TA.) You say, Hubisa TaloqFA, (so in the CK,) or TalaqFA↓, (K accord. to the TA, [and this is agreeable with the preceding context in the K, but it requires confirmation which I do not find,]) and with damm, [i. e. TuloqFA,] accord. to the K, but correctly with two dammehs, [i. e. TuluqFA↓,] (TA, and thus in the S,) He was imprisoned without shackle and without bond. (K, TA) See also TuluqN, first sentence.

[Hence,] Taloqu AllRisaAni, and Taliyqu↓ AllsAn, (S, O, Msb, K,) and AllsAn Tiloqu↓, (K,) and AllsAn Tulaqu↓, (TA,) (tropical:) Eloquent, or chaste, in speech, and sweet therein: (Msb:) and AllRisaAni munoTaliqu↓ and mutaTalRiquhu↓ (tropical:) [free from impediment of the tongue; or] eloquent, or chaste in speech. (TA.) And lisaAnN TaloqN caloqN, and caliyqN, TaliyqN↓, and culuqN TuluqN↓, and culaqN TulaqN↓, (S, O, K,) but the last two of these were unknown to As, and the latter of them was disallowed by IAar, (TA,) and caliqN TaliqN↓, (O, K,) [expl. in the K as meaning A tongue having sharpness; but correctly] meaning (tropical:) a tongue free from impediment, or eloquent, or chaste in speech, (cuw QnoTilaAqK,) and sharp. (O, TA.)

And Taloqu Alyadayoni, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) and Alydyn Tuluqu↓, (O, K,) and Alydyn Tuloqu↓, (O, TA,) and Alydyn Taliyqu↓, (L, TA,) (tropical:) Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) applied to a man: (S, Mgh, O, Msb:) and in like manner, a woman: (TA:) [or] a woman is termed Taloqapu Alyadayoni: (S:) and so, accord to AZ, Taloqu Alwajohi; which [generally] has another meaning, expl. in what follows. (TA.) And yaduhu TaloqN (tropical:) His hand is liberal; syn. bisoTN; (TA in art. bsT;) and so muTolaqapN↓: (S and K and TA in that art.:) or the latter signifies opened; and so maToluwqapN↓. (TA in the present art.)

And Taloqu Alwajohi, (S, O, Msb, K,) and Alwjh Tiloqu↓, (IAar, O, K,) and Tuloqu↓ Alwjh, (IAar, K,) and Alwjh Taliqu↓, (K,) and Alwjh Taliyqu↓, (S, O, K,) (tropical:) Laughing, or happy, or cheerful, and bright, in the face, or countenance: (K, TA:) or cheerful, or happy, displaying openness and pleasantness, in the face; and so TaloqN alone: (Msb:) and Alwjh Taliyqu↓ open and pleasant, and goodly, in countenance: (AZ, TA:) and TaliyqN alone, joyful, and open or cheer-
ful, in countenance. (TA. [And it is there said that the pl. of TaloqN is TaloqaAt: but this is app. a mistranscription for TuloqaAnN or TiloqaAnN.]) OuwojuhN TawaAliqu↓ is not allowable, except in poetry. (IAar, TA.)

And yawomN TaloqN, (Lth, S, Mgh, O, K,) and layolapN TaloqapN (Lth, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and TaloqN, (O, Msb, K,) (tropical:) A day, and a night, in which is neither heat nor cold: (Lth, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) or in which is no cold nor anything hurtful: (S:) or in which is no rain: or in which is no wind: or in which the cold is mild: (TA: [after which is added, mn AyAm TaloqAt: but the last word seems, as in an instance before mentioned, to be mistranscribed, or AyAm (i. e. OayRaAm) may be a mistake for layaAlK:]) or layolapN TaloqN means a night in which is no cold: (AA, TA:) or in which the wind is still: (O, TA:) and layolapN TaloqapN sometimes means a moon-lit, or a light, or bright, night: (IDrd, O, TA:) and one says also layolapN TaAliqapN↓, (K, TA,) meaning a still, or calm, and light, or bright, night: (TA:) and layaAlK TawaAliqu↓, (K, * TA,) meaning pleasant nights in which is neither heat nor cold. (TA.) Er-Rá'ee says,

L.foreign: falamRaA Ealatohu AlXRamosu fiI yawomi TaloqapK

sense.s: meaning yawomi layolapK TaloqapK [And when the sun came upon him, or it,] in a day of a night in which was neither cold nor wind; i. e., in a day after such a night; for the Arabs commence with the night, before the day: and the phrase fiI yawomi TaloqapK occurs in like manner in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh. (Az, TA.)
For the epithet Taloqu Alyadi AlyumonaI, (applied to a horse, accord. to the K,) see TuluqN.
And for other meanings assigned in the K to TaloqN, see TuluqN, in two places.
TaloqN signifies also The pain of childbirth. (S, O.) One says, DarabahaA AlTRaloqu [The pain of childbirth smote her]. (O.) [See also Tuliqat, of which it is the inf. n.]
And [it is said to signify] A sort of medicine. (S.) See TalaqN, latter half, in two places.
Tuloqu Alyadayoni:
and Tuloqu Alwajohi: see the next preceding paragraph.
Tiloqu AllRisaAni:
and Tiloqu Alwajohi: see TaloqN.

TiloqN signifies also (tropical:) Lawful, allowable, or free: (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA:) or it signifies, (Msb, TA,) or signifies also, (Mgh,) muTolaqN↓, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) [i. e.] a thing unrestricted, (TA,) i. e. any affair in which one has power, or authority, to act according to his own judgment or discretion or free will. (Msb.) One says, hecaA HalaAlN TiloqN (tropical:) [This is lawful, &c., unrestricted; using the latter epithet as a corroborative]: and [in the contr. case] HaraAmN giloqN. (TA.) And huwa laka TiloqFA (tropical:) [It is thine lawfully &c.]. (S, O, K, TA.) And AifoEalo hecaA TiloqFA laka (assumed tropical:) Do thou this as a thing lawful &c. to thee. (Msb.) And OaEoTayotuhu mino Tiloqi maAliI (assumed tropical:) I gave him of what was lawful &c., i. e. free to be disposed of by me, of my property: (Msb:) or (tropical:) of what was clear [from any claim or the like], and good, or lawful, of my property. (TA.) And Alxayolu TiloqN, occurring in a trad. as meaning (tropical:) Horses are allowable to be betted upon. (TA.) And Oanota TiloqN mino hecaA AlOamori (tropical:) Thou art clear of this affair; (S, O, K, * TA; *) quit of it, or irresponsible for it. (K, TA.)
[In consequence of a misplacement in some copies of the K, several meanings belonging to TalaqN are assigned to TiloqN.]
See also TalaqN, latter half.
TalaqN: see TaloqN, second sentence.

Also the subst. from Talaqati AlUibilu: (AZ, S, TA: [see 1, second sentence:]) and [as such] signifying The journeying [of camels] during the night to arrive at the water in the next night, there being two nights between them and the water; the first of which nights is termed AlTRalaqu [or layolapu AlTRalaqi (see HawozN)]; the pastor loosing them to repair to the water, [in the CK yajolibuhA is put for yuxalRiyhaA,] and leaving them to pasture while going thither: the camels after the driving, during the first night, are said to be TawaAliqu↓; and in the second night, qawaAribu: (S, O, K, TA:) or AlTRalaqu signifies the first of two days intervening between the camels and the water; and Alqarabu, the second: and layolapu AlTRalaqi, the night in which the faces of the camels are turned towards the water and during which they are left to pasture; and layolapu Alqarabi, the second night: (As, TA:) but it has been said that layolapu AlTRalaqi means the second of the nights in which the camels repair to the water: Th says that AlTRalaqu signifies the second of two days during which the camels seek the water when it is two days distant from them; and Alqarabu, the first of those days: and it is said that layolapu AlTRalaqi means [the night of] the turning of the faces of the camels towards the water: but this explanation was not pleasing to ISd. (TA.) [See an ex. voce HawozN, in which it is used tropically.]

Also A heat; i. e. a single run, or run at once, to a goal, or limit; syn. XawoTN; (S, IAth, O, Msb, K, TA;) meaning a running, of a horse, without restraining himself, [or without stopping,] to a goal, or limit: (Msb:) and the utmost extent to which a horse runs. (TA.) One says of a horse, EadaA TalaqFA or Talaqayoni [He ran a heat or two heats]. (S, O, Msb, K. [In the CK, erroneously, TaloqFA and Taloqayoni.])
And (hence, TA) (tropical:) A share, or portion, (Ibn-'Abbád, A, O, K, TA,) of property [&c.]. (A, TA.)
Also A shackle, or pair of shackles, (qayodN,) of skins: (S, M, O, K, TA:) or a rope strongly twisted, so that it will stand up. (TA.)

And sing. of OaTolaAqN which signifies The [intestines into which the food passes from the stomach, termed the] OamoEaMC, or the OaqotaAb of the belly; (IDrd, O, K; * [in some copies of the last of which, Alqunobu is erroneously put for Alqitobu as one of the words explaining AlTRalaqu;]) so in one or more of the dialects: AO says, in the belly are OaTolaAq, of which the sing. is TalaqN; (O, TA;) meaning the lines, or streaks, (TaraAYiq,) of the belly: and Talaqu AlbaToni is also expl. [in like manner] as meaning the judRap of the belly; pl. as above. (TA.)

Also The [plant called] Xuborum: [but what plant is meant by this is doubtful:] or a plant that is used in dyes: or this is a mistake: (K:) [or] accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, AlTRaloqu↓ is what is used in dyes; and is said to be the Xuborum: (O, TA: *) and (K) accord. to As, (O,) TalaqN signifies a sort of medicament, (O, K,) which, when one is anointed therewith, (K,) i. e. with the extract thereof, (TA,) prevents the burning of fire: (K:) or a species of plant: so says As: (O:) the appellation by which it is generally known is Taloq↓, with the l quiescent; (O, K;) or this pronunciation is incorrect: (K:) and AHát mentions, (K, TA,) on the authority of As, (TA,) its being termed TiloqN↓: (K, TA:) but it is not a plant: it is of the nature of stones, and of [what are termed] lixaAf [thin white stones]; and probably he [referring to As] heard that it is called kawokabu AlOaroDi, and therefore supposed it to be a plant; for if it were a plant, fire would burn it; but fire does not burn it, unless by means of artful contrivances: (O, TA:) the word is arabicized, from talako: (K, TA: in the O written tilk:) [it is the well-known mineral termed talc:] the Ra-ees [Ibn-Seenà, whom we call “ Avicenna, ”] says, (TA,) it is a brightlyshining stone, that separates, when it is bruised, into several laminæ and split pieces, of which are made maDaAwiI [correctly maDaAwiY, meaning small circular panes which are inserted in apertures to admit light,] for the [cupolas of] hot baths, instead of glass: the best is that of El-Yemen; then that of India; then that of El-Undulus [or El-Andalus]: the art employed in dissolving it consists in putting it into a piece of rag with some pebbles and immersing it in tepid water, then moving it about gently until it becomes dissolved and comes forth from the piece of rag into the water, whereupon the water is strained from it, and it is put in the sun to dry. (K, TA.)
TaliqN caliqN:
and Taliqu Alwajohi: see TaloqN.
Tulaqu AllRisaAni: and lisaAnN TulaqN culaqN: see TaloqN.

TuluqN, (S, O, Msb, TA,) with two dammehs, (Msb, TA,) or TaloqN↓, (K,) but this requires consideration, (TA,) Not shackled; applied to a she-camel, (S, O, Msb, TA,) and to a he-camel, (S, O, TA,) and to a person imprisoned; (O, TA;) as also TaAliqN↓ applied to a she-camel; but TuluqN is more common: (Aboo-Nasr, TA:) the pl. of TuluqN is OaTolaAqN. (S, TA.) See also TaloqN, second sentence.
[Hence,] lisaAnN TuluqN culuqN:
and Tuluqu Alyadayon: see TaloqN again.

And Tuluqu UiHodaI AalqawaAYimi (assumed tropical:) A horse having one of the legs without [the whiteness termed] AltRaHojiyl. (S.) And Tuluqu Alyadi AlyumonaI, (O,) or Alyd AlymnI Tuloqu↓, (K, [in this case again deviating from other authorities,]) (tropical:) A horse without taHojiyl in the right fore leg; (TA;) i. q. Alyd AlymnI muTolaqu↓. (O, K, TA.) And Alyadayoni muTolaqa↓ (assumed tropical:) A horse having the fore legs free from tHjyl. (Msb.)

[As an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] TuluqN, (Ibn-' Abbád, O,) or TaloqN↓, (K, [but this, as in the instances above, is questionable,]) signifies (assumed tropical:) A gazelle: (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K:) so called because of the quickness of its running: (O, * TA:) pl. OaTolaAqN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

And (assumed tropical:) A dog of the chase: (K:) because he is let loose; or because of the quickness of his running at the chase: (TA:) OaTolaAqN is mentioned by Ibn-' Abbád as signifying dogs of the chase. (O.)
TaloqapN [A single divorce: used in this sense in law-books]. (T and Msb in art. bt, &c.)
TulaqapN: see miTolaAqN.

TalaAqN is the inf. n. of Talaqat said of a woman: (Th, S, Mgh, O, K:) or the subst. therefrom: (Msb:) or [rather] it is also a subst. in the sense of taToliyqN; (Mgh;) [whence,] TalaAqu AlmaroOapi signifies (assumed tropical:) The letting the wife go her way: (Lth, O:) and it has two meanings: one is [the divorcing of the woman; i. e.] the dissolving of the wife's marriage-tie: and the other is the leaving, and dismissing, of the wife [either in an absolute sense or as is done by a single sentence of divorce]. (O, TA.) Some of the lawyers hold that the free woman whose husband is a slave is not separated but by three [sentences, as is the case when both husband and wife are free]; and the female slave whose husband is free, by two: some, that the wife in the former case is separated by two [sentences]; and in the latter case, by not less than three: and some, that when the husband is a slave and the wife is free, or the reverse, or when both are slaves, the wife is separated by two [sentences]. (TA.)
TaliyqN A captive having his bond loosed from him, (S, O, K, TA,) and let go. (TA.) See also TaloqN, first sentence.
And (assumed tropical:) A man freed from slavery; emancipated; i. q. EatiyqN; i. e. who has become free: pl. TulaqaMCu. (TA.)

It is said in a trad., AlTRulaqaMCu mino qurayoXK waAlEutaqaMCu mino vaqiyfK (assumed tropical:) [The TulaqaMC are of Kureysh; and the EutaqaMC, of Thakeef]: AlTlqAC being app. applied to Kureysh as it has a more special signification than AlEtqAC: but accord. to Th, AlTRulaqaMCu signifies those who have been brought within the pale of El-Islám against their will. (TA.)
Taliyqu AllRisaAni: and lisaAnN TaliyqN caliyqN:
and Taliyqu Alyadayoni:
and Taliyqu Alwajohi: see TaloqN again; the last in two places.
Taliyqu AlUilehi means (tropical:) The wind. (O, K, TA.)
TalRaAqN: see miTolaAqN.
TilRiyqN: see miTolaAqN.

TaAliqN A she-camel not having having her fore shank and her arm bound together: (TA:) or not having upon her a xiTaAm [or halter]: (IDrd, O, K:) or repairing to the water; and so miTolaAqN↓; (Aboo-Nasr, K, TA;) of which latter she pl. is maTaAliyqu: (TA:) or that is left a day and a night and then milked: (K:) pl. TawaAliqu and OaTolaAqN and TalaqapN; which last is expl. by AA as meaning she-camels that are milked in the place of pasturing. (TA.) See also TuluqN, first sentence: and for an explanation of the pl. TawaAliqu applied to camels, see TalaqN, second sentence. Also (O), TaAliqN, (S, O,) or TaAliqapN, (K,) signifies A she-camel which the pastor leaves for himself, not milking her at the water: (S, O, K:) the former is expl. by Esh-Sheybánee as meaning one which the pastor leaves [with her udder bound] with her SiraAr, not milking her in the place where she lies down to rest: (TA:) or the latter signifies, (Lth, O, K,) and the former also, (Lth, O,) a she-camel that is set loose among the tribe to pasture where she will in any part of the tract adjacent to their place of alighting or abode, (Lth, O, K, [mn jinAnihimo in the CK being erroneously put for mino janaAbihimo,]) that has not her fore shank and her arm bound together when she returns in the afternoon or evening, nor is turned away [from the others] in the place of pasturage: (Lth, O:) or TaAliqN signifies a she-camel, (S, Msb,) and a ewe, (S,) that is set loose, or dismissed, to pasture where she will: (S, Msb:) and also as first expl. in this sentence: (S:) it is mentioned by ElFárábee as signifying a ewe left to pasture by herself, alone. (Msb.)

[Hence,] TaAliqN and TaAliqapN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the former, without p, used by all, (Msb,) the latter occurring in a verse of El-Aashà, (S, Mgh, * O, Msb,) ending a hemistich, and pronounced TaAliqapN, (S, O, Msb, [which cite the verse somewhat differently,]) (tropical:) A woman [divorced, or] left to go her way, (S, * Mgh, * O, Msb, *) or separated from her husband [by a sentence of divorce]: (S, * Mgh, * Mgh, * K, TA:) both mentioned by Akh: (O, TA:) accord. to IAmb, one says TaAliqN only, because it applies only to a female: accord. to Lth and IF, TaAliqapN means TaAliqapN gadFA [divorced, &c., to-morrow]; and Lth adds that it is thus to accord with its verb, Talaqato: some, however, say that the h is affixed in the verse of El-Aashà by poetic license, to complete the hemistich; but an Arab of the desert, in reciting this verse to As, is related to have said TaAliqN [which equally completes the hemistich]: and the Basrees hold that the sign of the fem. gender is elided in TaAliqN because it is a possessive epithet, meaning caAtu TalaAqK [having divorce]. (Msb.)
OuwojuhN TawaAliqu:
and layolapN TaAliqapN and layaAlK TawaAliqu: see TaloqN, latter half.
TutayoliyqN dim. of AiTRilaAqN. (S, O.) See 8.
tuTayoliyqN dim. of AisotiTolaAqN. (S, O.) See 10.
muTolaqN: see TaloqN, first sentence.
[Hence,] yaduhu muTolaqapN: see TaloqN again, former half.

See also maMCN muTolaqN TiloqN. means (assumed tropical:) Water that is unrestricted. (TA.) And HukomN muTolaqN means (assumed tropical:) [A judicial decision, or an ordinance or the like, or a rule, that is unrestricted, or absolute, or] in which is no exception. (TA.)
muTolaqu Alyadi AlyumonaI: and muTolaqa Alyadayoni: each applied to a horse: see TuluqN.

[Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, explains it as signifying also A place where horses meet to be sent forth to run, or race: but what here next follows inclines me to think that it may be correctly muTalRaqN.]
muTalRiqN One desiring to outstrip with his horse in a race. (K.)
miTolaAqN: see TaAliqN.

Also, (S, O, Msb, K,) and miToliyqN↓, (O, Msb, K,) and TulaqapN↓, (S, O, K,) and TilRiyqN↓, (K,) and TalRaAqN↓, this last mentioned by Z, (TA,) (tropical:) One who oftentimes divorces, or dismisses, wives. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.)
miToliyqN: see what next precedes.
maToluwqapN: see TaloqN.
AimoraOapN maToluwqapN (assumed tropical:) A woman taken with the pains of parturition. (Mgh, Msb.)
muTayoliqN and muTayoliyqN dims. of munoTaliqN. (S.)
mutaTalRiaqu AllRisaAni: see TaloqN, former half.
munoTaliqu AllRisaAni: see TaloqN, former half.
nuTayoliyqN: dim. of AinoTilaAqN. (S, O.) See 7.

1. Talama Alxubozapa, (K,) aor.
Taluma
, (TK,) inf. n. TalomN, (TA,) He made the cake of bread even, or equable. (K.)
2. TlRm, inf. n. taToliymN, He beat a cake of bread baked in hot ashes with his hand, (K, TA) in order that it might become cool. (TA.) Hence the saying of Hassán.

(K, * TA:) or, as some relate it, yulaTRimuhunRa; but this is weak, or repudiated: (K:) or this is the correct reading, and the more obviously appropriate in meaning, accord. to MF; and accord. to IAth, it is the reading commonly known, and the same as the former in meaning: (TA:) the meaning is, [Our coursers passing the day running like the pouring of rain,] the women wiping the sweat from them with the mufflers: (K, TA:) or, as some say, [the women with the mufflers] beating them with the hands in removing the dust that was upon them. (TA.)
TulomN A table upon which the bread is expanded [previously to the baking]. (K.)
TalamN Dirt of the teeth in consequence of neglect [of the use] of the siwaAk [or tooth-stick]. (K.)

TulomapN A xubozap, (S, K, TA,) [i. e. a cake of bread, or lump of dough,] baked in hot ashes in a hollow in the ground; what people [now] call a malRap; but this is the name of the hollow itself: what is baked in this is [properly called] the
Tulomap and xubozap and maliyl: (S, TA:) pl. TulamN. (L, TA.) It is said in a prov., UinRa duwna AlTRalomapi xaroTa qataAdi huwobara (Meyd, TA) [i. e. Before the attainment of the cake of bread baked in hot ashes is the stripping of the leaves, by grasping each branch and drawing the hand down it, of the tragacanth of Howbar]: the Tulomap is the cake of bread that is put in hot ashes; and Howbar is a place abounding with the tragacanth: the prov. is applied in relation to a thing that is unattainable. (Meyd.)
TulRaAmN The [tree called] tanRuwm [q. v.]; which is [erroneously said to be] hemp-seed (HabRu AlXRahodaAniji). (K.)
miTolamapN The implement with which bread is expanded. (KL.)

1. Talawotu AlTRlaA, (S, TA,) or AlTRaliIRa, aor. OaToluw; (TA;) and Talayotuhu, (S, K, TA,) aor. OaToliI, inf. n. TaloIN; (TA;) I tied the young lamb or kid, (S, K, * TA,) by its leg, (S, TA,) to a peg, or stake; (TA;) and confined, restrained, or withheld, it. (S.) And Talayotu AlXRaIoCa I confined, restrained, or withheld, the thing. (S, K, * TA.)

Talayotuhu bihi, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor. OaToliI, (Msb,) inf. n. TaloIN, (S, Msb,) I daubed, bedaubed, smeared, or besmeared, it; (Mgh;) [rubbed, or did, it over; anointed, painted, varnished, plastered, coated, overspread, or overlaid, it; with it; i. e. with any fluid, semifluid, liniment, unguent, or the like; as, for instance,] with oil, (S,) or tar, (Mgh,) or clay, or mud, (Msb,) &c. (S, Mgh, Msb.) You say, TalaI AlbaEiyra AlhinaMCa, and biAlhinaMCi, [the latter of which is the more common,] aor. yaToliI, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He daubed, bedaubed, smeared, or besmeared, the camel with tar; as also TlRAhu↓, [but app. in an intensive sense, or relating to several objects,] (K, TA,) inf. n. taToliyapN. (TA.) [And TalaAhu biAlcRahabi He gilded it. And TalaAhu biAlfiDRapi He silvered it.]
Hence, TalaI AllRayolu AlMfaAqa (tropical:) The night covered [with its darkness] the adjacent regions, or the tracts of the horizon; like as when a camel is daubed with tar. (TA.)

And TalaI, aor. yaToliI, (assumed tropical:) He reviled [another], or vilified [him]; (TA;) as also TlRI↓, (K, * TA,) inf. n. taToliyapN; (K;) or taToliyapN signifies the reviling, or vilifying, in a foul manner. (IAar, TA.)
And TalaI Albaqolu (assumed tropical:) The herbs, or leguminous plants, appeared upon the surface of the earth [as though they overspread it with a coating of colour]. (TA.)

TaliIa fuwhu, aor. yaTolaI, inf. n. TalFA, His mouth had a yellowness in the teeth. (S, TA.) TalFA [in relation to the mouth but in a somewhat different sense] is mentioned in the K in art. Tlw and not in art. TlI; but it belongs to both of these. (TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

TalRayotu fulaAnFA, (S,) inf. n. taToliyapN, (S, K,) signifies also I tended, or took care of, such a one in his sickness; undertook, or managed, or superintended, the treatment of him therein. (S, K, * TA.)
And AltRaToliyapu also signifies The act of singing. (AA, K.)
4. ATlt She (a wild animal) had with her a young one, which is termed TalFA. (IKtt, TA.)

ATlI (said of a man, S, TA, and of a camel, TA) He had an inclining of the neck (S, K, TA) towards one side when said of a man, (TA,) on the occasion of death, (S, K, TA,) or on some other occasion. (S, TA.)

Hence, (IAth, TA,) maA OaTolaI nabiIRN qaTRu, (K, TA,) occurring in a trad., (TA,) means maA maAla UilaI hawaAhu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) No prophet ever inclined to his natural desire]: (K, TA:) as some relate it, maA QTRalaI; but this is a mistake. (TA.)
5. tTlRI: see 8.
Also, (said of a man, TA,) He kept to diversion, sport, or play, and mirth. (K, TA.)

8. AiTRalaI, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the measure AifotaEala, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and tTlRI↓, (S, K,) [He, or it, was, or became, daubed, bedaubed, smeared, or besmeared; rubbed, or done, over; anointed, painted, varnished, plastered, coated, overspread, or overlaid: or] he daubed, &c., himself: (S, * Mgh, Msb, K: *) bihi [with it]; (S, K;) i. e. [with any fluid, semifluid, liniment, unguent, or the like; as, for instance,] with oil, (S,) or tar, (Mgh, K,) or clay, or mud, (Msb,) &c. (S, Mgh, Msb.)
12. AiTolawolaI He was good in speech:
and He was defeated, or put to flight. (IAar, TA in art. xlI.)

TalFA The young one of any of the cloven-hoofed animals: (S, TA: [in the latter of which is added, as from the S, waAlxufRi; but this is app. a mistake:]) or the young one of the gazelle, when just born: (M, Msb, K: [see XaSarN:]) and the youngling, of any kind; as also TalowN↓; (K, TA;) which latter is mentioned by IDrd; but expl. by him as meaning the young one of a wild animal: (TA:) and TilowapN↓ has this last meaning (K, TA) likewise accord. to IDrd: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] of TalFA is OaTolaMCN (S, Msb, K) and [of mult.] TilaMCN (K) and TuliyRN (K, TA, but omitted in the CK) and TiliIRN (Lth, TA) and TuloyaAnN (K) and TiloyaAnN. (Lth, K.) [See also TaliIRN.]
[And, accord. to Freytag (in art. TlI), An infant until a month old or more: but for this he has named no authority.]
And The person; syn. XaxoSN. (S, K.) So in the saying, UinRahu lajamiylu AlTRalaA [Verily he is goodly, or comely, in person]. (S.)
Also Daubed, or smeared, (maToliIRN↓,) with tar. (S, K.) [See also TaloyaMCu.]
And A man having a severe disease: (K, TA:) having no dual nor pl., or, as some say, (TA,) the pl. is OaTolaMCN, and the dual is TalayaAni. (K, TA.) [See also muTalRFI.]

And Desire; syn. hawFI. (K, TA.) So in the saying, qaDaI TalaAhu mino HaAjatihi [He accomplished his desire of that which he wanted]. (K, TA.) [Or, as Freytag says, on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees, accord. to some it signifies Pleasure (voluptas): and accord. to others, thirst. But see TilFA.]
See also TulaAwapN, in two places.
And see also TilaMC, last sentence.
TilFA Pleasure, or delight. (K.)
See also TilaMCN.
TalowN: see TalFA, first sentence.
TilowN The wolf. (K.)

And A hunter, or pursuer of wild animals or the like, slender in body: (Aboo-Sa'eed, K, TA: [in the CK, AlqAbiDu is erroneously put for AlqaAniSu:]) said to be [so called as being] likened to the wolf. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.) Et-Tirimmáh says,

[She, or they, (app. referring to one or more of the objects of the chase,) encountered a hunter slender in body, a long endurer of hunger, one whom sleep did not overcome, little, or seldom, subject to disgust]. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.)
See also TilaMCN, last sentence.

TulaApN (S, K, TA) accord. to AA and Fr, (S, TA,) and so says Sb on the authority of Abu-lKhattáb, (TA,) or TuloyapN↓ (S, K, TA) accord. to As, (S, TA,) each with damm, (TA,) is sing. of TulFA or TulFI; which signifies Necks: (S, K:) or the bases of the necks: (M, K:) or the broad part [or parts] beneath the protuberant bone behind the ear: or, accord. to ISk, the sides of the neck: Sb says that TulaApN and TulFA are of the class of ruTabapN, and ruTabN, not of the class of tamorapN and tamorN: (TA:) [but see art. rTb, in which it is said, as on the authority of Sb, that ruTabN is not a broken pl. of ruTabapN, being masc. like tamorN:] TulowapN↓, also, signifies the side of the neck, as a dial. var. of [TulaApN or of] TuloyapN. (TA.)
TulowapN The whiteness of the dawn, (K, TA,) and of blossoms, or flowers. (TA.)
See also TulaApN.
TilowapN: see TalFA:
and see also TilMCN, last sentence.
TaloyapN A single act of daubing or smearing or the like: pl. TalayaAtN. (Mgh.)
See also TilaMCN, last sentence.
TuloyapN: see TulaApN.
Also A portion, tuft, or wisp, of wool, with which mangy camels are daubed [with tar]; also called ribocapN: whence the saying, maA yusaAwiI TuloyapF [It is not worth a Tlyp]. (TA.)
See also TaloyaMCu.
And see TilaMCN, last sentence.
TaloyaMCu A she-camel daubed, or smeared, (maToliyRapN↓, K, TA,) with tar. (TA.) [See also TalFA.]
And A mangy she-camel: (K:) app. so called because the she-camel is not daubed, or smeared, [with tar] unless mangy. (TA.)
And The rag of a menstruous woman: (K, TA:) whence the prov., Oahowanu mina AlTRaloyaMCi [More despicable than the TlyAC]: or, accord. to IAar, this is called TuloyapN↓. (TA.)
[In some copies of the K, this word is erroneously put for TaliyRaA, q. v.]
TulawaMCu: see TulowaAnN.
Also [The green substance that overspreads stale water, called] TuHolub; and so TulaAwapN↓. (Sgh, TA.)
TalowaAnN: see TulaAwapN.

TulowaAnN and TalawaAnN↓ and TulawaMCu↓ [or app. the last only accord. to some copies of the K] Expectation: and slowness, or tardiness; as also TalaAwapN↓, (K, TA,) with fet-h. (TA.) See also TulaAwapN.
TalawaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph: and see also TulaAwapN.
TiloyaAnN: see TaliIRN.
TalayaAnN: see TulaAwapN.
TulaMCN The coat upon the surface of blood. (K.) [See also TulaAwapN. And see TulRaMCN.]

TilaMCN Tar: and anything (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of the like kind (Mgh, Msb) with which one daubs or smears or the like; [i. e. any fluid, semifluid, liniment, unguent, oil, varnish, plaster, or the like, with which a thing is daubed, smeared, rubbed or done over, anointed, painted, varnished, plastered, coated, overspread, or overlaid;] (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also TulaAwapN↓, which by rule should be TulaAyapN↓, for it is from Talayotu. (TA, in which TulaAyapN is afterwards mentioned as having the same meaning.)

And, as being likened thereto, (assumed tropical:) Any thick beverage or wine: (Mgh:) expressed juice of grapes cooked until the quantity of two thirds has gone by evaporation; (S, A, Mgh;) called by the Persians mayobuxotaj [or maIo Puxotah]; called by the Arabs TilaMC as being likened to tar: (A, Mgh: *) or thick expressed juice, or wine, cooked until half of it has gone: (K:) in a verse of Ibn-Sukkarah, shortened to TilFA↓, for the sake of the metre. (Har p. 302.)

And (assumed tropical:) Wine [in an absolute sense] (S, K) is thus called by some of the Arabs, for the purpose of euphemism. (S.) 'Obeyd Ibn-El-Abras said to El-Mundhir when he [the latter] desired to slay him, hiIa Alxamoru tukonaI AlTRilaMCa kamaA AlcRiYobu yukonaI OabaA jEodapa [It is wine: it is surnamed AlTlMC like as the wolf is surnamed Abw jEdp]: i. e. thou pretendest to show honour to me while desiring to slay me; like the wolf, whose acting is not good though his surname is good: (S:) or, as cited by IKt, Eani Alxamori takoniI AlTRilaMCa: and in the M,
[forming a hemistich; the words kamaA AlcRiYobu Alx, cited above, completing the verse]. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) The ashes between the three stones upon which the cooking-pot is placed: so called by way of comparison [to tar]. (TA.)
And Pure silver. (TA.)
And (assumed tropical:) Revilement, or reproach. (K.)

Also The cord with which the leg of the lamb, or kid, is tied (S, K) to a peg, or stake; (S;) and so TilowN↓ and TilowapN↓: (TA:) or the string with which the leg of the kid is tied as long as he is little; (Lh, TA;) and so TuloyapN↓ and TaloyapN↓ and TalFI↓ [or TalFA]. (TA.)
TaliIRN Confined, restrained, or withheld; [and particularly tied by the leg, as is shown by what follows;] as also maToliIRN↓. (S.

And A young lamb or kid: (ISk, S, K:) so called because it is tied by the leg for some days to a peg, or stake: (ISk, S:) pl. TuloyaAnN; like rugofaAnN, (ISk, S, K,) pl. of ragiyfN: (ISk, S:) it is thus pluralized like a subst. because it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (AAF, TA.) [See also TalFA.]
[Hence AlTRaliIRu meaning (assumed tropical:) The sign of Aries: see an ex. voce HamalN.]
Also A yellowness in the teeth; and so TiloyaAnN↓: like SabiIRN and SiboyaAnN [in form]. (S.) [See also TulaAwapN.]
TalaAwapN: see the next paragraph, in two places:
and see also TulowaAnN.

TulaAwapN, and TalaAwapN↓, (Az, S, ISd, Msb, K,) the former preferred by Az, (TA, and this, only, mentioned in the Mgh,) and TilaAwapN↓, (K,) Beauty, goodliness, grace, comeliness, or pleasingness: (Az, * ISd, * S, Mgh, Msb, * K:) ISd says, it is in that which has growth and that which has not growth. (TA.) One says, Ealayohi TulaAwapN [Upon him, or it, is an appearance of beauty, &c.]. (Msb.) And maA Ealayohi TulaAwapN [There is not upon him, or it, &c.]. (S.) And UinRa liloquroMni laTulaAwapF [Verily to the Kur-án pertains beauty, &c.]. (Mgh, from a trad.) And maAEalaI wajohihi HalaAwapN walaA TulaAwapN [There is not upon his face an appearance of sweetness nor an appearance of beauty, &c.]. (TA.)
Also, (K,) or the first, with damm, (TA,) Enchantment, or fascination: (K:) a meaning mentioned by ISd. (TA.)
And (the first, TA) The thin skin that overspreads the surface of milk, (T, ISd, K, TA,) as also TulaAyapN↓, (Kr, TA,) or of blood. (ISd, K, TA. [See also TulaMCN.])
And Remains of food in the mouth. (Lh, K, TA.)

And Saliva becoming dry (K, TA) and thick (TA) in the mouth, by reason of some accident, (K, TA,) or, as in the M, from thirst, (TA,) or disease; (K, TA;) the first and ↓second have this meaning; (TA;) as also TalFA↓ (K) [and app. TulowaAnN↓ and TalawaAnN↓ also accord. to the copies of the K followed in the TA; but see TulowanN above]: it is also said that TalowaAnN↓, with fet-h, signifies saliva becoming dry upon the teeth from hunger; and has no pl.: TalFA↓ is the inf. n. of TaliIa fuwhu: and signifies also a whiteness that comes upon the teeth from disease or thirst; and so TalayaAnN↓. (TA.) [See also TaliIRN.]
For other meanings of TulaAwapN, see TulawaMCu,
and TilaMCN.
It signifies also A small quantity of herbage or pasture. (TA.)
TilaAwapN: see TulaAwapN, first sentence.
TulaAyapN: see TilaMCN:
and see also TulaAwapN.

TaliyRaA, thus correctly, as written by Sgh in the TS, not, as in the copies of the K, TaloyaA [or TaloyaMC], (TA,) The mange, or scab. (K, TA.) And A certain purulent pustule, [or eruption,] resembling the quwbaMC [or ringworm], (K, TA,) that comes forth in a man's side; whereupon one says to him, “ It is only qwbMC, and not TlyRA; ” thus making light of it to him. (TA.)
TulRaI A draught of milk: (K:) but this is of the measure fuEolaI, belonging to art. Tl. (TA. [See TulRapN in that art.])
TalRaMCN A seller of the thickened juice called TilaMC. (MA.)

TulRaMCN Blood, (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA,) itself; applied to that of a slain person: or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, a thing [or fluid] that comes forth after the flow of the blood, differing from blood in colour, on the occasion of the exit of the soul of the slaughtered animal: and the blood with which one daubs, or smears. (TA.) [See also TulaMCN.]
TaAlK A water to which camels come to drink overspread with [the green substance called] TuHolub [and TulawaMC]. (K, TA.)
And (tropical:) A dark night: (AA, K, TA:) as though it smeared [with tar] the forms, or persons, of men, and obscured them. (AA, TA.)
miTolFI: see what next follows.

miTolaMCN (S, K) and miTolFI↓ (K) A narrow tract of ground in which water flows: (K:) or soft ground that gives growth to the trees called EiDaAh, (as in the S and in some copies of the K,) or gaDFA: (so in other copies of the K and in copies of the T and M:) and AlmaTaAliI, which is the pl. [of the latter, or AlmaTaAliIRu pl. of the former], signifies the soft places: (TA:) or the places in which the wild animals feed their younglings: (S, K, TA:) so it is said. (S.)
maToliIRN: see TaliIRN:
