see also TalFA; and see the fem., with p, voce TaloyaMCu.
[Hence,] OamorN maToliIRN (assumed tropical:) A dubious and obscure affair, or case: as though it were smeared over with that which involved it. (TA.)
And EuwdN maToliIRN (assumed tropical:) A stick, or rod, or branch, not stript of the peel or bark. (TA.)

muTalRFI Having a constant, or chronic, disease, (K, TA,) and bent thereby. (TA.) [See also
TalFA.]
And Imprisoned without hope of liberation. (K.)

1. TamRa, (MA, K, TA,) aor.
Tamuma
, (TA, [by rule it should be
Tamima
,]) inf. n. TumuwmN (MA, K, TA) and TamRN, (K, TA,) said of water, It was, or became, abundant, (MA, K, TA,) and rose high, or to a high pitch. (TA.) [See also TamaI.] And TamRa AlwaAdiI means [TamRa sayolu AlwaAdiI i. e. The torrent of the valley or water-course] rose high, or to a high pitch, and predominated: whence the prov., jaraI AlwaAdiI faTamRa EalaI AlqariIRi; in explanation of which Meyd says, i. e., [The torrent of the valley or water-course (sayolu AlwaAdiI) flowed, (so in the Provs. of Meyd,)] and filled up, or choked up, meaning destroyed by filling up, or choking up, the channel by which the water ran into the meadow: and he says that the prov. is applied to the case in which evil exceeds the ordinary limit: (Har p. 127:) [or, accord. to Z, it means a man's overcoming his adversary: (Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 278:) but it should be observed that TamRa in this sense is trans. without a prep.:] one says of a torrent, (S, Meyd, and Har ubi suprà,) TamRa AlrRakiyRapa, (S, Meyd, K, Har,) aor.
Tamuma
and
Tamima
, (K, TA,) the latter on the authority of IAar, inf. n. TamRN, (TA,) It filled up, or choked up, the well, syn. dafanahaA, (S, Meyd, K, Har,) or kabasahaA, (IAar, TA,) and made it even or level (sawRaAhaA) [with the ground around it]: (S, K:) and TamRa AlXRaIoCa biAltRuraAbi, inf. n. TamRN, He covered over the thing with earth, or dust; syn. kabasahu: (TA:) and TamRa AlUinaMCa, (K, TA,) inf. n. TamRN, (TA,) He filled the vessel (K, TA) so that the contents overflowed its edges: (TA:) and TamRa AlbiYora wagayorahaA biAltRuraAbi, aor.
Tamuma
, inf. n. TamRN, He filled the well &c. with earth, or dust, so that it became even with the ground: (Mgh, * Msb:) and TamRahaA AltRuraAbu The earth, or dust, so filled it. (Msb.)

[Hence, i. e. from TamRa AlwaAdiI meaning as expl. in the beginning of the next preceding sentence,] one says, TamRa AlXRaIoCu, (S, K,) aor.
Tamuma
, (S, TA,) [inf. n. TamRN and TumuwmN,] (assumed tropical:) The thing abounded so that it rose to a high pitch, or had ascendency, and overcame. (S, K.) And TamRa AlOamoru, inf. n. TamRN, (assumed tropical:) The affair, or event, rose to a high pitch, or had ascendency, and overcame: (Msb:) or was, or became, great, or formidable. (Har p. 127.) And OamorN yTmR wlA ytmR [app. yaTimRu walaA yatimRu, agreeably with analogy, in order to assimilate the former verb with the latter, as is often done; meaning (assumed tropical:) An affair that is great, or formidable, and that will not become accomplished]. (TA.) And TamRati Alfitonapu (assumed tropical:) The sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like, was, or became, vehement, or severe. (TA.) And daAhiyapN tTmRu EalaI AldRawaAhI [i. e. taTumRu or taTimRu], meaning (assumed tropical:) [A calamity] that predominates over [the other calamities]. (Har p. 127.)
TamRa Alfarasa and TamRa EalayohaA He (the stallion) leaped the mare. (TA.) And TamRa AlXRajarapa, (K,) inf. n. TamRN, (JM,) He (a bird) mounted upon the top of the tree. (K.)

TamRa said of a man and of a horse, aor.
Tamima
and
Tamuma
, inf. n. TamiymN and TamRN, He was, or became, light, or active, (K, TA,) and quick: (TA:) or he went away upon the face of the earth: (K, TA:) or he went away in any way. (TA.) And He ran in an easy manner: (K:) or so TamRa, aor.
Tamima
, inf. n. TamiymN: (TA:) and marRayaTimRu, with kesr, inf. n. TamiymN, He passed along running in an easy manner: (S:) and so, accord. to As, TamRa, inf. n. TumuwmN. (TA.) [See also TamaI.]

TamRa raOosahu, (K,) aor.
Tamuma
, inf. n. TamRN, (TA,) He took somewhat from [the hair of] his head; gDRa minohu. (K. [So in my MS. copy: in the CK and TA, erroneously, EaDRa, with the unpointed E; and thus in the TK, in which, however, the phrase is well expl., on the authority of the A, as meaning he shaved a portion of his head: see also the pass. part. n.]) And TamRa XaEarahu, (S, K,) aor.
Tamuma
, inf. n. TamRN, (TA,) He cut his hair; (S, K, TA;) and he cut it off entirely. (TA.) And TamRa XaEarahu, (S, K,) inf. n. TumuwmN, (S,) i. q. EaqaSahu [i. e. He plaited his hair: or twisted it: &c.]. (S, K.)
2. TmRm, inf. n. taTomiymN, He (a bird) alighted upon a branch. (Aboo-Nasr, S, K.)
4. ATmR XaEaruhu His hair attained, or drew near, to the time for its being cut; as also AstTmR↓. (S, K.)
7. AnTmR, said of a rivulet, [and in like manner of a well, &c.,] It became filled up with earth, or dust, so as to be even with the ground [around it]. (Mgh.)
R. Q. 1. TamoTama He swam in the midst of the sea. (IAar, K.)
And It (the sea) became full. (TA.)
He had a barbarousness, or vitiousness, or an impotence, or impediment, in his speech, or utterance, not speaking clearly, or correctly. (TA.)
TamRN [as an inf. n.: see 1.
As a subst.,] see the next paragraph.

TimRN The sea: (S, K, TA:) said to be so called because of its overwhelming what is in it (liOanRahu TamRa EalaI maA fiyhi): but in this sense the word is said to be TamRN↓, and to be pronounced with kesr for the purpose of assimilating it to rimRN. (TA.) One says, jaMCa biAlTRimRi waAlrRimRi, meaning He brought much wealth: (S, TA:) or the meaning in this instance is AlAmr Alkvyr [app. a mistranscription for AlOamor Alkabiyr i. e. that which was a great event]: so says As: or much of everything: or much and little: thus accord. to Aboo-Tálib: or what was moist and what was dry: or the leaves of trees, and what had fallen off from them. (TA. [See more voce rim: and see also what here follows.])

And Water: (K, TA:) or much water; as also TaAmRN↓ [or maMCN TaAmRN]: (TA:) or the rubbish and scum, and the like, that is upon its surface; or that is driven along by it: (K, * TA:) and thus expl. as used in the saying above-mentioned. (TA.)
And A large number: (K:) and this also is said to be meant in the phrase above. (TA.)
And A wonderful thing; syn. EajabN and EajiybN [which here, as in many other instances, evidently signify the same]: (K:) and this too is said to be meant in the phrase above. (TA.)
And A male ostrich: (K:) because of the lightness of his pace. (TA.)

And A courser, or swift horse; as also TamiymN↓: (K, * TA: [see also TamuwmN:]) called TimRN because of. his light and quick, or easy, running (liTamiymi Eadowihi); or as being likened to the sea, as a horse is termed baHorN and sakobN and garobN. (TA.)
And A large cakar: (K:) because its head is maTomuwm [as though this epithet meant “ bare ”]. (TA.)
AlTRimRu is also said in the K to signify AlkayRisu; but [SM says] I think that this is a mistranscription for AlTRamRu meaning Alkabosu [see TamRa AlrRakiyRapa, in the first paragraph]. (TA.)

TumRapN A company, or congregated body, of men: and the middle of them: one says, laqiytuhu fI TumRapi Alqawomi [I met him, or found him, in the company of people, or in the midst of the people]. (TA.)
Also Error; or deviation from the right course: and confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see the right course. (TA.)
And Dirt, or filth; syn. qacarN. (TA.)

And Human dung. (K.) AZ says, When thou givest good advice to a man and he refuses to do aught but follow his own opinion alone, daEohu yataramRaEu fiI TumRatihi [leave him wallowing in his dung]. (TA.)
And A portion (K, TA) of herbage, mostly (TA) of what is dry, or dried up. (K, TA.)
TamimN Hardy, strong, or sturdy: occurring thus, without idghám, in a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd; applied to a beast such as is termed qaAriHN. (TA.)
farasN TamuwmN A swift horse. (TA. [See also TimRN.])
TamiymN: see TimRN.
Also A medley of men, or people: and a multitude thereof. (TA.)
TaAmRN [part. n. of 1]: see TimRN:
and see the paragraph here following.

TaAmRapN A calamity that predominates over others: (K, and Har p. 127:) or simply a calamity. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr En-Nessábeh, maA mino TaAmRapK UilRaA wafawoqahaA TaAmRapN (S, * TA) i. e. There is no calamity but above it is a calamity. (TA.)
And A great, or formidable, thing; as also TaAmRN↓. (TA.)
And A cry, or vehement cry, that overcomes everything. (TA.)

And AlTRaAmRapu signifies
The resurrection: (S, Msb, K:) so called because it surpasses, or predominates over, everything: (S, * Msb, * TA:) and also called AlTRaAmRapu AlkuboraI. (Har p. 346.)

TimoTimN and TumoTumaAniIRN↓ (S, K) and TimoTimiIRN↓ (K) and TumaATimN↓ (TA) A man having a barbarousness, or vitiousness, or an impotence, or impediment, in his speech, or utterance, not speaking clearly, or correctly: (S, K, TA:) and Aboo-Turáb explains [the pl. of the first] TamaATimu as meaning foreigners (Eajam). (TA.) Hence the saying of the poet, (S,) 'Antarah, (TA,)

L.foreign: taOowiI lahu quluSu AlnRaEaAmi kamaA Oawato

sense.s: (S, TA;) respecting which Fr relates his having heard El-Mufaddal say that one of the most learned of men explained to him Alxiraqu AlyamaAniyRapu as meaning the clouds [app. likened to rags of cloth of El-Yemen], and AlOaEojamu AlTimoTimu as meaning the sound of thunder: (TA:) or the latter hemistich is thus:

and the verse means, To whom (referring to a male ostrich) repair the young ostriches, like as herds of camels of El-Yemen repair to one who is impotent, and indistinct, or incorrect, in speech: he likens the male ostrich, in respect of blackness, and want of speech, to an Abyssinian pastor impotent, and indistinct, or incorrect, in speech. (EM p. 231.)
TimoTimN signifies also A sort of sheep, haring small ears, and OagobaAb [or what resemble dewlaps], like the AgbAb of oxen: they are in the region of El-Yemen. (IDrd, TA.)
TamoTamapN A barbarousness, or vitiousness, or an impotence, or impediment, in speech, or utterance, so that the speech is not clear, or correct. (TA. [See R. Q. 1, of which it is the inf. n.])
TimoTimiIRN: see TimoTimN.
TumoTumaAniIRN: see TimoTimN.

TumoTumaAniyRapu Himoyara The disapproved phraseology [or pronunciation] of the dialect of Himyer, (K, TA,) resembling the speech of the foreigners: thus expl. by Mbr and Eth-Tha'álibee and others: or, as some say, their change of l into m [in Aamo for Aalo; of which see several exs. voce Oamo]. (TA.)
TamoTaAmN The middle of the sea. (K, TA.)
And hence, (tropical:) Much fire: or the midst of fire: or the main part thereof: occurring in a trad. of Aboo-Tálib. (TA.)
TumaATimN: see TimoTimN.

[OacFI OaTamRu Vehement, or severe, annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt: in the TA carelessly written AcA ATm; and there said to be from TamRati Alfitonapu, q. v. See also an ex. in the Ham p. 363; where OaTamo occurs at the end of a verse for OaTamRa used in a like sense; i. e. as an epithet, not as a verb.]

OaTaAmiymu is said in the K to signify The legs of a beast: but AA says, respecting the phrase musotaEidRaAtN OaTaAmiymu in a verse of Ibn-Mukbil describing a she-camel, that the former of these words is used as meaning legs, and ATAmym means brisk, active, or quick: and by another, or others, this latter word is said to mean taTimRu fiI AlsRayori, i. e. that are quick in pace. (TA.)
XaEarN maTomuwmN means maEoquwSN [i. e. Hair plaited: or twisted: &c.]. (S, TA.)
And raOosN maTomuwmN A head of which all the hair is cut off. (K * and TA in art. zq.) And maTomuwmu AlrRaOosi A man having all the hair of his head cut off. (TA in that art.)

1. Tamavato, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Tamuva
, (S, K,) or
Tamiva
, (Msb,) inf. n. TamovN; (Msb, TA;) and Tamivato, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Tamava
; (Msb, K; [accord. to the former of which, the inf. n. of the latter verb seems to be TamavN; but accord. to the K, it seems to be TamovN;]) She menstruated; said of a woman: (S, Msb, K:) the primary signification, accord. to Th; that of “ devirgination, ” i. e. “ coition with the causing to bleed, ” being one subsequently given to TamovN: (TA:) or, as some say, for the first time: (Msb, TA:) and accord. to Lh, used peculiarly in relation to a girl, or young woman. (TA.)

TamavahaA, aor.
Tamiva
(S, Mgh, Msb, K) and
Tamuva
, (S, Msb, K,) the former accord. to most of the readers in the Kur [lv. 56 and 74], (TA,) inf. n. TamovN, (S, Msb,) He devirginated her, (Fr, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) namely, a woman, (Mgh,) or his wife, (Msb,) causing her to bleed; (Fr, Mgh, Msb;) not otherwise: (Msb:) or, accord. to some, i. q. jaAmaEahaA, in a general sense: (TA:) in this sense the verb is used in the Kur; (Msb;) or, as some say, in the sense expl. in the next sentence: (TA:) and Tumivato, aor. tuTomavu, she was caused to bleed by devirgination. (AHeyth, TA.)

Tamava, (AA, S, TA,) inf. n. TamovN, (AA, S, K, TA,) signifies also (tropical:) He, or it, touched a thing: (AA, S, K, * TA:) said in relation to anything that is touched: one says, maA Tamava caA AlmarotaEa qabolanaA OaHadN (tropical:) No one touched this place of pasturing, or this pasture, before us: and maA Tamava hecihi AlnRaAqapa HabolN qaTRu (tropical:) A rope such as is called EiqaAl never touched this she-camel: (AA, S, TA:) and hecaA jamalN maA Tamavahu HabolN qaTRu (tropical:) This is a camel which a rope has never touched. (TA.)
And Tamava AlbaEiyra, inf. n. TamovN (assumed tropical:) He bound the camel's fore shank to his (the camel's) arm. (TA.)

TamovN Blood: (Fr, TA: [the context in the TA seems to indicate that it means blood that flows when a woman, or girl, is devirginated:] or the blood of the menses; (KL, and TA in art. jzr;) as also TimovN↓. (KL.)
And Dirt, filth, or pollution. (K.)
And A thing that induces suspicion, or evil opinion: one says, maA bifulaAnK TamovN There is not, in such a one, anything that induces suspicion, or evil opinion. (TA.)
And Corruption. (L, K; but not in the CK.)
TimovN: see the next preceding paragraph.

TaAmivN, (S, Msb, K,) without p, (Msb, TA,) A woman, (S, Msb, K,) or, accord. to Lh, peculiarly a girl, or young woman, (TA,) menstruating: (S, Msb, K, TA:) or, as some say, for the first time. (Msb, TA.)

1. TamaHa baSaruhu Uilayohi, (S, L, K,) aor.
TamaHa
, (K,) inf. n. TumuwHN (K in art. md, and TK) and TimaAHN and TamoHN, (TK,) His sight, or eye, became raised towards it, (S, K,) i. e., a thing: (S:) or became stretched and raised towards it. (L.) And TamaHa bibaSarihi, aor.
TamaHa
, (L, Msb,) inf. n. TamoHN, (L,) or TumuwHN, (Msb,) He raised his eyes; (L, Msb;) [and] so baSarahu OaTomaHa↓: (S, K:) or cast his eyes: (L:) towards a thing (UilaI XaIoCK, L, or naHowa XaIoCK, Msb): [said to be] from the phrase jabalN TaAmiHN. (Msb.) And TamaHa baEayonihi, said of a proud man, He raised his eye. (A.) And TamaHato biEayonihaA She (a woman) cast her eye at a man. (L.) And TamaHato [alone], said of a woman, She raised her eyes. (L.) And taTomaHu UilaI AlrRijaAli [She raises her eyes towards, or looks at, men]. (S.)

And TamaHa, inf. n. TimaAHN and TumuwHN, (A, L, TA,) He (a horse) raised his head and his eyes in his running: (A, TA:) or he raised his fore legs; (L;) and so TmRH↓, inf. n. taTomiyHN: (T, L, K:) [or the former, he was, or became, refractory, and overcame his rider, running away with him: for] TimaAHN is syn. with jimaAHN, (K,) or like jimaAHN: (Yz, S:) one says, farasN fiyhi TimaAHN [a horse in which is refractoriness, &c.]. (S.)

TamaHato, aor.
TamaHa
, (L,) inf. n. TimaAHN, (L, K,) is also said of a woman, meaning (assumed tropical:) She was, or became, disobedient to her husband, resisting him, hating him, and deserting him: (L, K: *) and, thus said of a woman, TamaHato, (S, K,) or TamaHato EalaI zawojihaA, (A,) is syn. with, (A, K,) or like, (S,) jamaHato (tropical:) [she went forth from the place where she used to pass the night, in anger, without the permission of her husband]: (S, A, K:) and TamaHato mino zawojihaA and jamaHato (tropical:) she went forth from the house, or tent, of her husband, to her own family, before he divorced her. (TA in art. jmE.) And TamaHa, like jamaHa Alyh, said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He hastened, or went
quickly, to him, or it, so that his course was not turned for anything. (TA in art. TmH.)
TamaHa, inf. n. TimaAHN, also signifies (assumed tropical:) He was proud, and boastful; because he who is so exalts himself. (L.)

And TamaHa fiI AlsRawomi (assumed tropical:) He went far beyond what was right, or just, in making a bargain for his merchandise. (Lh, L.) And TamaHa, (S,) or TamaHa fiI AlTRalabi, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He went far in search; (S, K;) so accord. to some. (S.) [TamaHa UilaI kulRi XaIoC, said of the heart, app. means (assumed tropical:) It aspired to everything: see its part. n., TaAmiHN.]
TamaHa AlXRuxobu (assumed tropical:) The extended stream of milk from the udder fell upon the ground so as to be unprofitable. (Provs. of Meyd, section X: see XuxobN.)
TamaHa bihi (assumed tropical:) He made, or caused, him, or it, to go, go away, or pass away; took away, carried off, or went away with, him, or it. (K.)
And TamaHotu AlXRaIoCa [if not a mistranscription for TamRaHotu biAlXRaIoCi] (tropical:) I cast the thing in the air. (A.)
2: see 1.

TmRH bibawolihi, (S, K, TA,) and TmRH bawolahu, (L, TA,) and TmRH biAlXRaIoCi, inf. n. taTomiyHN, (T, TA,) (tropical:) He cast forth his urine, (S, L, K, TA,) and the thing, (T, TA,) in the air. (T, S, L, K, TA.) [See also 1, last sentence.]
4: see 1, second sentence.

TimoHN, or TimaHN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) expl. by Ibn-'Abbád, (K, TA,) in the Moheet, (TA,) as the name of A species of tree, is a mistake, being correctly with Z and x; (K, TA;) or it is also called Tmx as well Zmx. (TA in art. Zmx.)
niyRapN TamaHN i. q. baEiydapN [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A distant, or remote, thing, or place, that is the object of an action or journey]; like TaraHN and DaraHN. (O in art. DrH.)

TamaHaAtu AldRahori, (S, A, K.) and TamoHaAtuhu, (K,) the latter used by poetic license, (TA,) (tropical:) The hard, or distressing, events, or the calamities, or afflictions, of time, or fortune. (S, A, K.)
TamuwHu AlbaSari: see TaAmiHN.
baHorN TamuwHu Almawoji (A, TA) (tropical:) A sea of which the waves rise high. (TA.) And biYorN TamuwHu AlmaMCi (tropical:) A well of which the water has collected and risen high. (TA.)
sayorN TumaAHiIRN (assumed tropical:) A far, or distant, journey; like TuraAHiIRN. (As, O in art. TrH.)
TamRaAHN A long-sighted man. (L.) And TamRaAHapN A woman who looks much to the right and left at strange men, or at a man who is not her husband. (L.)
Also (assumed tropical:) Vehemently desirous, or greedy; or very vehemently desirous, or very greedy: (S, K:) applied to a man. (S.)

TaAmiHN [part. n. of 1: fem. with p: pl. of the latter TawaAmiHu]. You say nisaMCN TawaAmiHu UilaI AlrRijaAli [Women who raise their eyes towards, or look at, men]. (A.) And farasN TaAmiHu AlTRarofi, (A, L,) and TaAmiHu AlbaSari, and TamuwHuhu↓, (L,) A horse that raises, or elevates, his eye. (L.)

TaAmiHN [without p] is also an epithet applied to a woman, from TamaHato as syn. with, or similar to, jamaHato; [i. e. an epithet meaning That goes forth from the place where she has been accustomed to pass the night, in anger, without the permission of her husband; or that goes forth from the house, or tent, of her husband, to her own family, not having been divorced by him;] (S, K;) that raises her eyes towards, or looks at, men (taTomaHu UilaI AlrRijaAli): (S:) or that hates her husband, and looks towards other men: (Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee, T:) a woman disobedient to her husband, resisting him, hating him, and deserting him. (L.)

Also A high, overlooking, mountain. (Msb.) Anything high, lofty, or elevating itself. (S, K.) And (assumed tropical:) Anyone lofty, or elevating himself, in excessive pride. (T, TA.) And one says qalobN TaAmiHN UilaI kulRi XaIoC [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A heart aspiring to everything]. (Lth, O, K, TA, voce XaniqN.)

1. Tamara, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Tamura
, (O, Msb,) or
Tamira
, (K,) inf. n. TamorN, (A, O, Msb, K,) He buried (A, Msb, K) a corpse, in the earth: (Msb:) he hid, or concealed, (S, A, O, Msb, K,) a thing, (Msb,) or wheat, in a maTomuwrap, (S, O,) or himself, or his goods, (A, TA,) in a place where he, or they, could not be known. (TA.)
He filled a maTomuwrap. (S, K.) And He filled up a well. (TA.)

Az heard a man of 'Okeyl say of a stallion-camel that had covered a female, qado TamarahaA [meaning He inserted the whole of his veretrum into her; as is indicated by the context]: and UinRahu lakaviyru AlTRumuwri; and thus one says of a man, meaning Verily he is one who compresses much. (L, TA. [See also 4.])

Tamara signifies also He built. (O.) And [hence] one says, Oabiyhi huwa yaTomuru EalaI miTomaAri↓, (A, K, in the latter of which the verb is omitted,) meaning (tropical:) He imitates the actions of his father: (A, TA:) or he resembles his father in make and disposition. (K.)

And Tamara, aor.
Tamira
(S, O, K) and
Tamura
, (O,) inf. n. TumuwrN (S, A, O, K) and TamorN (K) and TimaArN (K, TA, in the CK TamAr) and TamaraAnN, (TA,) He leaped: (TA:) or he leaped downwards: (A, K:) or upwards (lit. in, or into, the sky): (A, K:) or he did what resembled leaping (S, O) upwards (lit. in, or into, the sky); (S;) thus does a horse; and the [bird called] Oaxoyal, in flying. (S, O.) And Tamara fiI AlrRakiyRapi, inf. n. TamorN and TumuwrN, He leaped into the well, from the top of it to the bottom. (Msb.) [It is said that] Tamara signifies He, or it, became, or rose, high: and also, became, or descended, low. (TA. [But perhaps it is a mistranscription for Tumira: see maTomuwrN.])

And Tamara fiI AlOaroDi, (TA,) inf. n. TumuwrN, (K,) He went away into, or in, the country, or land: (K, TA:) he became absent, or hidden, or concealed; or he absented, or hid, or concealed, himself. (TA.)
Tamara said of a wound, It became inflated, or swollen. (O, K.)
And Tamirato yaduhu, the verb in this case being of the class of fariHa, His arm, or hand, became swollen, (K,) and inflated. (TA.)
And Tumira fiI vadoIi AlmaroOapi The woman's breast became swollen. (O.)
And Tumira fiI Dirosihi Pain became excited in his tooth, or his lateral, or molar, tooth: (O, K:) the verb in this phrase [and in that next preceding] is like EuniIa. (K.)
2. TmRr, (O,) inf. n. taTomiyrN, (O, K,) He made his building high. (O.)

And i. q. TawaI [meaning He folded a written paper &c.; or rolled up a TuwmaAr, or scroll: and (assumed tropical:) He (the Creator) made the limbs, or shanks, of an animal, compact, or round; as though rolled up like scrolls]. (O, K, TA.) TumRirato, in a verse of Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr, [referring to a wild she-ass, or to her legs,] means (assumed tropical:) She was, or they were, rendered compact in make; or rounded, as though rolled up like as are TawaAmiyr [or scrolls]. (TA.)
And He let down a curtain. (K, TA.) One says, TamRaruwA buyuwtahumo They let down their curtains over their doors. (O, TA.)
4. ATmr guromuwlahu fiI AlHijori He (a horse) inserted the whole of his veretrum into the mare. (K. [See also 1, fourth sentence.])
8. ATRmr Ealayohi, of the measure AifotaEala, [originally AiTotamara,] He leaped upon him, namely, a horse, (K,) and a camel, (TA,) from behind, (K, TA,) and mounted him. (TA.)

TimorN An old and worn-out garment: (S, A, O, Mgh, Msb, K:) this is the meaning commonly known: (TA:) or an old and worn-out [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, not of wool: (IAar, A, K:) and TumoruwrN↓ signifies the same: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) pl. of the former OaTomaArN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the only pl. form. (Sb, TA.)
See also the next paragraph. [Freytag has assigned to this word, as on the authority of the K, three meanings which the K assigns to TumoruwrN.]

TimirRN (S, O, K) and TimorN↓ (O) and TimorirN↓ and TumoruwrN↓ (O, K) and TimoriyrN↓ (K) and OuTomurRN↓ (O, K) A horse in a state of excitement (musotafizRN [so accord. to my copies of the S, as though for musotafizRN nafosahu, or probably a mistranscription for musotafazRN,]) to leap and run: (S, O: [accord. to my copies of the former, musotafizRN lilowavobi waAlEadowi: in the O, musotafizRu Alwatobi waAlEadowi:]) or, accord. to AO, contracted [or compact] in make: (S, O:) and (O) a fleet, or swift, and excellent, horse: (O, K:) and the first, that leaps much; as also DibirRN: (O in art. Dbr:) or TumoruwrN↓ signifies longlegged, and light, or active: or ready, or in a state of preparation, for running: (K:) the fem.
TimirRapN is applied metaphorically by a poet to a she-ass as meaning vehement in running. (TA.)
And makaAnN TimirRN A high place. (O.)
TumurRN: see TumRarN.
TumurRapN: see TumRarapN.
TimorirN: see TimirRN.
TumoruwrN: see TimorN:
and see TimirRN, in two places.
Also A man (O) possessing nothing: (O, K:) accord. to IDrd, a low, vile, or mean, person, [so I render qaAniSN, q. v.,] in evil condition: a dial. var. of TumoluwlN. (O.) And A stranger. (O.)
And Dry wood. (O.)
And The [bird called] XiqirRaAq. (O, K.)
TimoriyrN: see TimirRN.

TamaAri, like qaTaAmi, [indecl.,] (S, O, K,) a proper name, (IAar, O,) The high place; (IAar, S, O, K;) as also TamaAra, with fet-h. (S, O, K.) One says, AinoSabRa Ealayohi mino TamaAri [He, or it, descended upon him from the high place]: (As, S, O:) Ks said mino TamaAra and TamaAri. (S. O.)
waqaEa fiI banaAti TamaAri (A, K, * TA) means (tropical:) He fell into calamities, and hardships, or difficulties: (A:) or calamity: (K, TA:) or trial: and hardship, or difficulty. (TA.)

TumRarN i. q. OaSolN; as also TimRaworN↓: (O, K:) so the former signifies in the saying, laOarudRanRahu UilaI TumRarihi [app. meaning I will assuredly reduce him to the utmost point, or degree, to which he can be reduced: see a similar phrase voce OaSolN]. (O, TA.)
And one says, fulaAnN TumRaru XarRK Such a one is evil in the utmost degree. (IAar, T in art. drn.)

And Oanota fiI TumRarika AlRaciI kunota fiyhi, (so in copies of the K and in the TA,) or TumurRika↓, (so in the O,) i. e. fiI girRatika wajaholika [Thou art in thy state of inexperience and ignorance in which thou wast formerly]: (O, K:) but [SM says] the right reading is fI garobika i. e. in thy [state of] sharpness, and briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: in some copies of the K, Eazomika wajahodika; and in some, Euroyika wajahodika; which are both mistranscriptions: (TA:) a saying mentioned by Fr. (O.)

TumRarapN, (so in copies of the K and accord. to the TA,) with damm to the T, and teshdeed and fet-h to the m; (TA;) or TumurRapN↓, with two dammehs, and teshdeed to the r; (O, and so accord. to the TK; [and this I think most probably the right;]) The first period of XabaAb [i. e. youthfulness, or young manhood, &c.]: (O, K:) so in the saying mentioned and expl. by Fr, kaAna celika fiI TumurRapi XabaAbihi [That was in the first period of his youthfulness, &c.]. (O.)
TimRaworN: see TumRarN.

TaAmirN (tropical:) The flea; (S, O;) [because of its leaping;] and (O) so TaAmiru bonu TaAmirK: (A, O, K:) pl. TawaAmiru. (TA.) One says, OaXoharu mino TaAmiri boni TaAmirK i. e. (tropical:) [More commonly known] than the flea. (A, TA.)
And TaAmiru bonu TaAmirK means also (assumed tropical:) The remote, who, as well as his father, is unknown: (K:) or the man (S, O) who is unknown, (O,) or whose place whence he comes is unknown. (S.)
TaAmuwrN: see what next follows.

TuwmaArN (S, A, K) and TaAmuwrN↓ (K) A piece of paper, or skin, on which something is written; syn. SaHiyfapN: (A, K:) [generally, a roll, or scroll;] a paper folded or rolled up (MA, and Har p. 254, each in explanation of the former word,) and written upon: (Har ibid.:) [a misarRap (an instrument in which one speaks secretly) is described in the S and K as being like a TuwmaAr: and this word is particularly applied, but perhaps as a post-classical term, to a roll of papyrus, or to paper made of papyrus; being syn. with qiroTaAsN used in this sense: (see De Sacy's “ Rel. de l'Égypte par Abd-Allatif, ” p. 109, where ElKindee is cited to this effect:) see also sijilRN:] TuwmaArN is said to be a foreign word introduced into the Arabic language; but ISd thinks it to be genuine Arabic, because Sb reckons it among the words that are Arabic in form, and asserts it to be quasi-coordinate to fusoTaATN: (TA:) the pl. is TawaAmiyru. (S, A, K, &c.) [qalamu TuwmaArK is a modern term for A sort of large handwriting.]
OuTomurRN: see TimirRN.

miTomarN The builder's ziyj, (S, O,) also called UimaAmN and turRN; (O;) [i. e.,] like these two words, it signifies the cord which the builder extends to make even, thereby, the row of stones or bricks of the building; (T in art. Am;) the builder's cord, or line, with which he proportions (K, TA) the building; (TA;) as also miTomaArN↓: (K, TA:) ↓the miTomaAr in the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz is the XaAquwl, (O,) which is a wooden implement, used by the sowers of the land at El-Basrah, (Lth, K, TA, all in art. Xql,) two cubits long, (Lth and TA ibid.,) or a staff a cubit long, (A and TA in art. bql,) having upon its head [or rather end] a zujR [or pointed iron], (Lth and K and TA in art. Xql, and A and TA in art. bql,) upon which one of them puts the end of a rope, and then he sticks it in the ground, and keeps it in its place firmly by stretching the rope [app. for the purpose of making even a row of seeds or the like]. (Lth and TA in art. Xql.) Hence, (O,) Oaqimi AlmiTomara, said to one relating a trad., means (tropical:) Rectify thou the tradition, and correct its expressions, (O, K, TA,) and trim it, and be veracious in it. (O, TA.) And huwa yaTomuru EalaI miTomaAri↓ Oabiyhi, expl. in the first paragraph. (A, K. *)
AlmuTomiraAtu: see AlmuTamRiraAtu.
muTamRarN (tropical:) Accumulated; applied to householdgoods (mataAE): and also applied to property (maAl) [in the same sense]. (A, TA.)
And, with p, applied to a she-ass, (tropical:) Long, and firm in make, (A, O, K, TA,) as though rounded, or rolled up, like as is the TuwmaAr [or scroll]. (A, * TA.)

AlEaZaAYimu AlmuTamRaraAtu, occurring in a trad., (O, TA,) as some relate it, (TA,) means The [great] sins that are hidden, or concealed: (O, TA:) or, as others relate it, the latter word is AlmuTamRiraAtu↓, (TA,) which means that destroy [the sinner]. (K, TA.)

AlOumuwru AlmuTamRiraAtu (so in two copies of the S, in the PS AlmuTomiraAt↓, in one of my copies of the S AlmTomiraAtu, and in the other of those copies omitted,) The affairs, or events, that destroy, or cause destruction. (S.) See also the next preceding paragraph.
miTomaArN: see miTomarN, in three places.
Also A man (K) wearing OaTomaAr [i. e. old and worn-out garments]. (O, K.)
maTomuwrN [pass. part. n. of Tamara, q. v.
Also] High: and low: thus having two contr. meanings. (TA.)

maTomuwrapN A hollow, or cavity, dug in the ground, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) widened in the lower part, (TA,) in which wheat is hidden, (S, Mgh,) or grain: (TA:) a house, chamber, cell, or cellar, constructed in the ground: (IDrd, Mgh, Msb:) pl. maTaAmiyru. (A, Mgh.)
And A prison, or place of confinement. (TA.)

1. Tamasa, aor.
Tamusa
and
Tamisa
, (S, M, Msb, K) inf. n. TumuwsN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and TamosN, (Zj;) It (a thing, as, for instance, a road, or path, T, S, M, Msb, and a writing, T, or a relic, trace, or vestige, A) became effaced, or obliterated; (T, S, M, A, Msb, K;) the trace, or mark, thereof (i. e. of a road &c.) became effaced, or obliterated: (M:) or it (a thing) quitted, or went from, its form, or shape: (Zj:) and AnTms↓ (said of a relic, or remain, or of a mark, or trace, and of a writing, TA, or other thing, S) has the first of the significations above; (S, A, K;) and so tTmRs↓. (S, K.)
It ((assumed tropical:) a star, T, M, and (assumed tropical:) the moon, and the sight, or eye, M) lost, or became deprived of, its light. (T, M.) [See also the pass. form in what follows.]
Tumuwsu Alqalobi means The heart's becoming in a bad, or corrupt, state. (O. [See also the last sentence of this paragraph.])
Tamasa AlrRajulu The man was, or became, distant, or remote; or went to a distance, or far away. (T, M, O, K.)
And Tamasa biEayonihi, (M, O, K,) inf. n. TamosN, (IDrd, O,) He looked far: (M, O, K:) or he looked at a thing from afar. (IDrd, O.)

Tamasahu, (S, IKtt, Msb, K,) and Tamasa Ealayohi, (M, TA,) aor.
Tamisa
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. TamosN, (S, Msb, K,) He effaced it, or obliterated it; (S, M, Msb, K;) he effaced, or obliterated, (M,) or removed, (TA,) or extirpated,
(K,) the trace, or mark, thereof; (M, K, TA;) as also TmRshu↓, (M, TA,) inf. n. taTomiysN: (TA:) or he destroyed it: (IKtt:) and Tamasa Almakotuwba is also expl. as signifying he covered the writing by folding. (Har p. 505.) You say, Tamasatohu AlrRiyHu The wind effaced, or obliterated, it; namely, the trace, or mark, of a thing. (A.) And it is said in the Kur [lxxvii. 8], faUicaA AlnRujuwmu Tumisato And when the stars shall have their traces extirpated: (O, K:) or shall lose their light. (T, TA.)
Tamasa OaEoyunahumo, [as in the Kur liv. 37,] (A,) and EalaI OaEoyunihimo, (T, A,) as in the Kur xxxvi. 66, (T,) He (God) blinded them. (T, TA.)
[Hence, app.,] Tamasa Algayomu AlnRujuwma (tropical:) [The clouds, or mist, covered, or concealed, the stars; as though it put out their light]. (A.)

And [hence also,] Tamasa, aor.
Tamisa
, (O, K,) inf. n. TamaAsapN, (O, * K, * TK,) (assumed tropical:) He conjectured, or computed by conjecture, (O, K, TA, TK,) a thing: (TK:) because the doing so is generally accompanied by the putting of the eyelids together, as though one were blinded. (TA.)

Tamasahu, inf. n. TamosN, also signifies He (God) transformed, or metamorphosed, him or it. (TA.) Hence the saying in the Kur [x. 88], rabRanaA QTomiso EalaI OamowaAlihimN O our Lord, transform their possessions: (TA:) they say that they became stones: (O, TA:) or change, or alter, their possessions: (S, O:) or destroy their possessions: (Ibn-Arafeh, O, Bd, K:) the verb is also read QTomuso. (Bd.) This Tamos was the last of the nine signs which were given to Moses, when the property of Pharaoh was transformed at his prayer, and became stones. (M.) [See the Kur xvii. 103, and xxvii. 12.] In like manner, it is said in the Kur [iv. 50], mino qaboli Oano naTomisa wujuwhFA Before we change, or alter, faces: (S:) or these words, with what immediately follows, fanarudRahaA EalaI OadobaArihaA, are expl. in three different ways: before we make faces to be like the backs of necks: or before we make faces to be places in which hair shall grow like the backs of necks: or (tropical:) before we make them to err, in requital of their opposition. (Zj, TA.)
TamosN also signifies i. q. fasaAdN [as though in the sense of UifosaAdN The making, or rendering, bad, corrupt, &c.: but see Tumuwsu Alqalobi, above]. (TA.)
2: see Tamasahu, in the paragraph above.
5: see 1, first sentence.
7: see 1, first sentence.
TamiysN: see TaAmisN, in four places.
TamaAsapN Conjecture; or computation by conjecture. (Fr, Mgh, O, K. [Accord to the TK, an inf. n.: see 1.])

rasomN TaAmisN [A relic, or remain, or a mark, or trace, becoming, or become, effaced, or obliterated]; (A;) [and so, app., TamiysN↓ and maTomuwsN↓:] and OarobuEN TimaAsN [pl. of raboEN TamiysN↓ or TaAmisN] dwellings of which the remains are becoming, or become, effaced, or obliterated. (M.)

[EayonN TaAmisapN An eye of which the sight is going, or gone: and] rajulN maTomuwsN↓ a man whose sight is going, or gone; as also TamiysN↓: (K:) or a blind man, (Zj, M,) the edge of whose eyelid is not apparent: (Zj, T, M:) or a man who has no slit between his two eyelids; as also TamiysN↓: (A:) and najomN TaAmisN (tropical:) a star [that is evanescent,] of which the light is going, or gone: (A:) and nujuwmN TawaAmisu (tropical:) stars that become hidden, or concealed, or that set: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) stars that are covered by the saraAb [app. a mistranscription for saHaAb or clouds], so that they are not seen. (Az, TA.) And TaAmisN signifies also Distant, or remote: (T, K, TA:) or a mountain not plainly discernible from afar: (TA:) pl. TawaAmisu. (K, TA.) And A desert far-extending and pathless. (M, TA.)
rajulN TaAmisu Alqalobi (tropical:) A man dead in heart, (A, K,) who keeps nothing in mind: (A:) or a man of bad, corrupt, or depraved, heart. (IKtt.)
riyaAHN TawaAmisu [pl. of riyHN TaAmisapN] (A, TA) Winds that efface, or obliterate, things, by repeatedly passing over them; syn. dawaArisu. (TA.)
maTomuwsN: see TaAmisN, in two places.

1. TamiEa fiyhi (S, O, Msb, K, &c.) and bihi, (O, K,) aor.
TamaEa
, (O, K,) inf. n. TamaEN (S, O, Msb, K) and TamaAEapN, (S, O, TA,) accord. to all the copies of the K [and my copy of the Msb] TamaAEN, but this is wrong, (TA,) and TamaAEiyapN, (S, O, Msb, K,) without teshdeed, (S, Msb,) and TamaAEiyRapN, with teshdeed, as in the L, but some disapprove this last, (TA,) He coveted it; i. e. desired it vehemently, eagerly, greedily, very greedily, excessively, inordinately, or culpably; or he strove to acquire, obtain, or attain, it; syn. HaraSa Ealayohi: (K, TA:) TamaEN signifying the longing, or yearning, for a thing; or lusting after it; mostly, for the gratification of animal appetite, without any lawful incitement: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and it is mostly used in relation to that of which the occurrence, or coming to pass, is [deemed] near: but sometimes TamiEa fiyhi signifies he hoped for it. (Msb.) [See also TamaEN below. One says also, TamiEa fiI fulaAnK, meaning He eagerly desired, or he hoped, to make himself master of, or to overcome, such a one: (see an ex. voce xaAziqN:) and TamiEa fiI fulaAnapa he eagerly desired, or he hoped, to gain possession of, or to win, such a woman; or he lusted after her.]

TamuEa, said of a man, means He became very covetous; (SaAra kaviyra AlTRamaEi: S, O, K:) [or rather how covetous is he! for] it is a verb of wonder; the verbs of wonder being of three forms, accord. to rule; as in the exs. maM OaHosana zayodFA and OasomiEo bihi and kaburato kalimapF; from which niEoma and biYosa are anomalous exceptions. (S, O.)
2: see what next follows.
[See also taTomiyEN below.]
4. ATmEhu He made him to covet, &c.; (S, * O, * Msb, * K, TA;) and so TmREhu↓, inf. n. taTomiyEN: (TA:) the verb is followed by fiI [and app. by bi also] before the object. (S.)
5. tTmRE fiI AlmaroOapi [He became excited to feel an eager desire for the woman; or to lust after her]. (TA in art. xDE.)

TamaEN an inf. n. of TamiEa. (S, O, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, AlTRamaEu faqorN waAlyaOosu ginFI [meaning Coveting, or covetousness, or greed, is a cause of poverty, and despair is a cause of freedom from want]. (TA.) And one says, AlTRamaEu TabaEN [Coveting, or covetousness, or greed, is a cause of disgrace, or dishonour]. (TA. See OaTomaEu.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce TabaEN. And see an ex. voce xaAYifN.]
And A thing that is coveted, or desired vehemently &c.: (Ham p. 517:) [pl. OaTomaAEN. See also maTomaEN.]

And hence, (Ham ibid.,) The daily, or monthly, allowance of food or the like, subsistence-money, or pay, (syn. rizoq,) of soldiers: pl. OaTomaAEN: (S, O, Msb, K:) or their OaTomaAE are their times of receiving such allowances. (K.)
TamuEN: see the next paragraph.

TamiEN (S, O, Msb, K) and TaAmiEN↓ (O, Msb, K) and TamuEN↓ (S, O, K) and TamRaAEN↓ and TamuwEN↓ (TA) epithets from TamiEa: (S, O, Msb, K:) [the first and second signify Coveting, &c.: and the rest, coveting &c. much, or very covetous &c.:] pl. [of the first] TamiEuwna and [of the second or of the first] TumaEaMCu and [of the first] TamaAEaI and [of the first or third or second] OaTomaAEN. (K.)
TamuwEN: see the next preceding paragraph.
TamRaAEN: see the next preceding paragraph.
TaAmiEN: see the next preceding paragraph.

OaTomaEu [More, and most, covetous &c.]. OaTomaEu mino qaAlibi AlSRaxorapi [More covetous than the turnerover of the great mass of stone] is a prov., of which the origin was this: a man of Ma'add saw a stone in the land of El-Yemen, on which was inscribed, OaqoliboniI OanofaEoka [“ Turn me over, I will benefit thee ”]: and he exercised his skill in turning it over, and found [inscribed] on the other side, yahodiI UilaI TabaEK rubRa TamaEK↓ [Many a coveting leads to disgrace]: and he ceased not to beat with his head the great mass of stone, by reason of regret, until his brains issued and he died. (Meyd.)
taTomiyEN inf. n. of 2. (TA.)

[Hence,] taTomiyEu
AlqaTori (assumed tropical:) The first of rain, when it begins, and little thereof comes: so called because it causes to covet more. (IAar, TA.)

maZomaEN A thing that is [or that is to be] coveted, or desired vehemently &c.: (O, K: [see also TamaEN:]) pl. maTaAmiEu. (O, TA.) One says, TamiEa fiIgayori maTomaEK [He coveted a thing not to be coveted; or] he hoped for a thing of which the attainment was remote, or improbable. (Msb.)
And [hence,] (tropical:) A bird that is put in the midst of the fowler's net in order to ensnare thereby other birds: pl. as above. (TA.)
[And it is also used as an inf. n., agreeably with general analogy.] One says, laA maTomaEa fiI buroYihi [There is no hope for its cure]. (K in art. srT.)
maTomaEapN [A cause of coveting, or desiring vehemently &c.;] a thing on account of which one covets, &c. (O, K.) En-Nábighah EdhDhubyánee says,
[And despair of what has become beyond reach occasions, as its result, rest: and assuredly many a cause of coveting is, in its result, (like) a disease in the fauces, or a poisonous plant]. (O.)
AimoraOapN miTomaAEN A woman that causes vehement desire (tuTomiEu) but does not grant attainment. (S, O, K.)
3. TaAmana: see Q. Q. 1, in three places.
6. taTaAmana: see Q. Q. 2: and also Q. Q. 4, in two places.

Q. Q. 1. TaOomana Zahorahu, (S, Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) with C, (Msb,) or TaAmanahu↓, (TA, and so in some copies of the K,) without C, for the C in AiTomaOanRa [q. v. infrà] is [said to be] for the purpose of preventing the combination of two quiescent letters, (TA,) or TaAmanahu also, the former being the original, (Msb,) He (a man, Msb) bent down his back; (Msb, TA;) he lowered it; (Msb;) and TamoOanahu signifies the same. (S, K.) [And in like manner one says of other things.]
And AlXRaIoCa TaAmana↓ [or TaOomanahu], and TamoOanahu, He caused the thing to be, or become, still, in a state of rest, quiet, or calm. (TA.)

And minohu TaAmana↓ [or TaOomana], (S,) or TamoOana mnh, (K, TA,) He (a man, S) was, or became, at rest from it, (S, K,) namely, an affair, or event. (K.) [The inf. n. of TOmn is TaOomanapN, said in the TA to be syn. with AiTomiYonaAnN. See also Q. Q. 4.]

Q. Q. 2. taTaOomana [more commonly written taTaAmana↓, without C, and AiTomaOanRa↓ also (see rakaEa)] He stooped, [bent himself down,] or lowered himself; syn. taTaOoTaOa. (S and TA in art. TO, &c.; and R and TA in the present art.)
And (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; syn. xaDaEa. (S and K in art. xDE, &c.: in some copies of each written with, and in others without, C.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.

Q. Q. 4. AiTomaOanRa is said by some to be originally [AiTomaAnRa] like AiHomaArRa, (Msb,) as Esh-Shiháb states in the Expos. of the Shifè, (TA,) and to be pronounced with C for the purpose of avoiding [the combination of] the two quiescent letters, (Msb, TA,) anomalously: (Msb:) and some say that it is originally AiToOamanRa, (Msb, TA,) because you say TaOomana AlrRajulu Zahorahu, with C, (Msb,) or, as Suh says, in the R, because it is from taTOomana, the m being put before the C in order to render the word more easy of pronunciation, (TA,) therefore it is anomalous; (Msb;) Sb [likewise] held it to be formed by transposition, and derived from TaOomana; but AA held the contrary to be the case. (TA.)
You say, AiTomaOanRati AlOaroDu, and taTaAmanat↓ [or taTaOomanat↓], meaning The land, or ground, was, or became, low, or depressed. (TA.)
See also Q. Q. 2.

ATmOnR, (S, Mgh, K,) inf. n. AiTomiYonaAnN and TumaOoniynapN, (S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mgh, Msb,) signifies [also] He (a man, S) was, or became, still, in a state of rest or ease, quiet, or calm; syn. sakana; (S, Mgh;) as also AiTobaOanRa, which is formed by permutation. (S.) And thus it signifies as said of the heart, i. e. It was, or became, still, in a state of rest or ease, quiet, calm, tranquil, unruffled, or free from disquietude. (Msb.) Thus too in the saying, ATmOn UilaI kacaA, i. e. (tropical:) He trusted to such a thing, or relied upon it, so as to become at rest or ease, or quiet, in mind. (K, * TA.) And one says also, ATmOnR jaAlisFA [He became still, or at rest, or at ease, sitting]: (TA:) and ATmOnR binaA Aljuluwsu [lit. The sitting became still, or free from disquiet, with us]; meaning AisotaqoraronaA wasakanRaA fiI Aljuluwsi [i. e. we became settled, or at rest or ease, and still, in the sitting; or became seated at ease]. (Har p. 280.) And ATmOnR biAlmawoDiEi [He settled in the place; i. e.] he remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place, and took it as his home. (Msb.) And ATmOnR EamRaA kaAna yafoEaluhu (assumed tropical:) [He became at rest from that which he was doing;] i. e. he desisted from that which he was doing. (TA.) And fiyhi taTaAmunN↓ [or taTaOomunN↓] In him is quietness, calmness, or sedateness. (TA.)
TamonN: see muTomaYinRN.
TumayoYinN dim. of muTomaYinRN; (S, K;) formed by rejecting the m at the beginning, and one of the two ns at the end, of the latter word. (S.)
TumaOoniynapN an [irreg.] inf. n. of AiTomaOanRa, (S, K,) or a subst. therefrom; as such signifying [A depression in the ground; as, for instance, in the S and K voce razonN: (comp. muTomaOanRN:)
and also] Stillness, a state of rest or ease, quietness, calmness, tranquillity, or freedom from disquietude. (Mgh, Msb.)
TumayoYiynapN dim. of TumaOoniynpN; formed by the rejection of one of the two ns in the latter word, because it is augmentative. (S.)
muTomaOanRN A place of depression or lowness in the land or ground. (Mgh. [See also the following paragraph.])
muTomaOanRN Uilayohi (tropical:) A thing to which one trusts, or upon which one relies, so as to become at rest or ease, or quiet, in mind. (S, K, * TA.)
muTomaYinRN A place low, or depressed. (Mgh, Msb.)

And A man (S) still, in a state of rest or ease, quiet, or calm; (S, Mgh, K;) as also TamonN↓, (K,) but this is a word unused in the [genuine] language, (TA,) pl. TumuwnN. (K.) Hence one says, huwa muTomaYinRN UilaI kacaA (tropical:) He is trusting to such a thing, or relying upon it, so as to be at rest or ease, or quiet, in mind. (S, K, * TA.) And [it is said that] AlnRafosu AlmuTomaYinRapu means (assumed tropical:) The soul that has become at rest or ease, quiet, or calm, by belief; and lowly, humble, or submissive, to its Lord. (TA. [See the Kur lxxxix. 27.])
Also Taking for oneself a place in the earth, or in a country, as a home, or settled place of abode. (TA.)

1. TayaA, aor. yaToyuw, inf. n. TuyuwRN; and TayaI, aor. yaTomiI, (S, K,) inf. n. TumiIRN, (S,) thus in the M [as well as in the S], or TamoIN, thus in the K and in the book of ISk; (TA;) said of water, (S, K,) It became high, (K,) or it rose high, and filled the channel in which it flowed. (S.) [See also TamRa.]
And, both verbs, said of a plant, It became tall. (K.)
Also, (K, TA,) said of the sea, and of a river, and of a well, (TA,) It became full: (K, TA:) so says Lth. (TA.)
And Tamato bizawojihaA (tropical:) She (a woman) exalted herself with her husband; syn. AirotafaEato bihi; (S, TA;) from TamaA or TamaI said of water: (S:) or she grinned at her husband. (Z, TA.)

Tamato bihi himRatuhu, aor.
1a2u2a
and
1a2i2a
as above, (assumed tropical:) His ambition elevated him. (K, * TA.)
And TamaA bihi said of anxiety, and of grief, and of fear, (assumed tropical:) It became vehement in him: the following verse by himself is quoted by Z:

L.foreign: qado TamaA biI xawofu AlmaniyRapi lekino

sense.s: [(assumed tropical:) The fear of death has become vehement in me, but the fear of what will follow death is more vehement.] (TA.)

And TamaI, aor. yaTomiI,
like TamRa, aor. yaTimRu, signifies He passed by, or along, hastening, or going quickly: (S, TA:) and hence, TamaA [or TamaI], said of a horse, He hastened, or went quickly. (TA.)

[TamaAyapN is said by Golius, as on the authority of Z, to signify Solicitude, and fear: but probably, I think, from his having found TayaAyapN hamRN waxawofN erroneously written for TamaA bihi hamRN waxawofN, meaning “ fear became vehement in him. ”]
maMCN TaAmK Water rising high, and filling its channel. (S.) And baHorN TaAmK A [high or] copious sea. (TA.)
OaTomaI [More, and most, vehement]: see the verse cited above.

1. TanRa, (MA, Msb, K, TA,) aor.
Tanina
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. TaniynN [q. v. infrà], (MA, Msb,) It made a sound [of a continued or a reiterated kind, and either low or sharp]; (MA, Msb, K, TA;) as also TnRn↓, and TanoTana↓. (K.) You say, TanRa AlcRubaAbu [and TanoTana↓, as also danRa and danodana,] The flies made a [humming, or buzzing,] sound. (MA, Msb.) And in like manner TanRa is said of other things than flies. (Msb.) [Thus,] TanRa AlTRasotu, (MA,) or TanRati AlTRasotu, (S,) The basin of brass or other metal made a [ringing, or tinkling,] sound. (S, MA.) And AlbaTRapu taTinRu The duck, or goose, utters a sound or sounds [i. e. quacks]. (S.)
[Hence,] one says also, TanRa cikoruhu fiI AlbilaAdi (assumed tropical:) [His fame resounded through the countries]. (TA.)
And TanRat AlUibilu (assumed tropical:) The camels thirsted [app. because thirst is often attended with a ringing, or tingling, in the ears]. (TA.)
And TanRato saAquhu (tropical:) His shank was quickly cut off: the verb being imitative of the sound of the shank in its falling. (TA.)
And TanRa (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA) died: (S, K:) so in the “ Musannaf ” [of Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee]. (S.)
And (assumed tropical:) He licked his finger. (TA.)
2: see the foregoing paragraph, first sentence.
4. ATnR AlTRasota He caused the basin of brass or other metal to make a [ringing, or tinkling,] sound. (S, K.)

And ATnR saAqahu (S, K) (tropical:) He cut off his shank (S, K, TA) quickly; (TA;) or ATnR yadahu he made his arm, or hand, to fall off; (so in a copy of the S;) by a stroke [of a sword or the like]; the verb being meant to imitate the sound of the cutting, (S,) or the sound of the limb in its falling; and in like manner one says OatanRahaA [and OaTarRahaA] and OatarRahaA, meaning the same. (TA.)
8. huwa yuTRanRu bikacaA, meaning He is suspected of such a thing, is originally yuZotanRu; as also yuZRanRu. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. TanoTana: see 1, first and second sentences.

TanRN [accord. to the CK TinRN, being there said to be with kesr, but not so in other copies of the K, nor in the TA,] Fresh, ripe, red dates, very sweet, (K, TA,) and having much flowing juice; as also TunRN↓, with damm. (TA.)
Also, [if not a mistranscription for TunRN,] A half-load, such as is borne on one side of a beast, of cotton that has been separated, or loosened, and cleared of its seeds: from El-Hejeree. (TA.)

TunRN A bundle of reeds or canes, (S, M, K,) or (so accord. to the Msb, but in the TA “ and ”) of firewood: (Msb, TA:) thought by IDrd to be not genuine Arabic: and pronounced by the vulgar TinR, with kesr: (TA:) n. un. with p; (K;) [i. e.] TunRapN↓ signifies a single reed or cane [or piece of firewood] of a bundle: (S:) and the pl. is OaTonaAnN: (Msb:) [or,] accord. to AHn, a TunR of reeds or canes, and of fresh branches, is a wryqp [app. meaning a leafy bundle] put together and bound round, and having flowers, or blossoms, and plucked fruits put in the interior thereof. (TA.)
And A thing that is put between the two half-loads that are upon the sides of a beast. (AHeyth, K.)

And The stature [of a man]: or, accord. to IAar, (TA,) the body of a man and of any animal: pl. OaTonaAnN and TinaAnN: (K, TA:) whence, he says, the saying, fulaAnN laA yaquwmu biTunRi nafosihi fakayofa bagayorihi [Such a one will not rise with his own body: how then with another?]: but accord. to IDrd, this is a saying of the vulgar; and he does not think it to be genuine Arabic. (TA.)
See also TanRN.
TunRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
TinRapN: see ZinRapN.
TunRiIRN A large-bodied man. (K, TA.)

TaniynN an inf. n.: (MA, Msb: [see 1:]) [as a simple subst.,] The sound of flies [i. e. a humming, or buzzing]: and of a basin of brass or other metal [i. e. a ringing, or tinkling]: (S, K, TA:) and of the ear [i. e. a ringing, or tingling]: and of a mountain: and of a hard thing [of any kind]: and TanoTanapN↓ has a similar meaning. (TA.)
qaSiydapN TanRaAnapN [A sonorous ode.] (TA.)

TanoTanapN: see TaniynN. It is an onomatopœia, meaning The sound of the [kind of mandoline called] Tunobuwr, and the like, (K, TA,) such as the lute. (TA.) And Low, faint, or soft, speech. (TA.) And Loquacity, and a sounding utterance of speech. (TA.)
rajulN cuw TanoTaAnK A clamorous man. (K.)

1. TaniYa, aor.
TanaAa
, said of a camel, He had his spleen adhering to his side. (K.) And, said of a man, He had a tertian fever, and his spleen in consequence became enlarged. (Lh, TA.) Thus pronounced by some with C [for TaniIa, q. v.]. (TA.)

4. OaTonaOa [He suffered not to retain the last remains of life]. One says, hecihi HayRapN laA tuToniYu This is a serpent that will not suffer one to survive; (S, O, K; *) that hills instantly: also without C, but originally with C; from TinoCN in the first of the senses assigned to it below. (S, O.)
TinoCN The [last] remains of the vital spirit. (S, O, K.) One says, tarakotuhu biTinoYihi I left him with the [last] remains of life. (S, O.)

And The remains of water in a watering-trough, or tank. (O, K, TA.) And it is said that rawoDapN, by which it is also expl. in the K [and in the O], has this meaning [as well as that of A meadow, &c.]; and therefore this explanation without the former is given in the L. (TA.)
And Ashes in a state of extinction: (O, K:) and so TanFI. (K and TA in art. TnI.)

[And app. A bier; for this is a meaning assigned to nayoTN; and] one says, rumiIa fulaAnN fiI TinoYihi [and fI Tinoyihi] and fI nayoTihi [Such a one was cast into his bier]; meaning, when he died. (AZ, TA.)
And A disease, or malady. (K.)

And Doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion; or a thing that occasions doubt or suspicion or evil opinion; syn. riybapN; (S, O, K, TA; in the CK ruboyap;) and tuhamapN: (TA:) and so TinoIF. (TA in art. TnI.) Fr. cites,
meaning, EalaI ciI AlrRiybapi [i. e. As though there were a discerning eye upon him in whom is that which occasions doubt, &c.]. (TA.)

1. Taniba, aor.
Tanaba
, inf. n. TanabN, He (a horse) was long in the back. (O, Msb, TK.) [See TanabN below: and see also 2.]
[And app., in like manner said of a horse, He was long and lax in the hind legs. See, again, TanabN below.]
And It (a spear) was, or became, crooked. (TK.)

2. TnRbhu, inf. n. taToniybN, He extended it, (K, TA,) namely, a tent, (A, TA,) by means of its OaTonaAb [or tent-ropes], and tied it, or made it fast. (K, TA.) And TnRb [alone] He stretched his tent-ropes and pitched his tent. (TA voce raAfiDN, q. v.)
[Hence,] TnRb biAlmakaAni, (S, K,) or biAlbaladi, (A,) (tropical:) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the place, or in the country or town. (S, A, K.)
And TnRb Alqawosa He attached an UiTonaAbap [q. v.] to the bow. (TA.)
And taToniybu AlsRiqaMCi means taTobiybuhu [q. v.], (K,) i. e. The hanging the milk-skin to a pole of the tent, and then agitating it to produce the butter. (AA, TA.)

TnRb said of a horse, He was long in the maton [i. e. the back, or the portion of flesh and sinew on either
side of the back-bone]. (S, O. [See also 1.])
And, said of a wolf, He howled. (K.)
3. TaAnabotuhumo fiI AlmaHaAlRi I had my tent-ropes (TunubiI) next to theirs in the places of alighting. (A.)
4. ATnbt AlrRiyHu, (inf. n. UiTonaAbN, Msb,) The wind blew violently, and was accompanied with dust. (S, O, Msb, K.)

And hence, ATnb said of a man, (Msb,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He exerted himself much, or beyond measure, or to the utmost, or was extravagant, or immoderate, (Msb, TA,) and profuse, (TA,) in praising or blaming: (Msb, TA:) or ATnt fiI AlkalaAmi he so exerted himself, or was extravagant or immoderate, in speech: (S, O, TA:) or he was eloquent in description, whether praising or blaming; (K, TA;) and so in speech: (TA:) and ATnb fiI AlwaSofi he exerted himself much, or beyond measure, or to the utmost, in description. (IAmb, TA.) And ATnb fiI Eadowihi (assumed tropical:) He exerted himself much, or beyond measure, or to the utmost, in his runnning. (IAmb, TA.)
ATnbt AlUibilu (assumed tropical:) The camels followed one another in journeying. (S, O, K.)
And ATnb AlnRahoru (assumed tropical:) The river went [or flowed] far away. (K.)
TunobN: see TunubN.

TanabN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (O, Msb, TK.) Length in the back of a horse; (A, O, Msb, K;) which is a fault (A, O, Msb, K, TA) in the male, but not in the female: (TA:) one says, fiyhi TanabN (A) or fiI Zahorihi TanabN (TA) In him is length in the back (A) or in his back is length. (TA.) And Length in the kind legs [of a horse], together with laxness. (K, TA.)
And Crookedness in a spear. (S, O, K.)

TunubN (S, A, O, L, Msb, K) and TunobN↓ (L, TA) A tent-rope: (Ham p. 687:) a rope with which the xayomap and the like are tied, or made fast: (Msb:) a rope of the xibaMC (S, O, L, TA) and of the suraAdiq [q. v.] and the like: (L, TA:) a long rope with which the srAdq of the tent is tied, or made fast; (A, K, TA;) or, as in the M, with which the tent and the srAdq are tied, or made fast, [extending] between the ground and the TaraAYiq [pl. of TariyqapN, q. v.]: (TA:) and also a watid [app. meaning a tent-peg]; thus in the K, and the like is said in the M; those who make Alwatidu in the K to be conjoined with srAdq [as though the author meant that Tnb signifies a long rope with which the srAdq of the tent, and the peg, are tied, or made fast,] being in error: (TA: [but in my opinion, this reading which is disallowed in the TA is more probably correct than the other: in the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K, instead of waAlwatidu, we find Aw Alwtd: in a copy of the A, Aw Alwatiru, an obvious mistranscription:]) the pl. is OaTonaAbN (S, O, Msb, K) and TinabapN; (K;) and some of the lexicologists assert that TunubN is used as a sing. like EunuqN, and as a pl. like kutubN; (MF, TA;) and Ibn-es-Sarráj says, in one place of his book, that it has no other pl. than OaTonaAbN; but in another place he says that it has this pl. accord. to those who give it a pl., thus giving to understand that there is a difference of opinion as to the plural's being allowable, and that it is used in one form as sing. and pl., which is the case: (Msb, TA:) the OaTonaAb are the OawaAxiIR [pl. of MxiyRapN], i. e. the long ropes of the Oaxobiyap [pl. of xibaMC]; the short ropes being called OuSurN, sing. UiSaArN: the former are the ropes with which the tent is tied, or made fast, between the ground and the TaraAYiq. (TA.) As an instance of a tropical usage, (A, TA,) it is related that when El-Ash'ath contracted marriage with a woman, (A, Nh, O, Msb, L,) namely, Meleekeh Bint-Zurárah, (Nh, Msb, L,) on the terms upon which she should decide, (A, Nh, O, &c.,) and she decided upon a hundred thousand dirhems, (A, Nh, Msb, L,) radRahaA Eumaru UilaI OaTonaAbi bayotihaA, meaning (tropical:) ' Omar reduced her to the dowry of the like of her among the women of her family; (A, Nh, O, Msb, L;) [lit., to the ropes of her tent, or to the tent-ropes of her family;] i. e., to the ground whereon was built the condition of her family, and over which their tent-ropes extended. (Nh, L.) And another tropical usage occurs in the saying, maA bayona TunubaIi Almadiynapi OaHowaju minRiI UilayohaA, (TA,) a saying ascribed to the Prophet, (O,) meaning (tropical:) What is between the two extremities, (O, TA,) and the two sides, (TA,) of the city is more in need of it than I. (O, TA.)

[Hence,] (tropical:) A sinew, or tendon, (S, O, K,) or ligament, (M, A,) of the body, (S, M, O, K,) that ties the joints and bones: (M:) pl. OaTonaAbN. (M, A.) OaTonaAbu AlOaSaAbiEi means (tropical:) The tendons of the fingers, [or the interossei,] on the outer side of the hand, extended above the sulaAmaI, from the wrist to the lowest parts of the fingers. (A, * and TA voce OaXojaEu, q. v.)

And (assumed tropical:) A certain tendon in the uppermost part of the chest: (K, TA:) [or,] accord. to the L, the TunubataAni [or TunubaAni?] are two tendons [or the sterno-mastoïdes] next the pit of the throat, that extend, or stretch, when a man turns his head aside. (TA.)

And (tropical:) The root of a tree: (S, A, O, K:) pl. OaTonaAbN: (A:) or this (the pl.) signifies the minor roots that branch off from the root-stock or main body of the root. (TA.) You say, taqabRaDato OaTonaAbuhaA (tropical:) [Its roots contracted;] meaning it was planted. (A.)

And OaTonaAbu AlXRamosi (tropical:) The rays, or beams, of the sun, that extend like sinews, or tendons, at the time of its rising. (TA.) You say, madRati AlXRamosu OaTonaAbahaA [and AimotadRato OaTonaAbuhaA] (tropical:) [The sun extended its beams and its beams became extended], meaning the sun rose. (A.)
See also UiTonaAbapN.
TaniybN: see muTaAnibN.
OaTonabu Having the quality termed TanabN; long in the back; [&c.;] (A, O, Msb, K;) applied to a horse: (A, O, Msb:) fem. TanobaMCu. (Msb, K.)
UiTonaAbapN A miZalRap; (S, O, K, TA; [in one of my copies of the S muZilRap, and in the CK maZalRap, but, as is said in the TA, it is with kesr;]) meaning a large tent of [goats'] hair. (KL.)

And A thong at the head of the bow-string; (As, TA;) a thong that is bound to the end of the string of the Arabian bow: (S, O:) or the thong that is at the lower curved extremity of the bow and that binds the string to the notch: (TA:) or, as also TunubN↓, a thong that is connected with the bowstring, and then wound round the kuZor, (K, TA,) which is the notch of the bow, into which the ring of the bow-string goes. (TA.)

And A thong, or strap, that is bound to the end of the girth, as an aid to its [main] strap when it becomes loose, or unsteady: (TA:) or a thong, or strap, of the girth, that is tied in a knot to the buckle: pl. OaTaAniybu. (O, TA.) En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee (O)] says, (O, TA,) describing horses, and the same words occur in a verse of Selámeh, (TA,)

which is said to mean, [Striking the ground with their hoofs,] the knots of the breast-girths (AlOalobaAb and AlHuzum) having become loose. (O, TA. [Euqodu is here put for Euqadu for the sake of the metre.])

One says also xayolN OaTaAniybu, (O,) and gaAraAtN OaTaAniybu, (A, O,) meaning (tropical:) [Horses or horsemen, and horsemen making a raid,] following one another (A, O) continuously, without [visible] end. (A.) And raOayotu UiTonaAbapF mino xayolK and mino TayorK (assumed tropical:) [I saw a number following one another of horses or horsemen and of birds]. (O.)

maTonabN The shoulder, syn. manokib; and the part between the shoulder-joint and the neck, syn. EaAtiq: (S, O, K:) and accord. to a marginal note in a copy of the L, miTonabN↓ signifies the same: (TA:) pl. maTaAnibu. (S, O.)
Also, with the article, i. q. Habolu AlEaAtiqi: [see HabolN and EaAtiqN:] pl. as above. (TA.)
muTonibN [part. n. of 4, q. v. As such signifying] (assumed tropical:) A great praiser of every one. (TA.)
And nahorN muTonibN (tropical:) A river that goes [or flows] far away. (A, O.) [See also muTanRibN.]
miTonabN: see maTonabN.

muTanRabN A tent, (bayot, O, or xibaMC, S,) and a riwaAq, (S,) tied, or made fast, with OaTonaAb [or tentropes]. (S, O.) A man is related to have said to Ubeí Ibn-Kaab, in reply to the latter's advising him to buy a beast to convey him to the place of prayer of the Prophet, maA OaHibRu Oano bayotiI muTanRabN bibayoti muHamRadK i. e. [I do not like] that my tent should be tied with tent-ropes to the tent of Mohammad: as though he reckoned upon a reward for his many foot-steps to the mosque. (O.)
And qawosN muTanRabapN A bow having an UiTonaAbap [q. v.] attached to it. (TA.)

EasokarN muTanRibN [perhaps correctly muTonibN, q. v.,]
(assumed tropical:) An army of which the remotest part is not seen, by reason of its multitude. (TA. [See also what next follows.])
jayoXN miTonaAbN (assumed tropical:) A great army; (K;) an army of which the two extremities are far apart, that is not near to ending. (O, TA. [See also what next precedes.])

muTaAnibN and TaniybN↓, of which latter the pl. is TanaAYibu, signify the same; the latter having the meaning assigned to the former in what here follows. (TA.) One says, huwa jaAriI muTaAnibiI He is my neighbour whose ropes (Tunub) of his tent are next to those of my tent. (Sh, A, O, K. *)
HaIRN mutaTaAnibN [A tribe of which the ropes of the tents, and therefore the tents themselves, are near together: see the next preceding paragraph]. (A.)
TinobaArN: see the next paragraph.

TunobuwrN (S, O, Msb, K) and TinobaArN↓ (S, O, K) [the former vulgarly pronounced Tanobuwr] A certain musical instrument; (O, Msb;) [a kind of mandoline with chords of brass wire, which is played with a plectrum;] arabicized, (S, O, Msb, K,) from the Pers., (S, O, Msb,) originally dunobaho barRaho, (K, TA,) [correctly dunobaho baraho, or] dunobi baraho, (O,) being likened to the tail (Oaloyap) of a lamb: (O, K, TA:) so says As: (O:) pl. TanaAbiyru. (MA.) [Accord. to the Msb, TunobuwrN is of the measure funoEuwlN: but accord. to the derivation mentioned above, the n is a radical letter.]
TunobuwriIRN [or, accord. to Golius, on the authority of Meyd, TunobuwraAniIRN,] A player on the Tunobuwr. (MA.)
TinojirapN: see the following paragraph.

TinojirN A certain vessel (O, Msb) of copper or brass, (Msb,) in which one cooks, (O, Msb,) nearly resembling a Tabaq, (Msb,) without a cover; (O;) also called TinojirapN↓ [vulgarly pronounced Tanojarap and tanojarap, and now applied to a saucepan]: (TA:) xabiyS [q. v.] is made in it: (K in art. xbS:) an arabicized word; in Pers. PaAtiylaho: (K: [in some copies of the K, and in the O, baAtiylaho:]) pl. of the former TanaAjiyru (Msb) [and of the latter TanaAjiru. Accord. to the Msb, it is of the measure finoEiylN: but accord. to the O and K, the n is a radical letter.]

It is also used by the Arabs of our time as a metonymical appellalation of (tropical:) A coward: or a low, vile, or mean, person: as though they meant thereby a townsman, or villager, who constantly eats in cookingpots and bowls of copper; differing from the people of the desert. (TA.)

1. Tanixa, (S, L, K,) aor.
Tanaxa
, (K,) inf. n. TanaxN, (S,) His (a man's, S) heart (qalob [meaning stomach, which is often thus termed in the present day,]) became overpowered by grease [or greasy food], and he suffered indigestion, (S, L, K,) in consequence thereof; (S, L;) as also tanixa, aor.
Tanaxa
, inf. n. tanaxN. (L.) And Tanixato said of camels, They suffered indigestion. (TA in art. TnH.) And Tanixato nafosuhu His soul [or stomach] became heavy; or heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit. (L.)
And He became fat. (L, K.)
2. TnRxhu, (K,) inf. n. taToniyxN; (TA;) and ATnxhu↓, (K,) inf. n. UiTonaAxN; (TA;) It (grease [or greasy food], TA) caused him to suffer indigestion. (K, TA.)

Sh says, I heard ElFak'asee say, naXorabu hecihi AlOalobaAna ftTnxnA Eani AlTRaEaAmi [i. e. fatuTanRixunaA or fatuTonixunaA↓] meaning [We drink these milks and] they render us in no need, or serve us in stead, of [other] food. (L.)
And one says, TunRixati AlnRaAqapu, and AldRaAbRap, meaning The she-camel, and the beast, became [or was rendered] very fat. (L.)
4: see 2, in two places.
TinoxN [is said to signify] A part, or portion, of the night: so in the saying, marRa TinoxN mina AllRayoli [A part, or portion, of the night passed]: (K:) but IDrd doubted its correctness. (TA.)
TanixN A man whose heart [or stomach] is overpowered by grease [or greasy food], and who suffers indigestion in consequence thereof; as also TaAnixN↓. (L.) [See also 1, of which each is a part. n.]
TanaxapN; expl. in the K [and in the JK, app. from the 'Eyn,] as syn. with OaHomaqu, is a mistranscription, correctly Tyxp [i. e. TayoxapN]. (TA.)
TaAnixN: see TanixN.

1. Tanaza bihi, (S, * A, MA, K,) aor.
Tanaza
, (S, A, TA,) inf. n. TanozN, (S, * MA, K, *) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him. (S, A, MA, K.) [See also TanozN below.]
3. TAnzhu, (A, TA,) inf. n. muTaAnazapN, (TA,) [He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, him, being mocked at, &c., by him.]
6. tTAnzwA [They mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, one another]. (A, TA.)
TanozN Mockery, scoff, derision, or ridicule: (S, K:) [J says,] I think it to be post-classical or arabicized. (S.) [Golius says, it is termed in Armenian “ dnâs. ”]
Also A species of fish. (K.)
TanRaAzN A mocker, scoffer, or derider. (S, K.)
humo maTonazapN They are [such as occasion mockery, scoff, derision, or ridicule; or] persons in whom is no good; held in light, or mean, estimation [by others or] by themselves. (K.)

1. Tanifa, aor.
Tanafa
, (K,) inf. n. TanafN, (TK,) the verb of AlTRanafu signifying AltRuhamapu, (K,) [app., as such, meaning He was suspicious, agreeably with the rendering of Golius; or he suspected; as is indicated by its being said of TanifN meaning mutRahamN, in the TA, that it is app. a possessive epithet; for if it were a part. n., Tanifa would signify he was suspected; as it is said to do in the TK and by Freytag; in my opinion, erroneously, on the supposition that TanifN meaning mutRahamN is its part. n.]

And Tanifa, aor.
Tanafa
, inf. n. TanaAfapN and TunuwfapN and TanafN, He was, or became, intrinsically corrupt. (K.)
2. TnRfhu, inf. n. taToniyfN, He suspected him. (O, K.) One says fulaAnN yaTanRafu bihecihi AlsRariqapi Such a one is suspected of this theft. (TA.)
TnRf nafosahu UilaI kacaA He made his mind to approach a coveting of such a thing. (IDrd, O, K.)
And TnRf liloOamori, inf. n. as above, He was, or became, near to the affair. (TA.) [See an ex. voce raAyafa.]

TnRf jidaArahu He put above his wall thorns or branches of trees, (O,) or thorns and sticks and branches, (K,) in order to make the climbing, or scaling, of it difficult: (O:) so says Az. (TA.) [And it probably signifies He made a Tanaf, or Tunuf, of any kind to his wall.]
4. ATnf He ascended upon the Zunuf [or Tanaf i. e. ledge, or projecting part, of a mountain]. (O.)
maA OaTonafahu How abstinent is he! (O, K.)
5. maA taTanRafato nafosiI UilaI hecaA i. q. maA OaXofato [app. meaning My mind did not come to the point, or verge, of this]. (O, K.)
And huwa yataTanRafu AlnRaAsa He comes upon people overwhelmingly; syn. yagoXaAhumo. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K. *)
TanofN: see what next follows.
TunofN: see what next follows.

TanafN and TunufN↓ (S, O, K) and TanofN↓ and TunofN↓ (K) A Hayod [or ledge] of a mountain; (S, O, K;) a projecting portion thereof; (K;) a portion projecting therefrom, resembling a wing: (TA:) [all these are meanings assigned to the Hayod of a mountain:] and a head, of the heads of a mountain: (S, O, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OaTonaAfN and [of mult.] TunuwfN. (O, K.)

Also, (K,) or the first and second, (S, O,) The Uiforiyz [i. e., app., the projecting coping, or ledge, or cornice, (see zayofN, and TaAqN,)] of a wall: (S, O, K:) and a projecting appertenance of a building: (K:) and a roof, or covering, made to project towards the road, over the door of a house; (S, O, K;) i. q. kunRapN. (IAar, TA.)

And TanafN is also applied to A low wall built on the house-top by
the people of Mekkeh. (Z, TA.)

And TanfN signifies also Thongs, or straps; syn. suyuwrN; (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K;) and so TunufN↓: (S, O:) or the red skins that are [put as coverings] upon [receptacles of the kind called] OasofaAT [pl. of safaTN, q. v.]: (K:) or TunufN↓ has this meaning as well as that next preceding. (O.) El-Afwah ElOwdee likens a woman's fingers to Tunuf↓, (O,) or Tanaf, (TA,) used in the sense last mentioned above (O, TA) [or, more probably, I think, in the sense here next following].
Also (i. e. TanfN [and probably TunufN↓ likewise]) A kind of red tree (XajarN [or perhaps fruit, vamarN,]) resembling the Eanam [q. v.]. (TA.)
And Suspicion. (O, K.) [See also 1.]
TanifN Suspected (O, K, TA) of a thing (biOamorK); app. a possessive epithet; and muTanRafN↓ signifies the same. (TA.)
And Intrinsically corrupt. (K.)
And One who eats little: (O, K:) thus expl. by Esh-Sheybánee. (O.)
TunufN: see TanafN, in five places.
TinaAfN: see TiyaAfN, in art. Tyf.

muTonifN, (S, O, K,) applied by Esh-Shenfarà as an epithet to bees (naHol) that have missed the cavity in a mountain [in which they are accustomed to hive], (S, O,) That ascend upon a Tanaf [of a mountain]: (S, K: * [in the latter, mano is erroneously put for AalRaciI: and so in the explanation here following:]) or it signifies, (O,) or signifies also, (K,) having a Tunuf (O, and so in some copies of the K) or Tanaf. (So in other copies of the K.)
muTanRafN: see TanifN.
Also, [if not a mistake for muTolafN,] i. q. muhodarN [Made to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; or to be of no account]. (TA.)

TinofisapN and TanofasapN, (M, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more approved, (Msb,) and TunofasapN (Kr, M, K) and TinofasapN, [which is a form often occurring,] (M, K,) and TanofisapN, (K,) [variously written in different copies of the S, and in that lexicon, and in the Msb, mentioned in art. Tfs, indicating that the n is augmentative in the opinion of the authors of those two works,] A carpet: and a piece of cloth (vawobN): or a kind of carpet called in Persian Tabosaho (Har p. 376) [and tanobasaho]: or a carpet having a fine nap, or pile: or, as some say, what is put beneath the raHol [or camel's saddle], upon the shoulders of the camel: (Msb:) or the numoruqap [q. v.] above the raHol: (M:) pl. TanaAfisu. (S, Msb, K.)

1. TaniIa, aor.
TanaIa
, (S, K,) inf. n. TanFI, (S,) said of a camel, He had his spleen adhering to his side in consequence of vehement thirst: (S:) or, said of a man, he had his spleen and his lungs adhering to the ribs on the left side, (K, TA,) so that, sometimes, they become putrid and black; but mostly this is the case in camels; (TA;) as also ATnI↓: (K:) or he (a man) had a tertian fever, and his spleen in consequence became enlarged: (Lh, * TA:) and, said of a camel, his spleen became enlarged in consequence of the [disease of the lungs called] nuHaAz. (Lh, TA.) [And TaniYa is a dial. var. thereof.]
And, said of a man, i. q. DaniIa [i. e. He was, or became, slender, and small in body: or diseased, disordered, or sick: or lean, or emaciated: &c.]. (TA.)

2. TnRAhu, inf. n. taToniyapN, He treated him to cure him of the disorder of the spleen mentioned above; (S, K;) namely, a camel, (S,) or a man: (K:) and he cauterized him (i. e. his camel) in his side; (K, TA;) or, as in the Nawádir of Lh, TnRI baEiyrahu fiI janobayohi he cauterized his camel [in his sides] by reason of the disorder above mentioned: and the cure [or curing] of that disorder is [also] the taking a wooden peg, and laying him [i. e. the camel] upon his side on the ground, and making, between his ribs, incisions [therewith], not penetrating through. (TA.)
4. ATnI: see 1.
Also He inclined to suspicion, or evil opinion: (K, TA:) and sometimes pronounced OaTonaOa. (TA.)

ATnAhu He (a man) hit him (i. e. another man) in that which was not a vital part. (K, TA. In some copies of the K, fiI Almaqotali is [erroneously] put for fiI gayori Almaqotali.) And, said of a disease, It left him (i. e. a sick man) with somewhat of life remaining in him. (IAar, TA.) One says, hecihi HayRapN laA tuToniI This is a serpent that will not suffer him who is bitten by it to survive; (ISk, * S, * K;) that kills instantly: (ISk, S:) or that will not miss: (AHeyth, TA:) originally lA tuToniYu. (ISk, S.) And Darabahu DarobapF laA tuToniI He struck him a blow that would not be slow in killing him. (TA.) And ladagatohu HayRapN faOaTonatohu [A serpent bit him and suffered him to survive]. (TA.) And the subst. [used in the sense of the inf. n.] from this verb as expl. in all these phrases is TanFI↓. (TA.)
TinoIN A bier: [like TinoCN:] one says, rumiIa fulaAnN fiI Tinoyihi, [and fI TinoYihi,] and fI nayoTihi, Such a one was cast into his bier; meaning, when he died. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
TanFI The adhering of the spleen to the side in consequence of vehement thirst. (S.) [See also TaniIa, of which it is the inf. n.]
And Disease [in a general sense]. (K, TA.) [Accord. to the CK, in this sense, and in other senses mentioned in this paragraph, TanoIN, which is wrong.]
And Ashes in a state of extinction: (K, TA:) and so TinoCN. (O and K in art. TnO.)
And Doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion; or a thing that occasions doubt &c.; (K, * TA;) as also TinoIN↓: and so TinoCN, with C. (TA.)
And Opinion, of any kind. (TA.)
See also 4, last sentence.
And see the next paragraph.

TanK A camel having his spleen adhering to his side in consequence of vehement thirst: (S:) or a man having a tertian fever, and his spleen in consequence having become enlarged: (Lh, * TA:) or a man having his spleen and his lungs adhering to the ribs on the left side, (K, TA,) so that, sometimes, they become putrid and black; but mostly this is the case in camels; (TA;) and so TanFI↓. (K, TA.)
R. Q. 1. TahoTaha He laughed immoderately: (L voce kadokada:) or you say TahoTaha fiI DaHikihi, meaning he laughed slightly; like TaHoTaHa. (O and TA in art. TH.)

Taho [at the commencement of the 20th chapter of the Kur-án] means AiTomaYinR [Be thou still, &c.]: (K, TA:) and thus it is expl. as occurring in a trad. respecting Moses' hearing the speech of the Lord of Might: (TA:) or, as some say, it is for TaOo [imperative of waTiYa], meaning tread upon the ground with the soles of both thy feet; because the Prophet raised one of his feet in prayer: (TA in art. wTO:) or it means O man, in the Abyssinian language; (Lth, K, TA;) or so in Syriac, accord. to Katádeh; or so in Nabathæan, accord. to other authorities: (TA:) read Tehe, with the two fet-hahs pronounced fully, it is two letters of the alphabet (mina AlhijaMCi [strangely misunderstood by Freytag as meaning “ quibus maledicitur ”]): (Lth, K, TA:) Ibn-Mes'ood is related to have read Tihi, with the two kesrehs pronounced fully: and Fr says that some divided it, reading Ti hi: (TA:) Abu-n-Nejm has called it TahaA. (TA in art. Thw, q. v.)
TahoTahapN sing. of TahaATihu, (TA,) which signifies The voices [or neighings] of horses. (K, TA.)
TahoTaAhN, as an epithet applied to a horse, That excites admiration by his beauty, or swift and excellent; youthful; excelling in beauty. (Lth, L, K, TA.)

1. Tahara Tahura, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. of each
Tahura
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. TahaArapN, (S, Msb, K,) which is of each verb, (S, Msb,) and TuhorN, (Sb, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (S, Msb,) It was, or became, clean, free from dirt or filth, or pure. (A, * Msb, K. *) ThArp is of two kinds; [properly] corporeal and [tropically] spiritual. (TA.)

And Taharato, (M, Mgh, K,) or Taharato mina AlHayoDi, aor.
Tahura
; (Msb;) and Tahurato, (M, Msb, K,) which is allowable, (IAar,) but of rare occurrence, (Msb,) and Tahirato, [which is of more rare occurrence;] (M, El-Isnawee;) inf. n. TuhorN and TahaArapN and TuhuwrN and TahuwrN; (TA;) She was, or became, pure from the menstrual discharge; (Mgh;) her discharge of blood stopped. (Mgh, K.) See also 5. The saying, UinRa AlXRaApa taqociI EaXorFA vumRa taTohuru
[Verily the ewe, or she-goat, emits a white fluid from her womb during ten nights, and then becomes pure,] is mentioned on the authority of Lh: but ISd says, whether he mentioned this as heard from the Arabs, or did so presumptuously, I know not. (TA.)
