Taharahu, aor.
Tahara
, (K,) inf. n. TahorN,) (TK,) signifies He made it, or caused it, to be, or become, distant, or remote; syn. OaboEadahu: (O, K:) and so TaHarahu; (O, TA;) the H being substituted for h. (TA.)
2. ThRrhu, inf. n. taTohiyrN, [He cleansed, or purified, him, or it:] (S:) and ThRrhu biAlmaMCi he washed him, or it, with water: (K:) and OaToharahu↓ signifies the same as ThRrhu. (Bd in lvi. 78.)

TahRiraA bayotiI, in the Kur [ii. 119], Cleanse ye my house [the Kaabeh] of the idols (Aboo-Is-hák, Bd, Jel) and impurities; and what does not become it: (Bd:) or clear ye it: (Bd:) or cleanse ye my house from [pollution by] disobediences and forbidden actions: (Az:) or, accord. to some, it means an incitement to purify the heart. (TA.)

waviyaAbaka faTahRiro, in the Kur [lxxiv. 4], means And cleanse thy clothes from dirt: (Jel:) or shorten thy clothes, to prevent their being rendered dirty by trailing along the ground: (Jel, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) purify thy heart: or (assumed tropical:) thy soul: or (assumed tropical:) make thy conduct right: (TA:) and see other explanations voce vawobN.
ThRr waladahu (assumed tropical:) He performed the rite of circumcision upon his son [and so purified him]. (TA.)
ThRrhu QllRehu (tropical:) [God purified him from sin]. (A.)
ThRrhu AlHadRu (assumed tropical:) The prescribed punishment, such as stoning &c., cleansed him from his sin. (TA.)
lamo yuridi QllRehu Oano yuTahRira quluwbahumo, in the Kur [v. 45], means (assumed tropical:) God hath not pleased to cleanse their hearts from infidelity: (Bd, Jel:) or to direct. (TA.)
4: see 2, first sentence.

5. tThRr, inf. n. taTahRurN, is sometimes changed into AiTRahRara, inf. n. AiTRahRurN, the t being incorporated into the T, and this requiring a conjunctive A, (Sgh, K,) in order that the word may not begin with a quiescent letter: (Sgh:) and TahuwrN is also an inf. n. [or rather a quasi-inf. n.] (Sb, K) of taTahRara, (Mgh, TA,) like as waDuwoCN is [said to be] of tawaDRaOa. (TA.) The meaning is, [He became cleansed, or purified: or he cleansed, or purified, himself: and] he washed himself. (Mgh.) You say, tThRr biAlmaMCi [He cleansed, or purified, or washed, himself with water]: (S:) he performed the ablution termed AlwuDuwoC: and that termed AlAisotinojaMC; (A;) as also tThRr alone, as used in the Kur ix. 109: (Mgh, TA:) and the same verb, alone, is expl. as signifying he made use of water, or what supplied its place; thus used in the Kur v. 9. (TA.) In the Kur vii. 80 and xxvii. 57, the verb is used derisively. (TA.) You say also, tThRrt, (Mgh, Msb, K,) and AiTRahRarato, (Mgh,) meaning, She cleansed, or purified, herself by washing, from [the pollution of] the menstrual discharge, (Mgh, Msb, K,) &c.; (K;) as also Taharato↓ and Tahurato; (Msb, * K;) agreeably with what is said in the B, that Tahara and Tahura and ATRhRr and tThRr have the same signification: (TA:) or tThRrt and ATRhRrt have this signification; but the unaugmented verb has the signification first assigned to it, or “ her discharge of blood stopped: ” (Abu-l-'Abbás, IAar:) in the Kur ii. 222, some read HatRaI yaTohurona; and others, HatRaI yaTRahRarona: but the latter reading is the preferable, on account of the difference between the two forms of the verb, just mentioned: (Abu-l-'Abbás:) or the law which allows not the touching a woman until she has performed the ablution mentioned above shows the two forms of the verb to be the same in signification. (TA.)
Also (tropical:) He removed himself far from unclean things, or impurities. (S, Mgh, K. *)

(tropical:) He refrained from sin, (K, TA,) and from what was not good: (TA:) he removed himself far from low, or ignoble, habits: and in this sense, accord. to some, it is used in the Kur vii. 80 and xxvii. 57. (TA.) And tThRr mina AlUivomi (tropical:) He removed himself far from sin. (A.)
TuhorN [see 1:
] Cleanness; freedom from dirt or filth; or pureness. (S, * Msb.)
The state of pureness from the menstrual discharge: (S, A, Mgh, Msb:) pl. OaTohaArN. (A, Msb.) And the pl. signifies The days of a woman's state of pureness from the menstrual discharge. (K.)
TahirN: see TaAhirN, in three places.

TuhorapN a subst. from AltRaTohiyru [and signifying A cleansing, or purification: and in this sense it was applied by the Christians to baptism]: (Mgh:) or from TahRarahu biAlmaMCi [and signifying a cleansing, or purification, by water]: (K:) or cleanness, or pureness. (TK.)
TahuwrN inf. n. of 1; as also TuhuwrN: (TA:) and inf. n. [or rather quasi-inf. n.] of 5. (Sb, Mgh, TA.)

A thing [such as water] with which one cleanses or purifies: (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) a word similar to faTuwrN and saHuwrN and waquwdN: (S:) and the author of the “ Matáli' el-Anwár ” mentions TuhuwrN also in this sense; but this is strange and anomalous: (En-Nawawee:) the former occurs in the Kur xxv. 50: (S:) or it signifies water with which the ablution termed wuDuwoC is performed: (A, IAth:) or it has the signification next following. (K.) It is said, AltRawobapu TahuwrN lilomuconibi (tropical:) [Repentance is a means of purifying the sinner, or criminal]. (A.) Lth says that it is that which is [accompanied] by the execution of the prescribed punishment, such as stoning &c. (TA.) [See also maToharapN.]

It is also an epithet, (Mgh, TA,) and signifies Clean and cleansing, or pure and purifying: (Th, T, Mgh, Msb:) whatever God has created descending from the sky, or welling forth from the earth as a spring or river or sea, in which a human being does nothing but drawing water, and of which the colour is not changed by anything mixing with it, nor the taste thereby, is Tahuwr: and what is otherwise, as the water of roses and of the leaves of trees, and what flows from the grape-vine, though it be TaAhir, is not Tahuwr: (Esh-Sháfi'ee:) the former removes impurities: the latter, if not at the same time Tahuwr, does not: (TA:) or very clean or pure: (A, Msb:) the explanation by Th, if meant to show that the word signifies of the utmost cleanness or pureness, is correct and good: otherwise, it is not so; for faEuwlN is not formed from tafoEiylN: (Mgh, O:) it is also explained as signifying, simply, cleansing, or purifying: (B, TA:) also as syn. with TaAhirN, as in the phrase riyquhunRa TahuwrN [their saliva is pure]: but here it is either an intensive epithet or used for TaAhirN for the sake of the measure. (Msb.)
TahiyrN: see TaAhirN, in two places.
TahaArapN [see 1.
] The act of performing the ablution termed Algusol, and that termed AlwuDuwoC, and that termed AlAisotinojaMC. (Msb, TA.)
TuhaArapN What remains of that with which one has performed the ablution termed TahaArap. (TA.)
TahuwriyRapN The quality of being Tahuwr. (Msb.)

TaAhirN Clean; free from dirt or filth; or pure; (Msb, K;) as also TahirN↓ (IAar, K) and TahiyrN↓: (M, K:) fem. TaAhirapN: (S, A, Msb:) pl. (of TaAhirN, TA) OaTohaArN (K) and TahaAraI, (S, K,) which latter is anomalous, as though its sing. were TahoraAnu, (S,) and, applied to men, TaAhiruwna: (TA:) and (of TahirN↓, TA) Tahiruwna; (K;) the only form; there being no broken pl.: (TA:) and of TaAhirapN, TaAhiraAtN (TA) and TawaAhiru. (A.) You say, rajulN TaAhirN and TahiyrN↓ [A clean, or pure, man]. (O.) And AimoraOapN TaAhirapN mina AlnRajaAsapi [A woman pure from dirt or filth]. (S.) And maMCN TaAhirN Clean, or pure, water: and also, fit to cleanse or purify with. (Msb.) And viyaAbN TahaAraI [Clean clothes]. (S.) [See also TahuwrN.]
Pure from the menstrual discharge; in this sense without p: (IAar:) as also TaAhirN mina AlHayoDi. (S, Msb.)

huwa TaAhiru AlEiroDi (assumed tropical:) He is clear from vice, or fault. (Msb.) AimoraOapN TaAhirapN mina AlEuyuwbi (assumed tropical:) [A woman pure from vices, or the like]. (S.) And rajulN TaAhiru AlvRiyaAbi, (S, A, TA,) and TaAhiru AlOavowaAbi, (TA,) (tropical:) A man free, or far-removed, from low, or ignoble, habits: (S, * A, TA:) and in like manner, TaAhiru Alxuluqi, and Alxuluqi Tahiru↓: fem. TaAhirap. (TA.)
OaToharu [More, and most, clean or pure].
[Hence,] hunRa OaToharu lakumo [Kur xi. 80] (assumed tropical:) They are more lawful to you. (O, TA.)

maToharapN and miToharapN, (S, A, K, &c.,) the former of which is the more approved, (S,) A vessel, (A, K,) or any vessel, (Mgh, Msb,) [for purification,
i. e.,] with which one washes himself, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and performs the ablution termed wuDuwoC, such as a saTol, or rakowap: (TA:) and (A, Mgh, Msb, K) i. q. UidaAwapN [a kind of leathern vessel for water]: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. maTaAhiru. (S, Msb.) Hence, [or from maToharapN as signifying, agreeably with analogy, A means of cleansing or purifying,] the saying, (Msb,) AlsRiwaAku maToharapN lilofami [The tooth-stick is a means of purifying to the mouth]. (S, Msb.)
Also A house, or chamber, in which one washes himself, (K, TA,) and performs the ablutions termed wuDuwoC and gusol and AisotinojaMC. (TA.)
SuHufFA muTahRarapF, in the Kur [xcviii. 2], signifies Writings cleansed from impurities and falsehood. (TA.)
And OazowaAjN muTahRarapN, in the same [ii. 23], Wives purified from the pollution of the menstrual discharge and the other natural evacuations. (O, TA.)

And laA yamasRuhu UilRaA AlmuTahRaruwna, in the same [lvi. 78], is said by some to mean, (assumed tropical:) None shall attain to the knowledge of its true meanings except those who have purified themselves from the filth of corrupt conduct, and ignorances, and acts of disobedience. (TA.)
wamuTahRiruka mina QlRaciyna kafaruwA, in the Kur [iii. 48], signifies And will take thee forth from those who have disbelieved, and make thee to be far from doing as they do. (TA.)
wayuHibRu AlmutaTahRiriyna, in the Kur [ii. 222], signifies And He loveth those who purify their spirits. (TA.)

1. TahaA, aor. yaTohuw and yaTohaI, inf. n. TahowN (S, K) and TuhuwRN (K) and TahoIN, (S, [so in both of my copies,]) or TuhiIRN, (K,) and TahaAyapN, thus app. accord. to the K, [and thus in my MS. copy and in the CK,) but in the M with kesr [i. e. TihaAyapN], (TA,) He cooked flesh-meat in the manner termed Tabox [meaning by boiling or stewing or the like], (S, K,) or by roasting or broiling or frying: (K:) and [he made, or kneaded and baked, bread; for] AlTRahowu signifies also Alxaboru. (TA.)
[And hence, (assumed tropical:) He performed, or executed, an affair firmly, soundly, or thoroughly; and matured it: see the pass. part. n., below; and see also TahowN.]

And TahaA, (S, K,) inf. n. TahowN, (TA,) said of a man, (S,) He went away into the country, or in the land: (S, K:) like TaHaA: (S:) [or] you say, TahaA fiI AlOaroDi, inf. n. TahowN; and TahaI fiI AlOaroDi, inf. n. TahoIN: both signify the same. (TA.) And in like manner, Tahati AlUibilu, (S, TA,) aor. taTohaI, inf. n. TahowN and TuhuwRN, (TA,) The camels went away into the country, or in the land, (S, TA,) having become scattered, or dispersed: (TA:) or went away at random into the country, or in the land. (Ham p. 12.)
And TahaA, inf. n. TahowN, He leaped. (IAar, TA.)
And TahaI, inf. n. TahoIN, He committed a sin, crime, fault, or misdemeanour. (TA. [See also TuhFI.])
4. AThI He was, or became, skilled in his work, art, or craft. (Az, K.)
TahaA is used by Abu-n-Nejm for Tehe meaning the Chapter of the Kur-án [thus called, because commencing with these two letters, namely, the 20th,] in his saying,

L.foreign: madRa lanaA fiI Eumorihi rabRu TahaA

sense.s: [May the Lord of Tehe lengthen for us his life]. (TA.) [See art. Th.]
TahowN [The cooking of flesh-meat: see 1, first sentence.

And hence,] (assumed tropical:) A deed, or a performance. (S, K, TA.) Thus in a trad., (S, TA,) in which it is related that it was said to Aboo-Hureyreh, “ Didst thou hear this from the Apostle of God? ” and he replied wamaA kaAna TahowiI i. e. (assumed tropical:) And what was my deed, or performance? or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, OanaA maA TahowiI [I, what is my deed, or performance?] (TA) or famaA TahowiI What then is my deed, or performance, (S,) if I have not made that relation to be soundly, or well, performed, (S, * TA,) like as the cook does the cooking of food? (TA.) See also TuhFI.
TahoIN: see TuhFI.
Also Thin clouds. (TA.) [See also TahaMCN.]

And it is said in the “ Nawádir ” that samiEotu TahoyahumN, as also dagoyahumo and Tagoyahumo, means I heard their sound, or voice: [or their sounds, or voices:] and one says, flAn fI ThI wnhI [app. fI TahoIK wanahoIi, as though meaning Such a one is engaged in clamour and prohibition]. (TA.)
TahFI Broken bits of straw. (K, TA.)
TuhFI Cooked flesh-meat. (IAar, K.) [It is said in one place in the TA that AlTuhI, with damm, (as though it were AlTRuhoIu, but I suppose AlTRuhaI to be meant,) is the subst. from TahaA AllRaHoma.]

Also A sin, crime, fault, misdemeanour, or misdeed; syn. canobN; (K, TA; [in some copies of the K, AlcRanabu is put (erroneously, as is said in the TA,) in the place of AlcRanobu; and in the CK, AlcRiYobu;]) as also TahoIN↓: and maA TahowiI↓ in the trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh [mentioned above] is expl. by some as meaning maA canobiI [What is my fault?]. (TA.)

TahaMCN, (S, K, TA,) with the lengthened A, (S, TA,) is like TaxaMCN; (K, TA; [in some copies of the K, each of these is erroneously written with the shortened A, without C;]) i. e. it is a dial. var. of the latter word, signifying High, or elevated, clouds: (S, TA:) or thin clouds: (Ham p. 12: [see also TahoIN:]) [and TahaMCapN is the n. un.:] one says, maA fiI AlsRamaMCi TahaMCapN, meaning There is not in the sky a portion of cloud. (S.)
TuhaAwapN The thin skin that is upon milk or blood. (ISd, K.)
maA OadoriI OaIRu AlTRahoyaMCi huwa means I know not what one of mankind, or of the people, he is: (K, TA:) like AIR AlDRaHoyaMCi: mentioned by Az. (TA.)
TahayaAnN The top of a mountain. (K.)

And A barRaAdap [meaning a stand, or shelf, upon which vessels of porous earth, containing water, are placed, in order that the water may become cool]. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, burAdap: as is said in the TA, and shown by what here follows, it is with teshdeed; and it is written in my MS. copy of the K barRaAdap.])
In the saying of ElAhwal El-Kindee,

L.foreign: falayota lanaA mino maMCi zamozama XarobapF

sense.s: [And would that there were for us, of the water of Zemzem, a cooled draught that had passed the night upon the TahayaAn], it has been expl. as having the former of these meaning, and as having the second thereof, and as meaning a certain mountain in El-Yemen. (TA.)

TaAhK A cook; (S, K;) a roaster, broiler, or fryer: and a maker, or kneader and baker, of bread: (K:) and, (K, TA,) as some say, (TA,) any dresser, or preparer, of food, (K, TA,) &c., who qualifies it well, rightly, or properly: (TA:) pl. TuhaApN and TuhiIRN: (K, TA: [in the CK the latter is written TuhFI, which is evidently wrong; whereas TuhiIRN is agreeable with analogy, being originally TuhuwoIN:]) the fem. is TaAhiyapN, and its pl. is TawaAhK. (TA.)
layolN TaAhK A dark night. (TA.)
OamorN maTohuwRN (tropical:) An affair performed, or executed, firmly, soundly, or thoroughly; and matured. (TA.)

TuwbN Baked bricks; syn. MjurRN: (S, O, Msb, K:) n. un. with p: so says Az, and El-Fárábee says the like; and accord. to them it seems to be [genuine] Arabic: accord. to IDrd, it is of the dial. of Syria; but [Fei adds] I think it to be of the dial. of Room: (Msb:) or it is of the dial. of Egypt: (S, O:) [probably of Coptic origin. It is mentioned in the S and K in art. Tyb.]

OawobapF waTawobapF, [the latter word] meaning AlTRiyba, [and both together A return and perfume,] is a phrase which one says to the person entering and to him coming [as though he who said this meant I experience a return that is to me like perfume]. (O.)
TuwbaI: see art. Tyb.
[TawRaAbN A baker of bricks: from TuwbN: mentioned by Golius, in art. Tyb, as occurring in the Hist. Sar.: and it is used in this sense in the present day.]

1. TaAHa, (S, A, L, K,) aor. yaTuwHu and yaTiyHu, (S, L, K,) inf. n. of the former TawoHN, and of the latter TayoHN, (L,) He, or it, perished, or came to nought; (S, A, K;) as also tTwRH↓: (A:) or
was, or became, at the point of perishing: (K:) and he, or it, (i. e. anything, TA,) went away; passed away; (K, TA;) came to nought. (TA.)
And (as some say, TA) He, or it, fell; (S, A, K;) and so tTwRH↓, as in the phrase tTwRH fiI AlbiYori [It fell into the well], said of a bucket. (TA.)
And He lost his way, syn. taAha, (S, A, K,) in the land, (S, K,) or in the desert; as also tTRwH↓ and tTyRH↓. (TA.) And, said of an arrow, It missed its aim. (Har p. 126.)

And Oayona TiyHa bika Whither hast thou been taken, or carried, away? (A.) And TAH bihi farasuhu His horse went away with him [or carried him away] like an arrow. (A.) And maA kaAnato UilRaA mazoHapF TaAHa bihaA lisaAniI [It was nought but a jest, or joke, which my tongue hastily uttered, or which my tongue let full]. (A.)
See also the next paragraph.

2. TwRHhu He caused him, or it, to perish, or come to nought; as also TwRH bihi, (A,) and TyRHhu; (A, and K in art. TyH;) and ATAHhu↓ signifies the same, (IAar, K,) said of a thing, (K,) or of property, (IAar, and K in art. TyH,) as is also TwRHhu, (IAar,) and he made it pass away. (K.) And He sent him to a land from which he should not return. (K.) And TwRH bivawobihi He cast his garment [app. meaning himself (see a verse of Esh-Shemmákh, or of Leylà, cited voce vwb)] into a place of destruction; as also TyRH bh. (L, and K in art. TyH.) And TawRaHatohu AlTRwaAYiHu↓ i. q. qacafatohu AlqawaAcifu (S, K) i. e. Accidents, or events, that cast into places of perdition [cast him thereinto]: (MF, * TK:) one should not say AlmuTawRiHaAtu: it is an extr. phrase, (S, K,) like the phrase in the Kur [xv. 22], waOarosalonaA AlrRiyaAHa lawaAqiHa accord. to one of the two interpretations thereof: (S:) and AlmaTaAwiHu OaTaAHatohu↓ and AlTRawaAYiHu signify the same, i. e. qacafatohu AlqawaAcifu; (A;) or [rather] the former of these two phrases has a similar meaning [i. e. the places of perdition caused him to fall thereinto; unless maTaAwiHu have a signification which I do not find explained]. (TA.) And TwRH bihi He incited him, induced him, or made him, to venture upon a desert in which perdition was to be feared. (K, * TA.)

Also He, or it, caused him to lose his way, syn. tawRahahu, (S, K,) and so bihi TAH↓, (Har p. 126,) and TyRHhu, (K in art. TyH,) and carried him away hither and thither, (S,) or so that he cast himself hither and thither, (K, TA,) and so TwRH bihi. (TA.) And TwRH nafosahu He made himself to be, or become, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; like tuwRahahaA and tayRahahaA. (S in art. tyh.)
TwRH bihi also signifies He threw it, or cast it, in the air. (K, TA. [For AlhawaMC, Golius and Freytag have read AlhawaI. See 5.])
And TwRHhu He beat him, or struck him, with a staff, or stick. (K.)
TwRH fiI AljibaAli He went round about much, or often, in the mountains; i. q. TawRafa and TawRada. (S in art. Twd.)
3. TAwHhu He contended with him in casting, or shooting. (L, K.) A poet says,
Now as for one, what would proceed from me would suffice thee: but who will be responsible for a hand with which several hands contend in casting, or shooting? (L.)
4: see 2, in two places.

One says also, TAH XaEarahu He, or it, caused his hair to fall off. (K.) [And ATAH qawaAYimahu is said of a horse, or of a man in relation to a horse, app. meaning He made his legs to fall in a particular manner: see misoEarN.]
maA OaTowaHahu and maA OaToyaHahu i. q. maA Oatowahahu and mA Oatoyahahu: see 4 in art. twh.
5. tTwRH: see 1, in four places.
Also [He lost his way, or was made to lose his way, and] he cast himself hither and thither (S, K) fiI AlbilaAdi in the countries. (S.)
And He, or it, went and came, or moved to and fro, in the air: and he moved to and fro in sleep, upon the back of a camel. (L.)
6. taTaAwuHN signifies The casting, or throwing, a thing [to and fro,] one with another; or one to, or at, another. (KL.)
[Hence,] taTaAwaHato bihimu AlnRawaI i. q. taraAmatN [i. e. (assumed tropical:) Distance cast them away, one from another]. (S, A, K.)
And taTaAwaHuwhu biAlDRarobi, and biAlOamori, They contended with him [in beating, and in the affair]. (A.)
niyRapN TawaHN i. q. baEiydapN [app. meaning A distant, or remote, thing, or place, that is the object of an action or a journey]; (K, and O in art. DrH;) like TaraHN and TamaHN and DaraHN. (O.)

TawaAYiHu i. q. qawaAcifu, (S, A, K,) i. e. Accidents, or events, that cast into places of perdition: (MF, * TK:) said in the 'Ináyeh to be an anomalous pl. of muTiyHapN↓, from OaTaAHa meaning “ he, or it, caused to pass away, ” and “ to perish, or come to nought. ” (MF.) See 2.
TawRaAHN is expl. by Freytag as signifying Evilaffecting: but he names no authority.]
TuwRaHapN A child's swing, of rope. (TA voce rujRaAHapN.)
TaAYiHN [part. n. of 1] Perishing [&c.]. (L.)
See also art. TyH.
[TAyiHap, correctly TaAYiHapN, is expl. by Freytag, on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees, as meaning An army.]
muTiyHapN: see TawaAYiHu.
miTowaAHN A staff, or stick, (K, TA,) [as being] an instrument of destruction. (TA.)
maTaAwiHu i. q. maqaAcifu, (S, K,) which means Places of perdition; (TA in art. qcf;) like maTaAwidu [pl. of maTaAdapN]. (S and TA in art. Twd.)

[mutaTaAwiHN, app. a mistranscription for mutaTaAwaHN, which lit. means A place of casting, or throwing, to and fro, is expl. by Freytag, on the authority of the Deewán of Jereer, as meaning the intermediate part between the top and bottom of a well.]

1. TaAxahu, (K,) aor. yaTuwxuhu, (TA,) inf. n. TawoxN; (K;) as also TaAxahu, aor. yaTiyxuhu, inf. n. TayoxN; which is the more common; (TA;) He charged, reproached, or upbraided, him with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, either said or done. (K.) [See also art. Tyx.]
1. TaAda, (aor. yaTuwdu, inf. n. TawodN, TK,) It (a thing, TK) was, or became, firm, or steadfast. (Fr, L, K.)

2. TwRd, (S, L, K,) inf. n. taTowiydN and taTowaAdN; and tTwRd↓; (K;) He went round about much, or often, syn. TawRafa (S, L, K) and TawRaHa, (S,) fiI AljibaAli in the mountains: (S:) or the former, he went round about much, or often, in the countries to seek the means of subsistence. (IAar, L.) And one says also, TwRd binafosihi [He went round about &c. by himself], and bifulaAnK [with such a one]. (L.)
TwRdhu, inf. n. taTowiydN, He (God) made it high, or tall. (A.)
4. ATAd He made, or rendered, firm, or steadfast: so accord. to Freytag; but he names no authority.]
5: see 2.
7. AnTAd It rose, or ascended, in the air. (K.)
TaAdN Heavy: (K:) and TaAdiIRN↓ firm, or steadfast: (L:) or both signify heavy and firm or steadfast. (TA.)
Also the former, A stallion excited by lust. (K.)

TawodN A mountain: (K:) or a great mountain (S, A, L, K) rising high into the sky: (A:) or i. q. haDobapN [either as denoting a hill or mountain or a tract of sand: see the next sentence]: (IAar:) pl. OaTowaAdN (A, L, K) and TiwadapN. (K.)
And An elevated, or overlooking, tract of sand; (K, TA;) as also haDobapN. (TA.)
And the pl. OaTowaAd is applied by a poet to signify (tropical:) Camels' humps; as being likened to mountains because of their height. (IAar, L.)

Aibonu AlTRawodi means (assumed tropical:) The mass of rock (Aljulomuwdu) that falls from the upper part of a mountain: (A, L, * K: *) or the echo. (A.) One says, OasoraEu mini Qboni AlTRawodi (assumed tropical:) Quicker, or swifter, than the mass of rock that falls &c.: or than the echo. (A.)
TaAdiIRN: see TaAdN.
maTaAdapN A desert, or waterless desert, far-extending: (K:) pl. maTaAwidu. (TA.) And the latter (i. e. the pl.), Places of perdition; (K, TA;) it is like maTaAwiHu. (S, TA.)
muTawRidN Remote, or distant. (K.)
binaMCN munoTaAdN A lofty building, (K, TA,) rising high in the air. (TA.)
1. TaAra Hawolahu, aor. yaTuwru, (TA,) inf. n. TaworN and TawaraAnN, (K,) He went, or hovered, (HaAma,) round about it. (K, * TA.)

Hence, laA yaTuwruniI He will not approach my immediate vicinage. (TA.) And laA taTuro HaraAnaA Approach thou not our environs. (S, O, TA.) And laA OaTuwru bihi I will not approach him, or it: (S, O, TA:) occurring in a trad. (TA.) And fulaAnN yaTuwru bifulaAnK Such a one as it were hovers round about such a one, and draws near to him. (TA.)
maA OaboEada TaAraka for mA AbEd daAraka: see the remarks on letter T.

TaworN A time; one time; like the French “ fois; ” syn. taArapN: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) pl. OaTowaArN. (S, K, A.) You say, Oatayotuhu TaworFA baEoda TaworK I came to him time after time. (A.) faEala celika TaworFA baEoda TaworK He did that time after time. (Msb.) And jiYotuhu OaTowaArFA I came to him several times. (A.)

And State; condition; quality, mode, or manner; form, or appearance: pl. OaTowaArN. (Msb.) You say, AlnRaAsu OaTowaArN Mankind are of divers sorts and conditions. (S, A. *) It is said in the Kur [lxxi. 13], waqado xalaqakumo OaTowaArFA And He hath created you of divers sorts and conditions: (TA:) or of different forms, every one of his proper form: (Th, TA:) or of various aspects and dispositions: (TA:) or one time, a clot of blood; and one time, a lump of flesh: (Akh, S:) or [one time,] seed; then, a clot of blood; then, a lump of flesh; then, bone. (Fr, TA.)

And Quantity; measure; extent: (K:) limit: (S, A:) a limit between two things. (O, K.) You say, EadaA fulaAnN Taworahu Such a one exceeded his proper measure, or extent: (TA:) or his proper limit: (S, A, O, TA:) and taEadRaI Taworahu he transgressed the limits of his proper state, or condition. (Msb, TA.)

A thing that is commensurate, (L, K, TA,) or equal in length [and breadth (see EadaMCN)], (TA,) or correspondent, to a thing; (L, K, TA;) as also TuwrN↓ and TawaArN↓. (K.) You say of anything that is the equal of another thing, huwa Tuwruhu↓, and TawaAruhu↓ It is the equal of it. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) You say also, hecaA AlHaAYiTi raOayotu HabolFA biTawaAri↓ I saw a rope of the length of this wall. (TA.) And hecihi AldRaAru hecihi AldRaAri biTawaAri↓ This house has its wall contiguous to the wall of this [other] house, in one rank, or series. (TA.) And daArK TawaAru↓, (S, O, K,) and dAr TiwaAru↓, (K,) and TaworuhaA, and TuwaratuhaA↓, (O,) The part of the finaMC [or exterior court, or yard], of a house, that is coextensive with the house; (S, A, O, K; *) i. q. jawaAruhu. (K in art. jwr.) [See also the next paragraph.]
TuwrN: see TaworN, latter part, in two places.
The yard (finaMC) of house; (K;) as also TuwarapN↓. (TA.) [See also TawaAr, voce TaworN, last signification.]

A mountain: (S, O, K:) or any mountain that produces trees, otherwise a mountain is not so called. (R, TA.) [Hence AlTRuwru is applied to Mount Sinai, which is also called Tuwru siynaMCa, and Tuwru siyniyna; and to the Mount of Olives, and to several other mountains; as is said in the K &c.]
TuwarapN: see TaworN, last signification: and also TuwrN.
TiwarapN i. q. TiyarapN [q. v.]; (K;) a dial. var. of the latter word. (O.)

TawriIRN Wild; that estranges himself, or itself, from mankind; (S, A, O, K;) applied to a bird, (S, O,) and to a man; (S, A, O;) as also TuwraAniIRN↓. (O.) You say, HamaAmN TuwriIRN, and TuwraAniIRN↓, Wild pigeons: (S, TA:) so called in relation to AlTRuwru, a certain mountain; or the mountain is called TurRaAn, and [if so] it is an irreg. rel. n.: or that have come from a distant country. (TA.) [See also EuzofN.] And OaEaAriybu TuwriyRuwna Wild Arabs of the desert, that avoid the towns and villages, from fear of epidemic disease, and of perdition: as though they were thus called in relation to the mountain named AlTRuwr, in Syria. (TA.) And rajulN TuwriIRN A stranger. (O, TA.)
maA bihaA TuwriIRN, (S, A, O, K,) and TuwraAniIRN↓, (Lth, O, K,) There is not in it (i. e. biAldRaAri in the house, A, TA) any one: (Lth, S, A, O, K:) as also duwriIRN. (TA.)
TuwraAniIRN: see TuwriIRN, in three places.
TawaArN and TiwaArN: see TaworN, latter part, in six places.

balaga fulaAnN fiI AlEilomi OaTowarayohi Such a one attained the two extremes of science, or learning; (S, O;) the beginning and the end thereof; (S, O, K;) as also OaTowariyhi: (K:) or the latter, which is the form mentioned by AZ, (S, O,) and by IAar, (Sh, TA,) signifies the utmost point thereof; accord. to AZ, as related by A 'Obeyd: (S, O:) or he attained, in science, or learning, his utmost, and his ambition; accord. to IAar: (Sh, TA:) or balaga OaTowarayohi he attained the utmost of his endeavour. (L.)
balagotu mino fulaAnK OaTowarayohi I did the utmost in the case of such a one. (ISk, TA.)
rakiba fulaAnN AldRahora waOaTowarayohi [Such a one encountered fortune and] its two extremes. (As, TA.)
laqiIa minohu AlOaTowariyna, with kesr to the r, He experienced from him, or it, calamity. (As, O, K.)

1. TaAsa, aor. yaTuwsu, (S, TA,) inf. n. TawosN, (S, A, K, TA,) He was, or became, beautiful, (S, A, K, TA,) and bright, or fresh, (K, TA,) in face, (S, A, K, TA,) after illness: (K, TA:) from AlTRawosu signifying “ the moon: ” so in the T: ascribed by Sgh to AA. (TA.) [In one copy of the S, this verb is omitted.]

TAs AlXRaIoCa, (M, O,) aor. as above, (O,) inf. n. TawosN, (M, A, O, K,) He trod, or trod upon, the thing; (M, A, * O, K; *) [like daAsahu;] and broke it: (M, O:) so says IDrd: (O:) and AlwaTosu is like AlTRawosu. (TA.)
2. maA OadoriI Oayona TawRasa I know not whither he has gone (T, O, K) bihi [with him, or it]. (K.)
5. taTawRasato She (a woman, A, K, or a girl, M) adorned herself: (M, A, Sgh, K:) [as though she made herself like a TaAWuws, or peacock.]

tTwRs He (a pigeon) shook, or ruffled, his feathers: you say, AlHamaAmu yakosaHu bicanabihi Hawola AlHamaAmapi wayataTawRasu lahaA The male pigeon sweeps with his tail around the female pigeon, and shakes, or ruffles, his feathers to her. (A, TA.)
TaAsN [A drinking-cup; also vulgarly called TaAsap;] a certain thing in which one drinks; (S, K;) or with which one drinks; accord. to AHn, also called qaAquzRapN. (M.)
TawosN The moon: (IAar, T, S, K: but omitted in one copy of the S:) or the moon a little after, or before, the change; i. q. hilaAlN: pl. OaTowaAsN. (M.)

TuwaAsN, (M, TA,) thus correctly, as written by El-Urmawee, with damm; not with fet-h, as in the K and as written by Sgh; (TA;) [in the O, TawaAsu;] One of the nights of the last part of the [lunar] month; (M;) one of the nights called layaAliI AlmuHaAqi. (O, K.)

TaAWuwsN, (S, M, A, &c.,) of the measure faAEuwlN, (Msb,) the hemzeh being a substitute for w, (M,) [The peacock;] a certain bird, (S, M, A, O, K,) beautiful, (M, TA,) and well known: (O, Msb, K:) dim. TuwayosN, formed after the rejection of the augmentative letters: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. TawaAwiysu (M, A, K) and (sometimes, M) OaTowaAsN, (M, O, K,) by the rejection of what is augmentative: (M:) the former pl. is the more known. (TA.)
(assumed tropical:) A goodly, or beautiful, man; (ElMuärrij, O, K;) in the dial. of Syria. (ElMuärrij, O.)
(assumed tropical:) Silver; (A, O, K;) in the dial. of El-Yemen. (A, O.)
(assumed tropical:) Verdant land, wherein, (O, K,) or whereon, (T, O,) is every kind of plant, (O, K,) or of flowers, in the days of spring. (T, O.)
muTawRasN Goodly, or beautiful; (M, A, Msb, K;) applied to a face, (A, TA,) or other thing. (Msb, K.)

1. TaAEa lahu, (T, S, O, Msb, K,) and TaAEahu, (Msb,) first pers. TuEotu, (Zj, O, Msb, *) aor. yaTuwEu, (T, S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. TawoEN; (T, Msb, TA;) and, first pers. TiEotu, (Zj, O, Msb, *) aor. yaTaAEu, (T, O, Msb, K,) a good dial. var., (T, TA,) and yaTiyEu, (Msb, and K in art. TyE,) inf. n. TayoEN; (TA in art. TyE;) three dial. vars., coordinate to
qaAla and xaAfa and baAEa; (Msb;) He was, or became, submissive to him; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also lh AnTAE↓; (AO, S, O, Msb;) and ATAEhu↓, inf. n. UiTaAEapN, and subst. [i. e. quasi-inf. n.] TaAEapN↓: (Msb:) or i. q. ATAE↓; (T, TA;) which is expl. by ISd as meaning he was, or became, gentle, and submissive; as also TaAEa, aor. yaTaAEu: (TA:) [or each of these two verbs may be rendered he was, or became, obedient; or he obeyed; when by this is meant compliance with another's will or wish, not with a command: but] one says, Oamarahu faOTaAEahu↓ [He commanded him and he obeyed him], with A, not otherwise; (S;) or Oamarahu qaOaTaAEa [he commanded him and he obeyed]; for it is said that AlTRaAEapu↓ is never otherwise than a consequence of a command; and IF says that when one goes by command of another you say of him ATAEhu: (Msb:) Er-Rághib says that AlTRaAEapu↓ is like AlTRawoEu; but is mostly used as meaning obedience to a command [or the like; whence the saying, AallRahumRa laA tuTiyEanRa liI XaAmitFA, expl. in art. Xmt]: (TA:) and TAwEhu↓, also, signifies he obeyed him; like ATAEhu↓: you say, EalaI Oamori TAwEhu↓ kacaA he obeyed him in respect of such an affair. (MA. [But see 3 below.])
[Hence,] lisaAnuhu laA yaTuwEu bikacaA (assumed tropical:) His tongue will not aid, or assist, him with such a thing. (S, O.) See also 2. [And see 3.]

And sometimes (S) one says, TaAEa lahu AlmarotaEu, (S, O, K,) like lh ATAE↓, (ISk, S, O,) or like ATAEhu, (K,) meaning (tropical:) The pasturage enabled him to pasture his cattle upon it (S, O, K, * TA) wheresoever he would, (TA,) and was ample to him; (O, TA;) and it was not inaccessible to him. (TA.)
2. taTowiyEN [primarily] signifies The making obedient; or the causing to obey. (KL.)

faTawRaEato lahu nafosuhu qatola Oaxiyhi, (S, O, Msb, * K, *) in the Kur [v. 33], means (tropical:) And his soul, or mind, facilitated to him [the slaying of his brother]; (Akh, S, O, Msb, TA;) like TawRaqatohu; (Akh, S, O, TA;) and like TaAwaEatohu↓, [which is one of the explanations in the O and K, and] which means the same; (Msb;) and accord. to this explanation it is tropical: Mbr says that it is an instance of faERalato from AlTRawoEu; and TaAEato↓ and TawRaEato are said to signify alike: (TA:) or the meaning is, aided him, or assisted him; (Fr, O, K;) accord. to which explanation, and that of Mbr, fiI is said by Az to be suppressed; the meaning being, fiI qatoli Oaxiyhi; or liqatoli Oaxiyhi; and he prefers the explanation of Akh: (TA:) or the meaning is, (O, K,) accord. to Mujáhid, (O,) encouraged him, and (O, K) A 'Obeyd says that by this Mujáhid meant (TA) aided him, and complied with his wish. (O, K, TA,)

3. TAwEhu, (IF, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. muTaAwaEapN, (S, O, TA,) and quasi-inf. n. TawaAEiyapN, (TA,) i. q. waAfaqahu [as meaning He complied with him]. (IF, S, * O, * Msb, K, * TA.) You say, TAwEt AlmaroOapu zawojahaA, quasi-inf. n. TawaAEiyapN, The woman complied with her husband. (TA.) It is said that TAwEhu differs from OaTaAEahu. (Msb, TA.) But see 1, latter half, in two places.
See also 2.
One says also, TAwE lahu AlmuraAdu (tropical:) The thing wished, or desired, or sought after, [was, or became, easy of attainment to him; or] came to him easily. (TA.)
4. ATAE, inf. n. UiTaAEapN, and quasi-inf. n. TaAEapN: see 1, in four places. It also signifies He consented; or complied with what was desired of him; and so AstTAE↓. (TA.)

[Hence,] ATAE lahu AlmarotaEu: see 1, last sentence. One says also, ATAE AlnRaxolu, (S, O,) and AlXRajaru, (S, O, K,) (tropical:) The palm-trees, (S, O, TA,) and the trees, (S, O, K, TA,) had ripe fruit, that might be gathered. (S, O, K, TA.) And ATAE AltRamoru (assumed tropical:) The dates attained, or were near, to the time, or season, for their being cut off. (TA.)

5. tTwRE lilXRaIoCi tTwREhu He desired the thing; or sought it; or sought it by artful, or skilful, management: or he constrained himself to do it: or he took it, or imposed it, upon himself submissively. (TA.) You say, taTawRaEo lihecaA AlOamori HatRaI tasotaTiyEahu, (S,) and taTaAwaEo↓, (S, K, *) Constrain thyself to acquire ability to perform this affair until thou shalt be able to perform it. (S.) And tTwRE biAlXRaIoCi He did the thing without its being incumbent, or obligatory, on him; syn. tabarRaEa bihi. (S, O, * Msb.) mano taTawRaEa xayorFA, in the Kur ii. 153 [and 180], means Whoso does good that is not obligatory on him: (Jel:) or does good in obedience, whether obligatory or supererogatory: or does good beyond what is obligatory on him: (Bd:) xayorFA being for bixayorK: (Bd, * Jel:) or it is an epithet qualifying an inf. n. suppressed: or the verb is made trans. as implying the meaning of OataI or faEalaI: (Bd:) and the Koofees, except 'Ásim, read yaTRawRaEo, for yataTawRaEo. (Az, * O, TA. *) [Hence,] TalaApu AltRaTawRuEi The supererogatory prayer; syn. AlnRaAfilapu. (O, K.) And Az says that taTawRuEN signifies A thing that one does spontaneously, not made obligatory on him by an ordinance of God; as though it were made a subst. (TA.)
6: see the next preceding paragraph.
7: see 1, first sentence.

10. AstTAE, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. AisotiTaAEapN, (S, O, Msb,) originally AisotiTowaAEN, (O, B, TA,) i. q. OaTaAqa [meaning He was able; and he was able to do, or accomplish, a thing, and to acquire or obtain it, and to have it, &c.]; (K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, OaTaAEa, which, however, correctly explains one meaning of AstTAE, as will be seen by what follows;]) the inf. n. being syn. with UiTaAqapN, (S, O, TA,) or TaAqapN, (Msb,) and qudorapN: (Msb, TA:) but it is said peculiarly of a human being [or a rational creature], whereas ATAq is used in a general manner: (IB, TA:) and the application of the former requires a peculiar constitution of the agent, and the conception of the act, and the fitness of the object to be acted upon or effected, and the possession of an instrument when the action is instrumental as in the case of writing: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and one says also, (K,) or sometimes they said, (S, O, Msb,) AisoTaAEa (S, O, Msb, K,) aor. yasoTiyEu, (S, O, Msb,) with fet-h [to the first letter]; (Msb;) rejecting the t, deeming it difficult of utterance with the T, and disliking to incorporate it into the T because the s would then become movent, which it never is: Hamzeh (i. e. Ez-Zeiyát, TA, not Khallád, O, K, TA) read, [in the Kur xviii. 96,] famaA QsoTRaAEuwA, with idghám, combining two quiescent letters: (S, O, K:) this reading is said by Zj, as on the authority of Kh and Yoo and Sb and others, to be incorrect; but Abu-l-'Abbás Ahmad Ibn Mohammad Ibn-'Abd-El-Ghanee Ed-Dimyátee, who died in the year [of the Flight] 1116, and Ibn-El-Jezeree, and El-Háfidh Aboo-'Amr, contradict him, affirming it to be allowable: (TA:) and Akh says, (S, O,) and some of the Arabs say AisotaAEa, aor. yasotiyEu, (S, O, K,) rejecting the T; (S, O;) which Zj holds to be not allowable in reading [the Kur-án]: (TA:) and some of the Arabs say OasoTaAEa, aor. yusoTiyEu, [in the CK, erroneously, yasoTiyEu,] with the disjunctive A [in the former], meaning OaTaAEa, aor. yuTiyEu, (Akh, S, O, K,) making the s to be a substitute for the suppressed vowel of the medial radical letter of the verb [ATAE], (Akh, S, O,) for, as is said by Kh and Sb, OaTaAEa is originally OaTowaEa; (TA;) or, as AZ says, the verb in this case, with damm to the aor., is likened to OafoEala, aor. yufoEilu, inf. n. UifoEaAlN: (Msb:) but Zj says that he who reads famaA QsaTRaAEuwA errs; for the s of AisotafoEala is never movent: and Sb mentions maA OasotatiyEu; holding it to be an instance of substitution. (TA.)

See also 4. Some say that halo yasotaTiyEu rabRuka Oano yunazRila EalayonaA maAYidapF mina AlsRamaMCi, in the Kur [v. 112], means halo yujiybu [i. e. Will thy Lord consent, or comply with the desire, that He should send down to us a table with food upon it from Heaven?]: (Er-Rághib, TA:)

and Ks read halo tasotaTiyEu rabRaka, meaning Wilt thou demand of thy Lord that He consent, or comply with the desire? (O, TA:) for AstTAEhu signifies also He demanded his obedience, and his consent, or compliance with what he desired of him. (TA.)
TaAEN accord. to the copies of the O and K; but some say TaAEK accord. to the O: see TaAYiEN, in three places.
TawoEN: see TaAYiEN, in seven places.
TaAEapN [quasi-inf. n. of 4: as a simple subst., sometimes meaning Submission, or submissiveness: but mostly, obedience to a command]: see 1, in three places; and see also TawaAEiyapN.
[See also TaAYiEN, of which it is a pl.]
TawaAEapN: see what next follows.

TawaAEiyapN i. q. TaAEapN↓: (S, O, K:) so in the say-
ing fulaAnN Hasanu AlTRawaAEiyapi laka [Such a one is good in obedience to thee]: (S, O, TA:) or it is a subst. from 3 [q. v.]; and so TwaAEap↓ [app. TawaAEapN]. (L, TA.)

TaAYiEN (S, O, Msb, K) and TaAEN↓, (O, K,) and some say TaAEK↓, formed from TaAYiEN by transposition, (O,) and TayRiEN↓, signify the same, (S, O, Msb, K,) i. e. Being, or becoming, submissive; [or, simply, submissive; and obeying; or obedient;] (Msb;) and TawoEN↓, originally an inf. n., is likewise used as syn. with TaAYiEN: (Ham p. 408:) the pl. is TuwRaEN, (S, O, K,) i. e. pl. of TaAYiEN, (S, O,) and TaAEapN is [also a pl. of TaAYiEN, like as baAEapN is of baAYiEN; or] syn. with muTiyEuwna: (TA in art. swE:) [whence one says, daxala fiI TaAEatihi, and xaraja mino TaAEatihi, He entered among, and he quitted, his obeyers, or those who obeyed him; i. e. he became obedient, and he became disobedient, to him:] and miTowaAEN↓, (S, O, K,) pl. maTaAwiyEu, (TA,) is [app., agreeably with analogy, an intensive epithet, meaning very submissive or obedient, but is said to be, in like manner,] syn. with muTiyEN, (S, O, K,) applied to a man: (S, O:) and miTowaAEapN↓, applied to a man, [is app. a doubly intensive epithet; or] is syn. with miTowaAEN: (TA:) and is applied to a pl. number, as meaning compliant and submissive. (Har p. 237.) One says, jaMCa fulaAnN TaAYiEFA Such a one came [submissively, or obediently, or willingly,] not being compelled against his will. (S, O.) And a poet says,

[I swore, or have sworn, by the House of God (i. e. the Kaabeh), and what are around it, of such as betakes himself for refuge to the House or of such as renders obedience by visiting it]. (O.) And one says also, jaMCa TayRiEFA↓ [He came of his own accord, or willingly]. (M and TA voce cuw.) And AllRisaAni TayRiEu↓ (tropical:) A man chaste, or eloquent, in speech. (TA.) And AlqiyaAdi naAqapN TayRiEapu↓ and AlqiyaAdi TawoEu↓ (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that is gentle; [or tractable;] that does not contend with her leader. (TA.) And AlEinaAni farasN TawoEu↓ (tropical:) A traciable horse. (S, O, K, TA.) And yadika fulaAnN TawoEu↓ (tropical:) Such a one is submissive to thy hand. (S, O, K, TA.) And AlDRajiyEi AimoraOapN TawoEu↓ A woman submissive to the bedfellow. (TA.) And fulaAnN AlmakaArihi TawoEu↓ (assumed tropical:) Such a one is submissive to misfortunes, [being] subject thereto. (T, TA.) [See also an ex. of TawoE↓ in a verse cited in art. Xmt voce XaAmitapN.] AlsRinaAni huwa OaTowaEu↓ means (assumed tropical:) He is one to whom the spear-head is subservient, howsoever he will. (K in art. sn.)
TayRiEN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

OaTowaEu [as signifying More, and most, submissive or obedient is regularly formed from TaAEa; or] is from AlTRaAEapu [i. e. from OaTaAEa], and similar to Oajowabu [from OajaAba, and therefore anomalous]. (M and L in art. jwb.) OaTowaEu mino farasK, and mino kalobK, [More submissive, or obedient, that a horse, and than a dog,] are provs. (Meyd.)
[It app. signifies also Very submissive or obedient: see an ex. in a verse cited voce tabadRaEa.
And it is also a simple epithet, like Oahowanu &c.:] see TaAYiEN, last sentence.

XuHRN muTaAEN means A niggardliness that is obeyed by him who is characterized thereby, by the refusing rights, or dues, (O, K,) which God has rendered obligatory on him, in respect of his property: occurring in a trad. of the Prophet. (O.) And AlmuTaAEu, as a name of the Prophet, means He whose prayer is answered; whose intercession for his people is accepted. (TA.)
miTowaAEN: see TaAYiEN, first sentence.
miTowaAEapN [an epithet of a very rare form, like miEozaAbapN, q. v.]: see TaAYiEN.

muTaAwiEN an epithet applied by the grammarians to (tropical:) A verb that is intransitive [such as I term quasi-passive; expl. as meaning a verb whose (grammatical) agent receives the effect of the action of the agent of another verb (fiEolN yaqobalu faAEiluhu Oavara fiEoli faAEili fiEolK Mxara)]. (S, O, TA.)
AlmuTRawRiEapu and AlmuTRawRiEiyna: see what follows.

mutaTawRiEN A supererogator in any good act. (O, K.) One says, faEalahu mutaTawRiEFA [He did it without its being incumbent, or obligatory, on him; supererogatorily: or gratuitously, unasked, or unbidden: or disinterestedly; not seeking, or desiring, a compensation: syn. mutabarRiEFA]. (S and K in art. brE.) And AlmuTRawRiEapu↓ means Those who exceed what is obligatory on them in fighting, or warring, against unbelievers or the like; (S, O, Msb;) originally AlmutaTawRiEapu: (Msb:) hence AlmuTRawRiEiyna↓ in the Kur ix. 80; originally AlmutaTawRiEiyna. (S, O.)

1: The inf. n. TawaAfN primarily signifies, accord. to Er-Rághib, The act of going, or walking, in an absolute sense: or the going, or walking, around, or otherwise. (MF, TA.) [Hence,] TaAfa Hawola AlXRaIoCi, (S,) or biAlXRaIoCi, (Msb,) or Hawola AlkaEobapi, (O, K,) and bihaA, (K,) aor. yaTuwfu, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. TawofN (S, O, Msb, K) and TawaAfN (O, Msb, K, and mentioned also in the S but not there said to be an inf. n.) and TawafaAnN, (S, O, K,) [and perhaps TuwfaAnN, q. v.,] He went round or round about, circuited, or circuited around, or compassed, (Msb, TA,) the thing, (S, Msb,) or the Kaabeh; (O, K;) and so TaAfa, aor. yaTiyfu; (Msb; [but this I think doubtful;]) and tTwRf↓, (S, Msb, K,) and AiTRawRafa↓, a variation of that next preceding, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. AiTRiwRaAfN; (TA;) and AstTAf↓, (S, Msb, K,) as also AstTAfhu↓; (TA;) and bihi ATAf↓, (Msb,) or Ealayohi; (TA;) and TwRf↓, inf. n. taTowiyfN↓; (K;) or this last signifies he did so much, or often. (S, TA.) And TAf biAlqawomi, aor. yaTuwfu, inf. n. TawofN and TawafaAnN and maTaAfN, He went round about [or round about among] the people, or party; as also ATAf↓: the aor. of the former verb occurs in the Kur lvi. 17 and lxxvi. 19, trans. by means of EalaI. (TA.) And Tufotu bihi EalaI Albayoti [I went round the House of God, i. e. the Kaabeh, with him; or] I made him to go round, or to circuit, or compass, the House. (Msb. [The vulgar in the present day say TawRafotuhu↓: and they apply the appellation muTawRif↓ to One who makes the circuits round the Kaabeh with a pilgrim, and serves to conduct him round about to the other sacred objects, or places.]) You say also, TAf fiI AlbilaAdi, inf. n. TawofN and taTowaAfN, He journeyed [or journeyed round about] in the countries, or tracts of country; and so [or as meaning he did so much or often] TwRf↓, inf. n. taTowiyfN and taTowaAfN. (TA. [In one place in the TA, the latter inf. n. is said to be with kesr, so that it is like tiboyaAnN; but see this latter, which is very extr.: see also tiTowaAfN below.]) laOaTuwfanRa↓ Tawofahu means the same as laOasoEaranRa saEorahu [app. I will assuredly practise circumvention like his practising thereof]. (Fr, O and K in art. sEr, q. v.)
See also 4, in two places.

TaAfa, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. TawofN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) from TawofN signifying gaAYiTN; (S, O;) as also AiTRaAfa↓, (IAar, S, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, ATRaOafa,]) He voided his excrement, or ordure; (Mgh, Msb; *) or he went away (S, O, K) to the field, or open tract, (S, O,) to void his excrement, or ordure. (S, O, K.)
2: see 1, in three places.
You say also, TwRf AlnRaAsu, and AljaraAdu, The men, or people, and the locusts, filled the land like the TuwfaAn [or flood]. (TA.)
4: see 1, in two places.
ATAf biAlXRaIoCi signifies also He, or it, surrounded, or encompassed, the thing. (Msb.)

And ATAf bihi He came to him; visited him; or alighted at his abode as a guest; syn. OalamRa bihi: and he approached him; or drew, or was, or became, near to him; syn. qaArabahu. (S, K.) [And] biAlnRisaMCi TaAfa↓, aor. yaTuwfu; and ATAf; He came to women, or the women; visited them; or alighted at their abodes as a guest; syn. OalamRa (Msb.) And ATAf bihi and Ealayohi He came to him by night: and sometimes improperly used as meaning by day: a poet says,

[I came to her by day, not by night, while the seeking for the camels' saddles, or for the things necessary for his journey, or for the places of alighting, diverted her lord, or husband, from attending to her]. (TA.) And bihi AlxayaAlu TAf↓, aor. yaTuwfu, inf. n. TawofN; and, as As used to say, TAf, aor. yaTiyfu, inf. n. TayofN; The xyAl [i. e. apparition, or phantom,] came to him, or visited him, (OalamRa bihi,) in sleep. (TA.)
5. tTwRf AiTRawRafa: see 1, first sentence.
8. AiTRaAfN: see 1, last sentence.
10: see 1, first sentence, in two places.

TaAfN A man who goes round, or round about, much, or often; (S, O, K;) [and] so TawRaAfN↓: and TawRaAfapN↓ a woman who goes round, or round about, much, or often, to the tents, or houses, of her female neighbours. (Msb.)
See also Tuwf.
TawofN in the phrase OaSaAbahu mina AlXRayoTaAni TawofN, i. q. TaAYifN. (TA. See TaAYifN below, and in art. Tyf.)

[Also A kind of float composed of] inflated water-skins bound together, (S, O, Msb, K,) with wood [or planks] laid upon them, (Msb,) so as to have the form of a flat roof, (S, O, Msb, K,) upon the water; (Msb;) used for embarking thereon upon the water and for carriage thereon (S, O, K, TA) of wheat or other provisions and of men, and for the crossing [of rivers] thereon: (TA:) i. q. ramavN: and sometimes it is of wood, or timber: (S, O:) accord. to Az, a thing upon which large rivers are crossed, made of canes and of pieces of wood bound together, one upon another, and then bound round with ropes of the fibres or leaves of the palm-tree so as to be secure from its becoming unbound; after which it is used for embarking thereon and crossing, and sometimes it is laden with a load proportionate to its strength and its thickness: and it is also called EaAmapN, without teshdeed to the m: (TA:) pl. OaTowaAfN. (Msb, TA.)
And The bull (vawor) around which turn the oxen in the treading [of corn]. (TA.) [See TaAYifN.]
And i. q. qilodN [app. as meaning A portion of water for irrigation: for it is immediately added], and Tawofu AlqaSabi signifies the quantity of water with which the canes are irrigated. (TA.)

Also The foul matter that comes forth from the child after suckling: (El-Ahmar, Msb, TA:) and by a secondary application, (Msb,) human excrement, or ordure, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) in an absolute sense: (Msb:) what Er-Rághib says respecting it indicates that this is metonymical. (TA.)
Oaxacahu biTuwfi raqabatihi and rqbth biTaAfi↓ i. q. biSuwfi rqbth (S, K) and biSaAfihaA. (K.)

TuwfaAnN An overpowering rain: and overpowering water, [a meaning erroneously assigned in the CK to TawRaAf instead of TuwfaAn,] that covers [or overwhelms] everything; (S, K, TA;) in the common conventional acceptation, water abounding to the utmost degree; [i. e. a flood, or deluge;] such as befell the people of Noah; (TA;) or TuwfaAnu AlmaMCi signifies the water that covers [or overwhelms] everything: (Msb:) and a drowning torrent: (K:) and (assumed tropical:) much of anything, [like as we say a flood of anything,] such as includes the generality of persons, or things, within its compass: (K, TA:) and particularly (assumed tropical:) death; or quick, or quick and wide-spreading, death; or death commonly, or generally, prevailing; (TA;) or quick, or quick and wide-spreading, death, commonly, or generally, prevailing: and (assumed tropical:) quick [and extensive] slaughter: (K:) and (assumed tropical:) any accident [or evil accident] that besets a man: and (assumed tropical:) trial, or affliction: (TA:) and El-'Ajjáj likens to the rain, or water, thus called, the darkness of night; using the phrase TuwfaAnu AlZRalaAmi; (Kh, S;) by which he means (assumed tropical:) the intensity of the darkness of the night: (TA:) TuwfaAnN is said to be a pl. [or coll. gen. n.]; (Msb, TA;) and its sing. [or n. un.] is TuwfaAnapN, (S, Msb, K, TA,) accord. to analogy: (S:) thus says Akh: (S, TA:) or it is an inf. n., like rujoHaAnN and nuqoSaAnN; and is from TaAfa, aor. yaTuwfu: (Msb, TA:) thus says Abu-l- 'Abbás; and he says that there is no need of seeking for it a sing.: some say that it is of the measure fuloEaAnN, from TafaA AlmaMCu, aor. yaTofuw, meaning “ the water rose, ” or “ became high; ” the l being transposed to the place of the E; but this is strange. (TA.)
TawaAfN [is an inf. n. of 1, q. v., sometimes used as a simple subst., and] has for its pl. OaTowaAfN [which is regularly pl. of TawofN]. (TA.)
TawRaAfN; and its fem., with p: see TaAfN.

The former signifies also A servant who serves one with gentleness and carefulness: (K, TA:) pl. TawRaAfuwna: so says AHeyth: IDrd explains the pl. as meaning servants, and male slaves. (TA.) It is said in a trad., respecting the she-cat, that it is not unclean, but is mina AlTRawRaAfiyna Ealayokumo, or AlTRawRaAfaAti; [i. e. of those that go round about waiting upon you;] she being thus put it. the predicament of the slaves: whence the saying of En-Nakha'ee, that the she-cat is like some of the people of the house, or tent. (TA.) [In the CK, a meaning belonging to TuwfaAn is erroneously assigned to TawRaAf.]
Also A maker of the Tawof that is composed of [inflated] water-skins [&c.] upon which one crosses [rivers &c.]. (TA.)
TaAYifN part. n. of TaAfa, signifying Going round or round about, &c. (Msb.)

[And hence,] The Easas [quasi-pl. n. of EaAsRN]; (S, O, K, TA;) [i. e.] the patrol, or watch that go the round of the houses; thus expl. by Er-Rághib; and said to mean particularly those who do so by night. (TA.)
And The bull that is next to the extremity, or side, of the kudos [or wheat collected together in the place where it is trodden out]. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) [See TawofN.]

The TaAYif of the bow is The part between the siYap [or curved portion of the extremity] and the Oabohar [q. v.]: (S, K:) or near [the length of a cubit or] the bone of the fore arm from its [middle portion called the] kabid [thus I render qariybN mino EaZomi AlcRiraAEi mino kabidihaA, which, I think, can have no other meaning]: or the TaAYifaAni are [two parts] exclusive of the two curved ends (duwna AlsRiYatayoni): (K: [this last explanation seems to leave one of the limits of each TAYf undefined:]) or, accord. to AHn, the TAYf of the bow is the part beyond its kuloyap [q. v.], above and below, [extending] to the place of the curving of the end of the bow: the pl. is TawaAYifu. (TA.)

laOaqoTaEanRa minohu TaAYifFA occurs in a trad. respecting a runaway slave, as meaning [I will assuredly cut off] some one, or more, of his OaToraAf [app. meaning fingers]: or, as some relate it, the word is TaAbiaqFA. (TA.) And Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhalee says,
meaning, it is said, [The swords fall upon] arms and legs or hands and feet [of them: but in this case, TawaAYif may be pl. of TaAYifapN↓]. (TA.)
One says also, OaSaAbahu mina AlXRayoTaAni TaAYifN [A visitation from the Devil befell him]; and TawofN↓ likewise, in the same sense. (TA. [See also TayofN.])

TaAYifapN A detached, or distinct, part or portion; a piece, or bit; [or somewhat;] of a thing: (S, Msb, K:) and a firoqap of men [i. e. a party, portion, division, or class, thereof; as those of one profession or trade: a body, or distinct community: a sect: a corps: and sometimes a people, or nation]: (Msb:) and a company, or congregated body, (Msb, KL,) of men, at least consisting of three; and sometimes applied to one; and two: (Msb:) or one: and more than one: (S, K:) so, accord. to I' Ab, in the Kur xxiv. 2: (S:) or up to a thousand: (Mujáhid, K:) or at least two men: ('Atà, K:) or one man; (K;) as is said also on the authority of Mujáhid; (TA;) so that it is syn. with nafosN [as meaning a single person, or an individual]: (K:) [and sometimes it is applied to a distinct number, or herd &c., of animals:] Er-Rághib says that when a plural or collective number is meant thereby, it is [what lexicologists term] a pl. of TaAYifN; and when one is meant thereby, it may be a pl. metonymically used as a sing., or it may be considered as of the class of raAwiyapN and EalRaAmapN and the like: (TA:) [pl. TawaAYifu.]
See also TaAYifN, last sentence but one.
TaAYifiIRN A sort of raisins, of which the bunches are composed of closely-compacted berries: app. so called in relation to [the district of] Et-Táïf. (AHn, TA.)

tiTowaAfN, (JM, TA,) with kesr, (TA,) [and app. taTowaAfN also, as it is sometimes written,] for cuw tTwAfK, (JM,) A garment in which one goes round, or curcuits, (JM, TA,) the House [of God, i. e. the Kaabeh]. (JM.)
maTaAfN A place of TawaAf (O, Msb, K *) i. e. of going round or round about, or circuiting. (Msb.)
muTawRifN: see 1, latter half.
1. TaAqahu, inf. n. TawoqN: see 4.
2. TwRqh, (S, TA,) or TwRqhu TawoqFA, (O, K, TA,) inf. n. taTowiyqN, (TA,) He attired him with a Tawoq [or neck-ring]. (S, TA.)

[Hence,] TawRaqotuhu AlXRaIoCa means (assumed tropical:) I made the thing to be [as though it were] his Tawoq [or neck-ring]: and thereby is expressed the imposing [upon one] a thing that is difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient: (Msb:) [i. e.] TawRaqotuka AlXRaIoCa means (assumed tropical:) I imposed, or have imposed, upon thee the thing as one that is difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient. (S, O, K. *) sayuTawRaquwna maA baxiluwA bihi, in the Kur [iii. 176], means (assumed tropical:) They shall have that whereof they were niggardly made to cleave to their necks [like the neck-ring]: (O, TA:) as is said in a trad., it shall be made a biting snake upon the neck. (Jel.) And [in the Kur ii. 180] some read, waEalaI QlRaciyna yuTawRaquwnahu, [in the CK, erroneously, yuTawRiquwnahu,] meaning, (assumed tropical:) And upon those who shall have it put [upon them] like the Tawoq upon their necks [shall be incumbent &c.]: (K, TA:) which is like the saying yujaXRamuwnahu and yukalRafuwnahu [i. e. shall have it imposed upon them as a thing that is difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient]: (TA:) another reading is yaTRawRaquwnahu↓, [in the CK, erroneously, yuTRawRaquwnahu,] originally yataTawRaquwnahu [meaning the same as the former reading]: and another, yuTayRaquwnahu↓, originally yuTayowaquwnahu [also meaning the same; in the CK, erroneously, yuTayoquwnahu]: and another, yaTRayRaquwnahu↓, [in the CK, erroneously, with damm to the first letter, and so in what follows,] originally yataTayowaquwnahu [also meaning the same]. (K, TA.) One says also, TwRqhu bihi and TwRqhu UiyRaAhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He made it, namely, a sword, &c., to be to him a Tawoq [or thing encircling, or going round, his neck]. (TA.) And TawRaqaniI niEomapF (tropical:) [He conferred upon me a permanent badge of favour]: and TuwRiqotu minohu OayaAdiIa (tropical:) [I had permanent badges of favours from him conferred upon me]: and the verb is also used [in like manner] to denote dispraise, to which it has been erroneously said by some to be restricted. (TA. [See also 2 in art. qld: and see TawoqN.])
TwRqt AlHayRapu: see 5.

TawRaqaniIa QllRehu OadaMCa HaqRka, (S, O,) or HaqRihi, (K,) means God strengthened me, or empowered me, sufficiently for the giving, or paying, of thy due, or of his due: syn. qawRaAniI (S, O, K) Ealayohi. (K.) And TuwRiqahu He was enabled to do it. (TA.)
TawRaqato lahu nafosuhu (Akh, S, O, K) is syn. with TawRaEato, (Akh, S, O,) meaning His soul, or mind, facilitated to him [the doing of a thing]. (Akh, S, O, K.)

4. ATAq AlXRaIoCa, (S, O, Msb, K,) and ATAq Ealayohi, (K,) inf. n. UiTaAqapN, (S, O, Msb, K,) and TaAqapN is the subst. (Az, Msb, K) used in the place of the inf. n. like TaAEapN in the place of UiTaAEapN, (Az, TA,) He was, or became, able to do, or accomplish, or to bear, the thing; (S, Msb, K;) as also TaAqahu↓, (Az, * K,) aor. yaTuwqu, (Az, TA,) inf. n. TawoqN. (Az, K.) It is not used exclusively of a human being, as some assert it to be; but is used in a general manner. (TA.) [One says laA yuTalqu meaning He will not be, or is not to be, coped with: and also as meaning it is not to be done, or to be borne, endured, or tolerated: and so maA yuTaAqu: see an ex. voce HamoDa.]
5. tTwRq He put on, or attired himself with, a Tawoq [or neck-ring]. (S, O, K.)

[Hence, tTwRqhu, and tTwRq bihi, (assumed tropical:) He had it put upon him, and he bore it, and he took it upon himself, like the Tawoq upon the neck: and he had it imposed upon him, and he imposed it upon himself, as a thing that was difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient]. See 2. [See also Har p. 310. And see 5 in art. qld.]
And tTwRqt AlHayRapu EalaI Eunuqihi (tropical:) The serpent became like the Tawoq upon his neck; as also TwRqt↓. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1. yuTayRaquwnahu, originally yuTayowaquwnahu: see 2.
Q. Q. 2. yaTRayRaquwnahu, originally yataTayowaquwnahu: see 2.

TaAqN A curved construction or structure; (S, O, K;) [said to be] a Pers. word arabicized; (S, O;) and its pl. is TaAqaAtN and TiyqaAnN: (S, O, K:) or an arch of a building, wherever it is; and the pl. is OaTowaAqN and TiyqaAnN: (JK, TA:) and as signifying [thus, or] an arch constructed with bricks, it is [said to be] originally TaAYiqN↓; and therefore to have for its pl. TawaAYiqu: so says Az. (TA.) [It is often applied to An arched gateway or doorway: and to a vault. And] i. q. kuwRapN [i. e. A mural aperture; a hole, or an aperture, in a wall; a meaning also assigned to UiforiyzN, by which TaAqN will be found to be expl. in what follows: or a niche in a wall; which, as also a window, is now often called TaAqapN↓]. (So in the Munjid of Kr.) [And app. A kind of arched construction with a flat top which forms a shelf, against a wall. (See rafRN and sahowapN.)] And i. q. UiforiyzN [which is expl. as meaning a projecting roof or covering of a wall: and a projecting coping, or ledge, or cornice, surrounding the upper part of a wall: and in the KL as meaning a hole, or an aperture, of a wall; (as mentioned above;) but its author adds “ so we have heard ”]: (MA voce UiforiyzN:) or so OaTowaAqN. (JK, and O on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád. [But this I think doubtful, and the more so as it will be seen in what follows that another meaning assigned in these same lexicons to OaTowaAqN is said by IB to be a meaning of TaAqN.])
See also TaAYiqN, in two places.

[Also A layer, stratum, lamina, or the like; or any flat piece, or portion, of a thing, such as is in some cases placed over, or under, a similar piece or portion: and anything such as is in some cases lined, or faced, or otherwise combined, with another similar thing: pl. TaAqaAtN.] You say TaAqu naEolK [A single piece of leather of a sole that consists of two or more of such pieces]; (S, O, K;) and nEolK TaAqapu↓ [which means the same]. (K.) And naEolN TaAqN waAHidN A single sole; i. e. a sole of a single piece; not made of two pieces sewed together, one upon the other. (TA in art. nEl.) And [in like manner] a garment is said to be TaAqN waAHidN [i. e. Single, not double, not lined nor faced nor stuffed]. (Az, in TA in art. smT, [where this meaning is clearly indicated,] and Th, in M, same art.) Thus one says saraAwiylu TaAqN waAHidN [Trousers, or drawers, of single cloth]. (Th, M and K in art. smT.) [See also what is said of the phrase AlsRaraAwiylu AlTRaAqu voce rijolN.] One says also gazolN TaAqN waAHidN [Spun thread that is a single yarn]: and gazolN mafotuwlN TaAqayoni [Spun thread twisted of two yarns]. (S and TA in art. sHl.) See also TaAqapN, which has a similar meaning. [And see an ex. of the pl. TaAqaAt voce raboEapN.]
Also A certain sort of garment, (S, O, K,) having sleeves. (S, O.) [And] accord. to Esh-Shereeshee, A garment worn by a new-born child, or young infant, without an opening at the bosom. (Har p. 502.)

And (O, K) accord. to IAar, (O,) A [garment of the kind called] TayolasaAn [q. v.]: (O, K:) or such as is OaxoDar [properly meaning green; but when applied to a garment commonly meaning, as used by the Arabs, of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour; or a dingy ashcolour]: (Kr, K:) pl. TiyqaAnN, like siyjaAnN pl. of saAjN. (TA.)
And A [garment of the kind called] kisaMCi: (IB, TA:) and (TA) so OaTowaAqN. (JK, and O and TA on the authority of Ibn- 'Abbád. [But this, as I have shown above, I think doubtful.])
And A [woman's muffler, or head-covering, such as is called] ximaAr. (IAar, TA.)
And one says, raOayotu OaroDFA kaOanRahaA AlTRiyqaAnu (tropical:) [I saw a land as though it were spread with the garments called TyqAn]; meaning, whereof the herbage was abundant. (TA.)

TawoqN [A neck-ring;] a certain ornament for the neck; (K;) a thing well known: (Msb:) [its most usual from is figured in my work on the Modern Egyptians, Appendix A:] pl. OaTowaAqN. (S, O, Msb, K.) It is said in a prov., kabira EamorNw Eani AlTRawoqi ['Amr has become too much advanced in age for the neck-ring]: (A 'Obeyd, O, K, TA: in some copies of the K [erroneously] kabura:) or XabRa EamorNw Eani AlTRawoqi, [which has the like meaning,] as in most of the books of proverbs: (TA:) applied to him who occupies himself with a thing that is beneath his ability. (K. [For the story of the origin of this prov., see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 319-21, or Har pp. 502-3; as it is too long to be quoted here.])
And Anything that surrounds another thing (Msb, K) is called its Tawoq. (Msb.)
Hence caAtu AlTRawoqi as an appel-lation of The [ringed] pigeon [or ring-dove]. (Msb.)

[And hence] one says, taqalRadotu AlnRiEomapa Tawoqa AlHamaAmapi (tropical:) [I bore the favour as the ring of
the pigeon; meaning, as a permanent badge or decoration]: and fiI EunuqiI TawoqN maA liI biOadaMCi Xukorihi TawoqN (tropical:) [Upon my neck is a permanent badge or decoration, for which I have not ability to render due acknowledgment]: so in the A: hence also the saying of El-Mutanebbee,
[Favours of his have remained upon the necks: they are the neck-rings, and the men are the pigeons]. (TA. [See, for this verse, p. 164 of Dieterici's ed. of the Deewán of El-Mutanebbee.])
AlTRawoqu signifies also The neck [itself]. (TA.)
And The karR, (O,) or HaAbuwl, (K,) [i. e. the rope in the form of a loop] by means of which one ascends the palm-tree. (O, K. *)
See also the next paragraph, first and second sentences.

TaAqapN is the subst. from OaTaAqa, (Az, Msb, K,) and is used in the place of the inf. n., (Az, TA,) and [when used as a simple subst.] signifies Ability, or power; (S, O, * Msb, K;) and so TawoqN↓, (S, O, K,) which is [originally] an inf. n., (Az, K,) and is also expl. as meaning the utmost that one can do, with difficulty, trouble, or inconvenience. (TA.) One says, [laA TaAqapa liI bihi I have not ability, or power, to do it, or to bear or endure or tolerate it: and, to cope with him: (see Kur ii. last verse: and verse 250:) and] huwa fiI TawoqiI↓ It is within my ability, or power. (S.) In the phrase Talabotahu TaAqataka, [as meaning Thou soughtest him, or it, in thy state of ability, or power,] Sb says, the [quasi-] inf. n. is prefixed [to the pronoun, and thus rendered determinate], though occupying the place of a denotative of state; in like manner as the article Al is prefixed [to ErAk] in the phrase OarosalahaA. (TA.)

[Also A slender and small bundle or fascicle of fibres or filaments or the like, one of those whereof two or more, twisted together, compose a rope; a strand, a yarn, a single twist, or single thread, of a rope or cord or fringe &c.] You say TaAqapN mino HabolK A strand, yarn, or single twist, of a rope; syn. quwRapN; (S voce quwRapN;) and so mino HabolK TaAqN↓, pl. OaTowaAqN: (JK voce quwRapN:) [the pl. of TaAqapN in this sense is TaAqaAtN:] TaAqaAtu AlHaboli means quwaAhu, as is said in the A. (TA.)

And A XuEobap [i. e. spring, spray, bunch, or branchlet,] of sweet basil, or of sweet-smelling plants: and likewise [a lock, or flock,] of hair: (JK, TA:) [and so of wool, and the like;] you say TaAqapu rayoHaAnK, (S, O, K, TA,) [or mino rayoHaAnK, &c.,] meaning XuEobapN minohu, as in the A. (TA.)
TaAqapu naEolK: see TaAqN, latter half.
See also another meaning of TaAqapN voce TaAqN, first quarter.

TawoqapN A round, and plain, or soft, piece of ground, amid rugged tracts of ground: (O, K:) mentioned by IDrd as occurring in some poem of the Time of Ignorance but not heard by him from his companions. (O.)

TaAYiqN (S, O, K) and TaAqN↓ (O, K) A prominence [app. meaning a ledge or ridge] projecting from a mountain: (S, O, K:) and the former, (S,) or the latter, (K,) or each, (O,) also the like thereof in a well; (S, O, K; [in the CK, AlnRiyri is erroneously put for AlbiYori;]) i. e., in the wall that surrounds the interior of a well; and its pl. is TawaAYiqu: (TA:) and between any two pieces of wood [or planks] of a ship, or boat: (S, O, K:) or TaAYiqN signifies one of the pieces of wood [or planks] of the interior of a zaworaq [or skiff]: accord. to Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, it is the middle. or in the middle, of a ship or boat: and accord. to As, a prominence projecting from a ship, or boat, like a ledge swelling out from a mountain: and also, he says, a ridge, or ledge, in a [mountain, or portion of a mountain, such as is termed] qunRap: accord. to Lth, TaAYiqu kulRi XaIoCK signifies any mountain, or [hill such as is termed] Oakamap, that surrounds anything: and its pl. is OaTowaAqN [like OaSoHaAbN pl. of SaAHibN]. (TA.)
TaAYiqN also signifies, accord. to Ibn-Hamzeh, The curved extremity of a bow; which is said to be called its TaAq↓; but this he disallows. (TA.)
See also TaAqN, first sentence.
OaTowaAqN [a pl. of TaAqN: and of TawoqN: and of TaAYiqN.

Also] The milk of the cocoa-nut: (O, K, TA:) AHn says, (O, TA,) it is very intoxicating; (O, K, TA;) moderately as long as its drinker does not go forth to the wind; but if he does so, his intoxication becomes excessive; (K, TA;) and when he who is not accustomed to it, (O, K, TA,) and is not suited to it, (O, TA,) continues constantly the drinking of it, it vitiates his intellect, (O, K, TA,) and confuses his understanding: (O, TA:) when it remains until the morrow, it becomes most acid vinegar. (K, TA.)
HamaAmN muTawRaqN, (O,) and HamaAmapN muTawRaqapN, (S, O, K,) [Pigeons, and a pigeon,] having [i. e. marked with] a ring upon the neck. (S, O, K.)
And muTawRaqapN signifies A large qaAruwrap [i. e. flask, or bottle,] having a ringed neck: (O, K:) thus called by the people of El-'Irák. (O.)

1. TaAla, (S, O, Msb, K,) said by some to be of the class of qaruba, being made by them to accord in from with its contr., which is qaSura, and by others said to be of the class of qaAla, (Msb,) first pers. Tulotu, [said to be] originally Tawulotu, because one says TawiylN, [not TaAYilN, when using it as an intrans. v.,] (S, O,) aor. yaTuwlu, (TA,) inf. n. TuwlN, (S, * O, * Msb, K,) It (a thing, S, O, Msb) was, or became, elongated, or extended; [i. e. it was, or became, long; and it was, or became, tall, or high; which meanings are sometimes more explicitly denoted in order to avoid ambiguity, as when one says TaAla EalaI wajohi AlOaroDi it was, or became, elongated, or extended, upon the surface of the earth or ground; and TaAla fiI AlsRamaMCi it was, or became, elongated, or extended, towards (lit. into) the sky;] (S, O, Msb, K;) and AstTAl↓ signifies the same. (S, O, K.) It is also said of any time that is extended; and of anxiety that cleaves to one continually; and the like: [see TuwlN, below:] thus one says TaAla AllRayolu [The night became long, or protracted]: (TA:) [and thus TaAla Ealayohimu AlOamadu, in the Kur lvii. 15, means The time became extended, or prolonged, unto them:] and Ealayohimu AlEumuru taTaAwala↓, in the Kur xxviii. 45, means, in like manner, [Life was prolonged unto them; or] their lives became long, or prolonged: (Jel:) and TAl Almajolisu The time of the assembly was, or became, extended, or prolonged: (Msb:) and TAl AlhamRu [Anxiety became protracted]. (TA.) [One says also TaAlamaA faEala kacaA Long time did he thus; and the like; with the restrictive mA: see Har p. 17.]

When trans. [without a particle it is of the class faEala; not faEula, because this is not trans.: (TA:) one says Tulotuhu meaning I exceeded him, or surpassed him, in AlTRuwl [i. e. tallness; or I overtopped him]: and also in AlTRawol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence, &c.]. (S, O, K.) See 3. A poet says,

[Verily El-Farezdak is a bare rock that has exceeded in height the mountain-goats so that the mountain-goats do not reach it]: he means TaAlati AlOawoEaAla. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., faTaAla AlEabRaAsu Eumara i. e. And El-'Abbás exceeded 'Omar in tallness of stature. (TA.) And you say, TaAlahu fiI AlHasabi [He excelled him in the grounds of pretension to respect or honour]. (K and TA in explanation of Xarafahu: in the CK [erroneously] TAwalahu.)

One says also, TAl Ealayohi, (S,) or Ealayohimo, (Msb, K,) the verb in this case being of the class of qaAla, aor. yaTuwlu, (Msb,) inf. n. TawolN; (S, * Msb;) and tTwRl↓; (S, Msb, K;) and ATAl↓; (Msb;) He bestowed, or conferred, a benefit or benefits, or a favour or favours, (S, Msb, K,) upon him, (S,) or upon them. (Msb, K.) And EalayonaA biXaIoCK tTwRl↓ He gave to us a thing; like tanawRala; but the latter is said by Aboo-Mihjen to be used only in relation to good; and the former, sometimes, in relation to good and to evil. (TA in art. nwl.)

2. TwRlhu, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. taTowiylN; (O;) and ATAlhu↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) and OaTowalahu↓, (S, O, K,) inf. n. UiTaAlapN; (O;) both signify the same; (S, O, Msb, K;) He elongated it; extended it; lengthened it; or made it long, or tall or high; (S, * O, Msb;) syn. madRahu, (S, * O, * Msb,) and jaEalahu TawiylFA. (O, TA.) You say, TawRalotu AlHadiydapa I elongated, or lengthened, the piece of iron. (Msb.) And QllRehu baqaMCahu ATAl↓ God extended, or prolonged, his continuance [in life]; or may God extend, &c.
(Msb.) And Almajolisa ATAl↓ He extended, or prolonged, the time of the assembly. (Msb.) And TwRal lilofarasi, (S, O,) or lildRaAbRapi, (Msb, K,) He slackened [or lengthened] (S, O, Msb, K) the tether, (S, O, K,) or rope, (Msb,) of the horse, (S, O,) or of the beast, (Msb, K,) in the place of pasture, (S, O, K,) or that it might pasture [more largely]: (Msb:) and lahaA AlTRiwala ATAl↓ and AlTRiyala [signify the same]. (TA, from a trad.) And [hence] TwRl lahu (inf. n. as above, S) He granted him a delay, or respite; (S, O, Msb, K;) said of God: (S:) and fiI AlmuTaAwalapu↓ AlOamori means AltRaTowiylu fiyhi; (Msb;) [i. e.] TAwlhu signifies he delayed, or deferred, with him, (S, O, K, TA,) fiI AlOamori [in the affair], (S, O,) or fiI AldRayoni [in the case of the debt] and AlEidapi [the promise]. (TA.) [And TwRl Ealayohi and tTwRl↓ He was prolix, or tedious, to him: see 2 in art. bsq; and see an ex. of the former voce HawozN.]

3: TaAwalaniI faTulotuhu↓ He contended with me for superiority (Ks, O, TA) in AlTRuwl [i. e. tallness], and also in AlTRawol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence, &c.], and I exceeded him, or surpassed him, therein. (S, O, K.) bika OuTaAwilu occurs in a prayer of the Prophet, and is from AlTRawolu, meaning [By means of Thee I contend for] superiority over the enemies. (O.) One says also, TaAwalahu biAlkibari waqaAla OanaA Oakobaru minoka [He contended, or disputed, with him for superiority in greatness, and said, I am greater than thou]. (A in art. kbr.) [And AlmuTaAwalapu fiI AlHuiZowapi, occurring in the TA in art. smw, means The contending, or vying, or competing, for superiority, in highness of rank.]
See also 2, last sentence but one.
4. ATAl ATwl, as trans.: see 2, in five places.

ATAlt AlmaroOapu The woman brought forth tall children, (S, A, O, K,) or a tall child. (K.) It is said in a trad., (S,) or in a prov., not a trad., (K,) but IAth declares it to be a trad., and in the trads. of the Prophet are many celebrated provs., (MF,) UinRa AlqaSiyrapa qado tuTiylu [Verily the short woman sometimes brings forth tall children], (S, O, K,) qado tuqoSiru waUinRa AlTRawiylapa↓ [and verily the tall woman sometimes brings forth short children]. (O.)
See also 1, last sentence but one.
One says also, ATAl lifarasihi He tied his horse with the rope [or tether, called Tiwal]. (TA.)
5: see 2, last sentence:
and see also 1, last two sentences.
6. tTAwl: see 1, former half.
Also It became high by degrees; said of a building. (L in art. Xyd.)

And i. q. taTaAlRa or taTaAlala, (S, K, TA,) meaning He (a man, S, TA) stood upon his toes, and stretched his stature, to look at a thing: (TA:) or taTaAwalotu fiI qiyaAmiI I stretched my legs, in my standing, to look. (O.) One says, yataTaAwalu liloOafonaAni wayajotacibuhaA biAlmiHojani [He stretches himself up towards the branches, and draws them to him with the hooked-headed stick]. (S in art. Hrq.) And it is said in a trad., tTAwl Ealayohimu AlrRabRu bifaDolihi The Lord looked down upon them, or regarded them compassionately, (OaXorafa,) with his favour (O.)
Also He made a show of AlTRuwl [i. e. tallness], or AlTRawol [i. e. beneficence, and excellence, &c.]. (TA.)

tTAwl Ealayohi and AstTAl↓ signify the same; (Az, S, O, Msb, K, TA;) He held up his head with a show of superiority over him; (Az, TA;) [i. e. he behaved haughtily, arrogantly, overweeningly, overbearingly, domineeringly, or proudly, towards him; domineered over him; or exalted himself above him;] or he overbore, overpowered, subdued, or oppressed, him: (Msb:) Elyh AstTAl↓ is also expl. as meaning he arrogated to himself excellence over him, syn. tafaDRala; (K, TA;) and exalted himself above him: (TA:) and Ealayohimo AstTAlwA↓ as meaning they slew of them more than they [the latter] had slain (S, O, K) of them [the former]: (O:) and fiI EiroDi AlnRaAsi AlAisotiTaAlapu↓ occurs in a trad. as meaning the contemning of men, and exalting oneself above them, and reviling them, vilifying them, or detracting from their reputation. (TA.) One says also tTAwl bimaA Einodahu He exalted, or magnified, or boasted, himself in, or he boasted of, what he possessed. (TA in art. ftH.) And AlfaHolu yataTaAwalu EalaI Uibilihi The stallion [overbears, or] drives as he pleases, and repels the other stallions from, his she-camels. (O.)
And taTaAwalaA They vied, competed, or contended for superiority, each with the other [in AlTRuwl i. e. tallness, or in AlTRawol i. e. beneficence, and excel-lence, &c.: see 3]. (TA.)
10. AstTAl: see 1, first sentence.

Also It extended and rose; (K, TA;) said of a crack [in a wall]; like AstTAr: mentioned by Th. (TA.) [And likewise said, in the same sense, of the dawn, i. e., of the false dawn; in which case it is opposed to AstTAr: see musotaTiylN.]
See also 6, in four places.

This verb is also used, by Z and Bd, in a trans. sense; and AstTAlhu, occurring in the “ Mufassal ” [of Z] is expl. as meaning EadRahu TawiylFA [He reckoned it long, &c.]; and in like manner it is used by Es-Saad in the “ Mutowwal: ” but this usage is on the ground of analogy [only]; for, accord. to the genuine lexical usage, it is intransitive. (TA.)
TawolN [is originally an inf. n.: (see TaAla Ealayohi:) and, used as a simple subst.,] signifies Beneficence; and bounty: (S, TA:) and [a benefit, a favour, a boon, or] a gift. (Har p. 58.)

And, (O, K, TA,) as also TaAYilN↓ and TaAYilapN↓, (K, TA,) Excellence, excess, or superabundance: and power, or ability: and wealth, or competence: and ampleness of circumstances: (O, K, TA:) and superiority, or ascendancy. (O, TA.) One says, lifulaAnK EalaI fulaAnK TawolN To such a one belongs excellence, or superabundance, above such a one. (O. [And the like is said in the Mgh.]) And it is said in the Kur [iv. 29], wamano lamo yasotaTiEo minokumo TawolFA Oano yanokiHa QlmuHoSanaAti, meaning And such of you as is not able to obtain superabundance so that he may marry the free women, let him marry a female slave; (Mgh;) i. e. such as is not able to give the dowry of the free woman, (Mgh, O, TA,) as expl. by Zj. (Mgh, TA.)
